text: I actually needed a bit more of a sieve but this fine mesh is close enough for my weird purpose (skimming rapidly breeding baby snails off the surface of the water in an aquarium).  Who knows, I may actually cook with it some day.  Escargot, anyone?

I'm all about the sauces - I claim to be able to cook but mostly I experiment with Indo-Asian condiments and noodles or vegetables and such.  If my guests like what I came up with I take the credit, otherwise I blame the sauce I snuck in on them.Other reviewers have already pointed out that this is pretty thick - it's not a paste but it's definitely not watery thin, and it's not oily thin either (think of sesame oil or chili oil - it's not like that).  To my taste, both the sweet and spicy elements are right there prominently in your face without a lot of subtlety which suits me just fine.  There is a slight smokiness to the flavor and it has a pretty spicy kick for a finish so there's more to it than just fire and sugar.I love hot stuff and can deal with quite a bit of heat, but I must say this would be a little over the top as the only sauce in, say, a stir fry.  The heat builds as you keep eating and it will get your attention.  (Lest you assume I'm a wimp, I'm the guy who brings his own chili oil/chili paste to the Asian buffet when a group of coworkers go out for lunch.)I marinated some raw shrimp in it before steaming with veggies and sticky rice and that was a perfect use for it.  It's also great as a flavor variation if you like doctoring up ramen noodles as I do sometime.  But my favorite use so far is to add it to pizza - it enhances pretty much any variation.  I was an early adopter of Sriracha sauce for this purpose, 20+ years ago, and I completely burned out on that stuff a long time back.  This has about the same punch but a completely different taste that works with old-school pepperoni and red sauce, chicken and white sauce, olive oil based pizza, veggie, you name it.  Just a bit here and there as an enhancement and you can transform what was an excellent pizza pie into a completely different, but still excellent pizza pie.  A two-fer!One caveat: Gochujang is a Korean staple, not an exotic rarity.  You can buy it in paste form for a lot less and mix up your own version of this sauce with, e.g., sesame oil and soy sauce and a few other odds and ends.  It's a convenience item and if you buy this product you are paying a premium for the convenience.I racked my brain to justify fewer than 5 stars because this is a Vine review of a free product, the presence of which appears to cause some folks all kinds of heartburn.  Apparently the only proper atonement for receiving a review sample at no cost is to despise the product you're reviewing, but I think this stuff is really tasty so...five stars.  Haters gonna hate :-)

This is a review of a Generac iQ2000 6866 portable inverter generator.  I received the generator at no charge in exchange for an honest review of it.  Coincidentally, I've been shopping in this market for at least a couple of years, having previously owned a gigantic, incredibly loud 7KW (13KW starting) monster that was more of a maintenance hassle than it was worth.  I've also tinkered with generator alternatives such as inverters powered by a car battery or by dedicated battery banks.  I'm by no means an expert but am not a complete novice either.This is marketed at a 2000 watt generator.  I consider it a 1600 watt generator because it will power stuff that draws up to 1600 watts when running.  Some items require some extra mojo when they start up (like an air conditioner) so you need a little headroom to allow the item to start up, and then settle back down to its normal wattage draw.  This generator has about 400 watts of headroom.  It will handle something that draws up to 2000 watts momentarily at startup, and then settles back down to no more than 1600 watts.  Generac isn't alone here.  The famous Honda EU2000i is also a 1600 watt generator with 2000 peak watts, and it's marketed as a 2000 watt generator as well.It gets confusing when comparing different pieces of equipment.  I have an inverter that runs off of batteries that's marketed as a 2000 watt inverter.  It actually produces 2000 watts of power continuously, and has approximately 2000 additional watts of headroom.  So it will power multiple devices that have pretty large startup surge demands, yet it's described as a 2000 watt device just like this Generac.The point of all this is to caution you to understand how much power you're going to need to produce to run the goodies you want to run.  My 2000 watt battery-backed inverter will run my refrigerator and my portable air conditioner without complaint.  This Generac 2000 watt inverter generator shut down due to overload when I tried to run the same two appliances.  Don't buy any generator until you understand starting watts vs. running watts and have learned how many starting/running watts are required by the devices you want to run.OK, on to the Generac.  This item is made in the USA and is targeted specifically at the Honda EU2000i, which is legendary for having a long, trouble-free life, being relatively lightweight and being relatively quiet (generators are notoriously noisy).  It arrived well packaged and fully assembled and even came with a bottle of oil.The one page quick start guide doesn't take you very far.  Step 2 is "fill with oil as indicated in manual" so you have to stop there and read the manual, which is just as well.Dealing with oil is almost always a messy job that Generac has done a decent job with.  The oil port is very easy to get to and doesn't require any tools other than your fingers to open or close.  There's an angled funnel that screws into the oil port for adding oil and I suppose it could be useful for draining oil as well (see photos).  How much to add is mostly guesswork; I overdid it and had to pour some back out.  If you can see some oil pooling about halfway up the threaded part of the port you're pretty much there.  A small plastic tray is molded into the cabinet to catch small spills or drips which is a thoughtful idea.While you're under the hood you might want to note a couple of other things (see photos).  The air filter cover easy to get to and is secured by one Phillips head screw, just behind what I call the Tube to Nowhere, a clear plastic tube that hangs inside the access door.  I have no idea what it's for and haven't been able to find out yet, but the generator works fine so I've left it hanging.  Just flip it out of the way to get to the air filter.After getting the right amount of oil installed and adding a tank of gas (I used 93 octane with fuel stabilizer already added because that's what I had), I fired it up per the instructions and it started on the first pull.  Weather was fine so it required virtually no time on choke, and we were up and running.  The first thing I noticed was that the engine purred.  I had already watched a video online comparing this Generac to the Honda EU2000i and thought that the Honda sounded smooth, purring like a cat, where the Generac sounded "valve-y," with a more harsh metallic sound.  Not so this one.  Very smooth and, for a generator, so quiet I actually said "wow."  (Emphasis on "for a generator".)Now the fun part: what can I run with this thing?  My portable AC (about 900 starting watts, 700 running) was no problem.  My fairly recent refrigerator (about 850/600) was no problem.  Both at the same time?  Overload.  Oh well.  The point is that each of them was happy with the power level and the sine wave quality.  The two of them together was a little too much for the Generac, but that's not unexpected.Speaking of which, the true-sine-wave-or-not question came up in the questions section and the answer was sidestepped (pretty clumsily IMHO) by someone who may be been a vendor rep, or maybe not.  So, being a professional jerk, I asked it in a different way and rather than evading the question again, it was just ignored.  I don't have the definitive answer but I can say that the UPS that I use to power my modem, router, printer, desktop and VOIP phone would click like a madman and refuse to charge when I attempted to power it with either my old giant monster generator or my battery-backed inverter.  This Generac makes it as happy as if it were plugged into the grid.  And in fairness, even Honda's marketing refuses to come right out and explicitly claim pure sine wave.  So I'm going to guess it's not pure, but it's close enough to make my stuff happy, which makes me happy.Odds and EndsThere's no 12V or USB or 220V output.Build quality looks and feels very good.  Even the access door is finished with insulation.The gee-whiz displays are actually helpful.  I'm looking out my closed glass door and can easily see the remaining estimated runtime, fuel level and output percentage being used on the generator a goodly ways away on the patio.I'd love to see watts and amps being consumed in realtime; maybe in a later version.The owner's manual talks about spark plug and muffler/spark arrestor maintenance but doesn't show you how to get your hands on them to do the maintenance.  So I called the toll free number on the Quick Start Guide to ask about that and also about the Tube to Nowhere.  10 minutes on hold, then got the encouraging sound of ringing...after about 10 or so rings back to hold, then in about 10 more minutes fast busy (disconnected).  Not a stellar day at the old call center.  So I decided to play around (see photos).The spark plug is underneath that wired thing where you probably think it is anyway - if you give it a good tug it will come off and reveal the plug.You can see the muffler and spark arrestor but it quickly becomes clear that you're not going to get the arrestor out with your fingers.  You have to take off the black trim/grill that covers the rear of the unit using an Allen wrench on the four bolts at the corners.  Then you can have at it with a Phillips.So the only mystery remaining for me is the Tube to Nowhere.  That could stand explaining, as could accessing the spark plug and spark arrestor since they're described as routine mainenance items in the manual.  And there was that call center problem, never a good thing but unfortunately not a very rare thing.If you're considering the higher-end portable inverter generators (Honda, Champion, Yahama) you need to put this guy in the mix.  This is a nice piece of work at a reasonable price point.  If you have any questions please post a comment and I'll try to answer as best I can.Final note: I'd planned to add captions to the photos but it's not clear to me how to do that within the Vine review submission interface.  If I can add captions later I will.

I can't remember when I've filled a lawn mower and NOT spewed at least a little gas even when I was being oh-so-careful.  The first time you use this you will do a smack-my-head double take.  It just stops pouring when the tank is full.  I think this is right up there on the level of whoever finally thought up putting wheels on luggage.
It's oval.  It says WOOF.  It sticks on the back window.  What more could a guy ask for?  My dogs even approve.  At this price who can complain?

The dogs like these and despite their "nesting" behavior haven't been able to tear into one yet (I have 2 dogs and 3 of these beds).  They (the beds) fit into my standard sized washing machine and dryer and come out looking and feeling the same as new, no bunching up of stuffing at one end or the other.  Recommended.

These things kick hiney.  The noise reduction on an airplane is startling.  They will amp up your music source to ridiculous volume levels if you like.  The controls (particularly the volume control) require no fumbling or feeling around to make sure you hit the right thing.  They sound great whether connected via Bluetooth or wire.  I haven't used them to talk on the phone but I love the feature that cuts off the music source and turns on the mic so you can hear conversation without taking them off, then resume whatever you were listening to.  Battery reserve is great; I traveled from San Francisco through Denver to Raleigh using them pretty much the whole time (including a 3 hr layover in Denver).  My phone needed a charge and my tablet needed a charge but these phones didn't.  I've bought and sold/discarded/gifted I don't know how many headphones over the years and finally, these are it.

Cheap look and feel.  Muddy (and very little) bass, no sparkle in the highs and the midrange isn't anything to get excited about either.  I'm surprised that HP allowed its name to appear on this product.  I own (or have owned) several 2.1 systems ranging from around $50 to over $300 and I'm telling you that you can do *much* better for this amount of money.  I added one star because the speakers are very small and might be better than nothing for a really, really cramped space.  Take a look at the Arion Legacy AR504LR-BK for roughly the same price.  They're inelegant but they blow this product away.  This is a Vine review; I received the product at no cost in exchange for an honest review.

This is a review of the Wi-Fi only Samsung Galaxy Tab S2 in the 9.7" format.  An 8" version is available that costs about $100 less.  I received the S2 at no charge in exchange for writing an honest review of it.  I'm not going to rehash the dazzling tech features as others have done that better than I ever could.  This is a take mostly about the value proposition.I've been using tablets for a while as entertainment devices going back to the introduction of the Barnes and Noble Nook Color about five years ago, which I rooted immediately after purchase and used as a generic Android tablet.  For the past couple of years I've been happy with my much slimmer and lighter LG G Pad 8.3" tablet.  The Samsung S2 is ridiculously slim and light with a gorgeous screen and bottomless (for my purposes) memory expansion via a 128GB microSD slot.  Installation/setup was a breeze as I already had a Google account with my LG tablet backed up to it...I just selected the apps I wanted to bring overfrom the LG  to the Samsung and off it went.  If this were just about the tablet I'd state my preference for the 8" form factor, say "five stars!" and quit here.  But as these things have proliferated there's more to it than that.As mentioned, I use tablets as entertainment devices and I don't think I'm unusual in that.  Web surfing, music/video streaming, playing locally-stored audio and video files, email, reading apps, games...general end-user stuff.  Tablets have gotten very good at such things, so good in fact that I've started to wonder why one would spend so much money on the latest and greatest.  Example: the first thing I did when I ordered this beautifully thin and light S2 was to order a faux leather case with a Bluetooth keyboard for it, easily doubling the weight and tripling the thickness.  If you plan to accessorize your tablet, how much of a premium is thin & light worth to you given that you're going to pay even more to add thickness & weight as soon as you get your hands on it?Another consideration is depreciation.  Consumer electronics seem to depreciate even faster than cars.  If you're shopping for a tablet, can you justify the cost of the latest smokin' hot tech vs. the bargains you can find on what was just as hot - and still works just as well - as a year ago?  I just looked on Craigslist and even in my small metro area there are hundreds of hits for "android tablet" in the for sale listings.  There's a lot of very nice used hardware out there for the picking and choosing, and for cheap.Is the Samsung S2 a great tablet?  Absolutely!  Would I spend $500 to have one?  Probably not.  I'll enjoy using it in some scenarios, but will probably continue to use my 8" LG tablet while traveling as it fits those dinky little seat back tray tables better whilst I get to work on my snack and beverage.  Yes, the visuals are bigger and better on the S2 but the point is that they are plenty good enough on the ~2 yr old LG.  And if I lose it in the airport, it's no big deal.  I can pick up another one, or the rough equivalent, for next to nothing.I hate to give less than 5 stars to something as beautifully executed as this, and I won't argue with someone who says it's unfair to mix the used toy market into the equation.  But the quality and capability of these appliances (there, I said it!) has gotten incredibly good such that the former "wow, check THAT out!" impact of the latest model is giving way to "oh look, a tablet.  Is that new?"  I argued with myself over 3 vs. 4 stars and settled on 4 ("I like it") but a 3 ("it's OK") is just as accurate from my POV.

I started watching these when I got a few Season 1 discs from Netflix to share with my elderly aunt at her request.  I was sure I was *much* too sophisticated for such sophomoric stuff, but the more I watched, the more I liked.  This is a surprisingly versatile, remarkably talented ensemble cast, the members of which work very well together.  Yes, it's wholesome (what used to be called "in good taste" before good taste became a bad thing) but Billy Gray ("Bud Anderson") does a terrific smart-*ss who adds an edge the others play off of.  I've become a huge fan of Jane Wyatt (see her Wikipedia biography for some surprises).  I used to think of Robert Young as just "that Sanka commercial guy" and had really no exposure to Elinor Donahue or Lauren Chapin before I started watching, but all these people could *act*.  Start at Season 1 if you've not seen this and want a taste - you can get it on Amazon or rent it on Netflix.  It just gets better from there.  Mr. Young apparently pulled the plug after ~7 seasons when they were at the top of their game and everybody wanted more, but he was probably right to let it go then.  You won't regret time or a few bucks spent on this show.

Apparently an earlier wired version has been out for a while and it looks like Amazon has put the reviews for different versions in one place.  The BP5 Wireless supports Android as well as iOS, although the box and some of the documents don't advertise that Android is supported.This is an arm cuff with a white plastic pod attached, with no tubes or wires coming from it.  The pod contains the rechargeable battery, the air pump, the Bluetooth radio and the electronic goodies that make all that stuff work.  The only switch is a power button.  You control the device using a free app that you install on your Android or iOS device.There is no power brick included.  You do get a charging cable with a standard USB on one end and a mini (not micro) USB on the end that connects to the cuff.I tested this with an Android phone so I got the Android flavor of the app from the Play Store.  It's called "iHealth MyVitals."  When I searched for that, two versions showed up so I read the descriptions and grabbed the latest one, version 2.1.6.  The improvement over the earlier version is said to be "an auto-log functionality to bring you a better Android experience in the future."  Nope, didn't mean anything to me either but at least I've got it!The app installed without issues and I paired my phone with the BP5 via Bluetooth with no problems.  The first time I ran the app I was prompted to create an iHealth Cloud account.  Oh, grand, another Cloud.  I was glad to see there was an option to continue using the app as a "guest" (without registering) for the purpose of this review.  That said, it's good that multiple users are supported by the software.I'm thinking this device may be all about the Android (or iOS) app since that's how you relate to it.  My relations with it weren't very successful.  I was occasionally able to complete a reading but I seemed to fail to connect via Bluetooth about as often as I succeeded.  As I wrote this paragraph the app has tried and failed to connect several times (although it doesn't announce a failure, it just stops trying).  I shut down my phone and the BP5 completely, brought them back up and experienced the same thing.  I "forgot" the BP5 in my phone's Bluetooth settings, re-paired it without problems, then started the app on the phone again - which failed to find the BP5 again.Assuming you can get the BP5 and your phone/tablet/whatever on reliable speaking terms, the iHealth MyVitals app seems to have lots of capabilities in terms of recording a history of your readings and health trends (if you choose to record weight, sleep and physical activities).  Assuming you store data in their Cloud you can access these data from other devices in other places and even share it with others.  I'm pretty sure my primary care doc isn't sitting up late at night on weekends hoping I'll post my weight and BP after finishing that Mucho Grande Burrito platter, but apparently you can make that happen.  The how-to info is under Help in the software, not online, which makes sense.  Instructions will differ for Android vs. iOS, and they'll change with different versions.  Makes no sense to maintain it in multiple places.  Anyway, don't look for app details online; they're not there.The big problem for me is the weight of this thing.  The sleek white pod attached to the side of the cuff has a battery and an air pump and all the electronics inside.  Trying to place it on my arm with my free hand is surprisingly hard to do.  It wants to slide down my arm to my wrist as soon as I position it and then reach for the Velcro closure thingie.  It can be done, but it's a hassle.  When I add that hassle to the intermittent performance I've experienced with Bluetooth connections, I find that my old wrist-attached monitor does the job pretty well without having to schedule a session with it.  I just wrap it around my wrist, hit the go button and in 30 seconds I'm done.The bottom line is that this doesn't work for me.  I can see value in the ability to track metrics other than blood pressure readings, and to be able access those metrics anywhere.  Some folks have to be that religious about such things and this might be a good fit for them, but the software and connection problems I experienced make it too much hassle for me to use routinely.

The smell...er, aroma...wasn't nasty or anything, just smelled kind of cheap and a little burnt.  I think I'm going to try some of that aroma therapy stuff to help with my less-than-aromatic dogs and sometimes hygiene challenged roomate.

This is a review of the Sony SRSX77 portable speaker.  I received it at no cost as an evaluation unit for review.  These are my honest comments written from the POV I take when I've paid for an item.This is a pretty substantial item, comparable in size and weight to a house brick.  There are smaller and lighter competitors out there (see photo showing it next to a Bose Soundlink Mini).  It belts out the tunes with plenty of volume for a bedroom, study or office and yes, it's portable, but its size and weight really suggest a mostly stationary role.  I'm hearing punchy bass, nice mids and sparkly highs.  Heavy bass will rattle stuff on the table with the speaker.  You don't feel it like you would with a subwoofer but you can clearly hear low frequency notes, not just a bit of percussive noise that wants to be that low note if you know what I mean.Sony offers a free app called Song Pal that you can use as a remote control for the speaker on an Android or iOS device.  You use it to select a preset equalization or set your own, control how long the speaker idles before automatically powering down, Google Cast settings and other general operational-type stuff.  Song Pal can also be used as a music player.  I have to admit that I found Song Pal a little tedious in that role and I found it most useful to tweak settings on the speaker.  I used other apps that I'm already familiar with (e.g. Amazon Music, RadioTunes) to play tunes.I told a friend that I was going to review this and he loaned me his Bose Soundlink Mini to compare.  The two don't compete directly (this Sony costs ~64% more than the Bose at this writing).  The Sony is louder, more interface-able, has crazy longer battery life and sounds a lot better to me.  But the Bose is much more portable and would suit me better for use in a product demo or a hotel room, and it sounds awfully good.  This isn't a review of the Bose; I bring it up to make the point that whether the Sony is right for your application depends on how you want to use a device like this.  I'm liking it for ambient tunes in my kitchen/dining area.  It turns my phone or tablet into an exceptional table radio, and it could serve as a complete audio system for a guest or kids room TV (you can plug it into a 3.5" jack too).  I'm giving it 5 stars because even at this price point, I think it succeeds at what it's trying to be.Pic compares size of Oontz XL, Bose Soundlink Mini and Sony SRSX77.

I've been using these for a while now and they are great.  No color bleeding onto other items in the washer (I generally use cold water), the elastic is holding up perfectly and they are pretty sturdy so far (I have a big dog who sleeps with me and he likes to dig around and make a nest before retiring).  No disintegrating seams or loose threads.  I have a standard king and the fitted sheet fits well...there's a little room to spare, but not so much that it doesn't stay snugly in place.  I wasn't sure that 450 thread count would be enough but they're supremely comfortable and I'd buy these again.

This is a review for the USB 2.0 version of a Belkin add-on Ethernet port for devices that don't have an Ethernet port built in.  I first bought a device like this a few years ago when I got a Samsung Chromebook and found myself in a hotel that offered both wired and wireless connections, but the wireless was pretty bad - if you were lucky enough to get a connection for more than a few minutes it was painfully slow.  I thought "no problem, I always carry an Ethernet cord in my bag, I'll connect to the wire" and then realized that minimalist devices like Chromebooks don't have such ports.  Oops.  Now something like this is one of the must-have accessories in my toy bag.I've migrated from the Chromebook to a HP Stream 14 running Win 8.1.  Like the Chromebook that inspired it, this laptop has a solid state drive, no optical drive and no RJ45 Ethernet port to save space and weight.  This little goodie from Belkin lets me turn one of my USB ports into an Ethernet port so I have an option if there's no wireless, or if the wireless is too sucky to be of any use.In the box: the adapter and a CD containing a setup program, a user manual in PDF format, and a folder for Mac users (presumably the stuff not in that folder is for Windows computers).  No cable is included to connect between the adapter and an Ethernet port; if you're like me you have a drawer full of such things anyway.My little HP Stream has no optical drive so I didn't run the setup.exe and didn't even open the PDF manual.  I just turned off the wireless, plugged the Belkin adapter into a USB port and connected a cable from it to an available port on my router and BANG - I'm connected.  When I did get around to looking at the PDF manual on the CD, I saw a stern warning under the instructions for Windows XP/Vista/7/8:  "Caution: DO NOT connect the Ethernet adapter to your computer before you install the provided driver.  You will be instructed to do so later."  I'm happy to report that nothing bad happened despite my connecting the adapter without installing the driver.  I didn't just defer the setup, I never installed it at all and the adapter works great.Why not 5 stars?  Price.  At the writing there's at least one no-name equivalent available on Amazon, also with Prime shipping, for 60% less.  No, we're not talking big bucks and the Belkin is a bit smaller (see photo), but that no-name has been working fine for me for several years now and is plug-and-play just like the Belkin.This is a fine product.  The price could be a little more competitive but it does what it promises and couldn't be easier to use.

These things may have good battery life but I can't use them long enough to find out.  I was impressed by other reviews and bought these and took them on a road (air) trip.  Thankfully I took another pair as backup - the backups sucked but I already knew that, and they didn't suck like these. These won't stay in place on my ears, slip sliding away and requiring constant adjusting to stay in place.  And staying in place is important, because if these are just a bit off-center on either ear the volume goes away.  And there's not much volume.  Not much bass or treble either.  On a recent flight I had to just put them away because I couldn't hear the source material, either from my phone or my tablet, trying to hear recordings from a variety of sources.  Oh yeah, and noise reduction?  What noise reduction?  Well, on the plane somebody in my vicinity definitely farted (it was ghastly) and I didn't hear it, but I'm not sure that counts as noise reduction.There are so many good reviews that I'm thinking I got a defective pair, but I'm remembering what my Mama said: "don't get too cheap."  I think that's what happened to me here.

Brilliant green lasers, three for the same price as just one at my local office supply big box store (when they have one in stock).  Even though only two worked that's still a decent price.  Would have been 5 stars if not for the dead one.

This is a review for a two-product bundle: one TL-PA4010 adapter (a.k.a. AV500 1 port) and one TL-PA4020 adapter (AV500 2 port).  I think Amazon is mixing reviews for this two-item bundle with reviews of the individual adapters.  Here are the items and bundles I've become aware of:TL-PA4010 = 1 port adapter available singly or in bundlesTL-PA4020 = 2 port adapter available only in bundles as near as I can tellTL-PA4010KIT = a pair of TL-PA4010sTL-PA4020KIT = a pair of TL-PA4020sTL-PA4026KIT = one TL-PA4010 and one TL-PA4020 (this review)Background: I've been using a similar Netgear product for years.  It consists of two devices: one that you plug into the wall and then connect your router to.  It pipes your Internet signal into your household wiring.  I came to call this the transmitter.  The second device plugs into the wall where you want the Internet signal to be available, far from the transmitter.  I call it the receiver and I plug stuff into it...like a computer or TV or DVD player or streaming device (Roku, FireTV).So I thought in terms of a single-purpose transmitter and a single-purpose receiver when I got this TP-Link bundle, and that's how I was thinking when I set these devices up.I plugged the AV500 1-port into wall power near my router and connected a cable from my router's output to the single port on the AV500, thus creating what I call my new transmitter.I plugged the AV500 2-port into wall power in a distant bedroom, thus creating what I call my new receiver.  Then I ran a cable from one of the 2 ports to the input of my FireTV box (substitute Roku or DVD player or TV, whatever you have).  Bingo, I have faster-than-wireless Internet in my distant bedroom connected to my FireTV.  Because this AV500 2-port has another connection available, I can connect a cable from it to another device like, say, a desktop computer as well.  No configuration, no muss, no fuss, it really is as simple as plugging stuff in.As an experiment, I swapped the devices so that the AV500 2-port became the transmitter and the AV500 1-port became the receiver.  Everything still worked, showing that either the single or dual port flavors can perform either function, unlike my older Netgear setup.  That's good to know since it adds flexibility.  Since I have no need for the second port on the transmitting end, I swapped the devices back.Then I decided to take it a bit further and add another receiver in a guest room, and I couldn't figure out what to buy.  Long story short, I bought another TL-PA4010 1 port.  I used it as a receiver in the guest room, connected to another FireTV box, and still using the original TL-PA4010 1-port as the transmitter.  I can now stream from the origihnal TL-PA4010 transmitter to the second TL-PA4010 1-port in my guest room, and to the TL-PA4020 2-port that I'd previously installed in another room.  I streamed Netflix in one room and Prime Video in the other at the same time and the results were great.So a TL-PA4010 can be a transmitter or a receiver.  So why not buy a pair of TL-PA4010s in a cheaper starter kit, instead of the pricier bundle I'm reviewing here?  Here's why you might want a TL-PA4020 with its second port on the receiving end, using my guest room as an example.  That room has a FireTV box connected to my TV's HDMI1 port, and the TL-PA4010 1-port is connected to the FireTV box.  But that room also has a Blu-ray player connected to the TV's HDMI2 port.  When I play a recent vintage Blu-ray DVD, it complained that I'm missing out on additional content because the Blu-ray player isn't connected to the 'net.  And that's a fact.  I have no available port to connect the Blu-ray player to.  That doesn't bother me, but I can see why the convenience of another port could come in handy.  So I would recommend the bundle I'm reviewing.  The small additional cost for that second port on the receiving end is minimal and will be soon forgotten.Now comes the frustrating part.  Suppose you buy this 1-port (as transmitter) + 2-port (as receiver) bundle and want to expand by adding another receiver.  Want just a single port for your new receiver?  Do what I did and buy a single TL-PA4010 (cheap and easily available) and you're done.  Prefer two ports on your receiving end?  Obviously, buy another TL-PA4020 instead of a 4010...but not so fast.  I can only find the TL-PA4020 2-port as part of this bundle or as a two-pack (a pair of 4020s).  Maybe I haven't looked hard enough, but it bugs me to be forced to buy two when I just want one and that looks like the marketing-via-packaging strategy here.Other than that annoyance, these things work great and the fact that either the 1-port or the 2-port can serve as transmitter or receiver is commendably flexible.  Setup is beyond painless.  Performance using cnet's internet speed test is virtually identical to the very satisfactory performance of the Netgear boxes I've been using for some time.  The price is very reasonable.  The power-saving features may save you as much as $0.08 over a hundred years on utility costs (hey, "green" BS moves product nowadays even if it is just BS).Sorry if this is more of a sorting-it-out diary than a review; it took me a while to sort it out and I decided to inflict all that on you, dear reader.  I'd recommend this but advise thinking through the config you want to create before buying.

I've been invaded by Malaysian Trumpet Snails (MTS), apparently piggybacking onto a fancy male guppy from a chain pet store (just a guess).  From reading on the web I came to understand that these guys can be introduced to your tank by new animals or plants you add, and they can survive anything and then reproduce like mad once they get into a hospitable environment.  Apparently all you need is one egg and BANG, you have a colony of MTS.  This trap is clever, but in my tiny tank all it trapped was a guppy or two, even with all the prison bars in place that should have kept them out.  Maybe the trapped guppies chased any MTS visitors away from the bait (the guppies certainly ate it all).  When I removed the trap there was a cluster of MTS underneath as if they had gathered looking longingly at the bait within, and I was able to siphon several dozen of them out of that gathering.  So I guess it worked to that extent, but I don't think that's what the designers had in mind.  I won't flatly say this doesn't work - the design is intelligent and the concept *should* work - but unfortunately it didn't work as hoped for me.  Your experience may be better and I do think it's worth a try in a different situation.

I won't hype the Walkers product because you probably know they make good stuff.  My elderly aunt loves shortbread but eats like a bird and if I send her a big package, much of it would likely go stale before she got around to finishing it.  Here is the solution!  I love shortbread too, but have the opposite problem: if I order myself a big package, I'll consider it a single serving and feel compelled to eat it all before it has a chance to go stale...I mean, I can't just waste those wonderful cookies, can I?  Here's the solution to that extreme too.  This is a great idea.

This is the 3rd iteration of this Arc mouse that I've owned and by far the best yet.  The earlier USB-connected ones were OK, but just OK in terms of usability.  They were worth the less-than-stellar mouse-ing performance because the form factor is so perfectly portable.  This is my first bluetooth one and I was hoping for merely okay usability to match what this replaced (a MSFT Sculpt Comfort BT mouse).  The Sculpt was/is adequate but this thing is much more responsive and sensitive than I would have expected from any BT mouse and blows the bulkier Sculpt away.  This Arc Touch tracks accurately on pretty much anything and tracks through anything (e.g. layers of plastic).  I'm using it on a HP Stream 14 and couldn't be happier with it.

One star means "I  hate it," two means "I don't like it."  Truth be told, I'm afraid of it and I'm going to peg that between 1 and 2 stars.  I wore these to the range today and was so alarmed (fear of ear damage) after firing ~a dozen 9mm rounds that I left the range to go rent some of their plain vanilla house ear cups.  Others were on nearby lanes and I was stunned at how loud things were with these things on when I walked in, even with the amplification completely off.  After firing for a while with the house rental I tried the Peltors on again, this time reversing the earpieces to see if orientation made a difference.  It may have subjectively made a very slight improvement but I still had to leave the range and go back to the house rental after just a few minutes.  My ears were ringing and actually hurt - we're not talking the fit; these  are perfectly comfortable and very tight.  Wearing them frontwards or backwards, with the amplification off or on, I found it not just distracting but painful to be on the range wearing these.To be fair, I wear eyeglasses and wear oversized clear protectors over my glasses (a range requirement).  So there are those items between the cups and my head which could cause some loss of effectiveness, but I've had a similar set of earphones for years with no problems.  There were no problems with the generic, no frills, well-used house rentals either.  For me, these are just not usable.

I have a Worx cordless mower that I use in my tiny fenced back yard and it is a wonderful thing.  Light as a feather, zero maintenance, does a surprisingly good job even when I'm less than timely with my mowings and the grass gets a little thick.  I could use it two or three times without recharging.  I made the mistake of leaving the mower on a covered porch with the battery installed during a rainstorm.  The battery got soaked.  Actually, this little box is a container with two batteries and a circuit board and some connective wiring inside and those are the things that got soaked.  After they marinated for a week or so I tried to mow the lawn and the battery was dead.  Not weak, not in need of a charge, not pining for the fjords, dead.  Took it to my local Batteries Plus and the helpful guy opened the container and you could see the corrosion on the circuit board...clearly not a candidate for a rebuild.  Bottom line: this is a fine product, just treat it with respect and keep it dry.

I also had to buy some for myself.  What's not to like?  Awesome shortbread and good-enough dark chocolate, although I've had better.  The chocolate melts too easily and it doesn't seem to have the punch of a good quality dark chocolate bar, hence four stars.  But Walkers Shortbread is so fine that it makes up for that.  Adds a touch of decadence or elegance or you get the idea to a glass of milk or a cup of coffee or a cordial.

I bought a Mercedes Benz.  The sales rep used a snippet of this ancient ditty as his ringtone, which made me laugh, so I downloaded the song so I could spring it on unsuspecting passengers.  It generates the giggles and eye-rolls I expected which is worth a buck any day.  I actually have one friend who drives a Porsche so there's a tiny little bit of legitimacy here.

It may have been in the product description but if so I missed it.  The part that grips your phone and is normally attached to the end of the stick can be detached from the stick, and the threads allow you to attach it (and thus your phone) to any old tripod.  You can then use the stick as a remote shutter for your phone's camera sitting across the room.  I'm not all that into the selfie thing so this may be old news to some, but it was a pleasant surprise to me.  It makes the device much more flexible than I expected.

I have an elderly relative in rehab after a bathroom fall and she is all about the video, generally DVDs.  She has a hard time with complex electronics, has no use for laptops or tablets, but took to this immediately and loves it.  Nice big screen, just a few intuitive controls, good battery life for use on a hospital type bed table.  Unfortunately, it just doesn't get loud enough for her.  I added an amplified Bluetooth speaker (this is NOT a Bluetooth-capable device, I just wanted the amplification) that I plugged into the headphone jack on the Sylvania and that did the trick.  This would also be great with headphones, in a car, in any number of situations.  A really successful purchase!

This knocks those nasty little flying things off my patio container veggies and herbs and keeps them away for a day or so, typical of products of this kind.  It more annoys them than anything, but it doesn't annoy me by loading up my eats with poisons and I have to tend to the plants anyway (frequent watering) so it's not a burden to spray every day or so.  If I had any complaint it would be that the sprayer doesn't deliver a true mist, more like something between a stream (which it will produce if you like) and a mist if that makes any sense.  I've used a similar no-name product from a big retailer and find this works about the same, which is fine.  I just want the critters to stop eating my dinner!

Aroma is a matter of personal preference and this Hawaii one doesn't work for me at all.  It smells to me like concentrated snow-cone syrup or something that could be used as a base (subject to dilution and lots of it) for one of those fancy rum-based adult beverages with lots of fruit and a cute little paper umbrella on top.  We are talking SWEET, and way too sweet for me.  After about 10 minutes on the lowest burn setting I had to unplug the thing.  This is my first exposure to an air freshening product, done at the suggestion of a relative who says my house smells like wet dogs; she's probably right and I hope to find another Air Wick scent that works for me.  But my occasionally wet dogs smell better to me than this does, so I'll have to keep shopping.  Nice little burner though!

Youll only need to read through the instructions once and yes, youll need readers or a magnifying glass (I dont care how old you are).  There really is a very tiny manual with very tiny print in the blister pack that will explain a couple of non-intuitive things.Good things:Tootsie-Roll-sized item fits in pocket, purse, satchel, briefcase, whatever (were talking full-sized, old-school Tootsie Rolls here, not the miniatures you hand out at Halloween)great size and shape for a handy flashlight when used that wayeasy to find by feel by digging your hand into whatever bag its in (and has probably settled to the bottom of)quick (and multiple) charges of smaller items like music players or phonesgets only slightly warm when charging other devices or when it is being rechargedcompetitive priceNot so good things:you may need a little more horsepower to keep a heavily-used tablet running all dayfor heavy travel days (air, taxi, rental car, hotel, lounges, meetings) you will want something with mutiple outlets and more muscle - Amazon Basics has a 10,000 mAh item about the size of a mobile phone that might be more suitable in a situation like that at about twice the priceSummary: a nice tidy piece of work with a flashlight thats more useful than you expect (I seem to have a talent for dropping anything and everything between my cars seat and the center console and then have to go hunt for whatever it is).  Does the job, decent price, clean design, worth having around IMHO.  Probably all you need for a local days work, probably not all you need for a hard-core road trip, but that isnt what its for.

I recently bought a German-made car and this is much cooler than the dealer's advertising plate that came on the car.  I bought a blank US-sized license plate to affix it to and it looks good on the front of the car.  This method will let me remove/replace it later with no hassle.  Search Amazon for "blank license plate" to check out the selection and read the reviews so you don't get the one that disintegrates in a car wash :-)FYI, there is a tiny, pre-cut tear-away border all the way around the image.  I struggled to separate the backing from the sticker until I realized that the slim border could be peeled away.  After that the actual sticker is painless to remove.  Seems durable and of high quality with a little stretchy-ness and a forgiving adhesive that allowed me to peel the sticker off the target surface several times and reapply until I got it positioned just right.
I must say that it seems to fit better when you shove all the stuffing up one end, though.  Ni!

I liked this shirt until some passing animal food trough waterer read it to me.  As a Knight who until recently said Ni! there are some words that I cannot bear to hear and this shirt contains one of them.  Do not dare to speak that word or I shall say Icky Icky Icky Icky za Pang OOOO Long unto you!

My new car has so many pushy buttons in the rear view mirror/sunroof area that there was no room left for a sunglass holder like the one in my previous car.  I got one of these clips for each visor so I can store my glasses, my gas-only credit card, car registration and have room left for a dry cleaning ticket or two so I don't have to root around for these items when I need them.  The visor clips have a clean, quality look to them.  Very happy.

My last car (an Acura TSX wagon) came with no spare tire, ostensibly to save weight and boost Acura's fleet mileage numbers.  Instead, it included a non-branded item almost identical to this with no hint as to the manufacturer - a can of tire sealant goo and a 12V air pump connected to work together.  I had occasion to use it and wow, this is a great concept!  Beats the heck out of changing a tire in the sun or the cold or, well, it beats the heck out of changing a tire.  I sat in the car with the AC blasting while this little gem (OK, the Acura-supplied equivalent) sealed and inflated my punctured tire, and I was off.  This Slime version (including the electric pump) cost roughly half what the Acura goo refill can *alone* cost, so I bought this Slime kit.  Sure enough, I had another puncture and the Slime kit worked exactly like the Acura version.  So I replaced just the goo refill on the Slime kit and it's as good as new.I just traded the Acura (sweet car BTW) on a car that does have a spare tire, but I'm buying another Slime kit for the new car anyway.  It's cheap and if you get a puncture that it can handle you will bless the day you bought it.  Oh yes, I did replace the two Slime(d) tires on the Acura eventually and it was not an issue for new tire installation or the TPMS.  There are some urban legends out there about such products...if you use them your wheels will rot, your tires will dissolve, your sainted Grandma will come back from the grave and curse you...not true.  You may get warts, though.

This is a review of the Fluval U1 filter for the Fluval U1 pump  It's a manufactured sponge, shaped to fit inside the Fluval U1 filter, nothing more or less.  It works great in the U1.  There is no bio media, no charcoal, nothing to see here but a sponge.  (I think the U2 and up models have fancier filtration.)  I use my U1 as a cleaning aid before water changes.  I remove the fishies, immerse the U1 in the tank, plug it in and then blast the substrate with a turkey baster  That blows all kinds of nasty crud out of the substrate and suspends it in the water, where the U1 can suck up the crud.  I keep doing that until the water is reasonably clear.  That may require removing the U1 and rinsing the filter under running water and then putting it back in for another go, especially the first time you do it.Then I do a normal partial water change.When done, I remove the filter, rinse it and set it out to dry.  There's no need to replace it as long as cleans up nicely under running water.Note: if you try this method, the first time you do it you will be entirely grossed out by the amount of crud in your substrate which you probably thought was as pure as the driven snow.  Stay calm and don't try for spotless the first week.  Things will get better as you repeat the technique over timeThe main point to understand is that, at least in my experience, these filters will last a very long time without replacement if you rinse them thoroughly between uses.  They're just sponges.

Somebody is getting rich on this thing and s/he deserves every penny.  I've been using fan-based white noise machines my whole adult life and can't sleep without one.  I've even had to set a TV to a dead station, turn down the brightness and turn up the volume to get a decent all-night hiss going in a hotel to mask other sounds.My first machine came from the Sears Catalogue's sickroom supplies section since the product category didn't really exist back in the 1970s.  I've since tried many nature sound, white noise, brown noise, etc. synthesizers, including looping MP3s of such sounds on a player of one kind or another, and always went back to my fan-in-a-box from Sears or Hammacher-Schlemmer.  But this thing blows the fan box away in every way.  Volume can be much louder or much softer if you like.  I can make it sound exactly like my current fan box if I want to, or something completely different but equally pleasing.  And it's smaller (less than half the size), lighter (although it still feels substantial) and can be powered from different sources...a laptop, a wall socket, one of those portable battery charger doohickeys (a technical term) used for portable electronics when traveling, the USB port on the desk lamp in your hotel room, what have you.If I could add anything it would be internal batteries and bluetooth (or at least a headphone jack), but I'm not complaining.  This is vastly superior to my old faithful fan-in-a-box.  If you're not a user of such things my enthusiasm will seem a little deranged, but if you are a user please trust me - you need one of these even if you don't know it yet.

...because taste is taste and why should you care what I think?  I mean, I don't care what YOU think.  But this is such a *FUN* piece of work I had to.  61 yr old white dude here and this takes me back to Parliament, George Duke, disco clubs...except they didn't have subwoofers back in that day, and you must have one to enjoy this.  This rocks, this kicks *ss, this is (for me) one of those rare instant-ecstasy tunes that nobody has a formula for, but every now and then somebody squirts one out.  Find this online somewhere and listen, but this needs to be LOUD and there needs to be LOTS of treble and LOTS of bass.  This is a perfect example of why God invented the subwoofer.  I believe I'll go disturb the nasty lady next door right about now...

I have a big dog with big feet who likes to stand on a door armrest in the back and hang his head out the window.  I had another brand of door panel cover that fit with tabs like the Krunco, but the other brand just wouldn't stay in place more than a few minutes.  As a result, the armrest/door trim in the back seat was taking a lot of abuse.  The Brand X covers finally fell apart so I decided to try another brand and lucked into these.  It has been 3 weeks and NOT ONCE have Buford's big feet managed to pull one of the Krunco covers off of the door.  (I used the tabs for installation.)  If you've soured on door protectors like this because yours won't stay in place, do yourself a favor and give these a shot.  The tabs can be positioned in a couple of ways to fit a variety of cars.  Understand that you're placing a bet here - these may fit your car or not, and they may stay in place in your car with your dog or not (that's a lot of variables).  But in my case these are like night and day.  And the cost of refurbing interior trim for trade-in/lease-turn-in time for any car is going to be substantial - these are way cheap in comparison.  Really happy with these and deliberately waited to review them for several weeks to see if they'd stay put.  So far they have.  Great stuff.  BTW, I have these in a 2012 Acura TSX wagon.  I understand that the TSX is a clone of the Honda Accord so I'd expect similar performance in an Accord.

I didn't have any of the packaging or leakage problems that others reported.  This came premixed and ready to go and is perfect for my situation - an established lawn (not exactly yard of the month quality but presentable) next to a common area in the neighborhood that is effectively a dandelion and clover farm.  So all those lovely things migrate to my lawn first.  I hosed down a bunch of early dandelion blossoms and yes, in about a day's time they were all clearly dying - not shriveled into husks yet, but clearly not long for this world.  I'll be repeating this from time to time as the spring wears on.  I like the fact that it's premixed and ready for spot treatment because that's what I need in this instance.  Can't speak to how it handles crabgrass as I won that war a few years ago, but it kicks some dandelion and clover hiney and is probably enough to last me all season.
Took no time to assemble the first one,  then the rest went even faster.  Not industrial strength but plenty durable for my purpose, very attractive, very flexible.
Wow.  This takes a little getting used to but not very much, after which you can load mags faster and so much easier than the old way.  A way better mousetrap.

I got this for my sister for Christmas.bu  She is all about the landscape presentatinion thing and is tasteful about things.  Too tasteful in my view.  Since I knew she'd never feature lawn flamingos in the yard I got her this for her deck.  I love it and in spite of her Better Homes & Gardens bent, she does too.  Or at least she says she does and sets it out when I visit.

Oh great...a zoomable photo that hides the model number/manufacturer and all other specifics, but lets you get close-up view of some black plastic housing.  How freaking helpful.  FWIW, I have a Fluval branded replacement pump supposedly for the Spec III and Spec V and I'm thinking this is a non-Fluval-branded version of the same thing.  Whether it is the same or slightly different, know this: use a box cutter, razor blade or similar to remove those suction cups before you install it, *especially* if you are installing in a Fluval Spec V.  If those suction cups are firmly in place in the V, you WILL NOT be able to remove the pump when it fails.  You may have better luck in a Spec III because the pump cavity is bigger.Oh, and you also won't be able to remove the pump if it's still working, but the water supply tube has come away from the pump and needs to be refitted (my situation).  My solution in my Spec V: cut the power cord to the pump while it's place and leave the pump and remaining wire in place.  (Yes, unplugging it first would be a splendid idea.)  Yank the water tube off the pump and attach it to your replacement pump (maybe with a zip tie).  Drop the replacement pump on top of the original (now disabled) pump and connect the spout from the tube to the water outlet.  Now you have a *removable* pump in your Spec aquarium.  It would be really swell if you had this feature from the factory.  JEEZ.

I won't say this is a real looker, but it's not at all unattractive.  It looks a LOT better to my taste than 2.1 systems in this price range with exposed speakers with gaudy trim, fancy lights that pulse or change color, that kind of thing.  It works well as a monitor for my little vinyl-to-MP3 setup with a turntable and a dedicated laptop.OTOH, I have one of those visually ultra-tacky 2.1 systems in the same room.  Its bass is punchier, treble is cleaner and fresher, and the midrange is much more present, and it cost about the same as the Edifier.  But the Edifier is indeed more attractive, sounds perfectly okay in this price range, and the satellite volume/input/output module is really cool (but why no standby or full power switch on it?).Not sorry I bought this but not sure I'd do so again.  But if I didn't, I'd be looking for something that looks clean *and* kicks a bit more audio butt, and I'm pretty sure I'd be looking at a noticeably higher price range.  So there's that.

I dare not allow these items into my house.  I buy them as gifts for my aunt for one occasion or another, and of course she graciously offers me one when she opens the package.  I'm telling you, avoid that first one as these are addictive and you will suck down the entire can once you start.  I'm mostly a dark chocolate guy and these are more on the milk side, but there's a combination of textures at play here that is absolutely hypnotic.  Also, I was originally put off by the reference to toffee...I thought caramel, chewy, gooey.  Nope, none of that.  This is a crisp, fresh, clean taste that lingers just right and just long enough (not embedded in your teeth for the next hour).  Awesome with coffee or a cordial or a big ole glass of milk.  Or all three.Plus I have to mention that when I've bought these directly from the manufacturer the shipping charges have been nuts.  At least for my purchases this past holiday season, Amazon was the way to go.

I'm returning to drumming after, oh, 40 years or so.  Just hacking around and found that I kept dropping the sticks, so I looked around and found sticks with this coating or that which promised to be grippier, easier to hold onto.  The concept is logical and I'm sure there are some out there that do the job, but these did nothing for me.  I'll probably try some gloves; this brand has an awesome rep and if they can't get it right I'm wondering if anybody can.

I wore out a precious USB port on a laptop after years of plugging and unplugging devices.  I just bought a new laptop and got two of these hubs...one for the old laptop's surviving USB port, and one for the new laptop.  Plugging and unplugging taxes the contacts - we are talking cheap, mostly plastic connectors here, after all - and so the Sabrent stays plugged in all the time.  I'm hoping to put most of the wear on the inexpensive Sabrent hub which I can easily replace, rather than the one built into my laptop which I can't.  This hub is so small that it can usually stay in place even when transporting the laptop, and the ability to rotate means it can flip up out of the way when I want to open my optical drive.The fact that it turns one port into four comes in handy as well.  I have other Sabrent products and all perform as advertised.  Very nice piece of work at a crazy good price.

OK, first off, this is a lousy time of year to test and review a garden hose here in central-ish NC.  Winters arent that cold but we get the occasional Arctic blast.  In this case a couple of weeks of wildly erratic weather gave me a chance to take this hose around the block.We had a couple of unseasonably warm days so I used it with my pressure washer to spray out my screened porch.  It never kinked, and I did maneuvers with it that ALWAYS resulted in kinks and nasty expletives.  So theres that.  But dragging the washer around was a chore as usual and I couldnt feel any of the light weight, easier handling benefit promised on the package.  It never fully uncoiled either, but thats to be expected when the high for the day is in the low 50s.I drained the hose but left it lying on the patio overnight, where the temps plummeted to the mid-teens and froze it solid.  After a little warmup the next afternoon the hose was stiff but undamaged.  I coiled it for storage as I would with any hose and found that the stiffness and tendency to hold the coil made this pretty much the chore it usually is.  In this case, though, I could tell that the hose was lighter toward the end of the process (when most of the hose is in your arms rather than on the ground).  So I think there is something to the claims of lightness.I think the problem is that I want a hose that doesnt exist: 100 feet long, three pounds total weight, flaccid as a shoestring, self-deploying and self-storing.  This aint that, but it is a well-made (in the USA), high-quality hose that resisted every attempt I made to make it kink and thats its claim to fame.  It will replace one of those horrible spring-like coil hoses that has tortured me with tangles for the past couple of years.  This guy is a lot closer to Nirvana than that!

These little guys arrived feisty and ready to munch out on some aqua-crud.  I had one DOA Red Cherry but they threw in two extra Amanos so I have no complaints..the survivors were healthy and vigorous and beyond ready to get out of their shipping bags.You really, really need to keep a cover on these and use caution while acclimating and adding them to your tank - the Amanos (at least) will jump like tiny crickets and get away from you if you give them a millisecond.  Also don't assume that little piece of remaining crud in the shipping bag is just a shred of Java Moss...in my case it was an Amano caught in a wrinkle in the bag.If your filter's water intake has holes that would allow a very, very tiny shrimp to slip through, put some gauze (or something) over the holes.  The babies are incredibly small.  I have two Fluval Specs and found that I can cover the main water intake with a bit of bandage gauze secured by big paper clips.  The filtration still works but it doesn't let the tiny shrimp get sucked into filter oblivion.I will buy from these folks again.  Great products, great service.

I have a 24-hour timer plugged into the front face of this, which obscures the lower outlet on the front, but I still have two regular power cords and two power bricks (transformers) connected (one of the bricks is plugged into the timer) and there's still an available outlet.  Not too shabby.  There's room to plug in power bricks on the face and on the sides.  Nice job.

Arrived in perfect condition and was much more than I expected.  I split it into two groups that I planted (weighed down with pebbles) in different sections of my aquarium.  It is doing very well but is really too much for my Fluval Spec V (5 gallon).  You won't be disappointed.

I almost overdid it after seeing the teeny-tiny live plants available in my local pet stores.  This arrived quickly with no dead leaves and was too easy to plant (if that's the right word).  I just set it on my gravel substrate and weighed it down with some decorative pebbles and it is doing phenomenally well.

I was in Tampa recently for leisure and happened on the Columbia Restaurant in Ybor City, in business since 1905 so they are clearly doing something right.  I had a bowl of the Spanish Bean Soup (a.k.a. Garbanzo Bean Soup) and it brought back memories of a version of that soup that my dad used to make.  There are a bunch of recipes for it on the web and many of them call for one or two packets of this stuff and I have to say, it perks up that soup and pretty much any Latin dish in a noticeable way.  If you like Mexican food, Tex-Mex, Cuban or any of the whole Latin American flavor genre, this is something to have in your cooking arsenal.  Good stuff.  And if you're in the Tampa area, find one of the Columbia locations and grab a Cuban Sandwich and a bowl of Spanish Bean Soup.  Ecstasy.

I really like this and the convenience is outstanding, but it's really hard to pay that much for rice, even though sticky (glutinous) rice products are often sold at a premium.  I went through an order of this from Amazon, then spotted a similar Annie Chun variety at Wally World for a lot less and went through a few of them.  Searched on the web and found a number of ridiculously complicated techniques to make sticky rice and they were all way too much work.Finally bought a big bag of plain old white glutinous rice and followed the instructions.  It's just too easy.  Grab a measuring cup and put about a cup of glutinous rice in it.  Cover the rice with water and let it sit on the counter for at least two hours (all day is fine too).  Strain it and dump it into a dish, then steam it for 30 minutes.  That's it.  You don't need a new appliance (although if you don't have an electric steamer you don't know what you're missing).  You don't need exotic culinary implements.  I thought sticky rice was a closely-guarded secret of the ancients but in reality, there ain't nothing to it.I'm not a cheapskate at all but sometimes I look up and say "I paid WHAT?"  This is one of those things.

It takes a little while to get your fingers and lips acclimated to this...it's more like sucking on a straw than drinking from a glass, but not exactly.  But it does exactly what it's supposed to do.  Also, I suppose I should be more fastidious but I don't bother with the laborious cleaning instructions after every use and it continues to work just fine.  The care instructions suggest that this will be a high-maintenance PIA but it's not at all.

I bought one of these a while back that was a little cheaper.  That version was not in retail packaging but rather in a plain brown OEM looking box.  Of that one, the Time Warner tech said the MAC ID was already in use on the Time Warner network and we just couldn't go any further.  He sounded competent and straight-up and I had (still have) no reason to think he was wrong.  So I returned it and just forgot about it.Last month my Time Warner bill reflected an additional charge for modem rental for the first time, which motivated me to try again.  I bought this item and installation was totally smooth...after I navigated the Time Warner voicemail menu tree, easily the biggest challenge of the episode.  When I finally got a live tech, he was awesome and patiently stayed with me through a couple of reboots until I was up and running.  Happy camper here.

I bought this to use with a bag of Dyson Zorb carpet cleaning powder and it is perfect for the task.  Unfortunately I think it really is time for me to replace the carpet!  The combination of this tool and the Zorb did make for a noticeable improvement, but sometimes you just have to acknowledge reality and accept that the carpet is just worn out.

I was able to cram a bag in, but this is a little large for the Fluval Spec filter.  I have a Spec V (5 gallon) but I believe the filter is the same for the Spec 3 (2.6 gallon).  Once I stuffed it into place it worked well.  I was going to rate it 4 stars but then realized this was a user (me) problem so I upped it to 5.

The AMZN blurb says "Controls 2 outlets simultaneously."  No, it doesn't.  It plugs into your typical two (female) plug wall outlet and occupies both of those outlets, and then you have one outlet on the Hydrofarm available to plug something into that you want to turn on/off with the timer.  I guess you could say it OBSCURES two outlets simultaneously, but it doesn't CONTROL them.  It just hides one of them.No large deal for me.  I use it with the "6-Grounded Outlet In-Wall Adapter with Resettable Circuit Breaker, White 56575" that allows me several other connections, and the whole arrangement is pretty compact.  So I have one timed outlet (the Hydrofarm doohickey) which allows a power brick (transformer) for an aquarium light.  I have another outlet for another power brick for my motion detector alarms.  I have two more outlets for my aquarium heater and pump, and I have two left.  Not too shabby.This item fits perfectly into a wall socket if you need only one outlet.  If paired with the item described above (search AMZN for it), you can enjoy one timer outlet and a bunch of power-brick-friendly other outlets.

I just got this bundle last week so this is my initial impressions and then I'll update the review as I use it more.It took me almost 2 hours of set-up, updates and install time before playing the game but Fallout 4 made it all worth it. I've got about 20 hours in so far and it's incredible. I installed Fallout 3 using the code included first, just so I knew I had it and that the code worked and it did.  Both games installed with no issues.The graphics are insane and so far I've experienced no glitches or issues.Fallout 4 was responsible for me buying the console and it was worth it.  The Bundle including both games makes it a pretty good deal.

This is a nice case.  It provides good protection and does not intrude on using the buttons on my phone.  I've dropped my phone a couple times on the ground and it made it through undamaged.  It looks nice on my phone too.  It fits well and I like that it's not bulky.  I tried the scarlet crystal before the black and that one looked like it had a hint of pink color to it and was too feminine for me, so I prefer the black crystal.

I fluctuate between a size 38 and 40 jean.  When I saw this I didn't think it was going to fit, but it did and covers my twig and berries and stays on while I walk around.  The Velcro closure stretches and is very accommodating.The material is comfortable enough, but does not absorb water that well.  If it was five dollars I'd shrug and say good enough, but the quality is much cheaper than I was expecting at the price it's at.Care instructions say Cold water wash on gentle cycle, tumble dry low, do not bleach.

If I'd paid for this I'd feel ripped off...it is so cheap.  Dollar store cheap.  The title for my review was originally going to be back to the drawing board with this one...but I see someone else already said that.It looks and feels so cheap...and it leaks.

I really like this piece of exercise equipment.  If I had rated it based on my initial impression of it, I'd have done it an injustice because I didn't realize that to decrease the amount of resistance I just remove bands from it.  So I was trying to use it with the full 3 bands and it was way too much resistance for me even though I lift weights and use resistance bands regularly.Pros+ Adjustable resistance levels are very useful, especially if more than one person is going to be using it and they have different resistance levels between them.  One band is light resistance (but still a good workout) and 3 bands is strong resistance+ The bands are very easy to take in and out+ The handle grips are comfortable to use, even for longer workouts+ Comes with exercise guide (with color pictures and full instruction) for recommended exercises to do with it+ Sturdy qualityCons- None foundSuggested improvementI'd have really liked it if it came with a drawstring or zippered bag that it fit in, just for convenient portable storage of it.

I am renovating a historical building and I used this to evaluate the moisture content in the existing framing.  It was accurate and easy to use.  I used it in pin mode in comparison to my other moisture meter and the reading was consistent between the two. There is a menu pop up that is simple to navigate through.  What I really liked about this moisture meter is the multitude of options that I have to determine the different conditions.The other feature that set this meter apart from other meters is the IR imaging which gives me a visual picture of where the moisture problem areas are.  I was able to quickly locate moisture issues within a wall surface where an existing pipe was leaking and created mold within the wall.I'd have expected it to come with a protective case for an instrument of this quality and cost.

These are really nice speakers.  The sound output is great on them, very clean and clear.  The bass is not overwhelming on them.  The connections on the back are very secure and the build quality is top notch.

Overall, I like this wrist brace and with a couple tweaks it could be a great brace.Pros+ Very supportive+ Quality straps (see exception in cons) that stay in place+ Keeps the wrist stable+ Good length on it, not too longCons- The second strap on it should be longer.  It fits great at the wrist and that strap secures it tightly there but as the arm starts to taper up in size at the second strap...that strap should be longer than the first strap.  Unless you have a slender upper wrist area, the fit isn't as great as it could be if it just had a longer second strap.- Material makes me feel itchy after wearing it for a bit.
Used this wiring harness to install a stereo in my Ford F-350 and it worked great, no issues.
Used these to remove the factory stereo in my Ford F-350 and they got the job done.

These are nice garden stakes.  We had one of them break in the middle because it had such a big knot in it that it weakened it, but the rest of them are good.They are accurately sized and a decent value at the quality they are.

We had some break-ins in the neighborhood and wanted an inexpensive motion light that operated on batteries.  We bought two of these and when we first pulled them out of the packaging and installed the batteries they were a little wonky and we thought they were cheap and wouldn't work and we'd have to return them.  But after a few minutes they started working right and we put them up in their locations and we haven't had any problems with them since.  They are bright and work as they are supposed to.

I am not wild about the scent of this hair mask, but the way it actually works is amazing.  The scent is a little like a medicinal flowery pine to me and it stays on your hair.  It's not bad, it's just not a scent I'm fond of.  It works better than any hair mask that I've tried in memory though. I noticed that right away when rinsing the product out. My hair is super soft after using it and it brings out my curls.  I have medium length hair and I'd say there is enough in the container for 4 or 5 uses so it's a good value.  I will buy more of this when I run out.Product provided for evaluation.

This was a one and done product for me, it's not something I'd get again.  The product I've been using for a long time is Uni Fresh, Vanilla scent and it works and smells great.  I get twice as much product for half the cost of this freshener.The other problem I have with Poo-Pourri is it just didn't work.  It is strong so it overwhelms the senses at first, but that is short lived.  Then it's like poo with roses mixed in and not fooling anyone.  Also, if you are a believer in courtesy flushes...you do that and you flush the product down the drain so that defeats it's purpose.Also, my current freshener lists the ingredients right on it...why doesn't this product list the ingredients?  Judging by the price, it must contain some gold flecks in it somewhere?

I have a senior dog who has urine leak issues and is in diapers.  I use wet wipes to clean her up when she does leak and I wanted a natural deodorizer to use after that just to keep her fresh smelling between baths.  This works great for that.  It is a nice, fresh scent without being overpowering.Ingredients: De-ionized water, natural conditioners, colloidal oatmeal, aloe vera, vitamin E, eucalyptus and peppermint essences.  It says all ingredients are natural, gentle and 100% biodegradable.
Good batteries.  Expiration date on them 12-2024.  I will update this review if I have any problems with them lasting.

I have been using resistance bands for awhile now for conditioning, stretching and rehabilitating an injured knee.  I chose the purple band according to the charts and because I wanted heavy resistance, not light.  I do not use it for pull-ups, only full body exercising so I can only review it for that purpose.  It is one of the highest-quality bands that I've used and definitely a heavy duty resistance.  It is so strong that I can't see having a problem with it.  If you are new to exercising or bands, I think it would be too much resistance and I'd go with a lighter band.  The resistance level challenges me and I've been building up my strength on them for awhile.Product provided for evaluation

I have medium-length, naturally wavy hair and I really like this brush.  It brushes my hair out without snapping it or damaging it. It's the first brush that I've used that actually makes me want to brush my hair more, I'm not sure why that is.  I like how it feels on my scalp and I like how soft my hair feels after brushing it out.Product provided for evaluation.

This leash is attractive and really built solid.  The seams are very straight and reinforced in the needed areas.I have two dogs with different situations for each that I've used this leash on walks with and it is very helpful. We have a 15 year old Lab who wears a stability harness on her walks because she has balance issues and it's easier to walk and help support her in a harness.  This leash works great with her harness....when she starts to wobble I can hold the short handle and help steady her.  I have a younger Chihuahua who when people pass on the trails, I have to pull him aside and wait. The short handle works great there.  It also works great when he starts to pull.Product provided for evaluation.

This newest Halloween Drops is super fun. I find myself saying "just one more level" a lot.  I absolutely love the colorful, cute boards and powerups/special objects.  Gameplay is the right balance of relaxing and challenging.  I both love the orb and growl at the orb.  On the levels where there are under 10 of them, I enjoy them a lot but when levels come up where there are more than that I cringe because it gets to be orb overkill.  There aren't many of those levels though.

These are good entry level virtual reality glasses to try out the technology.  They have a comfortable fit and easy to adjust. I used them with a Samsung Galaxy S5 and they worked fine. I wish there were more higher quality VR apps available out there, but there isn't a shortage of low-budget free ones.The glasses themselves work nicely, I think they would benefit from having more concise, understandable instructions.Product provided for evaluation.

We chose this gate to use on a door that goes to the outside so that our dog can lay in front of it and watch the yard when she's not able to be out in it.  She's a 15 1/2 year old Lab and she loves watching the activity in the yard.  I prop open the door and keep the gate in so she can do that and it works great.  It's a really nice dog gate, very sturdy and it was simple to install.  I love the extra height on it and that you can keep it open or keep it closed.  I also like that you can just walk through it instead of some gates that you have to step over or lift up each time you want to go through it.

I have medium-length, naturally curly hair and this argan oil shampoo and conditioner set works so well with it.
