After my daughter had a meltdown while out shoe shopping with my husband I was informed that she had her heart set on Skechers Kids 81896L Skech Appeal Limited Edition Sneaker but at the time they were $50. If you've ever had a child in the preschool and early grades you know that you can buy a pair of shoes and they'll outgrow them overnight. So I was really hesitant to drop the cash on them. So I searched here on Amazon for a similar shoe that was a lot closer to our budget for a pair of sneakers for school and I found this pair of Twinkle Toes. Not only were these $20 less in price, they are far cuter.I honestly completely forgot that Twinkle Toes light up when I showed them to my daughter and asked if she'd prefer them. When they arrived she pretty much spent the next 3 days running because that sets off the lights. I also love that since she's learning to tie her shoes these have flat laces which I find are easier for her to grip and they stay tied for longer. Overall, I think these are a fantastic pair of street shoes that are priced just right for what they are. I'd definitely buy them again.

If you love alternate history WOLF BY WOLF is an engrossing swap as a young Jewish girl attempts to kill Hitler. But it's also so much more. I don't want to say that there's a strong focus on relationships yet that's really an important piece of what makes this such a good book. Yael's relationships with the people she has lost and those she is competing against play significant roles in who she is and what she is trying to do.While I felt that at times it was slow or that it cut off where more information would have been useful WBW was a really good read and one I think most of the target audience will find enjoyable. I'm looking forward to thrusting it on my own teenager to read.

While I was really impressed that this product did not irritate my sensitive (and highly reactive) skin, I do have a few reasons I wasn't impressed. First of all, no where on the package is a recommended frequency of use mentioned. I had to find that information here on the product page. Secondly, you wash it off after only 2 minutes while most other mud masks sit for 10... could this really just be a 10 minute mask that they tell you to wash off sooner to market it for sensitive skin? It just seemed fishy.Suffering from really awful adult acne that's hormonally driven and made worse by side effects of a medication I take I was hoping for a little relief. But I haven't noticed any difference good or bad in my skin. I made need to use it for a few months to see any change. I do like it in general though as it does leave the skin soft and refreshed without the redness I typically experience with masks touted for acne treatment.

Kinda wishing I'd given Fluxx a try sooner, what a fantastic game! It's definitely one you've got to have some patience to learn but once you get it going and have a good grasp of the concept it's really fun. Complicated but fun. I would definitely recommend doing a solo double play rundown if you're new so you can see how the flow of game play goes. That worked really well for me. I'm not sure if every 8 year old will have the patience for this but the cute Adventure Time theme is sure to help them want to try. Overall, a funny game that will keep players on their toes.

If you suffer from stressdon't we all?you've probably tried all kinds of things to help you cope. I know plenty of people who resort to happy hour or binge eating as a way to manage their but that's just not mine. A good book and a cup of herbal tea are always a nice and yoga or a walk in the park can be good too. For me, however, I find that my stress and anxiety tend to peak as soon as I'm trying to go to sleep and I remember everything I didn't get done or need to get done. Not always the perfect time to fill up on liquids or attempt a warrior pose, I'm tired and I want to go to sleep.So I accepted the Ohuhu Ocean Wave Night Light Projector and Music Player for review to see if it was an option that worked for me. It's really cool for other uses since it has so many light settingskids love itbut my goal was something to help me distract myself from a racing mind so I could fall asleep. I am 100% sold! The first time I tried it I think I barely made it 10 minutes before I dozed off. There's just something soothing about the gentle motion of the light and the soft blue color (the light setting I would recommend for those seeking sleep) that works. I love that it shuts off automatically after an hour too so it doesn't run all night long. If you were to pair it with ocean/lake/rain sounds I imagine the effect would be two fold though I chose not to.Overall, I think it's a great soothing or stress relieving item for the price point and since it isn't chemical it's great for small children and those with sensitivities. I do want to point out, however, that there is one light setting that flashes heavily and could be dangerous for those who have seizure disorders so use at your own risk. Other than that I absolutely love it and would recommend it.Note: I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

After hearing a lot of buzz about NAKED I was quite interested in the story of a girl who had been a prostitute going home. It is just as complex as I expected but I genuinely could not say that I liked it. The challenge for me was that aside from Jackson (and even he wasn't well fleshed out enough to be the redeemer for me) most of the characters were deeply unlikable. Not that every character or even protagonist must be a delight, but in a story where one wants to feel something resembling sympathy I found myself constantly scowling at the characters. It's easy to loathe the obvious ones like Anna's abusive father and her former pimp, Luis. But Anna herself was difficult to feel truly sympathetic for. The way she constantly defended Luis was bothersome but the way she would think down about herself for her former role and yet be scoffing about it a moment later like it wasn't a big deal just bothered me. The ultimate challenge though was the whole cartoony villain element. I don't want to spoil anything but I felt like I was watching Scooby-Doo with that subplot.While I wouldn't not recommend NAKED, it's not an easy read. It's the sort of story that makes you think and feel for those who have been trafficked. It had a good ending though, so if you like to see a character rise from something so dark I think it will satisfy you.

I've read a lot of wonderful teen fiction from Entangled Teen over the years and even some that just didn't work for me. THE BODY INSTITUTE, however, is one of the most phenomenal reads I've had with the imprint to date. Not only does it touch on themes that could easily skew dystopian such as the government's control over a person's body, it also address issues of what makes a person a person. It felt much longer than it was because it packed so much into one novel.While a romance is a part of the overall story and I found it to be very unique and enjoyable, I was considerably more swept up in the pseudo science used in the world building. If you're looking for a great book club read for teens I think this would make for excellent conversations about the factors that play a role in a person's physical, emotional, and mental well being. I feel like young women in particular would greatly benefit from reading this and discussing it's themes. It could be deemed a little controversial due to the focus on how weight and health revolve around one another but ultimately it is this that makes it interesting.I was quite certain going into TBI that I would like it but I'd not expected to love it and want to tell everyone I know about it. While I can't imagine it every being into one, I think it would be marvelous as a film. It's everything I love in entertainmentromance, action, family, and social issues all wrapped up into one package. If you have a tween or teenage daughter I can't recommend this one enough. A RhiReading must read recommendation!Notes: ARC received via NetGalley.

Holy so-similar-to-my-life-story Batman! Having attended a couple of online book chats before I read WRITTEN ON MY HEART I already knew that the author had drawn from her own personal experiences with homelessness for the story. What I didn't realize is that there would be many small subtle things that were so like my own life that I'd fall in love with this book each painful page at a time. Abusive, controlling stepdad. Check. Homeless. Check. Falling for a guy who is all kinds of right and wrong. Check. I have even worked as a barista. Perhaps it was all the things that I found relatable that made me love WOMH, it isn't every day that I find a heroine whom I so uniquely relate to.What I think most readers will love about it is just how deserving Lane and Ash are of the love they find in one another. They've both had some tough struggles that make them wary of their attraction to one another but good gravy the chemistry between them just jumps off the page! If you like your New Adult reads chock full of painful angst and your characters a little bit broken by circumstance before their happy ending, I think you'll really enjoy the journey Ash and Lane experience. It made me angry, it made my eyes wet (onion chopping ninjas were hiding in my house I swear!), and it reminded me that everyone should be so fortunate to find another person in who makes them feel safe and loved.WOMH is a wonderful romance and one of my favorite romances I've read this year. A RhiReading recommended MUST READ.Notes: ARC received via NetGalley.

Phew! I had heard that Jackson was going to get crazy darker before he was going to change and dang is that spot on. If you haven't read the previous installments please do not read this review! I can't promise it won't spoil previous events.After the big cliff hanger ending of DEEP DOMINATION I expected things would start moving in a more positive direction between Hannah and Jackson. Boy was I wrong! If you thought things were dark before you are in for the worst kind of shock. Jackson is one hero I would never want on my bad side. He's capable of some pretty heinous behavior that I'd honestly never come back from but this is fiction and it works to show how messed up he is by what he has been through and how desperately both he and Hannah need someone to love them. It was pretty much the only thing I didn't like about this book, I hate it when heroes do something truly awful to the heroine and it is quickly glossed over. When he realizes what a terrible act it was it was really great to finally see the potential he had to be a good guy.This is one of the most out-there plots overall but if you're in the mood for something kind of over-the-top dark, nail-nibblingly suspenseful, that's full of good old-fashioned hardcore smutty goodness you need to get going on the Bought by the Billionaire serial. Is it even remotely grounded in plausibility? Not really and that's exactly what makes it a dirty good fun read.

There are a handful of classics that I have a deep soft spot for and anything Alice always catches my eye. I've wanted to read Splintered since before it came out but somehow managed to not get to it until I finally bought an audio copy. I'm actually really glad I did as the narration was very good and I felt more free to just let my mind take over the painting pictures part of reading. If ever there was a classic retelling or reimagining that was more suited to letting the mind wander I don't know what it could be.Howard's reimagining is darkly twisted but not in the usual horror or gothic stylings many writers and artists choose. It's more earthy and surreal and works to delicious effect. I can see why so many people loved it. I loved it. Occasionally it felt a little bit forced, in particular the romantic elements, but knowing there are further installments I feel confident that I'll enjoy seeing where this rabbit hole goes. It's wicked and weird, sexy and sweet.If you've held back from getting to this series like I have I'd certainly recommend giving it that shot. Especially if you're a fan of all things Alice.

Since the Mercy Thomson series of novels first came out I've been a huge fan. I remember the the excitement I felt when I picked up the first book at the store at random and found a map of my hometown inside. I've not been as avid of a fan of the comics but mostly just due to time constraints. I'm glad I took the time to sit down and devour this one though. Garcia did an excellent job of capturing the region while also bringing the characters to vivid life.It's not my favorite Mercy story but it was spooky and impressively not completely predictable. The story hinged much more on Jesse than Mercy which was also a nice change of pace. On a totally gratuitous note... hello crazy hot Zee. lolIf you've enjoyed the other comics/graphic novels I think you'll dig this one too. If you've a fan of the novels this actually fits into the series continuity so that's a huge plus. Definitely check it out.Notes: ARC received via NetGalley.

If you're looking for a beautiful, well-made floral head wreath I cannot recommend this stunning piece of Valdler Elegant enough. Each flower is handmade and lovely. They're tightly bunched unlike other low priced options I've found in stores and online. The ribbons are long enough that you have a lot of adjustability for both the crown and the wristband. For my daughter we chose to have her wear the wristband as an anklet to adorable effect but I'd dare say the same could be done for an adult too. Overall this is a striking pair that would be wonderful for a child, teen, or grown woman equally.I have a few ideas for ways I would use this that I wanted to specifically share for this blog post: This would make a fantastic photographer's prop both for portraits and editorial projects. Because it's well made it can handle a lot of adjustment and wear by children! Cosplay, renfaire, and music festivals! The high quality of this piece make it a great choice because it can hold up to all day wear and hot weather and the flowers look more real than many of the other options out there. Weddings and special events. This one is pretty obvious, it's inexpensive so it won't break your budget and if you're crafty you could easily add netting, ribbons, rhinestones, feathers, or other accents to individualize it to your tastes. Perhaps this pink version for the flower girl and the white version for the bride? A dress-up box item. We turned an old dresser into a really great costume closet for our daughter a couple of Christmases ago and filled it with clearanced Halloween costumes. But we've since added nicer pieces (now that she's older and doesn't damage everything) like this and some costume jewelry that make her feel really special when she plays. Perfect for a older child who loves to dressup.Notes: I received a complimentary product in exchange for this honest review.

I knew from the first time I saw this cover that this book was gonna be for my almost-6 year old daughter. My kid has a pretty great sense of humor and sure enough she absolutely loves this book. To the point I'm kind of getting sick of having to read it to her. That said, this is one of those fantasticly fun children's books that has such wonderful subtleties that the kids might not notice that as an adult I really appreciated. Like Princess Pinecone being biracial. Or that there were male and female warriors of all colors AND body types. For me those are such important things for my kid to see in an enjoyable story just as much as I want her to love fart jokes as much as I do.If you love gender-neutral stories with princesses and warriors and ponies that fart you (and your kids) will love The Princess and the Pony.

Having used Zaca's patches for hangovers in the past I thought the chewables would make a great option for workout recovery. With the summer heat and the HIIT workouts I've been doing on occasion I find that sometimes water and a protein filled snack aren't enough. I still feel drained and wind up so fatigued that I have a hard time getting a solid workout the next day.So far I've found that 2 tablets about 20 minutes after I finish followed by some water works well for me. Normally I avoid stevia like the plague because it majorly upsets my stomach and overall digestion but I've found that not only do I not taste it (ugh I hate that sickly sweet taste it has) I haven't had the tummy trouble. They even taste good and not weird or medicine like as many of them do.If you're looking for an easy to carry recovery option for your gym bag I would definitely recommend checking them out. I honestly haven't had a drink in a long time so I can't say if these work as well as the patches for a hangover but I think they'd be even better based on how they've helped with my hardest workouts.Notes: I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

I grew up quite poor. I remember watching my mother slice the moldy parts off of 'government' cheese for sandwiches while things like chips and snack cakes were luxuries I only saw in the lunchboxes of my peers. But if there's one thing growing up mostly in poverty will teach you, it is how to be resourceful and grateful for what you do have... because there is always someone who has much less or does not have the skills to make do with what they do have. With this in mind I was quite eager to see what Brown had put together.GOOD AND CHEAP has a lot of fantastic information about not just how to prepare food, but when and how to buy it to maximize your budget. Whether you're receiving SNAP benefits or just living on a tight budget as a single-income family there are recipes and information here that will help you eat well and even quite healthfully.The one area it doesn't seem to hit on that I felt would have been of great use is food allergies. Having discovered earlier this year that my partner is allergic to wheat, rice, corn, potatoes, tomatoes, and a host of other inexpensive staples I struggled for several months with horrifying grocery bills trying to find ways to avoid allergens while on a very tight budget. I'd have liked to see some budgeting advice for those who are struggling with food allergies or celiac disease because those conditions affect low income families just as much as those of wealth and alternative foods can be costly.Overall, while I feel that some of the recipes and ingredients were still a bit unreasonable to expect someone of limited means to get on board with, GOOD AND CHEAP is still a fantastic general resource for anyone who wants to eat well with limited funds. This would make a terrific gift for young adults new to living on their own.Notes: Review copy received via NetGalley.

I'm still not sure if I like this series or not. I know that's a terrible way to open up the review but as much as I'm enjoying the characters I feel strangely detached from their adventures. I think something that might have made my enjoyment stronger was if I knew much about the poetry mentioned in the blurb or the churches of London. Even the undead fights felt a bit dry.I did find that while this plot had really draggy parts this time around, I felt like the characters had more going on. Especially Malcolm, whom I have really grown to like more and more. In fact, I felt like Simon and Kate took a bit of a backseat to him this time. The scenes featuring Imogen and Charlotte were my favorites.The mystery this time felt a bit anticlimatic and it ended on a small cliffhanger that makes me quite glad the next book is coming out so close to it.Notes: ARC received via NetGalley.

I'd never tried resistance bands before getting this set to try and I'm now wishing I had been using them much sooner! There's so much you can do with them from physical therapy exercises to actual strength training workouts. My primary use for them though is increasing my flexibility through stretching. Sometimes you just can't reach your own foot or other hand and these bands provide a simple and effective solution.While I don't have any basis for comparison I feel confident in recommending these to those seeking a great set of bands at different resistance levels. I tend to stick with the medium most days and if I'm feeling like I really want to challenge myself I will go with the heavy. Maybe some day I will advance to the x-heavy but it's pretty hard core. If you've never added resistance bands to your fitness routine I think this set from Phantom Fit is an excellent place to get started.Notes: I received a complimentary product in exchange for this honest review.

Awwww you guys! While ANYA AND THE SHY GUY had a couple of tiny continuity issues and it was pretty far-fetched, I couldn't help myself. I loved it.There's always something fun about the twin-swap in a romance and I totally fell hard for Will/Matt. If you adore the funny types I think you'll like him too. I couldn't help but picture a teenage version of an adorable celeb who recently became a mega-star. Anya on the other hand, earned a very special place in my heart more based on circumstance than personality. I have a big soft spot for teens who are or have been homeless, especially the ones who are smart enough to pull off what Anya does. I really wanted her to get her big scoop but at the same time I hated the idea of her story destroying S2J. I think you'll be as pleased as I was with the way their story plays out.I came in late to the series and read DAISY AND THE FRONT MAN first and I think you could almost do the same for AATSG but I would recommend starting from the beginning. There's enough back story about who the secondary characters are that felt unexplained enough I think you would enjoy it more if read in order. That said, it's going to be well worth the wait.Notes: ARC received via NetGalley.

My friends and family think I love to cook but the truth is... I love to eat! And if you're not going to go broke enjoying eating there are things you learn to cook. But whipping up the basics had never really seemed like a thing you could do until I stumbled on this book on NetGalley last year. Translated and adapted from the French version I found it exceptionally accessible and friendly.While I had originally sampled it as an advanced readers copy I wound up buying it because I liked it so much that I wanted to have a permanent copy. I've admittedly not actually used any of the recipes yet but I've been hoping to start making all of my own mayonnaise, ketchup, and the chocolate milk powder from the book. If you've ever considered purchasing a cookbook to teach you the basics I would definitely put this at the top of the list. From marshmallows and crackers to hamburger buns and fries you're going to have an arsenal of basics you'll never have to buy again... and you'll always know what goes into them!

Absolute garbage. As attractive as it looked in the photos and on the package (not to mention the retail price) you'd think this might be an attractive option. Alas, all of the parts beyond the bars and the end pieces are cheap, flimsy plastic. My husband and I spent quite a while trying to get this up only to have the part you screw to tighten it once you get it in place snap with the slightest pressure. We can't even use it now.Would not recommend.

It's no secret that I'm not that big on contemporary romances and even less into New Adult. When I accidentally accepted a review invite for HIDE ME I was pretty peeved at myself but I went against my gut and figured I'd just give it a couple of chapters before I DNF'd it. Yeah, I went in knowing I wouldn't like it... and came out loving it.Whit Conrad is terribly deep in grief and running away from any chance at happiness she could possibly have when aimless surfer boy Deo Beckett happens into her life. I'll admit his chick-magnet, disgustingly confident attitude irked me at first. But it wasn't long before he grew on me and I really wanted him to win Whit over. Equally so I hated how much she was forcing herself to suffer needlessly. They are that young couple with sizzling sexual chemistry that uses it to keep from going any deeper at first. But when he wants more and she pushes him away I was surprised because of how directionless he seemed.Peppered with smolder love scenes, angst thicker than molasses, and grounded just enough in reality to feel possible, HIDE ME, is a page turner that kept me up way past my bedtime. Having gone in not expecting to like it I was stunned when I finished the book and immediately thought to myself how flawless it had been. I was definitely in book-high because it has a few minor flaws but they were so little to me that I don't even feel like I need to note them in this review. I'll let other readers tell you what didn't work for them since I enjoyed it so much I went on a spree of adding every single Silver Strand book to my Want-To-Read shelf on Goodreads as soon as I marked HIDE ME finished.If you're a fan of New Adult where there's a lot of physical intimacy between the hero and heroine countered with drama outside of the bedroom I have to recommend giving this book a try.Notes: ARC received via NetGalley.

With no clue where we got lice from I found out on a Saturday evening that my 5-year-old was infested and since she had been waking at night and climbing in bed with me... so was I. *facepalm* After 10 hours of shampooing and laundry I went to bed at 4am and was so itchy I couldn't sleep so I started shopping Amazon for a better lice comb and found this. I ordered it and paid the extra to have it shipped out as fast as I could. Let me tell you what... it was worth every penny!!!After spending 3 days hand picking as many nits as I could my eyes and fingers were tired and between my daughter and I (both with very long hair) and my teenage son (turns out he had some too) we'd spent 6 hours every night at it. On day 4 the comb arrived and while there was a minor learning curve to it we reduced our combing time dramatically to about 4 hours. By the 4th night of using the comb we were completely lice free.Is this going to mean you won't get reinfested? Not at all. But I can say that I think it was a miracle. My husband went to the Fairy Tales website and watched the video and we followed the same procedure each night. It made it hurt less and cut down the amount of time he was spending going through my hair and the time I was spending on our kids. If lice are a common occurrence in your schools I recommend purchasing one of these. It's really not that expensive for how well it works and how much time and stress it saves. It truly made all the difference for us.A huge thanks to all the other reviewers who shared their experiences with it, you're the reason I decided to buy this.

Having read a wonderful book called Everyday Witchcraft by Deborah Blake earlier this year I decided that I wanted to add a morning oracle-related ritual to my day to help me feel grounded, encouraged, and inspired for the day.I have a couple of lovely oracle decks that I love but I also had this one wishlisted because I adore the artwork of Jasmine Becket-Griffith. While her artwork for this deck is not my favorite, I still love the beautiful cards. But I absolutely have hated the card interpretations. They're all so negative. I thought perhaps I was just drawing a lot of unhappy and hard stuff due to recent circumstances but when I began looking through the book more I found that the general tone is just icky. A lot of the interpretations read like you're doing something wrong. I have found it very discouraging and that it goes against the reason I use an oracle deck in the morning. I've decided not to use it anymore.

What a fun and different set! I've been waiting ages for the folks at Mattel to do a Monster High circus theme and this particular set does not disappoint. It's not often I don't want to let my daughter have the Monster High toys we get but this was one of those times when I really wanted to keep it for my collection. Rochelle has such fantastic hair and I love the swing.The one major flaw I see to the set is that the picture of Rochelle as well as the Manny photo are made from cardstock and for younger kids these might be easily torn. That said, my daughter (who is 5) absolutely adores this set. She especially loves the camera and photo booth props.

I love strange books. I love strange characters, worlds, writing styles. I should have known by the Gaiman quote on the cover this was going to be fantastic and odd in all the best ways. That said, it took me several chapters to warm up to the story even though I was loving Headley's voice. It's a tricky thing to make a world within a world work and as an adult reader of YA I sometimes struggle with letting myself believe it. Once I warmed to the idea the pages seemed to fly by and I found MAGONIA difficult to set down.I feel like anything I could review in regards to the plot would spoil discoveries I think readers should get to uncover on their own but I will say that if you like alternate histories or parallel universes this has similar elements. Though I was left with some unanswered questions and threads left unraveled I thoroughly enjoyed MAGONIA and have put Headley on my list of authors to watch.Romance, airships, strange biology, outcasts... this book has it all. If you enjoy the work of Neil Gaiman or Diana Wynne Jones do not miss out on this one.

Where has this been all my life? I'm pretty much a coffee and herbal tea drinker but I've recently been considering keeping some coconut water on hand as a nice post-workout option and I think this one totally fits the bill. I was really skeptical about the idea of a chocolate drink that had the thinner texture of water but after having my picky 5 year old and equally picky spouse both sample it we all agreed it was like a thin chocolate milk. None of us taste coconut.If you're looking for an after workout drink that tastes indulgent instead of the artificially dyed fruity sports drinks that are out there I would definitely recommend giving this a try. I also think it would make a delicious ingredient in smoothies!

It has been a wonderful and wild ride being a reader of the Hard Ink series. With any romance series ending novel it can be a tough challenge for an author to close out existing series arcing plots while still providing a great romance story. I've been through it spectacularly with Kaye once before and I am thrilled to say that once again she blew me away with a heartfelt romance and a fantastic end to the plot that brought the Hard Ink guys together.Kat Rixey is just as complex and great as her brothers, their family dynamic is great. But it's how she manages to get the previously grunty and closed-off Beckett Murda to... dare I use the word bloom... that makes this a really great romance. Their sexual chemistry is off the charts and while it really is the catalyst that brings them together, their love develops slowly and sweetly. I honestly was pretty ambivalent to Beckett before HARD TO LET GO but after I think he's one of my favorites. Like the saying goes, still waters run deep, and there is so much going on underneath his silent brooding facade.If this had just been another installment of the series it would have easily been one of my favorites but as it was tasked with closing the series it was so much better. To finally get the resolution to what happened to Frank Merritt and the guys' team, who was really behind it all... wow. I won't spoil it for anyone but there was a scene there at the end that made me cry, it was so unexpected and perfect and well, it added a reality to the military aspects of the story that I think every reader of the series will appreciate.As she always manages to do Kaye made me laugh, wince, pant, and reach for the tissues. I am once again reminded of what a fantastic talent for storytelling she has and I am super eager to dive into the spin-off Raven Riders series I once begged her to write. If it's even half as good as HARD TO LET GO and the rest of the Hard Ink series is it's going to get loads of recs from me.If you are new to the series please, please don't start here! This is one series you really need to read in order to enjoy the mystery and development of each of these wonderful characters. That each also touches on real issues faced by military veterans be they scars emotional or physical makes them all the more valuable in my eyes. Hands down one of my most recommended romance series. Just go start reading them!Notes: ARC received via Edelweiss.

Dang! If you read my review for the previous installment in this serial you'll know it pushed my boundaries intensely but that I really enjoyed it. Love it even. But I had a much harder time with DEEP DOMINATION's sex this time around. Everyone has a thing or two that they just don't care for and spanking is high on my list of no-no's but I can often pass over it no biggie. But then there was some pretty hardcore deep throat action that while written very sensually was really uncomfortable for me to read. I was just cringing and holding my breath just to get through reading it. Neither are my cup of tea so I didn't dig the erotica part of the book as much this time around.Hawke ramps up the vengeful hate-effing this time too. He's so hard to like and yet so easy to love. I burned through the entire book in one sitting anxiously dying for Hannah to just tell him he had the wrong sister already. The dark thoughts both have are deliciously dramatic and if you ever really want broken people to find healing together you're sure to find yourself wondering how these two will fare once the truth comes out. It could almost be terrible, however, Valente is a master at taking these dark things and polishing them just right so you can see the sparkle hiding under all the dirt. Readers who've enjoyed graphicIf you enjoyed DARK DOMINATION and are ready to face another, even better, cliff-hanger before the third installment buckle your safety belt and one-click DD. Then be on the lookout for book 3 next month!Notes: ARC received via author.

My 5-year-old and I are Monster High fanatics and though we've slowed down our collecting considerably due to the sheer unaffordable amount of new products they put out now we had to have this one! This is one of the coolest Monster High toys we've seen in a long time. Astranova really floats!If she just floated it would be pretty neat (yay for getting to explain the magnets to my little one) but the added lights that respond to music or even just voices make it ridiculously cool. I honestly wanted to do a video review but I can't pry this away from my daughter long enough to review it without her spazzing out about it. lolThe neatness of it aside I have to admit it has very little play factor for what you pay. You can't put her guitar in her hands after you use it to get her floating (you'll see what I'm talking about when you read the instructions). Much touching at all makes her either fall or stick to the magnet again. I would consider this one more of a collector piece compared to most. With the movie this character appears in not coming out until October the enclosed character diary does provide some hints at the plot.

I'm notably new to the DC universe. I've just always been a Marvel girl but I'm trying to expand my reading this year and I'd heard good stuff about Gotham Academy. I'm so glad I did because I love a good boarding school story and this one is really good.Since I was previously unfamiliar with the characters I definitely felt like I was missing something but that added to the mystery that Olive and Maps are trying to solve. I was pretty amused with what they discovered and am very eager to see where the story heads in the next volume. In particular I loved the illustration style, it suited the story so very well I felt it was important to mention.If you liked the new Batgirl or have enjoyed the Vampire Academy graphic novelization or loved Runawaysall three of which I lovedI would highly recommend picking this up!Notes: ARC received via Edelweiss.

What a terrific, unusual concept! A delightful read for every reader who ever kinda wished they could trade places with the heroine of their favorite romance novel.While it's by no means perfect, I thought that HER FORBIDDEN HIGHLANDER was a great story. My only big complaint was that I wish it had been twice as long so I could have had more connection with Gabby before she finds herself thrust back in time living in her favorite book. Even still it was enjoyably escapist and not so brooding that it felt melodramatic. I've read many of Niles' previous books and if you know her work you know she can write a fantastic love scene and this is no exception.If you love highlander romances and would love a brief but fun palate cleansing read that tweaks the genre a little I would definitely recommend picking it up. I spread it out over a few nights but it could easily be read in one sitting making it a perfect read for summer travel. Enjoy!Notes: Review copy received via author.

I love being the envy of my friends (who doesn't) and everyone has been asking me how I always have amazing mint water all summer long... FOR FREE. Well my secret is that I planted mint in my flower beds instead of shrubs and flowers because it's crazy low maintenance while providing food for the bee population in my area, looks amazing without much more than weeding, smells phenomenal, and of course, has wonderful edible uses. My favorite of whichaside from homemade mint ice cream, of courseis infused water.Every couple of days I go out and snip stalks of chocolate-mint or my new favorite orange-mint and pop them in an infuser bottle to make chilly good drinks. But let's face it, not all infuser bottles are awesome. I have one I love but the infusion cup is at the top and you're drinking the water right through it which can be a little awkward. So I picked up this one from Live Infinitely for review because the infuser is in the bottom of the bottle.Drinking wise I prefer it! I used it wrong the first time, forgetting that the words have to be a certain way and hated it but once I realized I had it wrong I was really pleased with the comfortable rim for drinking. I would love it with a spout at the top so it's just a little easier when I'm working out but it's not a deal breaker. I do feel it worth noting that I get a tiny bit of leakage that I can't seem to fix. (You can see it in the photo). It's very minimal so it would only bug me if I regularly stuck it on a wood surface. And no it's not condensation as the photo might suggest, I tested for that a few times and it does it with every use I've had.I would give this a try with delicious combos like strawberry-basil, lemon-thyme, ginger-orange, raspberry-mint, and pineapple-blueberry!Notes: I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

Every once in a while a read comes along that starts off not so hot where I almost give up on it. HUNTER OF HER HEART got off to a tough start. Zane wasn't very likable and Candi wasn't helping that by being a bit of a flake. I was bummed because I had enjoyed them in LONE WOLFE PROTECTOR and I always love seeing secondary characters get together later in a series. The first third of the book had me ready to call it but I decided to stick it out just a little bit longer. Which I'm glad I did because the story picked up quite a bit.If you're like me and commitment-phobe heroes make you cringe I think you'll find yourself in the same boat I was in. I wanted to think that it was because of Zane's secret but it seemed more just his personality and that didn't work for me. Once Candi brings in a good reason for him to commit even then he gets all wishy-washy but the process slowly starts.What ultimately saved this one from a lower rating was that once they started sorting their stuff out I liked Candi and Zane together. They felt more real than most paranormal romance couples are and that made me want them to find their HEA ending. While it was flawed enough I almost gave up on it, I also felt like the latter half of the story was good enough that most readers might like it.Notes: ARC received via NetGalley.

I've got to say, it takes a lot to impress me with fitness gear but the Marcy flat bench is fantastic. It was quick and easy to put together and is surprisingly light for how sturdy it is. Unlike other models I've seen with rounded feet the flat feet on this are perfect for staying put. The bench is supportive but not so soft you'll slide around.I think this is a great option for the price point and will definitely look into the Marcy brand next time I'm in the market for fitness equipment for my home gym.

If you've read LOVE AT STAKE then you're ready for Melissa's turn at having a match made through the service, Fated Match. If not, I really feel like this is one time when I have to recommend reading it first. You won't need it for the happily ever after to make sense but to really get Melissa and her dad you need that background.I was really stoked to see the paranormal world expand a bit with the introduction of Tarian and the necromancers.  It added a good element of urgency and suspense to the plot. I'll admit it took me a while to warm up to Tarian, I can't quite put my finger on it but something about him felt really closed off. The chemistry between he and Melissa, however, was really good and made their situation both intense and satisfying.The one thing that didn't really work for me is kind of silly but I didn't really feel like this fit the Fated Match series because the whole matchmaking thing didn't play a very big role in the story. It's not a big deal as it's still an enjoyable read, I just think readers who come to it wanting a matchmaking story will not find what they were hoping for and thus it felt worth noting.Overall, it was a quick and enjoyable paranormal romance read. Sure to satisfy readers who like Romeo-and-Juliet (aka Our-Races-Are-Enemies) PNR.Notes: ARC received via NetGalley.

My personal experience with electric toothbrushes has been limited more to those with rotating heads but I really was excited to see just how slim and portable this was so I gave it a try. It's impressively sleek and comes with a great case for travel which definitely makes it an excellent choice for those who do so regularly. It also seems to hold charge for a very long time once it's been fully charged. It did take a little getting used to the sonic style but I have to admit I think I'm liking it better, my teeth feel much cleaner and the massage setting it very nice.The one major disadvantage over my last electric is that the brush storage isn't what I'd prefer. My previous electric had a lid over the stored brushes when not in use. But overall I'm very happy with it and I think I would recommend it to my friends and family.

As with a lot of things in life, I came in a bit late to the Backstage Pass series. I was never into boy bands growing up but for some reason I just couldn't resist jumping into this series anyway. I love musichonestly, who doesn't?so I often find myself enjoying romantic reads featuring characters who play it and DAISY AND THE FRONT MAN wound up being no exception.When Daisy Morris is stood up for homecoming by the front man of her favorite band, Seconds to Juliet, she's humiliated. But when she finds out her bodyguard dad whom she'll be spending the summer with is working for S2J she sees an opportunity to have her revenge. What ensues is a fun beachy read that's sure to satisfy your sweet tooth for romance that's fluffy and lighthearted. There's a certain every-girl quality to Daisy that I think most YA readers will love and I was thrilled that Trevin was Korean, such a nice change of pace!Since this was my first Backstage Pass series read, I was occasionally left feeling I had missed something important by not reading the first two but it wasn't bad enough that I feel you couldn't read these out of order. DATFM is a warm, guilty pleasure type read that I think will make you grin if the plot appeals to you at all. I would definitely recommend it!Notes: ARC received in exchange for this honest review.
Perfect replacement of my previous NuTone door chime button.  The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is the original button only lasted 2 years before the plastic button broke away.
These were a perfect replacement for the vanity bulbs in my 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokee.  Fit well and match the other LED bulbs I replaced throughout the interior.

I've had a few issues with these cracking and breaking when dropped, but they are still decent cases.  My daughters use them to sort out all of their rainbow rubber bands that they use to make bracelets.

When these first arrived, I loved them.  I thought they were amazing, and I couldn't get enough of them.  Now, however, I seem to be finding an oily film floating and several chunks floating on my drinks.  I only use bottled water to fill them, and that hasn't changed.  I think the freezer is breaking down the silicone.  I still use these, but I rinse the cubes really well after I take them out of the molds.  Unfortunately, that melts a lot of the cube away, making it much smaller than before.

Wow!  Bought these for a cruise to Alaska this past summer.  I'm so glad my wife thought it was a good idea to order some for the trip.  I could not be happier with them. I bought the Bushnell 8x21 and 10x25.  My daughters carried the 8x21 and they were easy for them to spot and focus with.  The 10x25 are a little more difficult to use because the higher magnification makes it harder to keep still.  But they were perfect for my wife.

What really needs to be said about Angostura bitters?  You cannot make a good Manhattan or Old Fashioned without them.  Just a few drops is all you really need to add a complex flavor profile to your drink.
Use this spoon quite frequently.  It is a quality bar spoon.  I haven't put it in the dishwasher, so I cannot speak to that.  But after at least 50 washes, there is no visible rust.

My daughter absolutely loves the breyer classic horses.  She spends so much time playing with them.  I'm really just amazed that kids can still be entertained by a plastic horse.  They don't always need video games, computers, and streaming media to make them happy.

I recently purchased several of these and several of the Greg Norman ML75.  While I like this shirt, I don't quite think the material is as nice the ML75.  I usually wear these around the house and to work in the yard, but prefer to wear the nicer ML75 to the office.  I didn't realize that when I ordered all of them, so I hope this helps someone out.
This has turned out to be a really nice addition to my bar.  It is very nice quality and fits well in both a standard pint glass as well as my stainless shaker.

This wasn't an easy part to track down.  My Jeep didn't have a factory installed trailer tow hitch, but did have a factory installed wire harness for me to add one later.  This adapter goes from the factory 7 pin USCAR female adapter to a 4 pin flat.  It doesn't mention fitting a Jeep Grand Cherokee on the packaging, but this is definitely the right adapter.  If you need an RV 7 and a 4 flat, I would suggest the Curt 55774 adapter instead.  As far as the receiver hitch, I went with the Curt 13065 which was super easy to install and hides well up under the bumper, with only the bottom of the receiver extending.Now, here's where things get a bit tricky.  Take note of this! The factory installed wire harness doesn't actually work until you re-program the vehicle's onboard computer.  You need to take the vehicle into the dealership and tell them to update the VIN with dealer option AHX.  They will then use their wiTECH scanner and enable the feature in the onboard computer.

I've had these speakers nearly 4 years now.  When I bought them, I loved them.  I've never listened to them loud, they provided low volume background music for me while at work.  Recently, however, the speaker with the audio controls has developed an annoying crackling and popping noise, louder than the music.  The speaker sometimes works and sometimes doesn't, while the remote speaker works all the time and doesn't make any unusual sound.  They were good speakers, just wish they lasted longer.  They've always been plugged into a decent APC surge protector, so I don't think power was the issue.
Don't let the dealer sell you an OEM cabin air filter for 2 or 3 times the price of one of these.  They are very easy to replace and work just as well.

I bought both the Magic Mouse as well as the Apple Trackpad with my MacBook Air.  They are both connected and setting on my desk, but I find myself always reaching for the mouse over the trackpad.  I love the touch surface; it is very functional.

I have two of these, one at home and one at work, and I haven't had issues with either of them connecting my MacBook Air to a larger 27" monitor.  This cable transmits both video and sound.  You just need to change the sound output setting on the Mac from the internal speakers to the monitor.
Surprisingly nice for the price.  I use it as a stand where the family can leave their tablets while charging.  It is a really nice size and the color matches nicely with the rest of my furniture.

I've bought dozens of these.  You need 2 for every flat panel TV you hang on the wall.  This allows you fish all those low voltage cables inside the wall down behind your media cabinets for clean installations.

But now I'm several months into it and it doesn't feel nearly as comfortable as it did new.  It often shifts and needs to be re-adjusted.  I think mine has alzheimer's because it has certainly lost its memory.
I'm glad I purchased this with my new treadmill.  It is very thick and works well on my carpet.  Now I don't need to worry about oil dripping from the treadmill after I lubricate the tread.
I spend a lot of time in hotel rooms, and this is a must have for charging a cell phone, tablet, pc, and mifi off that single outlet they give you at the desk.  I never leave home without these.

I bought this for my wife.  She loves the Sangria served at our local steakhouse which I prefer not to mention.  I'm sure you can guess the chain.  This and the Monin Mango syrup are the two key ingredients to matching the flavor of the sangria she loves so much.
I haven't had any issues with these braking on me.  They don't seem to be too brittle, as others I've bought in the past.

I actually have half a dozen or more of these covers in varying colors.  I've bought many other brand of cases, including the Apple smart cover, and I prefer the style of these cases the most.  They are of good quality material (both the genuine leather and fake vinyl like), good liner and nice stitching.

I bought these to replace the batteries in my Panasonic cordless phones.  They work well and charge automatically when I place the phone in the base station.  No need to charge them in a separate charger.
This is a must have for cooking thanksgiving turkeys or smoking meats in an outdoor smoker.  Works great, very accurate.  Would buy it again.
I've used this both in my oven and my smoker.  I compared it to my digital thermometers and it seems to be very accurate.

I purchased two of these.  They are pretty decent.  I did notice a drop in sound using the headphone jack, so I ended up just plugging my headphones directly into the PC instead of the monitor.  I would have rated this monitor 5 stars, if it had built in USB ports for thumb drives and wireless keyboard/mouse receivers.  It helps to get the wireless receivers up near the monitor, and out of the cabinet.
We used this to rub our thanksgiving turkey this year.  Rubbed it first with bacon grease then sprinkled generous amounts of this seasoning inside and out of the bird.  Turned out great.

Not sure why there are holes in the top.  When you run the pump, water comes through the holes and settles on top of the cover.  Eventually, the center of the cover sinks into the pool.  Additionally, the rope draw string gets dry and brittle after enough chlorinated water and sun get to it.  At that point, it needs to be replaced.  I've had to purchase a few of them over the years, but luckily they are pretty cheap.

Have only used this for about a week, but seems to be working well. I like the ability to adjust the grind from fine to coarse.  I also purchased the pepper mill and found it interesting that the grinding mechanism on the salt mill is nylon or plastic, while the grinder on the pepper mill is a metal alloy.  Apparently, if you put salt in a peper mill, it will corrode and ruin the metal alloy grinder, so be sure to buy an actual salt mill.

This just came in yesterday.  Seems like a good quality item.  Problem is they shipped a 45 pound item in the same box, and smashed it pretty good.  The reason I am posting this here, rather than rating the shipping itself is that it speaks to the quality of the product.  Despite being smashed by a very heavy item and even protuding from the box and being drug across the ground by the shipping company, this is still in great shape and will work just fine.  Just a little marred, but obviously of good quality.

I've had this light up for about 3 days now, and I really struggle to get the motion sensor dialed in properly.  It is mounted on the side of my house to light up a sidewalk between the houses.  I originally had it facing toward the front of the house, but every time the wind blows, the moving shrubs and trees activate the light.  I tried turning the sensitivity down, to no avail.  I have since adjusted the sensor so it is simply facing the house next to me.  This is less than ideal, because you have to be half way up the path before the light ever turns on.  I like the light, but it is going to take a lot of patience to properly adjust it.
Have only used this for about a week, but seems to be working well.  I like the ability to adjust the grind from fine to coarse.

This is  my second Intex Easy Set pool.  I purchased an 8' by 30" pool about four years ago, and used it for a couple of years.  This year we upgraded to the larger 12' by 30" pool, since the kids are getting bigger.  This is one of the cheapest forms of entertainment I can find to keep my kids occupied during the summer.  It may or may not last past this season, but it is worth it either way.  I made sure to put down a ground tarp beneath the pool before I started adding water, this prevents any small rocks and debris on the concrete from puncturing the pool, and makes smoothing out the bottom much easier.  It is also important to have a level surface for the pool.  Mine is on the patio, and concrete is graded away from the house by design.  This 2 or 3 inch drop over the 13' foot width of the patio does not cause any real issue, although it isn't ideal.  The more level you can get the better, but keep in mind concrete patios are always intentionally sloped away from the house.  Check out my 3 photos as well.
it seems with batteries you can buy in bulk and really save.  These are no exception.  The batteries work well, and were a great value.
I've bought a number of these to upgrade the many notebooks in my household.  I haven't had any failures and it seems to be good quality memory.  Worth upgrading.
I bought these to laminate my gun registration cards.  They work really well, and certainly make the paper cards more durable.

I really like these, they are just difficult to get my hands on.  I frequently check Amazon, but they are always out of stock.  The product itself is great, just wish it was easier to get my hands on.
I'm not going to get technical. It simply wasn't my favorite bond movie.  I do enjoy the 007 movies with Daniel Craig, it just wasn't my favorite story.
I bought this for my kids to watch.  I enjoyed it myself as a kid, and it just seems to be one of those timeless movies that generations enjoy.

Some may still remember this weird kidnapping case that really happened in 1978, Switzerland. About two months after his death. Charlie Chaplin's body was dug up by two men and held for ransom. Directed by Xavier Beauvois (Of Gods and Men), La ranon de la gloire (The Price of Fame) is loosely based on this strange case.Dont expect thrills or suspense, however. The French/Swiss/Belgian film is not so much an in-depth look at this crime itself as a drama about these two desperate men told with homage to the great artist still loved by many people.The story is about the two kidnappers: Osman Bricha (Roschdy Zem), struggling father who needs money for his daughter Samira (Sli Gmach) and hospitalized wife Noor (Nadine Labaki); and Eddy Ricaart (Benot Poelvoorde, Man Bites Dog), recently released from jail. To Osman, who is denied a bank loan, Eddy proposes a perfect plan to get money quickly. That is, stealing the body of Charlie Chaplin.La ranon de la gloire is obviously sanctioned by the Chaplin family (Charlie Chaplins real-life son Eugne Chaplin and granddaughter Dolores Chaplin appear), so one good thing about the film is, naturally, that the film looks very authentic, with some scenes filmed in Manoir de Ban in Switzerland, the place where Chaplin really lived. Also, Michel Legrands beautiful score is another plus. Some of the homage is amusing. Supporting players include Chiara Mastroianni and Peter Coyote, but I am not sure the roles they play are really necessary.Obviously the film needs improvement. La ranon de la gloire attempts to be so many things at the same time  buddy-buddy film, drama about family, comedy (inspired by Chaplin), etc.  that some parts of the film look awkward, or are just unnecessary. The film feels very slow when it should be quick. Some events including the prolonged circus episode (another reference to Chaplin) look out of place, especially when we want to know more about the case itself and those who are involved with it.La ranon de la gloire is a missed opportunity for a great comedy drama. Some parts of it are interesting, but the whole is unsatisfying.

David Oelhoffens Far From Men (Loin des hommes) is based on a short story The Guest by Albert Camus. Set in the early days of the Algerian Revolution, the French drama follows the story of Daru (Viggo Mortensen speaking in French), a reclusive teacher living in the mountains of Algeria, and Mohamed (Reda Kateb), Arab prisoner Daru is made to escort to the town.Told against the background of political turmoil in Algeria, the story of two men seems rather simple, but poses many intriguing questions. Through several life-threatening incidents both characters come to understand each other, and in so doing, they are given a chance to make a choice, choice that would change their future.Interestingly some parts of the film adaptation are considerably different from the original Camus story it is based on. Some of you might not like the changes done to the original storyline. I for one do not know which is better. You should decide it for yourself.Being slow-moving at time, the film requires some patience, but with the beautifully shot landscape of the barren mountains and the convincing portrayals of the two main characters by Viggo Mortensen (who also co-produced) and Reda Kateb, Far From Men is a moving and thought-provoking drama.

Set in Belfast in 1971, the British film follows the story of Gary Hook (Jack O'Connell, Started Up Unbroken), a new recruit of the British Army. When his squad is sent to support the Royal Ulster Constabulary, however, a riot breaks out and Hook is accidentally left behind by the unit in the confusion.This means the young soldier has to survive the night alone, disoriented in the streets of Belfast, while not knowing whom to trust. 71 is a tense action thriller with a focus on realism as well as the political aspects of the Troubles.The film begins with a fast pace, with some frenzy, semi-documentary action sequence in the first half that may remind us of the style of Paul Greengrass, but it is in the films slower-paced second half that the first-time feature director Yann Demange shows what he is really capable of, with a suspenseful building up to the conclusion.And the film could not be a success without the talented players including Richard Dormer, Sean Harris, Killian Scott, David Wilmot and of course the star Jack O'Connell. Tat Radcliffes effective photography capturing the streets of Belfast is another plus.

As you know, Ant-Man will be the final entry of Phase Two of the ever-expanding Marvel Cinematic Universe that started with Iron Man in 2008, but dont worry. You dont have to see any of the previous Marvel Comics movies to enjoy Ant-Man, an enjoyable action movie featuring an insect-sized hero with superhuman powers.Paul Rudd is Scott Lang, a whistleblower and thief recently released from jail. He breaks into the house of Dr. Pym (Michael Douglas), former S.H.I.E.L.D. agent and original Ant-Man. What Scott finds there is something interesting; the Ant-suit, a suit created by Hank Pym that can turn the wearer into Ant-Man.So the film is about the second-generation Ant-Man, I mean, Scott, who trains to be a superhero in order to regain his daughters love (and save the world, too). Story-wise Ant-Man is pretty formulaic, but director Peyton Reed (Bring it on) keeps a good pace throughout, emphasizing the comical side of the situation in which our hero is in. The climactic one-on-one combat against the supervillain can be thrilling and funny at the same time.As I said, Ant-Man can be enjoyed as a stand-alone action film, but some knowledge about the Marvel Comics would help, especially when a certain character appears, fighting Ant-Man in a unique and amusing combat sequence. And of course, dont miss the post-credits scene that suggests the beginning of Phase Three.

Eight years after their 9-year-old daughter Cassandra went missing, her parents Matthew (Ryan Reynolds) and Tina (Mireille Enos) are to know, in a different way, that their daughter may be still alive. Told in a chronologically shuffled order (like some of Christopher Nolan films), Atom Egoyans thriller attempts to captivate the heart of viewers, but except the star Reynolds effective acting and beautifully shot landscapes, the film fails in doing so.I think I see the directors intention of focusing the impact that the sudden and unaccountable absence of someone would give to us  and I have seen some of the directors films including The Sweet Hereafter  but even so, The Captive is not very convincing either as a thriller or a drama, with flat characters lacking reasonable motives.You see, in The Captive, a police officer (played by Scott Speedman), who should be polite and calm in dealing with this kind of delicate case, is incredibly rude and stupid. Kevin Durands one-note character walks and talks like a villain from a Victorian novel, with monster written all over him. In short, people just don't act that way.Egoyans previous effort Devil's Knot was criticized for not telling us anything new about the case it depicts. Maybe so, but it is still ten times better than watching the badly written potboiler that makes little sense

If you have seen Rob Reiners Stand by Me (1986) and two Steven Spielberg sci-fi fantasy films in his early days, you have virtually seen Earth to Echo. Director Dave Greens feature debut is so obviously inspired by those classic movies he must have seen as a child, that it is nearly impossible not to notice the similarities.I am not saying the film is all bad. The film is entertaining and it certainly tries to be original, but I think in a very wrong way.In Earth to Echo three boys Alex, Tuck and Munch embark on a bicycle trip to uncover the mysterious incident of messages sent to the cell phones. As their neighborhood is going to be torn down to build a highway, they know this will be the last chance for them to be together. On their journey the boys stumble on something unexpected, something that some suspicious-looking men seem interested.Now, most moviegoers know where the story comes from, but the problem of Earth to Echo is not that. The real problem of film is that it employs the overused technique of the Blair Witch-like shaky, hand-held camera. I know the film is made for the YouTube generation, but honestly, do we really need that here?The acting of the kids is pretty good, and the special effects are decent, but, despite some nice ideas (see the unique car crash scene, for example  dont worry, no one dies in this movie), Earth to Echo needs more originality.

The good news about Insurgent, the second installment of the Divergent, series is that Shailene Woodley returns as the young heroine Tris. Woodley manages to be attractive in the clich-ridden dystopian story.With the Flightplan director Robert Schwentke (replacing Neil Burger, who directed Divergent), the new film is more fast-paced and adult-oriented, focusing more visuals (released in 3D) and action. Some of the special effects, especially those during the test scenes, are worth watching.Story-wise, however, Insurgent does not offer anything new or original. There is another problem that is even bigger; that is, with too many subplots and characters, the story gets muddled as it goes on. As a consequence, certain things look just illogical  How did they enter the building? etc.  and most of the seasoned actors involved are either miscast (Naomi Watts) or wasted (Octavia Spencer).It is reported that Insurgent will be followed by two more sequels. I hope they come up with a better story next time.

Frank Martin is back in The Transporter Refueled, but not Jason Statham. In the fourth feature film of the hit franchise Ed Skrein plays the role of the ex-special agent who is hired to transport anything to anywhere. Perhaps the new entry may not be as bad as you may be led to believe, but still a disappointment.The story (set in South France) is nothing particularly new. Frank gets mixed up with violent gangsters led by Karasov (Radivoje Bukvic), when he accepts a job from a mysterious young woman to carry a package, which turns out to be something Frank did not expect.What is unique about the film is that the screenplay focuses the relationship between Frank and his father, a retired secret agent played by Ray Stevenson. In fact, the comical interaction between the father and son, which reminds us of Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade, is more interesting than the convoluted main plot.You get a handful of decent action sequences (which could have been better without the quick cuts), but my impression is simply this: So whats the point of making another Transporter film without Jason Statham?

Belle and Sebastian (Belle et Sbastien) may not be the greatest French film ever made, but Nicolas Vaniers family picture has a few fine things that only this adventurist-turned-director can offer: stunningly beautiful nature of the Alps, realistic descriptions of the people living there, and a likable protagonist Sbastien, a six-year-old boy, who befriends a dog Belle.Set in 1943, the film is basically about Sbastien (Flix Bossuet), an orphan boy living with his adoptive grandfather Csar (Tchky Karyo) and Csars daughter Anglina (Margaux Chtelier) living in the Alps. One day Sbastien meets Belle, a wild dog mistakenly believed to be the Beast by the villagers. Their friendship begins. This is the most appealing part of the movie.For the new version the filmmakers decided to add another material to the story. A German army arrives at the quiet village to capture the refugees trying to cross the mountains. Nicolas Vanier wisely avoids any violent content in furthering the added story, which is a good thing. But I am not sure that the original storyline needed this episode, which is neither suspenseful nor dramatic enough.The original novel Belle and Sebastian, written by Ccile Aubry, was turned into a French TV series of the same title (19651970), which starred Aubrys son Mehdi as Sebastian. For the new film Mehdi appears briefly in a cameo role as hunter named Andr. The location is changed to the French Alps, and so is the purpose of the boys journey with the dog.Belle and Sebastian is an above average family picture with beautiful photography and capable acting from the cast, but the adult audiences might feel there is still something missing here.

The Diabolical starts off as a typical haunted house movie with a single mother Madison (Ali Larter) and her two children Jacob (Max Rose) and Haley (Chloe Perrin) terrorized by some weird phenomena in their suburban house. Even the paranormal experts Madison hires get terribly scared, so she starts to investigate the place with her boyfriend and science teacher Nick (Arjun Gupta).(The following paragraph includes some mild spoilers.)About halfway through the story the film suddenly transforms into a sort of sci-fi thriller, trying to explain how and why these entities have to appear specifically in Madisons house.The basic idea has potential for unique, genre-bending thriller, but sadly The Diabolical is simply not that. Some may turn a blind eye to the films obvious logical inconsistencies, but even so, The Diabolical has another and bigger problem. That is, the film is dull and boring.Director Alistair Legrand (nephew of Oscar-winning composer Michel Legrand) knows what he is doing and the cast including Ali Larter are doing their best, but The Diabolical is plodding, lacking the finesse of a skilled storyteller. Scares and tension are severely diluted with exposition delivered clumsily. Strictly for the fans of the star Ali Larter.

Kung Fu Killer (also known as Kung Fu Jungle) marks the star Donnie Yens comeback to the traditional martial arts action film. Directed by Teddy Chen (Bodyguards and Assassins), the film is also homage to the long history of the Hong Kong action movies.Donnie Yen plays Hahou Mo, a former police officer and martial arts now in jail for accidentally killing his opponent in a fight three years ago. When martial arts masters are found dead in the city, Hahou Mo knows that someone killed them in a combat and only he can prevent the murderer from killing another fighter.The story is contrived, but the fast-paced film gives us enough thrills with bone-crunching action scenes that feature Donnie Yen and Baoqiang Wang who almost steals the film. It is also amusing to find many cameos including Raymond Chow, founder of Golden Harvest.King Fu Killer may not be as intense as Donnie Yens hit Ip Man and its sequel, but is still very entertaining.

Good Kill is a war drama without war. The film is about Major Thomas Egan (Ethan Hawke), a drone pilot and family man struggling with his consciousness while remote-controlling from Las Vegas a military drone flying over Afghanistan. The topic is timely and the setting is intriguing. Ethan Hawke is convincing as dutiful and tormented drone pilot.After the halfway mark, however, the film focuses the psychological changes that take place in the protagonist. That is not bad, but the way those changes happen needs improvement. Without revealing much about what happens, I can say that the latter half of the film is too melodramatic to be taken seriously, with the cop-out conclusion that leaves us with the impression that the film does not know where to go.Good Kill stars Ethan Hawke and is written and directed by Andrew Niccol. You may remember they made an excellent drama Gattaca back in 1997. The New Zealand-born director is also responsible for the script of The Truman Show in 1998. Both films have immediacy, interesting characters and thought-provoking story. Good Kill starts out promising all three, but ends up delivering only the first one.

Two years after a terrible incident in the Kolkata subway, a pregnant woman named Vidya Bagchi (Vidya Balan) arrives from London and visits the police station looking for her missing husband. A young police officer Rana (Parambrata Chatterjee) is helpful, but there is no trace of her Bengali husband who she claims must be working in this city. A seemingly routine case of a missing person becomes complicated and even deadly as they continue to investigate.Deftly directed by Sujoy Ghosh, Kahaani is a slick Indian thriller centering on this heroine determined to find out what happened to her husband. The fast-paced film offers enough thrills and entertainment to satisfy the most jaded fans of the genre, with Vidya Balans strong performance as he unique protagonist and the vivid depictions of the busy city streets of Kolkata, where filming took place.It is obvious that the films heroine and story has something to do with the Hindi mythology which I do not know. Even so, I enjoyed myself watching the two-hour non-stop thrill ride.

Even Marvel makes mistakes, and the new Fantastic Four proves it. It is only 100 minutes long and it feels like eternity. I think the actors and crew are doing their best, but the film Even Marvel makes mistakes, and the new Fantastic Four proves it. It is only 100 minutes long and it feels like eternity. I think the actors and crew are doing their best, but the film lacks everything that made Marvels superhero movies attractive, things such as thrills, humor and most of all interesting characters.This is the origin story of Fantastic Four, just as in the 2005 version of Fantastic Four. The difference is that the team gains their new (and unwanted) powers when an unauthorized teleportation to another universe goes terribly wrong.The problem is that director Josh Trank (Chronicle) takes too much time in the first half of the story, trying to explain the backgrounds of each member  Reed Richards/Mr. Fantastic (Miles Teller), Johnny Storm/The Human Torch (Michael B. Jordan), Susan Storm/The Invisible Woman (Kate Mara) and Ben Grimm/The Thing (Jamie Bell).Some say the reboot Fantastic Four movie has a darker tone compared with other Marvels works including two previous Fantastic Four movies. I know what the film is trying to do, but to be honest I found the first half of the film dull with too much talking. Things do not get better in the second half that unfolds too fast. When we are finally introduced to Fantastic Four as a team, the film is almost over.Probably the films biggest flaw is that it has no rhythm in telling the story, with action sequences that feel rushed. In addition to that, there is just no dynamic in the relationship between characters. With OK visuals and production designs, Fantastic Four needs a better story to tell., things such as thrills, humor and most of all interesting characters.This is the origin story of Fantastic Four, just as in the 2005 version of Fantastic Four. The difference is that the team gains their new (and unwanted) powers when an unauthorized teleportation to another universe goes terribly wrong.The problem is that director Josh Trank (Chronicle) takes too much time in the first half of the story, trying to explain the backgrounds of each member  Reed Richards/Mr. Fantastic (Miles Teller), Johnny Storm/The Human Torch (Michael B. Jordan), Susan Storm/The Invisible Woman (Kate Mara) and Ben Grimm/The Thing (Jamie Bell).Some say the reboot Fantastic Four movie has a darker tone compared with other Marvels works including two previous Fantastic Four movies. I know what the film is trying to do, but to be honest I found the first half of the film dull with too much talking. Things do not get better in the second half that unfolds too fast. When we are finally introduced to Fantastic Four as a team, the film is almost over.Probably the films biggest flaw is that it has no rhythm in telling the story, with action sequences that feel rushed. In addition to that, there is just no dynamic in the relationship between characters. With OK visuals and production designs, Fantastic Four needs a better story to tell.

Jerry (Ryan Reynolds) is an ordinary guy working at a bathtub factory in the (fictional) sleepy town of Milton. He is pretty shy and not good at talking to others, especially women, living in a small apartment with a cat Mr. Whiskers and a dog Bosco, whose voices he hears. You may think Jerry is a little bit like Norman Bates, even though Jerry wants to be a nice person.Now, Jerry has a crush on the gorgeous Fiona (Gemma Arterton) at his workplace. When he has a chance to be alone with her, an accident happens, which leads to a much bigger and bloodier disaster, in spite of his best efforts to prevent it.Despite Ryan Reynolds effective performance as socially awkward Jerry, The Voices offers little that is interesting either as a comedy or a thriller (or anything else). You may say this is one of the darkest comedies you have seen and indeed you cannot just ignore the films twisted sense of humor seen in the talking head scene. Yes, it is weird and that is all.The Voices is directed by Marjane Satrapi, who is best known for her Oscar nominated animation Persepolis (co-directed by Vincent Paronnaud). This is a strange career move, which I think is damaging, if not fatal.If you are looking for something completely different, you may try The Voices. But you know being different does not always make a film interesting.

There are many ways to describe the unique world of Turbo Kid. It is a Mad Max-like post-apocalyptic world where civilization has collapsed; where tyrannical warlord Zeus (scene-stealing Michael Ironside) rules with an army of warriors riding BMXs (yes, bicycles, not motorcycles). And in this wasteland the Kid (Munro Chambers), a comic book reading, bicycle-riding boy, meets a mysterious girl named Apple (Laurence Leboeuf).Turbo Kid is not just an ode to the 1980s and 90s; it works well as a piece of entertainment on its own, with ridiculously gory action scenes and delightfully eccentric characters. This is a well-worn story of heroism and boy meets girl, and the writer-director team (of Franois Simard, Anouk Whissell and Yoann-Karl Whissell) takes it very seriously.The result is a low-budget movie with a high entertainment value, a fun movie for moviegoers, especially for those who like the pop culture of the 1980s and 90s, or things such as retro games and Giorgio Moroder synth music. And the heroine Apple is really charming.

Jonathan Glazers Under the Skin is a kind of film that challenges the viewer to see things differently. Thats a good thing, and the premise is intriguing. Its about the human world (in this case Scotland) seen from a predatory life form disguised as a young woman played by Scarlett Johansson.The films sparse narrative and measured pace is far from that of Hollywood sci-fi movies like Species. No scientists show up to explain the mysterious womans motive for capturing men. Johanssons character, whoever it is, seems to undergo a certain psychological change at a certain point, but we are not really sure when and how this happens. And these are not bad things.Even so, and despite some brilliant images and eerie soundtrack that may draw comparison with more famous film directors like Kubrick, Under the Skin is drawn out to the point of being pretentious and self-indulgent. Even those who think the film is unique and inventive would agree that it takes too much time trying to make its point.Under the Skin strives to be unconventional at the risk of alienating viewers. I respect the decision, but also think that, slow-moving as it is, 2001: A Space Odyssey offers enough mystery and suspense, and most importantly, is not boring.
