Bought two, one for me, one for the wife. Now we're playing Diablo 3 to death. Seems to be as good as my more expensive Asus 27" that I have attached to my main gaming rig. Excellent price as well.
Excellent product. I write at a stand-up desk for up to 8 hours at a time. This mat has made a huge difference in the amount of fatigue my legs/knees can withstand.

So far, this stick is excellent. I returned an X-55 Rhino as the throttle was terrible (sticky/jerky), and the stick was just too dang big (and I've got fairly large hands). The X-55's spring tension made my hands ache after about half an hour of Elite: Dangerous. This stick is very smooth and has plenty of motion.I am NOT a hardcore flight sim or space sim junkie, so keep that in mind if you read this review. However, I did spend almost a month with the X-55 and played the heck out of E:D (right at "Wings" update). I just like this stick far better than the X-55 and the X-52 that I tried out at Best Buy. In fact, liked this so much bought one for my wife, and my friend picked one up as well.
Excellent containers. Highly recommended for anyone who likes to cook.

Good quality materials. As typical of slippers like these, the sole is thin, and the padding is very squishy. However, did not buy them for all-day comfort wear (have Minnetonka slippers for that!). Bought them because... HAWKS!
Love it, except the zipper (the part you grab onto to pull up/down) is cheap and has already broken. Otherwise, got it for a great deal and it fits perfectly!

For my Nexus 6P, I bought this "Cruzerlite Cell Phone Case for HUAWEI Nexus 6P - Retail Packaging - Red" to match my old Nexus 5's Nexus 5 Case, Cruzerlite Bugdroid Circuit TPU Case Compatible for Nexus 5 - Red.  They look to be nearly identical.  The case fits the phone just fine, all the openings line up correctly with their corresponding parts of the phone, the slight thickness of the case gives just enough extra material to make picking up the Nexus 6P a bit easier, and the material around the power/volume buttons makes it a lot easier to avoid accidentally hitting those buttons (which is my biggest gripe with the phone).  The one slight negative is the same as many others here have mentioned:  because the openings for the power/volume buttons are recessed into a thinner rectangle of edge material, that area of the case's edge doesn't grab the phone as firmly as the rest of the package.  I doubt there'll be a problem in normal use.  But, it's definitely noticeable with my first time exploration of the case.  Still, for about $10, I'm happy with the case and rating it at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.

It's still early days yet with this "Premium Teak Corner Shower Bench With Shelf, Shower, Spa Seat."  But, it sure is nice.  It's very sturdy, very well built, and beautifully finished.  It fits in the corner of our shower without issue and, surprisingly, the slant of the shower floor at that point isn't enough to cause any wobble with the front foot  The finish is so nice that it's hard to believe that it's just the natural, sanded teak.We were going to coat the bench with linseed oil to protect it from the water and soap.  But, after checking on some woodworking sites, it looks like the teak would only weather to a grey finish if exposed to sunlight.  So, in the shower, it ought to maintain its looks without the linseed oil.  We'll wait and see.My only issues are theoretical.  First, it was shipped in a perfectly fitting single box.  It really should have been double-boxed since any damage to that shipping box could very well have carried through and damaged the wood.  Ours was in perfect condition, so, again, it's just a theoretical issue.  The other possible concern might be with the feet.  They're hard rubber feet screwed into the wooden legs and are non-adjustable.  Adjustable ones would have been nice for shower floors more slanted than ours.  But, overall, I can't complain.  So, I'm rating this at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

"In the Best Families" is the 17th book (first published in 1950) in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  In a slight departure from previous books in the series, there's no "reflection" of the then-current issues of the day showing in the book (i.e., no "Commies" for 1950).  The story focuses on the case and on Nero Wolfe's little tiff with his nemesis.  The writing is amongst Stout's best and the story very satisfying.  I rate it at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

Unfortunately, I agree with many of the other low rating reviews of Terry Pratchett's "The Shepherd's Crown:"  this book is not Pratchett.  Everything's flat.  There's no music to what's happening.  As you read through it, there's nothing in your head but the words.  There's no fizz.  The characters are just words being written instead of the beings we know and love living their lives.  So, with regret, I've got to rate the book at a Not Very Good 2 stars out of 5 and say "don't bother."

"Three Doors to Death" is the 16th book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  Note that it's not a novel.  It's three short stories ("Man Alive," "Omit Flowers," and "Door to Death") of about 70 pages each.  The book, itself, was first published in 1950, while the short stories were first published in 1947, 1948, and 1949, respectively.  Since this is the 16th book in the series, I'll assume you know the drill:  the writing is good old Stout/Wolfe writing.  No real surprises here.  There are a couple of weak points though.  In "Omit Flowers," for some reason, it seems as if the police never even bothered to talk to the victim's ex.  That doesn't seem likely.  And, in "Door to Death," the police arrest, handcuff, and cart away their choice of evil-doer.  Yet, they can't even show a likely motive.  Again, that seems a bit odd.  Anyway, those are fairly minor points and I'm still rating the book at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.

This "USB C Charger, iOrange-E6.6 Ft (2M) Braided Cable with Reversible Connector..." is undoubtedly the nicest cable I've ever owned.  It looks beautiful with it's braided cable and nice connectors, and comes in a fancy box (with a fancy bag and fancy tie).  It works nicely for connecting my Nexus 6P phone to my computer's standard USB 2.0 ports.  The connection to the phone is a bit tight, but that seems to be the recurring motif with these USB-C connectors and phones.  Best of all, Benson Leung (an engineer on the Pixel team at Google) has tested it and pronounced it to be one of the few properly designed USB-C/A cables out there:http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A25GROL6KJV3QG/ref=cm_cr_dp_pdpSo, even though the price is a bit high, I'm rating it at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

"The Second Confession" is the 15th book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  It was first published in 1949, and since these books mirror the prevailing issues of the day, it's interesting to note how fast the enemies changed in society.  In the previous couple of book, the common enemies were Japan/Germany (WWII).  In this book, it's the "Commies" (Cold War).  Anyway, that's just an interesting aside.  The writing, story, characters, humor, etc., are all excellent.  The only quibble I've got is that antagonistic actions of several pairs of characters don't really get explained.  The assumption is that the bad guy had something on them.  But, it's just left hanging.  For that, I'd drop the rating half a star.  But, of course, integers are the rule.  So, I'm rating the book at an Excellent 5 stars out  of 5.

"Trouble in Triplicate" is the 14th book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  It's NOT a novel.  Instead, it's a set of three short stories ("Before I Die," "Help Wanted, Male," and "Instead of Evidence" -- each only about 70 pages long).  The book, itself, was first published in 1949.  But, the short stories, for some reason, are out of order amongst themselves and within the series (they were initially published in 1947, 1945, and 1946 (respectively), whereas the previous book was first published in 1948).  Unfortunately, even though Stout's technical writing is as good as it always is, the quality of the three stories varies drastically.  The first story, "Before I Die," is the best of the lot and is worth 4 stars.  The story is good and the dilemma Wolfe and Archie face when stuck with a client they definitely don't want is interesting.  The second story, "Help Wanted, Male," is the worst of the lot and is only worth about 2 stars (inconceivable for a Rex Stout "Nero Wolfe" story).  Very simply, the degree of luck, happenstance, and planning on the part of the bad guy are just beyond belief.  It's just ridiculous.  The final story, "Instead of Evidence" is OK (call it 3 stars).  The issue with that story is simply that the perpetrator is obvious (again, not something we usually see with these books).  So, averaging them out, I'd rate the book at an OK 3 stars out of 5.  Disappointing.

My only issue with Rex Stout's "And Be a Villain" (the 13th book in his Nero Wolfe series (first published in 1948)) is that the ending is a tad weak.  In a lot of these books, Nero Wolfe pulls the answer out of his posterior-dorsal.  When he does that, usually we see how he got there and agree with it.  In this book, his "answer" is really weak.  But, other than that, the book is excellent with Stout's excellent writing, a twisty plot, and crazy characters.  Also, in my review of the previous book, I complained about how Stout was portraying Cramer.  In this book, Cramer is much better.  So, I'm rating the book at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.

Ho-hum.  Yet another excellent Nero Wolfe book by Rex Stout ("Too Many Women," the 12th in the series, first published in 1947).  This one's particularly lively since Archie is basically rolling in clover throughout it.  The usual excellence in writing.  The one thing that bothers me a bit is Stout's continuing caricaturization of Inspector Cramer.  In the earlier works, Cramer was very competent and occasionally got a bit miffed with Wolfe.  In this one, Cramer's still competent, but he's in permanent volcano mode every time he meets our protagonists.  That's particularly irritating since Wolfe saved his bacon in the previous book.  Still, it's a minor thing and I'm keeping my rating of an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

"Shadows of Self" is the 5th book in Brandon Sanderson's "Mistborn" series (the 2nd of the "Wax and Wayne" sub-series).  The writing follows right in the footsteps of the previous book (with maybe a bit more tie-in to the original trilogy).  So, if you enjoyed that, you'll enjoy this.  I'm rating it at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.The novels currently in Sanderson's "Mistborn" series are:1, 2, and 3.  Mistborn Trilogy4.  The Alloy of Law: A Mistborn Novel5.  Shadows of Self (Mistborn)

"The Silent Speaker" is the 11th book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  It was first published in 1946 and is the first of the post World War II books.  On the assumption you've read the first 10 books in the series, you know exactly what to expect here:  great writing, wonderful language, tongue-in-cheek humor, and a good story.  Because I find one of the murders in this book to be particularly nasty, I'd actually like to reduce my rating by a half star.  But, since I can't, I'll leave my rating at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

"Not Quite Dead Enough" is the 10th book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  It's actually two novellas:  "Not Quite Dead Enough" and "Booby Trap."  Both of these stories were first published at the height of World War 2 (1944), and that leads to a problem.  The first novella ("Not Quite Dead Enough") is fine.  Since it's so short, it's a bit abrupt.  But, it's a decent Nero Wolfe mystery.  The second novella, though ("Booby Trap") just suffers from too much wartime propaganda.  I can certainly understand why it does that (the "Nero Wolfe" series works within the society present at the time of their writing, and the war was certainly at the top of everything at the time), but it just doesn't feel right for Nero Wolfe.  The writing is still good, so the book is something any "Nero Wolfe" fan will want to read.  It just might not be something they'd go out of their way to read twice.  I'm rating it at an OK 3 stars out of 5 (definitely the weakest book of the series to-date).

"The Rubber Band" is the 3rd book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series (first published in 1936).  It's got Stout's usual great writing, and is an interesting mystery with a few nice twists.  About the only thing I'd like to have seen more of is Archie.  In this book, Stout's got him doing almost nothing.  He's out and about at the beginning and in one or two other places.  But, mostly, he's in his confidential assistant role.  If he were doing more leg work, we'd be better able to form our own opinions on whodunit.  I'm rating the book at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.

The most important thing to know about Peter Clines' "The Fold" is that it's not really science fiction.  It's really a horror story camouflaged as science fiction.  The problem is that I didn't really figure it out until about half way through the book.  Up to that point, it reads like science fiction with some really stupid people in it (stupid because they don't figure out what's really happening until after that half-way point, even though it's blatantly obvious immediately after they describe what they think is happening at the beginning).  Other than that, the book reads fine until that point.  Then it starts collapsing.  First, the "science" isn't internally consistent (most obviously is the first really bad thing that happens wouldn't appear out of nowhere -- they would see it coming).  Second, as the science fiction aspect fades away and is replaced by horror, the characters start doing things half-posterior-dorsaled.  And finally, as the story reaches its climax near the end, Clines' writing gets more and more descriptive.  So, what should be a series of actions scenes get drawn out in a frustrating manner.  A lot of my complaints here are really my fault, though.  I should have recognized Clines name from The Eerie Adventures of the Lycanthrope Robinson Crusoe and realized what the book was before I started.  So, I'm rating it at a Neutral 3 stars out of 5.

"Black Orchids" is the 9th book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  It's really two novellas ("Black Orchids" (1941) and "Cordially Invited to Meet Death (1942)) packaged together and loosely linked by some black orchids.  Both of these novellas are excellent.  I don't usually like short stories or novellas.  I find them too truncated and abrupt.  But, these two put that preference to shame.  They've got the usual Stout excellence and instead of feeling rushed or choppy, they feel like a tightly wound spring.  So, once again, I'm rating a Nero Wolfe book at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

"Too Many Cooks" is the 5th book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  Once again, Stout shows his excellence as a purveyor of plots and in his use of the language.  The writing and story are really well done.  The one thing that brings it down a bit is the prevalence of race issues throughout it.  Now, I'm not one of those people who wail and moan when they read 80 year old books and find that people then didn't share in today's politically correct attitudes.  So, I'm not complaining of the existence of some of the racial stuff in the book (actually, I found Stout's attitude (assuming Nero Wolfe is his avatar in these books) to be amazingly modern).  It's just that there's quite a bit of it, and it is a tad off-putting.  Regardless, the book is still well worth the read and I'm rating it at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.

Rex Stout's "Over My Dead Body" is the 7th book in his "Nero Wolfe" series.  It's a bit different from previous books in that there's quite a bit of a political intrigue flavor to it.  Of course, that might be expected since the book was published in 1940.  That's not really a problem.  My reason for dropping my rating for the book a star to a merely Very Good 4 stars out of 5 is because there seems to be several discrepancies in behavior (especially near the end).  Still, it's a fine Nero Wolfe mystery with the usual Rex Stout writing characteristics.

"Some Buried Caesar" is the 6th book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series, and it's the best of the series so far (of course, this is only book 6 of 40-some-odd).  From the very first paragraph, I was laughing.  From the very first paragraph, I was enthralled.  An absolutely wonderful book, so I'm rating it at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

"The Red Box" is the fourth book in Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" series.  It was first published in 1937, so it describes a world very different from today.  But, what can I say?  The book follows Stout's standard of excellent plot, tongue-in-cheek humor, wonderful use of the language, and an interesting, head-scratcher of a  mystery.  I rate it at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

We bought two of these "Kindle Voyage, 6" High-Resolution Display (300 ppi) with Adaptive Built-in Light, PagePress Sensors, Wi-Fi" devices at another retailer (whose initials are BB) simply to ease the return process in case we got units with bad screens (it looks like somewhere between 5 and 10 percent of these reviewers are having that issue).  I'm happy to report that both of our Voyages have fine displays.  We're upgrading from our old Kindle Paperwhites, though, so even though there are a lot of improvements, they're not earth-shattering.  Basically, the display is a bit better, but not a lot.  The interface is a bit faster, but not a lot.  The hardware's a bit smaller and lighter, but not a lot.  The PagePress buttons are nice, but not a lot (even though I've got the level of effort turned all the way down on that, I still find it harder to turn pages that way than just tapping on the screen).  I'd say there are only two things which are significantly different between the Voyage and the Paperwhite (and they're both minor).  On the plus side, the change in location of the power button from the bottom of the device to the back-right of the device is really nice:  it's a lot more convenient and easy to use than before.  On the negative side, the length of the provided USB charging/data cable and the lack of an AC Adapter (actually, that last might be a change from several versions back) is disappointing.  My old cable is about 6 feet long.  The new one is about 5 feet long.  That loss of a foot means the new cable is too short for where I use it.  For the price of the Voyage, Amazon should have included a rapid charging system with a longer cable.So, overall, even though we're pleased with these Voyages (I'm rating them at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5), I'm not sure everyone would consider the improvements to be worth the extra price.  If you're coming from several generations of Kindle back (or don't have one at all), go ahead and get this.  But, if you're just one generation of Kindle back, it's more of a personal preference.

"Fer-de-Lance" is the 1st of Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe Mysteries."  The book was published in 1934 and the style of the writing is very much in line with other mysteries that I've read from the period.  With the caveat that the world and writing were very different then from what they are now, the book is very well done with excellent technical writing, really interesting characters, and a good plot.  An interesting twist is added to the progress of the mystery due to Nero Wolfe's "genius."  So, you think you know how things are going to play out, but get surprised by Wolfe balancing the artistry of the situation.  Not only is this a Very Good book (I'm rating it at 4 stars out of 5), but it's also a very good start to the series.

I'm a bit disappointed with Anthony Ryan's "Queen of Fire."  I was very pleased with both the first and second books in the trilogy.  But, even though this book has a similar structure to the second book and ties up the trilogy nicely, it, at best, is only so-so.  As far as I can determine, the problem is that the book has too many main characters and their activities all center on battle. Now, the first book revolved around Vaelin.  That was good.  The second book rotated through four main characters:  Vaelin, Frentis, Reva, and Lyrna (each with his or her own entourage).  That's a bit much.  But, for the most part each main character was doing very different things, so their storylines were both interesting and separable.  This book also rotates through those four main characters.  But, except for Vaelin (mostly and oddly), almost everything involves the battles needed to finish the war.  Essentially, the book goes from battle to battle to battle with oodles of horrific stuff thrown in for leavening.  By the time the end rolls around, we're just numb with it.  Also associated with the rotation through four main characters is the trouble with keeping all their associates straight.  According to the Dramatis Personae, there are 83 notable characters in the book.  Again, by the time the end drew near, I had basically given up trying to keep everyone straight.That overabundance of characters and battle might be the crux of my problems with this book. But, there are other, smaller issues that are bothersome as well.  First, except for one case, every tribe of "savages" that anyone meets is a tribe of "noble savages."  Once, OK.  Twice, maybe.  But, after that, no.  Secondly, and somewhat related to the "noble savage" issue is the "John Carter of Mars" syndrome:  almost every person in the book seems to be some kind of latent warrior hero.  Find some orphan, rescue a damsel, free a slave, or whatever.  Give them a sword and a bit of training, and they're killing supermen who've been bred and raised their whole lives fighting.  Again, once is OK.  Twice, maybe.  But, after that, no.  And, finally, there's the logistics of the war.  The biggest issue I have in that area is the production of the fleet the Realm needs.  I don't care how wonderful their spontaneously generated, out of the blue, da Vinci is, they're not going to build that amount of capital ships inside of six months when all their processed materials are gone, their timber burned, and their manpower wiped out.  It just can't be done.So, overall, I'm not impressed with this final book in the trilogy and am rating it at a merely OK 3 stars out of 5.  The more worrisome thing, though, is that I have the feeling at the back of my mind that I'm rating the book higher than it really should be simply because I liked the first two books in the series and really want to like this one.  But, I suppose that if you've already read those first two book, you'll want to read this one regardless.The books in Anthony Ryan's "Raven's Shadow" series are:1.  Blood Song (A Raven's Shadow Novel Book 1)2.  Tower Lord (A Raven's Shadow Novel Book 2)3.  Queen of Fire (Raven's Shadow Novel, A)

Twice in Carol Berg's "Restoration," I became so frustrated and depressed over how the story was "progressing" that I put it down thinking not to continue.  But, because I wanted to see how she was going to resolve things, I forced myself through.  Similarly to how the second book goes on and on about nasty stuff and never seems to get anywhere, this book goes on and on about frustrating stuff and never seems to get anywhere.  Yes.  Carol Berg can write.  I've got no doubt of her ability to craft world, story, and characters.  But, she just seems to drive a point home until the legs rot off the horse.  In this book, as the bad things pile up and up, it takes over 40% of the book until the main characters manage to stumble into the obvious (and only) solution to their problem.  Meanwhile, we're treated to their frustrations and loss for the whole time (heck, they can't even have a meal, go to the bathroom, or take a bath without disaster befalling them).  Then, for a bit, things look better.  Until we get to watch the protagonist led by his nasal protuberance down the rue du primrose while we scream about brain damage and missing the obvious.  Of course, by the end, she does manage to tie things up nicely.  But, that only allows me to bring my rating up to an OK 3 stars out of 5.  Overall, I'm a bit disappointed in the series.  I was very pleased with the first book.  But, the pain involved in wading through the last two books was just too much.The novels in Carol Berg's Rai-Kirah series are:1.  Transformation (Rai Kirah Book 1)2.  Revelation (Rai Kirah Book 2)3.  Restoration (Rai Kirah Book 3)

Carol Berg's philosophy in this book seems to be:  "into every life, ... the other shoe will drop, and you might as well become a shoe salesman."  The first book ("Transformation") in Carol Berg's "Rai-Kirah" series focuses on the protagonist's physical enslavement and how he has to work through it to fix much bigger problems.  This book ("Revelation") focuses on his character-driven self-enslavement and how he has to work through that to fix even bigger problems (the first and last thirds of the book are centered on this).  For icing, Berg has the protagonist drop himself into a world of physical hurt (because, yes, it has to be done) for the middle third of the book.  So, the book is highly depressing.  Still, this could have been fine.  Except that Berg goes on and on with these terrible things.  Of course, the protagonist struggles time and time again to take steps to correct these bad things.  But, inevitably (and we know it's inevitable as we see it building up), bad things come of it.  I'm hoping the third book won't be as nasty, since Berg's writing is so good and the story so interesting.  But, I have to rate this book at merely an OK 3 stars out of 5.The novels in Carol Berg's Rai-Kirah series are:1.  Transformation (Rai Kirah Book 1)2.  Revelation (Rai Kirah Book 2)3.  Restoration (Rai Kirah Book 3)

I bought this "AmazonBasics USB 3.0 Cable - A Male to Micro B - 6 Feet (1.8 Meters)" as a longer (and hopefully better) replacement for the dinky cable that came with my Samsung T1 Portable 500GB USB 3.0 External SSD (MU-PS500B/AM).  It works perfectly fine.  Running some CrystalDiskMark speed tests on that drive using each of the cables gives, essentially, the same results.  The recurring negative comments I've seen here about this AmazonBasics cable is that the Micro B connector is smaller than normal and the cable is awkward to manage because of its thickness.  In my case, both connectors are exactly the same as the one that came with that drive.  Yes, the cable is thicker than other cables.  But, with the six foot length I got, I'm not having any handling issues.  So, for less than $6, I'm very happy with it and rating it at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

EDIT 4:  I assume this will be my final edit.  As a follow-on to what I reported in the Edit's below, I just got a refurbished version back from them today. Same problem:  the drive might or might not connect.  I can't come up with any way to pinpoint the problem. It happens with multiple computers, multiple cables, multiple operating systems, multiple USB ports, and now, multiple drives. At this point, I guess I'm just going to consider it a total loss and accept that I threw over $200 down the toilet.  If you do buy one of these and it starts to give you issues connecting, don't wait and see if it gets better.  Return it if you can.EDIT 3:  Over the last three months, the intermittent connection problem I noted, below, has extended itself from the initial drive setup, past a 50% successful connection rate in regular use, and into a definite connection struggle.  This morning, in Linux, Windows 10, and Windows 8.1, I ended up trying multiple USB ports and finally rebooting the machine with the drive connected to get it to connect.  Initially, I thought this was a problem with the Windows drivers.  But, since it's also happening on Linux, happens with different USB ports, different machines, and different cables, and is getting worse, I'm now saying the drive is bad.  So, I'll try contacting Samsung (1-800-SAMSUNG) and see what they'll say.  Also, I'm dropping my rating from my initial 4 stars all the way down to 1 star.EDIT 2:  No.  The connection problem, at least in my case, doesn't appear to be a problem with the cable.  I got my AmazonBasics USB 3.0 Cable - A Male to Micro B - 6 Feet (1.8 Meters) and tried to connect from various ports.  Same problem:  sometimes it connected and sometimes it didn't.  CrystalMark gives about the same speed results.EDIT 1:  I've seen several reviews running back to January 2015 about the possibility that the cable (which is ridiculously too short) is the cause of these connection problems.  I'm going to see if a replacement cable will work and do a little talkin' to Amazon and Samsung about this.ORIGINAL REVIEW:  I'm very happy with the speed of this "Samsung T1 Portable 500GB USB 3.0 External SSD (MU-PS500B/AM)."  My primary use for it is for backup files across multiple machines.  For my first test, I had Windows 10 Build 10130 store a System Image to this drive.  With my old WD40EZRX drive in an external enclosure attached to the same USB 3.0 port, that usually took about 25 minutes.  With this T1, it took four (4) minutes.  I sure can't complain about that.  I also ran CrystalDiskMark 4.0.3 x64 on it and got the following:Seq Q32T1:  Read = 435.0 MB/s, Write = 418.4 MB/s4K Q32T1:  Read = 146.8 MB/s, Write = 136.7 MB/sSeq:  Read = 406.4 MB/s, Write = 389.1 MB/s4K:  Read = 24.24 MB/s, Write = 40.90 MB/sVery roughly speaking those non-4K results are about 80% of each of my internal (SATA 3) SSDs, while the 4K Q32T1 test is about 40% of them, the 4K Read is about 70% of them, and the 4K Write is about 30%.  I really have no idea about those benchmarks (I've included them in case someone's interested).  But, I assume the difference in speed is due to the differences between the SATA 3 and USB 3.0 interfaces.Alright.  I'm happy with the performance.  But, I've got issues with the arrogance of Samsung regarding how they've packaged this drive.  When you first plug it in, it runs some software that lets you name the drive and decide about encryption.  There's no way around that.  If your machine can't run that utility, your drive doesn't work.  Once that utility runs, it's not needed any more.  Yet, it sits there staring at you from the System Tray.  There's no obvious way to turn it off and there's no entry for it in Programs & Features, so you can't uninstall it.  Even more fun, it turns out that Samsung's utility sticks this software under the hidden "ProgramData" folder.  So, to get rid of it, you first have to bring up your Task Scheduler, find Samsung_PSSD_Registration there, End it, Disable it, and Delete it (that's what I did, anyway).  Then you can delete (or move to an archive somewhere) the "Samsung Apps" folder under "ProgramData."  This is just plain arrogant.  The drive should just work as soon as it's plugged into any USB 3.0 port on any computer of any flavor.  If Samsung wants to have a utility to rename and encrypt the drive, then they should just give us a normal download on their site.And, finally, I've got my "iffy" section.  It took me 5 tries across two machines to get that utility to run.  On my Windows 10 Build 10130 machine, plugging the drive into a front USB 3.0 port resulted in nothing.  Zip, zero, nada, etc..  The OS didn't even recognize that anything had been plugged in.  On a Windows 8.1 machine, I got the same result.  Eeek.  Next, I tried plugging it into a rear USB 3.0 port.  On the Windows 10 machine, I got a beep that indicated the OS had recognized something had happened.  But, nothing else.  On the Window 8.1 machine, I got the same beep and an OS notification that the device was being installed, but nothing else.  Back on the Windows 10 machine, I again tried that USB 3.0 rear port and, finally, the OS recognized it and the Samsung installation utility ran.  So, I'm a bit worried about the drive.  It seems to be running fine and everything tests out OK.  But, I'm just wondering about why it took all those tries to get things working.Also, my Windows 10 machine will not "Safely Remove the Hardware...."  I've run SysInternal's Process Explorer and looked for anything accessing the drive.  But, there's nothing.  This could very well be a Windows 10 issue, though.Without the mandatory, hidden Samsung utility and without my initial connection problems, I'd have given this a full 5 stars.  But, because of them, I'm knocking a star off and rating it at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.

These "DII Kitchen Millennium Cleaning, Washing, Drying, Ultra Absorbent, Microfiber Dishcloth, Grey Stripes, Set of 8" are exactly what I've been looking for to use for wiping down the kitchen and cleaning things up.  They're perfectly sized (not too big, not too small), properly shaped (square, not a big rectangular strip), a good weight (not too heavy, not too light), and they clean surfaces well.  Even better, they go through the laundry without issue.  The only thing I can come up with that might be a negative is that the texture and pattern make them ideal for Pappillon or Dega to use as supplements to their wardrobes:http://www.imdb.com/media/rm3090795520/tt0070511?ref_=ttmd_md_nxtBut, that's a minor thing.  So, I'm very pleased to rate them at an Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

I'm pretty darn depressed about this Nvidia Shield 16GB (Android TV).  Upon it's release a week or so ago, I drooled over the hardware specs and jumped up and down about the possibility of replacing my Roku 3 Streaming Media Player (2014 model) and Xbox 360.  Plus, the ability to cast and mirror from my Nexus 5 phone and link to the stuff in my Google account was just gravy.  Alas, it was not to be.  I'm assuming the problem is that I jumped on this too early.  NVIDIA is still trying to work out the bugs, kinks, and lacks.  So, here's a list of my current issues with it:- No Amazon Apps:  That's right.  As of this writing, there are no Amazon apps officially available for this.  Yes.  You can sideload a few of them.  But, they either just don't work, or work miserably (lack of controller support).  This is an absolute killer for me.  My primary reason for buying this Shield was to replace my Roku 3.  Yes.  I can use the Google Play Movies & TV app to watch the few movies I've bought through the Google Play Store.  But, the vast majority of my media is right here on Amazon.  Without an Amazon Instant Video app (and it can't even be sideloaded), the Shield has lost most of it glamour.- USB Keyboards and Mice Don't Work:  There's a thread on this over in the NVIDIA Shield forums.  I don't know if the Shield has a problem with ALL USB keyboards and mice.  But, my Logitech Mk560 Wireless Wave Combo Plus: K351 Keyboard & M705 Wireless Mouse is one of the ones that just doesn't work.  The connection to the devices seems to drop whenever they're idle for about two seconds.  So, typing and pointing with these is just impossible.  Without a keyboard and mouse, you're stuck with using the controller for text/pointing input.  And that's a pain.- No Multiple Users:  The Shield just doesn't support multiple users.  If a second person wants to sign in to the device for a personalized experience, he's SOL.  Yes, a second person can sign in.  But, to do that, the previous person must be logged out.  And, not JUST logged out.  Their account must be REMOVED.  That means that when they want to sign back in, they can't just choose a remembered account.  They have to laboriously go through the whole log in procedure again.  And, they have to use the controller for text input because, as noted above, the keyboard and mouse don't work.  Plus, the Settings/Apps/Recommendations/NVIDIA Gaming ID all stay the same across the accounts.  The only thing that logging in seems to do is specify the Google account to use to buy things.- External Storage Isn't All That Useful:  Unless a game has been written to support external offload, you won't be able to move your games to an external device you've added for storage (USB connected drive or Micro SD card).  Yes, you can store data files, music, and photos on an external drive.  But, games are going to take up a lot of space.  As such, the 16GB version I bought isn't all that useful.  I read one review where the reviewers downloaded four games and filled up their storage.  Theoretically, that should change with Android M.  But, right now, if you're a gamer, it's not a good situation.- I'm Just Old:  This relates to that 10 foot, living room, controller-based interface.  It just makes my brain itch.  The interface design standards seem to be such that nothing tells anyone anything.  In general, if you've got a row of icons sitting on the screen, making them active and waiting doesn't get you any information.  I can't tell you how many times I've looked at those icons throughout the games and system and wondered what in the heck they do.  If I select it (using the never explained buttons on the controller), will it erase the game, format the drive, blow up the television, crash the car, and level the house?  Or, will it mark something as a favorite?  I don't know.  I'm of an age where I wonder about older people who can't understand that they can just click on the Start Button to do something.  Now, I've realized that my son is of an age where he's got to wonder about me when I can't understand what the buttons and icons on these controller-based interfaces do.  It's sad.Anyway, I'm a bit upset with this NVIDIA Shield.  With it's tremendous hardware specs, it promised so much.  But, it just hasn't delivered yet.  So, I'm sorry to say that I'm rating it at a Not Very Good 2 stars out of 5.  I'll see if Amazon will let me return it.  Maybe I'll end up selling it.

I got this NVIDIA Shield Remote to go along with my NVIDIA SHIELD (Android TV).  It's nice looking, small, and works well with the Shield.  But, now that I've used it for a bit, I realize there's really no purpose to having it.  Whatever it can do, the controller that comes with the Shield can do just as well.  The only benefit to having this is that it's a boat-load smaller than the controller, so (assuming you've got the controller somewhere else) it takes up far less table room.  If, for some reason, you need an extra remote (and the app you can add to your phone isn't good enough), then go ahead and buy this.  Otherwise, don't bother.  So, I'm rating this at an OK 3 stars out of 5.

I'm very impressed with Carol Berg's "Transformation."  Her writing is excellent and her world, characters, and plot are all very well done and interesting.  From the very first words, I was captivated.  The only issues I have with it are 1) we can see some of the situations that the protagonist gets into from quite a way off, and 2) the "density" of the activities in the second half of the book is different from that of the first half (i.e., the activities in the first half take up most of the timeline, but there are more gaps where time passes in the second half).  Neither of these things is drastic, but they were enough for me to just barely knock my rating down a notch.  So, I'm rating this book at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.The novels in Carol Berg's Rai-Kirah series are:1.  Transformation (Rai Kirah Book 1)2.  Revelation (Rai Kirah Book 2)3.  Restoration (Rai Kirah Book 3)

I'll get the elephant in the room out of the way right up front.  If you're intending to use this monitor for graphics work, don't.  It uses a TN panel, so the colors and color shifts preclude any accurate color work, If you're planning on using it for gaming, you might think twice about it.  Only by using the DisplayPort 1.2a connection and a fairly powerful graphics card (and I'd guess that the equivalent of a GTX 970 would be the bare minimum) can you even get 60 fps in a game at full resolution.  Because of the huge number of pixels you'll be pushing, your actual frame rates will probably be lower than you'd like.With that elephant gone, I will say that ViewSonic is up-front on their own web site about the target audience for this monitor.  The main product page there says it's designed for "Scientific/Rendering, Finance/Modeling, Surveillance/Mapping."  If you go to their Downloads tab and look at the Datasheet, it says it's designed for "Business, Finance, Surveillance."  So, jumping the gun to put my overall rating up front (since this review is so long), WITH THAT AUDIENCE IN MIND, I'm rating this "ViewSonic VG2860MHL-4K 28-Inch 4K Ultra HD LED Monitor" at an OK 3 stars out of 5.Now for some supporting information.  First, the relevant specs/components:- According to the factory service menu, the LCD panel it uses is an M280DGJ-L30 C2 TN panel made by Innolux.  The normal issues around TN panels are color shifting at angles and lack of colors.  ViewSonic has gone above the normal behavior by using 10-bit color (true 8-bits + 2-bits FRC) as compared to the usual use of 6- or 8-bit color for TNs.  Theoretically, that makes this monitor good with color (more on that later).  The color shifts when looking at the monitor at an angle are present, but they're not as bad as I had expected.  Still, they exist.- Even though both Amazon's and ViewSonic's product pages frequently mention "Future-proof" in reference to connectivity, the monitor uses DisplayPort 1.2a instead of 1.3 and HDMI 1.4 instead of 2.0.  Use of DisplayPort 1.2a is not really an issue since that will still allow 60 Hz at the monitor's native resolution (3840 x 2160).  HDMI 1.4 is a different matter.  Where HDMI 2.0 would allow 60 fps at native resolution, HDMI 1.4 allows a maximum of 30 Hz.  So, not only is this monitor not "future-proof," it's actually somewhat obsolete (not many monitors use HDMI 2.0 yet).- The two speakers are on the BACK of the monitor.  I checked them out and they're loud enough.  But, pretty much as expected, they sound about like transistor radio speakers (or, more currently, cell phone speakers).  I'd highly recommend you use something else for sound (like Audioengine A2+ Premium Powered Desktop Speakers - Pair (Black)).  However, the headphone jack produces GREAT sound (depending on your headphones, of course).- This is a 16:9 monitor instead of 16:10.  Granted, most monitors these days use 16:9.  But, my old HP ZR2440w 24-inch, 1920 x 1200, 16:10, LED Backlit, IPS Monitor has only about an inch less vertical space than this monitor (though horizontally, there's a big difference).- As near as I can find, my old HP monitor has it's pixels packed at about 100 dpi.  This Viewsonic monitor's pixels are packed at about 160 dpi.  Yet, looking at the two screens next to each other, I can't really tell the difference in the fineness of the display.  I was VERY surprised by this.Packaging/Set up/Web Site:- The monitor came nicely double-boxed and packaged.  Putting it together was easy:  lie the monitor face down with the bottom facing you, rotate the mounting arm so it faces the bottom of the monitor, hook the base on and tighten it with the finger screw.  Plug in the obvious power cord, the non-obvious data cable, turn it on, insert the CD and check it for the User Guide, Registration, and VSFiles (drivers and color profile stuff - note that the "software" directory they mention isn't on the CD -- the files are in the VSFiles directory and you'll have to point your monitor's properties at that directory to update to those files).  The biggest problem with this is that the bags of cables are not labeled with what they are.  You have to know enough to figure out what cable is what and eyeball them to figure out which one to use.  The next biggest quibble is with the information tag hanging from the tab that locks the monitor to keep it from raising/lowering.  It's nothing but a mess of pictures, so you get to exercise your creativity trying to figure out what it's really saying.  Similarly, the Quick Start piece of paper is a set of four fairly worthless pictures that mean exactly what I wrote earlier in this paragraph.- There's no hard copy of the User Guide included with the packaging and it's not available for downloading from the ViewSonic web site.  So, if you don't have an existing monitor, you won't be able to read the User Guide until after you've got the monitor set up.  Similarly, if you don't have an optical drive (I don't on this computer), you won't be able to access it at all (the drivers, though, ARE available on the ViewSonic web site).- With just the default Windows drivers, the Nvidia Control Panel said "this display does not support HDCP (High-Bandwidth Digital Content Protection)."  But, after installing the included drivers and rebooting, that changed to say it DID support HDCP.  So, make sure you install the drivers (though the colors looked no different between the default Windows color profile and the one included with the monitor).- I see absolutely no physical problems with the monitor:  no scratches, no dead pixels, no stuck pixels.  Perfect.- The monitor controls for the OSD are located UNDERNEATH the bottom edge of the screen (i.e., they can't be seen).  Plus, they're tiny little nubs of buttons.  Their labels are not colored.  They're just embossed into the bottom front plastic (i.e., they're hard to see - while I was trying to manually calibrate the monitor, I actually had to sit there with a flashlight pointing at the bezel).Testing:- Relevant to the testing of this monitor, the significant parts of my system are 1) an ASUS STRIX-GTX970-DC20C-4GD5 Graphics Cards STRIX-GTX970-DC20C-4GD5 which has one DisplayPort 1.2 and one HDMI 2.0 port, and 2) that earlier-mentioned HP ZR2440w 24-inch, 1920 x 1200, 16:10, LED Backlit, IPS Monitor.  To get a full 60 Hz on this monitor, I connected it to my video card via the included DisplayPort cable.  I left my HP monitor connected via its HDMI cable.  I'm running Windows 10 Technical Preview Build 10122 (x64).- Windows found the monitor without problems and I set it up for the full native resolution of 3840 x 2160 at 60 Hz.- To test the colors, I went to lagom.nl.  Firstly, on that web site's Display Settings screen, it says the resolution is 2560 x 1440 even though it's set to native 3840 x 2160.  I'm assuming that's an artifact of how the monitor handles the high resolution through the DisplayPort.  Outside of a yellowish  tinge, the display is pretty good for its audience.  Even the color shifting at angles isn't that noticeable.  The gamma is too low (1.4 or 1.5 instead of 2.2).  And, under lagom's Contrast mode, I lost a bottom bar or two of blue color.- I tried calibrating the colors through Windows' Calibration routine.  But, I couldn't fix the gamma.  My best manual color adjustment was from the monitor's OSD:  in Color Adjust, I switched from Native to a User Color of 80/80/100 (R/G/B) (none of the pre-made options under the OSD were any better).  But, in general, even adjusted like that, the colors were sort of washed out.  So, I went back to the yellowish defaults (less washed out).  The color difference is pretty obvious when two displays are next to each other and I move things across them.  But, with only the one display on, you get used to it and don't really notice it any more.- I played some games (Overlord and Borderlands 2).  Because the colors are generally a bit washed out and yellowish, they were similarly washed out and yellowish in the games too.  To limit my frame rate to 60 fps, I keep my display driver on Adaptive.  Surprisingly, even at native resolution, the game frame rates didn't suffer unduly (maybe down in the 40s -- but then, a GTX 970 is no slouch).  The fans on my video card ramped up pretty quickly though. In general, I was pleasantly surprised by gaming with this monitor.  I expected far worse.  But, if you've got a really good graphics card, you could consider it.- I watched some HD videos and had no issues.  With the general color issues in mind, they were fine.- For office applications, I fired up all my applications and apps.  Again, the colors are a bit yellow and washed out.  But, except for one application (SpiderOak), everything scaled just fine (Windows defaults to 150% scaling) and was readable at this high resolution.  The large increase in the horizontal is nice since you can slap documents side-by-side quite nicely.  But, the lack of vertical increase in space over my old monitor means that there doesn't really feel like there's all that much added real estate.Personal Opinion:  My old HP ZR2440w 24-inch, 1920 x 1200, 16:10, LED Backlit, IPS Monitor is not being made any more.  But, its current "new" price on Amazon is about $499 ($399 when I bought it 3 years ago).  This VG2860MHL-4k monitor is currently selling at around $649.  Personally, I don't think the price difference is worth it.  I'm happier with the crispness and colors of my 24-inch IPS display than I am with those on this 28-inch TN display.  To me, vertical space is more important at this point than horizontal space.  And that 16:10 ratio on the smaller monitor gives me almost as much space as the 16:9 ratio on the larger.  If you're a graphics professional, I'd say you absolutely need an IPS monitor (if you're a ViewSonic fan, maybe their ViewSonic VP2780-4K  27-Inch 4K Ultra HD LED Monitor (3840x2160, 60Hz, 5ms, 20M:1 DCR, HDMI 2.0, Dual MHL, DisplayPort, MultiPicture, Pre-Calibrated) would fit the bill (I've never seen it, but it looks like it might work)).  If you're a gamer, you're probably better off "future-proofing" yourself by trying a monitor with DisplayPort 1.3 and HDMI 2.0 connections (maybe multiples of those at 4K resolutions just to make sure you can pump the pixels through fast enough).  But, in general, I'd say just about everyone would be better off finding a good 24-inch, 16:10, 1920 x 1200, DisplayPort 1.3, HDMI 2.0, IPS monitor for, probably, a lot less money.  If you really need the space, pop that up to a 27-inch, 16:10, 2560 x 1600, DisplayPort 1.3, HDMI 2.0, IPS monitor.  Overall, this monitor is adequate for its target audience and budget.  But, I just can't see spending the extra money for not much gain (if any).Notes:- To get to the factory service menu, first turn off the monitor.  Then hold Button 1 (the one you normally use to bring up the OSD) and press (shortly) the Power On button.  Keep holding Button 1 until anything happens on the monitor to indicate it's on.  Then release Button 1 and press it as if to call up OSD.  Go down to the "F" at the bottom of the OSD and select it with Button 2.- The monitor comes with an MHL cable.  According to Wikipedia, MHL (Mobile High-Definition Link) "is an industry standard for a mobile audio/video interface that allows consumers to connect mobile phones, tablets, and other portable consumer electronics (CE) devices to high-definition televisions (HDTVs) and audio receivers."  Unfortunately, all we have around here are Nexus 5 cell phones which don't support MHL.  So, I wasn't able to test that.

Dave Barry's "Dave Barry Turns Fifty" isn't quite what I expected it to be.  I expected more of Dave's observations on growing old.  That stuff is in there.  But, most of the book focuses on what happened during the years from Dave's birth to his adulthood.  I enjoyed that material because it reminded me of all the similar things way back in my youth (and, it's funny, too).  It's a fun book, though not gut-bustingly so, and I rate it at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.

In "Sky Coyote," Kage Baker seems intent on missing the boat with her own series.  First of all, in almost all technical aspects, this book is worse than the first book in the series.  Where that book had well-done and well-researched writing, with varied and decently filled-out characters, this book rambles about unimportant trivia, buries any historical research under horse-feathers, and has only one character with any semblance of depth.  The one thing in this book that is done better than in the first is a sense of purpose.  Unfortunately, it's really the wrong purpose.  OK.  Some details:First, besides the mere existence of the two cultures in the area where this story takes place, Baker has destroyed almost everything that might lead towards a feeling of historical accuracy.  She's replaced almost every aspect of the tribe that is the protagonist's mission with allegorical representations of the worst of our own culture.  She's replaced the historical story of the first book with allegorical preaching in this book.  I mean, really, she's putting talk of management/labor relations, child care, divorce, alimony, business, etc., into the mouths of Stone-Age, pre-literate, pre-anything people.  It's just silly.Second, in this book, we've got the return of the two main characters of the first book.  Joseph is the protagonist and is reasonably filled out.  Mendoza comes along for the ride and, like every other character, is a nullity.  There's no character there even though a few more interesting and tantalizing tidbits of her past are revealed.And, finally, the story Baker goes on and on about (the mission that Joseph is on) ought to have been merely a side-quest.  What's really interesting (and should be the core of the series) is the relationship between these immortal cyborgs and their future creators (or masters, i.e., the Company).  About 10% of the book involves that relationship.  And, it's fascinating:  what is truly happening between immortals who are better, faster, stronger, smarter, wiser, etc. and the people/culture/company that created them.  Especially when it looks like those creators might be on their way to Eloi-hood.So, unfortunately, I'm rating this book at a Pretty Bad 2 stars out of 5.  Even worse, I'm not even sure I'll continue with the series.  I'd love to find out what's really going on with Mendoza and what's going to happen between these immortals and the Dr. Zeus Company.  But, if that's going to be buried under another nine books of cruft like this book, then I don't think I'll want to wade through it.The novels in Kage Baker's "Company" series are:1.  In the Garden of Iden (The Company)2.  Sky Coyote (The Company)3.  Mendoza in Hollywood (The Company)4.  The Graveyard Game (The Company)5.  The Life of the World to Come (The Company)6.  The Children of the Company7.  The Machine's Child (The Company)8.  The Sons of Heaven (The Company)9.  The Empress of Mars (The Company)10.  Not Less Than Gods (The Company)11.  Nell Gwynne's On Land and At Sea

Kage Baker's "In the Garden of Iden" is a bit of a let-down.  Supposedly, it's an historical-based science fiction story.  But, really, the science fiction aspect seems to be merely a wrapper around nothing but an Historical Romance novel.  I suppose it could also be called a "coming of age" book (though you'd have to twist the term to apply to the protagonist) or a plain old "slice of life" story.  It's a shame.  The concept behind the book is interesting, the writing is well-done and well-researched, and the characters are varied and decently filled-out.  But, except for the first few chapters, nothing of any importance happens.  Instead, we're treated to the chronicling of a 19 year old girl's first love.  Now, this is Kage Baker's first novel (and the first of her Company series).  So, I'm going to hope for better in later works.  But, for this one, I'm going to rate it at merely an OK 3 stars out of 5.The novels in Kage Baker's "Company" series are:1.  In the Garden of Iden (The Company)2.  Sky Coyote (The Company)3.  Mendoza in Hollywood (The Company)4.  The Graveyard Game (The Company)5.  The Life of the World to Come (The Company)6.  The Children of the Company7.  The Machine's Child (The Company)8.  The Sons of Heaven (The Company)9.  The Empress of Mars (The Company)10.  Not Less Than Gods (The Company)11.  Nell Gwynne's On Land and At Sea

Sorry, but this is not going to be all that good of a review.  I could only use this "NOW Foods Pygeum and Saw Palmetto + Pumpkin Seed Oil, 120 Softgels" for about a week.  I had some kind of reaction to it (I broke out in an itchy rash) and had to stop taking it.  During the time I was using it, I didn't really notice any difference in my symptoms.  But, because I couldn't properly test the product, I'm rating it at a Neutral 3 stars out of 5.

Like many (if not most) of Tim Powers' works, his 1979 novel "The Drawing of the Dark" (his third novel) is historically based with a supernatural twist.  This one's a little different from his other works since the focus is more on an historical event (the siege of Vienna in 1529) than on an historical person (though the main characters are out of the Arthur/Merlin/Fisher King legends).  Also like his other works, it takes quite a while to figure out what's going on.  In this case, we can't start seeing what's going on until we're almost a third of the way through the book.  For the most part, the writing is just fine until about the 80% point.  Then, it seems to weaken (it doesn't get bad, it's just that a few things happen that seem out of character or more removed from us than they should be).  This trend continues right through to the end:  the final scene just doesn't have any personal oomph to it.  It feels like the main characters have been taken over by their roles and are just going through the motions to tie things up.  Once they've done that, everyone's given their walking papers, and they head on home.  Because of that weakness at the end, I'd like to reduce my rating by half a star to 3-1/2 stars.  But, since I'm restricted to integers, I'll be generous and leave it at a Pretty Good 4 stars out of 5.

Initially, I laughed when I saw the descriptions of the premise for this movie coupled with its very high ratings.  I mean, come on:"My name is John Wick.  You killed my dawg.  Prepare to die."Imagine my surprise when I found that the darn movie actually works and is Very Good (I'm rating it at 4 stars out of 5).  The problem was that the premise I had been reading wasn't actually complete.  Instead, it should read:"My name is John Wick.  I'm not a good man.  But, for my wife, I was trying.  You killed my dawg.  The last gift from my wife and my last hope.  Prepare to die."We're not talking Shakespeare, here.  We're talking a Murder Death Kill type of movie.  And, it works.  I've got only one complaint with the whole thing:  [minor spoiler] at one point, the bad guys have John down.  Instead of ending it right there, the bad boss has him taken back to a lair so he can gloat and prepare the shark-mounted lasers (well, not really).  This is the same guy who practically soiled himself when he found out someone in his organization had done John wrong.  Yet, given the chance to get clear of it, he blows it [/minor spoiler].  Other than that, I've got no problems with the movie.

If anyone needs proof that our civilization is at its end, all they have to do is go buy a toaster.  We, can no longer even make fire.  If you look at my toaster history, below, you'll see that this collapse has been going on for at least the last 14 years.  Our cheap Oster toaster that lasted us for 5 years finally reached the point where we had to replace it.  This "Kitchenaid Contour Silver 2-Slice Toaster KMT2115CU" is our third attempt at a replacement in four days.  They've all failed and all been returned.  In this case, the toaster actually works a bit.  The problem is that the two sides of a piece of bread do not toast equally.  To get the lesser-cooked side decently toasted, the more-cooked side will be burned.  To get the more-cooked side decently toasted, the lesser-cooked side will be un-browned.  Plus, it takes a long time to toast.  This is better than the previous two toasters, but not good enough (heck, the old one we're replacing still toasts better than this).  So back it goes.  I have no idea how retailers can survive the inventory churn caused by this total lack of quality and quality control.  Ditto for the manufacturers.  But, since the manufacturers are the problem here, they can go bankrupt and improve the world for all that I care.  Anyway, I rate this thing at a Very Bad 1 star out of 5.And, if anyone's interested, here's the history for our search for fire:-05/12/15:  Kitchenaid Contour Silver 2-Slice Toaster KMT2115CU:  Returned.  Two sides toast very differently.  To get the lesser-cooked side decently toasted, the more-cooked side will be burned.  To get the more-cooked side decently toasted, the lesser-cooked side will be un-browned.  Plus, it takes a long time to toast.- 05/11/15:  Oster 4 Slice Long Slot Toaster (TSSTTRJB30):  Returned.  On first use (where we were just trying to burn off the stuff from the coils), toasting lever refused to rise after the toasting cycle was done.  Nothing we could do could get that lever back up.  Plus, looking at the coils while they were working, the outside set were not heating up anywhere near the amount the inside set were.- 05/08/15:  Hamilton Beach 24810 4-Slice Long Slot Keep Warm Toaster.  Returned because, out of the box, it toasted only one side of the bread.  Plus, it beeped annoyingly.- 11/29/12: Frigidaire Professional 4-Slice Wide Slots Toaster, Model #FPTT04D7MS. Returned because of useless digital darkness settings and bad toasting. Went back to old Oster toaster, below.- 03/20/10: Oster 6330 Inspire 4-Slice Toaster, Brushed Stainless Steel. After over five years, it's starting to die.- 12/21/09: Exchanged the Delonghi Stainless Steel 4Slice Toaster (below) for another. Seven weeks later (49 days), the right set of slots again failed to lock down and turn on.- 12/05/09: Original DeLonghi CTH4003 Pro-Metal 4-Slice Toaster. After 16 days, the right set of slots failed to lock down and turn on.- 03/27/06: Dualit 4-Slice Toaster. The catch on the slots was starting to fail (i.e., they failed to lock down and turn on, occasionally -- but, it lasted over 3 years).- 11/21/04: Another Villaware 5850 (bought mistakenly). Same problem as the previous Villaware: left set of slots failed to lock down and turn on after about 1 week.- 05/01/04: Some GE toaster we bought locally. Didn't break (lasted almost two years), but was starting to take a long time to toast.- ???: There must have been at least one toaster in this gap. I can't find any records of it, though.- 12/03/01: Villaware 5850 Uno Classic 4-Slice Toaster. It lasted about a week. Then, the left set of slots failed to lock down and turn on.

We picked up this "Hamilton Beach 24810 4-Slice Long Slot Keep Warm Toaster" at Costco for FAR less than it is here.  Regardless, it's going back since it only toasts one side of the bread (the inner side).  Also, the darn thing beeps.  For some reason, it beeps once when you depress the lever to start toasting (as if you didn't know you had just started toasting something even though your finger is still on the lever) and it beeps three times when the toast is done.  I suppose the beeping when the toast is done might serve some purpose (though theoretically (and the manual specifically states it), you shouldn't leave the toaster unattended while toasting).  But, I imagine many people will scoff at that since they've got things to do while the toast is toasting.  The trouble is that we can't disable that beeping and it sounds like my backup batteries on my computer during a power failure (very jarring).  So, again, it's going back and I rate it at a Very Bad 1 star out of 5.And, if anyone's interested, here's the history for our search for fire:- 11/29/12:  Frigidaire Professional 4-Slice Wide Slots Toaster, Model #FPTT04D7MS.  Returned because of useless digital darkness settings and bad toasting.  Went back to old Oster toaster, below.- 03/20/10: Oster 6330 Inspire 4-Slice Toaster, Brushed Stainless Steel. After over five years, it's starting to die.- 12/21/09: Exchanged the Delonghi Stainless Steel 4Slice Toaster (below) for another. Seven weeks later (49 days), the right set of slots again failed to lock down and turn on.- 12/05/09: Original DeLonghi CTH4003 Pro-Metal 4-Slice Toaster. After 16 days, the right set of slots failed to lock down and turn on.- 03/27/06: Dualit 4-Slice Toaster. The catch on the slots was starting to fail (i.e., they failed to lock down and turn on, occasionally -- but, it lasted over 3 years).- 11/21/04: Another Villaware 5850 (bought mistakenly). Same problem as the previous Villaware: left set of slots failed to lock down and turn on after about 1 week.- 05/01/04: Some GE toaster we bought locally. Didn't break (lasted almost two years), but was starting to take a long time to toast.- ???: There must have been at least one toaster in this gap. I can't find any records of it, though.- 12/03/01: Villaware 5850 Uno Classic 4-Slice Toaster. It lasted about a week. Then, the left set of slots failed to lock down and turn on.

Robert Kroese's "Mercury Rises" is the 2nd in his "Mercury" series of book.  Unfortunately, it suffers a bit from sequelitis.  Specifically, it's got all the elements of the first book:  irreverent humor, constant japes and wisecracks, and a nicely intertwined plot.  But, it's just missing something.  It feels just a tad less clever than the first book.  My biggest issue with the book, though, isn't really with that lack.  Instead, unlike the first book, this one definitely requires the later books.  Now, I'd read the first three books once before.  From that vantage, I can see that the first book really wasn't complete.  But, it "felt" complete.  This book doesn't end in a cliff-hanger.  But, it's very obvious that there's more that needs doing.  These aren't huge issues.  But, they're enough for me to drop the rating to merely an OK 3 stars out of 5.The novels in Robert Kroese's "Mercury" series are:1.  Mercury Falls (Mercury Series Book 1)2.  Mercury Rises (Mercury Series Book 2)3.  Mercury Rests (Mercury Series Book 3)4.  Mercury Revolts: (Book Four of the Mercury Series)

Robert Kroese's "Mercury Falls" is both a(n) humorous and an intellectual book to read.  Be warned, though, that the humor might not appeal to everyone:  it's highly irreverent.  So, as another review here states (from the opposite side of the ratings spectrum), read the material in the "Look Inside" link on Amazon's product page before buying it.  Even better than the humor, is the intertwined nature of the plot.  Kroese weaves just about everything in the book, including the number of footnotes and the asides, into the plot at some point.  He's also really good at bringing in references to other works.  I especially liked the reference to Douglas Adams' bowl of petunias from The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy.  So, I'm very happy to rate the book at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.The novels in Robert Kroese's "Mercury" series are:1.  Mercury Falls (Mercury Series Book 1)2.  Mercury Rises (Mercury Series Book 2)3.  Mercury Rests (Mercury Series Book 3)4.  Mercury Revolts: (Book Four of the Mercury Series)

Robert A. Heinlein's "The Puppet Masters" hasn't weathered the 64 years since its initial publication well.  Back in 1951, when he first published it, I suppose the behavior of the main characters would have been considered risque and "edgy" (one of the reasons it was so severely censored back then).  But, today, that behavior (particularly the main character's behavior) just comes across as being caddish or loutish.  Oddly enough, Heinlein muffs the one thing that should have been a positive in our current world view:  the main female character starts out as an emancipated, strong lead (she's smarter, faster, and a better agent than her mail counterpart).  But, by the end, Heinlein has turned her into some kind of Stepford Wife whose sole line seem to be "Yes, dear."  Even worse than what the changes in how we expect people to behave have hit the book is the discontinuity in the main character's role:  He's supposed to be a kind of super agent.  Yet, he never behaves as such, either in physical "agent" ability or in his mental acumen.  He basically comes across as a boss's pet (and that come's across even more when a relationship is revealed about a third of the way through the book).  This really hits home near the end when he's actually promoted.  Yet, all of the previous is fairly trivial compared to the biggest problem:  every single character in the book behaves illogically.  It's not just a matter of doing things that make no sense (which happens, too).  No, the big problem is that nobody does what they, very obviously, really should be doing.  All the time.  From the very start, right down to the finish line.  It makes the book painful to read.All of that is a shame.  In my youth, Heinlein was my favorite author (not just one of my favorites -- he was THE favorite).  Even today, his Starship Troopers is one of my favorite books.  So, it pains me to have to write such a negative review here.  Yes.  This book is interesting and Heinlein's foresight makes his books worth reading.  But, the problems with this book just override that.  So, all I can do is rate the book at a Not Very Good 2 stars out of 5.

Yes.  Linda Nagata's "Deception Well" is weird, slow, and filled with contradictions.  But, the biggest problem is the whole family of logic elephants in the room.  From almost the very start of the book until its very end, you're annoyed with structural issues.  But, you've also got to contend with the constant nagging question in the back of your head related to the core plot:  why didn't/don't the powers that be (TPTB) just let those people go down to the surface of the planet?  Those people are nothing to TPTB.  In fact, they're worse than nothing:  they're invaders.  Why not just let them go down to what TPTB are sure is certain doom?  That decision leads to a whole lot of baby elephants that keep nagging at you:- if TPTB want to avoid deaths, why do things that lead directly to the death of most of them?- if TPTB want to save them, why keep them as permanent refugees?- if TPTB are worried about what the main character will do, why not just let him go down to the planet?- if TPTB believe absolutely that they can be re-born from their own metadata (to an extent one main character will let his body be killed so he can transmit said metadata to a different location and only have one instantiation), why don't they just record the main character (to salve their consciousness) and toss him out an airlock?- if TPTB are afraid of reactions from whatever's down on the planet, why fire weapons down there?- if TPTB want the main character to come back once he's out of reach, why ask him when there's not anything he can do about it?- if TPTB want the main character's help, why do they beat him about the head and shoulders and otherwise torment him?It would have been nice to have all those elephants removed (as well as the structural problems (especially the slow pacing)) since Nagata might have been able to focus some attention on her weird universe and explain it better.  But, the way this is written, I'll have to rate it at a Pretty Bad 2 stars out of 5.

If you've read much of Jack L. Chalker's works, you'll understand how something related to H.G. Wells' "The Island of Dr. Moreau" might appeal to him.  Thus, we've got Chalker's "The Moreau Factor."  It's an interesting plot coupled with some of the very serious issues that our technology is presenting us with.  I enjoyed it quite a bit.  But, it does suffer from some problems.  First, there are some editing issues.  Oh, not things like misspelled words or grammar.  Instead, there are discontinuities where it looks like he wrote the book for a bit and then stopped for a while.  Then, when he picked it up again, he didn't re-read the earlier stuff and we get either duplicate or contradicting information.  More subtly, the tone of the book changes.  The first few chapters feel more gritty and less high-tech than I'd have expected from Chalker.  After that, things feel smoother and much higher tech.  And then, the remainder of the book reads more like Chalker's other works (i.e., very high tech and centering around personal transformation).  This isn't a major problem, but it does jar a bit.  More bothersome is that even though, by the end, we learn who's doing what to whom and why, I still have problems with it.  There are much easier, cheaper, and less messy ways of solving the problems the antagonists were facing than what they chose.  To me, it looks like they chose these methods because that's what Chalker likes to write about.  But, even with that, I found the story to be a good one.  So, I'm rating the book (with some slight misgivings) at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5.

Others here have noted that Joe Abercrombie's "Half a King" is less "gritty," bloody, visceral, etc. than some of his other works.  I agree (a bit - don't go looking for the characters to be dancing with rainbows or singing in six part harmony).  But, whereas they bemoan that "loss," I'm happy with it.  There's more than enough blood, guts, death, dismemberment, torment, meanness, etc. in this book, but it's been tempered by a slightly rosy suggestion of cleverness and maybe (just maybe) a hint of decency.  Abercrombie's writing is very good and the world, plot, and characters are all very well done.  I'm usually a bit ambivalent about his books, but this one's got enough of a positive trend for me to rate it at a Very Good 4 stars out of 5 and to look forward to the next in line.The novels in Joe Abercrombie's "Shattered Sea" series are:1.  Half a King (Shattered Sea Book 1)2.  Half the World (Shattered Sea Book 2)3.  Half a War (Shattered Sea Book 3)

The Icefalcon is an interesting enigma of a character throughout Barbara Hambly's "Darwath" series.  This book, "Icefalcon's Quest," is designed to flesh out and give the background of the Icefalcon.  It's definitely a book that needed writing and actually does a pretty good job of giving us that information.  But, unfortunately, the story could have been (and should have been) better.  I've got three main problems with it.  First, for all that it dumps us right into Hambly's signature despair, it takes fully two-thirds of the book before we even get an inkling of what's happening.  Instead, those first two hundred pages are filled with the Icefalcon following Tir.  Yes, we're getting all the Icefalcon stuff.  But, we're sitting there for all those pages scratching our heads and wondering when the story is going to go someplace.  Second, there are just too many gaping holes in what's happening.  For instance:- The wet-work in this book is personally handled by our old pal Bektis, the somewhat incompetent, pompous, and cowardly court mage.  He'd never do that.- We never get an explanation of why Bektis is doing this (especially since he's got a nifty new gadget that should keep him out from under someone's thumb).- We get almost no explanation of Bektis' nifty tool nor why he would continue using it more than once.- The rationale we get in the last few pages of the book for the main bad guy doing this is horribly weak.- It makes no sense that all the resources (and their ability to be used) that the bad guys have were found where they were.And, finally, it's just silly to think that all those guys with swords and the wizard with the nifty tool would put up with the abuse that the lead bad guy heaps on them.  These guys have passed straight through henchman status and are plummeting through minionhood.  So, all together, I can only rate the book at an OK 3 stars out of 5.  It's good for an Icefalcon fix, but as a story, it's just too weak and drawn out.  If Hambly had condensed the first couple of hundred pages down to 50 or so, and then worked some more with the last 150 pages, it would have been better.The novels in the Darwath series are:1, 2, and 3.  The Darwath Series: The Time of the Dark, The Walls of Air, and The Armies of Daylight4.  Mother of Winter (Darwath)5.  Icefalcon's Quest

Unfortunately, I'm stuck with being able to give only one rating to Steven Barnes' "Blood Brothers."  It's unfortunate, because technically, the book is very well written with good characters and an engaging plot.  But, personally, I found that the pure nastiness of the book overrode all the technical excellence.  I probably could have lived with the book if the 100 or so pages of Dahlia Childe's diary stuck in the middle had been summarized or otherwise sanitized.  It takes the cake for awful things happening (but, then, it really has to given the subject matter).  So, I'm sorry to say I can only rate the book at a Pretty Bad 2 stars out of 5.  If you're made of sterner stuff than I am, give it a try (again, it's technically very well done (say 4 stars)).  But, be warned.

I'm highly disappointed with Jack L. Chalker's "Priam's Lens."  It doesn't read like the Chalker I know.  The most prevalent problem with it is that there's just too much talking.  It goes on and on.  Heck, the story doesn't really begin until around 250 pages into the book.  Coupled with that is the fact that fully half of the book follows a tribe of survivors of the evil aliens and is not interesting at all (in characters or in story).  But, the biggest problem is that the book is just filled with inconsistencies and contradictions.  Things will be described as being one way, only to be described as being totally different in the next chapter.  It's not much fun reading a book where even the author couldn't keep his own story straight.  So, I'm sorry to say that I'm rating this book at a Pretty Bad 2 stars out of 5.  Don't bother.

Through most of Eric S. Nylund's "Signal to Noise," the biggest issue I had with it was that the main character, Jack, is an idiot.  I'm not talking about just a slow guy.  I'm talking about a guy who seems to be incapable of understanding some of the main characteristics of his milieu (his forte, his arena, his bailiwick, etc.).  Here's a guy whose profession is encryption and who does side jobs for the NSA-equivalent organization of his universe.  Yet, from day one, he's constantly neglecting computer security (and human security, too).  Of course, I figured that this character flaw would enable some nice character growth as the novel progressed.  Nope.  If anything, his idiocy gets worse.  Even more heinous, after using something that's supposed to make him better at what he is, he gets even worse.  OK.  Fine.  I was still very happy with the book.  It's fast-paced, well-written, and interesting.  But, in the last 30 pages or so, the book collapses.  Yes, it's the first of two books.  But, with what happens at the end of it, I basically have to throw up my hands and say "why bother?" (I wish I could say more, but it would be a major spoiler).  So, I'm docking the book one star from where I would have originally rated it and am giving it an OK 3 stars out of 5.The novels in Eric S. Nylund's "Signal" series are:1.  Signal to Noise2.  A Signal Shattered

I'm sad to say, Arthur C. Clarke's "2061 (Space Odyssey Book 3)" is nowhere near as good as the previous book in the series.  First of all, the first third of the book is almost entirely filler.  Some of it is used for positioning the pieces on the board.  But, for all intents and purposes, it could have been cut entirely from the book.  Second, the crux of the rest of the book is that a spaceship gets stranded somewhere.  It survives its "landing," but can't leave without fuel.  But, unless I'm mis-remembering some of the stuff from the filler third of the book, it's surrounded by the very material it uses for propellant.
