And if he does, is that part of his plan, or something he needs to skirt around?Those aren't even the only questions, but the biggest one is posed by Lenka himself: can he do the right thing even if it means he'll continue to be condemned? Just one problem: does he know for sure what the right thing is?There's a whole lot more going on here, but that's all I can say without giving the plot away. Suffice to say I can't wait until the next installment of the series...even if it leads to yet more unanswered questions.

This is better seen as three parts of the same story told from different angles rather than standalone novellas. Of the three, only the second is truly self-contained; it provides useful information that informs the other two but doesn't need them to tell it's story. Please keep that in mind as you read; I was very frustrated by the ending of the first book but satisfied by the end.Poor Ellie Brooke perhaps wasn't surprised to feel herself pulled into a world haunted by death from the very first page of the story, but that she felt herself literally haunted was the surprise. Why had the seeming bon vivant Laurent summon her all the way from England to restore his garden in modern-day Porquerolles, and why did his mother regard her with such antipathy from the first? It's not hard to figure out what happened to Ellie and what-or who-is going to follow us into the next story, but the question is why.The second novel follows blind Marthe Lincel as she bravely works to use her gifts mixing scents for the kindly Mussets into something useful for the French Resistance. She is blessed with bravery and integrity; her weaknesses are, as for everyone else, other people: whom can she trust, and how can she protect those she cares for without harming others. Worse, how can she go on after a painful loss? Of all three stories, this was the one that moved me the most.The final story follows Iris Nightingale from the 1940s to the present day, and here all the strands come together. Iris works for British Intelligence, helping the French Resistance coordinate intelligence with the larger effort. Pragmatic and competent despite her young age, she nevertheless finds herself swept up into a romance with a head-on is it reckless?- French agent. Tracking down what became of him and her later resignation that she'll never know us just one of the meanings behind the title "The Shadow Life". Iris will eventually get her answers, but is the cost worth the truth?This spooky tale of romantic suspense had a slow build that made the ending more satisfying even if many of the connections were easy to spot. I would recommend this to fans of historical romance as well as paranormal suspense.

I received a review copy in exchange for an honest review.In Mystical High, the first book of The Desert Series, the town of Mystekal was in decay. As if to underscore how much, multiple people reported ghost sitings. But they quickly found out that the living could be much more frightening than the dead, and the death of the Ernest Carrow, the murderous high school principal who also owned much of the town, allowed the residents to start rebuilding their lives and rebuilding Mystekal.Arielle Dalworth, newly returned to Mystekal (and remarried to her husband after an ill-conceived tryst with a slimeball Hollywood producer) is charged with reviving the once grand theater. As she's making arrangements, her hilariously brilliant son River meets Larsen "Lars" Davis, a talented young man who dreams of a career as an actor but whose life is made hellish by the bullying he suffers over his sexuality- both in school and at home. River may be quirky, but he's also brave, and there's no way he's going to watch someone suffer like that. But there are limits to what a good friend can do, especially when most of your trouble is at home. Lars is going to need a guardian angel to help get him out of his miserable situation...and one happens to be working in his school cafeteria. But what is haunting gentle, kind Kathryn, and why does it hurt her so much to see him bullied? There's a lot to unravel and unpack, and some of it is going to include a shocking revelation that will help explain some of the past. But is that going to be enough to prevent another disaster just as the town is coming back to life?From page one, the reader knows this story is going to be about bullying. As hard as it is to read about someone being bullied in school, it's even harder to read about someone being bullied at home. Your heart will break as you read how sweet and thoughtful Lars suffers through his mother's insults (and those of the people she brings home). However, seeing the Dalworths, especially River and Arielle, reach out inspires hope that Lars' situation will improve.One of the things I love about Brodey's writing is that she shows the shades of all of her characters, whether they're "good" or "bad". Some of the characters do stupid things, but she gives all of them the capacity to dig deep and understand why so that both they and the readers understand. Still, as someone points out, it takes a lot more than logical understanding to prevent your insecurities from being your own worst enemies, and sometimes that process takes time. Arguably, one of the questions lingering over the series is whether people have enough time to "grow up" before they do something they'll regret.The shocking revelation in this book helps shed some light on some of what happened in the first book. (Hint: if you liked Book Two and Six of the Harry Potter series, you'll definitely get a kick out of this one.) But ultimately, tragedy is a circumstance, and people still make choices. Brodey explains some of her characters' actions more deeply, but she doesn't excuse them.I found myself tearing up at the end when we finally get to meet the "desert star", and I'm pretty sure other readers will too. Recommended for fans of young adult paranormal.

In 1982, Michele Balistreri is an angry young police captain who holds bureaucracy, religion and politics in almost as much contempt as he holds himself. Good thing there's plenty of partying, alcohol and willing women to quiet his demons. However, when he mishandles the disappearance and murder of a beautiful young woman he'd had designs on, his life is changed forever. By 2005, he's living on anti-depressants, decaf coffee and rations out both his cigarettes and alcohol (and sex isn't something he wants to allow himself any longer either). He's a walking attempt at penitence with nothing to believe in. A slew of murdered young women gives him the will to do more than exist, but when the murders become too reminiscent of his earlier professional and moral failure, he has to ask himself how much the truth is worth.The Italy of 1982 is decadent, and you can feel how someone young and with something to prove would find that Italy, with its easy beauty and luxury, frustrating. It was however, filled with promise, even if Balistreri can't recognize it. The Italy of 2006 is just as corrupt but now it's stagnant. If Italy was fighting for its soul in 1982, by 2006 its fights are about power and the big ones are orchestrated. The Italy portrayed here is is decaying from the inside out, and now the foreign faces that fill it aren't tourists but the immigrants it both depends on and scorns. This novel is as much an examination of Italy and the people in it vying for power as it is a mystery/thriller.I figured out the villain (or is it villains?) and the dominant motivations pretty quickly, but those were the easy questions to answer. How it was done and everyone who was involved- and why- were the bigger mysteries, and watching Balistreri and his team unwind the puzzle was engrossing. Before I was halfway through I was unable to put it down and spent the better part of a day finishing it.Recommended for fans of international mysteries and thrillers.

Very pleased with the ease of set up and high quality performance of this printer. The printouts are professional-grade; if I used higher quality paper, I could pass them off as purchased worksheets or printed book pages.Even better, the cartridges this printer takes are not significantly more expensive than the cartridges used by black and white printers, which was my initial concern about this product.Highly recommended for anyone who needs a color printer.

I found this book difficult to get into; the author's style immediately gives away how personally attached she is to her subject matter, and some of her enthusiasm and effusiveness was jarring. However, once I hunkered down, I could understand her fascination. Most of the women she wrote about did lead fascinating careers and were, if not all revolutionary, definitely trailblazers.It shows how quickly things turn that while we are immersed in an almost survivalist "back to nature" phase in cooking and home decor, people aren't talking about the contributions of Patience Gray, who literally lived what she preached about the snout-to-tail philosophy from the 1960s onward. It's equally surprising that as we "look forward" to the post-apocalyptic world (of climate change) we don't reflect more on what architect Alison Smithson had to say about her period's visions of what the world would look like after The Bomb. The more things change...It is, perhaps, less surprising that we don't reflect on the genius that Muriel and Betty Box brought to the silver screen, in large part because the work they produced wasn't genius- just very successful at a time when women were not expected to know how to shape anything other than "women's" stories for women. And while there were representatives from "women's" fields here (Nancy Spain, the journalist who was assigned the women's page; Margery Fish, the garden writer; and Gray), the stories I found most engrossing were of Jacquetta Hawkes, the archaeologist and Rose Heilbron, the barrister and later judge. Honestly, I dreaded going into those chapters, but rather than being dry they painted a picture not only of the women who forged ahead in spite of opposition but also the fascinating times and societies they traveled in. (Heilbron's story was my favorite; it made me smile to think of a prim, educated woman calmly putting some of the organized crime members she defended firmly in their place.) Some of my enjoyment might also stem from the fact that Cooke's style is more serious and calmer in these chapters; I got the sense throughout that she was mimicking the writing style of each of her subjects.It's a worthy read for anyone interested in the history of Feminism and British History. However, twenty years after reading Susan Faludi's Backlash, I have to say that it's depressing that it would be such a surprise that women in the Fifties worked outside the home as much as they did or that they enjoyed the measure of success and influence that they did, prejudiced laws notwithstanding. Hopefully this will be a good reminder that the reason the Fifties media pushed the idea of the ideal housewife so hard was because women like this were putting the lie to it.

As much as this is the story of the 19th century Korean artist "Ohwon" (Jang Seung-ub), it is also the story of Korea's last years as an independent country. (Korea lost its independence in 1905 and did not regain it until the end of World War II.)As others have broken down, Jang Seung-ub was born a peasant. His life is saved as a young boy by a nobleman when he is being beaten by another peasant, but the nobleman can do only so much for him; his wife admonishes him to send the boy away...because they can't afford to feed him. Several years later, the two meet up again, and the nobleman arranges for him to be sent to gain artistic instruction from a respected master. This is the first time Jang will run into the confinements not only of the system of the arts but also most of Korea at that time: talent is not as valuable as connections.In fits and starts, the Korean establishment (as represented by a group of fellow artists who comment on his works throughout the film) comes to respect Jang's genius, but each snub pushes him further into his vices: drinking, disrespecting women and refusing to work. His most stable relationship is with a courtesan he rents a house with, but the woman who haunts him is the noble younger sister of the man who saved him. She, however, is untouchable, not only because of the class difference, but because of a congenital illness. It's fair to say that she was his idea of perfection, and when she dies he's plunged into another depression. When, years later, he meets a courtesan who looks exactly like her, he's quickly disillusioned to find that she's as coarse as the rest of her class.The woman he does truly love, the courtesan Mae-Hyang, is separated from him by religious persecution: she's Catholic, and after they meet Catholics are purged and persecuted. It's only toward the end of the story, when Korea is in such a state of decline that religious persecution is low on their list of priorities, that the two can meet again without fear. However, so much damage has been done to both Jang and Korea that any thought of permanence is doomed.As Jang's reputation spreads and Korea's politics decay, he (and Korean art in general) become more and more the solace for the Korean psyche. This is particularly painful to Jang when he is struggling to find his own vision and not simply copy old masters. For anyone who knows the history of this period, it's impossible not to hear an indictment of the intellectual culture of Korea, which rewarded mastery of Chinese Classics and considered any deviation from it heresy.Throughout the film, China and Japan struggle for dominance over Korea; we see this through not only the soldiers stomping through the scenes but also the people vying to own some of Jang's art. This is a reflection of the Korean nobility's struggle of ideas between a Reformist and Conservative vision, and to what extent foreign influence should be allowed. It becomes clear that the only thing authentically Korean is the voice of the artist- but an artist is as influenced by his times as anyone else.Highly recommended for those interested in Korean history and art.

I received a review copy in exchange for an honest review.Casey is in her early thirties, holed up in the mountains of New York State while she licks her wounds from the break up of her longtime relationship with Nick. Even in her sleepy campsite she can't help but hear about his debut novel and how it's taking the literary world by storm. She's closer to reconnecting with the self she lost in her twenties while she was nurturing his dreams, but that doesn't make his thanks to his new girlfriend any less stinging.In walks Ben, a camper in his late twenties that Casey knows she can't have but that she can't stop thinking about anyway. And who could? He's tall, dark-haired, handsome, kind, a great cook- and really into Casey. She soon realizes that she doesn't want to say no to a future with him, but what about his dreams?And really, what about hers? What I found most thought-provoking in this book was the implied question of whether dreams change. The younger Casey wanted to be a painter but shelved that ambition and replaced it with a more practical degree in Art History. So when she gets an unexpected opportunity to have a long-buried fantasy satisfied, why does she hesitate? Is she unworthy of the dream- or is the dream unworthy of her? And how many of her desires invite the same question?There are several graphic sex scenes in this novel, but everything goes toward the development of the relationship between Casey and Ben. The novel is very sensual even before the two meet: as I was reading, I felt myself transported to the lake, mountains, cabin and campsites. Brooks does an excellent describing not only the way a setting looks but how it feels. And not just settings: even though I'm an avowed tea drinker, I found myself craving a cup of very hot French-pressed coffee with a splash of cream, accompanied by an almond croissant with powdered sugar on top. Really, everything that Brooks described was mouthwatering- and not just the food.This was an enjoyable, quick but not-too-quick read. I would happily read more from Brooks (but I really hope she incorporates more food in future works).

I'm not one for coffee, but I like a little kick of energy in the morning and afternoon. Matcha tea lattes fit that bill perfectly, but they get to be ridiculously expensive if you buy them in cafes.Kazu's matcha tea mixes very well (as with most such powders, it's better diluted with a little warm water first) and one and a half teaspoons is perfectly complemented by a half teaspoon of sugar. This is very good with either steamed or iced milk.This also works well for baking, although that's more of an acquired taste.

Rosie "Aunty" Lee is a wealthy widow who keeps herself occupied by running a catering business. Even indulging her lifelong love of cooking isn't enough to keep her out of trouble- although when someone is killed at one of the function she's catering, it's hard to blame her.The pat answer for why Mabel Sung and her sickly son Leonard ended up dead is murder-suicide, but Aunty Lee isn't having any of that. Too bad, because the next easiest answer is that one of her specialties poisoned him, and she knows that isn't true either. And what does this have to do with the young Chinese national who just committed suicide, the boyfriend who is presumed dead and the house that Mabel Sung constructed shortly before her death?It always strikes me as odd that the word "cozy" is applied to something that involves murder; doubly odd here that it will also apply to one of the darkest forms of human trafficking. You might find yourself giggling at some of Aunty Lee's (contrived) outbursts, but you'll also find yourself genuinely disturbed by what you read.Aunty Lee is not a perfect detective, and that's part of her charm. The story doesn't suffer from an overuse of red herrings, but Aunty Lee's ability to read people works only up to a point. However, her instinct that something doesn't quite fit and her determination to fully understand something more than makes up for it. So, too, does the fact that she's ultimately a good judge of characters, and even the most irritating of the people she keeps around end up having more to them than might be evident at first.Highly recommended for fans of mysteries- and food.

This was not predictable, but that was due in part to the number of red herrings and detours thrown into the story. Even the big angle hinted at on the cover and in the promo materials is meant to throw you off. There's a point at which that can come off as clever, but at 407 pages, it's more irritating that anything else.Mongo the hit man thinks he's very smart, good looking and suave. He may very well be one of the smartest people he's ever met- and that only highlights that he needed to get out more. He doesn't read as a sociopath as much as he does a sophomoric loser who's gotten lucky enough times that he now believes his own PR. Detective Jeb Barker has a lower estimation of himself, but that doesn't keep him from underestimating the importance of politics and optics, especially when you're dealing with a high profile case like the murder of a Hollywood starlet. Both of them are going to trip themselves up, but one of them is going to do a better (or worse) job of it.Mysteries have a certain rhythm to them, and cops and detectives should be approaching their cases in a no-nonsense way if it's going to come off as at all believable. This does that. However, even within those parameters, this comes off as stilted, and without too many dialogue tags it's difficult to tell who's speaking at times. And some of the language just doesn't work in some places and made me think that I was reading something that might be better set in the Fifties than in the 21st century. (What guy describes two topless women as "terrific broads" in this day and age?) The expository dialogue also got to be a little bit much, and given that much of it was part of the red herrings, annoying.Finally, the loose ends, as someone mentioned, are frustrating, particularly the lack of explanation for a very important "tip" that came through early on.Not the worst mystery I've ever read, but definitely one that could have been tightened up more.

If you think you're going to read a book like this and come away with a better understanding of any candidate's policy on anything, you're mistaken. This is all political calculation with a big dose of gossip and some armchair psychoanalysis. Once you accept that, you can enjoy the ride.This book lacks the fun factor of Game Change in part because the 2012 campaign wasn't nearly as much of a circus as the 2008 one. The Republican field was filled with unstable lunatics (calling the candidacy for Romney early on was easy) but, obviously, the Democrat's nominee was known from the get-go. And while the Obamans may have been as dysfunctional as any political operation, that's just not the same thing as John Edwards trying to get past his own mistakes and Hillary Clinton trying to overcome her reputation (and establishment sexism). On the GOP side, while Bachmann,Gingrich, Cain and Perry provided plenty of amusing and cringe-worthy episodes, they were never nearly as important as the star of 2008's GOP debacle, Sarah Palin. Oddly, there was almost nothing about Ron Paul, arguably the wackiest of all of the candidates.People who watched the Republican presidential field closely might be surprised by how many, well, sane and sagacious characters there were: Haley Barbour, Mitch Daniels and Jeb Bush most prominent among them. All of them had reasons to stay out of the race and away from the national stage, but they saw pretty clearly on that Mitt was a weak candidate who would create a vacuum that would invite a freak show.The candidate that many thought had the best chance: Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey. Although he flirted with the idea for a few weeks, ultimately he decided that his bona fides weren't strong enough. Once he made his decision to stay out, putting his clout behind Mitt was the obvious choice. While many thought he would make a strong candidate for VP, the vetting process dashed that notion pretty decisively. Suggestion: don't bet on Christie in 2016 (even if he clears BridgeGate). Who else will you probably not see again? Jon Huntsman, the ostensibly reasonable and moderate candidate who turned out to be not nearly as wealthy or principled as his public image led observers to believe.The story presented here is that Romney lost because he refused to apologize even when he knew he had made a mistake and because he was so desperate to keep the conservative base that he wouldn't take on obviously offensive positions that he didn't agree with (e.g., Rush Limbaugh's insults to Sandra Fluke). While I agree that these were mistakes, I think it's odd that they didn't speak to the other obvious observation about the Romney candidacy: he lied and frequently, and his statements such as the infamous 47 Percent remark highlighted the electorate's worst fears that he was a plutocrat who didn't understand middle- or lower-economic-classes. (His team's explanations for why they lost only seemed to confirm those fears.)Is that a lot of Romney? Yes- and perhaps it's even clearer why the book lacked the fun factor of Game Change.Recommended for political news junkies who aren't interested in policy.

I might not have been the best person to read this; a family member of mine was stationed in Mali during the coup- for the Peace Corps. Obviously, I'd been following the developments pretty closely, and I had a good source to check in with after I read this book. So I can confidently report that Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb was not a feint and no one was kidnapped from the Peace Corps in Mali. And while there was some corruption, a drug ring leading to Al Qaeda is highly unlikely. What I'm more likely to find plausible are the tales of inter-departmental infighting in the US, and that the person trying to control everything would be a fish-out-of-water academic works too. (The wink in the last chapter about just who might be running back channel operations is maybe a little much, but this is fiction and that was fun.)My bigger gripes are about the writing style, some of which I found plodding and overly declarative, and at times I had trouble telling who was speaking. For whatever reason, that was more of a problem in the task force and departmental meetings; outsiders- and particularly the Malians- were more enjoyable to follow. In spite of the awkwardness, the author was able to convey the personalities of the characters and I could easily imagine the scenes.All in all, recommended with some reservations for fans of political thrillers.

Disclosure: I received a free copy in exchange for an honest review. This did not bias my review at all.I laughed and cried while reading this novella. Helen's a young woman who's keeping it together for the sake of her son in spite of her dysfunctional parent, failed marriage, teeth-gritting job and compromised health. The Guy Who Got Away is the perfect salve for her wounds- unless being selfish isn't something people outgrow. So what does she need? I'm not going to give it away, but it's literally staring her in the face. Watching her realize that was delicious.Recommended for fans of chick lit.

Semya Slotin is brilliant, loyal and brave (or is it reckless?). Hyper-competent and self-sufficient, she'd get through life just fine with her best friend/partner-in-crime Polliannah Koch. But she doesn't have to; the perfect man for her is out there, and his name is Vincent Mallory Edgerton.Vincent is also smart, loyal and brave, but just as cocky (being born into a loving, uber-privileged family can do that to a guy). But his family does try to give back, hence the creation of FREGG, a secret crime fighting organization that doesn't answer to any government but occasionally gets tapped on the shoulder by one. Vincent is the second generation and one of their best assets...so it takes something as serious as an attempted hit on him to make his superiors (including his father) put him on a deep undercover assignment. Vincent is pretty sure the next two years are going to be hell- until tying up some loose ends puts him directly into a beautiful detective's path. Just one problem: the gorgeous woman who's seemingly made for him is related to the people who put the hit on him. Make that two problems: she doesn't know. One more: he can't tell her.Think I just gave away the plot of the book? That's just the sideshow; the real work is tracking down a missing person, and that investigation quickly reveals something much more nefarious. Good thing Vincent is so experienced...so how come Semya keeps getting the scoop first?I loved this; fast-paced, international reach, and a case that had personal meaning for the detectives (and an issue that's shockingly prevalent across the world). Semya shows real vulnerability for the first time in this series; she's earned the right. (But even at her most vulnerable, she still manages to do some damage...) But I still have questions: Why is Semya's adoptive mother sniping at Vincent's father, and why did Semya's biological mother go to him before Semya was born? How come her biological father was never told about her? What isn't Vincent's father telling us? Finally, where is Vincent now? I am waiting impatiently for the next book to answer those questions!Recommended for lovers of mystery and romantic suspense

This book follows Dr. KittyCat, a veterinarian, as she tends to assorted patients with the assistance of her helper, Peanut, the mouse. The focus is a puppy that has injured her leg. The artwork features black and white photographs of real animals accented by ink illustrations and details. It is hard to resist the photos of baby animals but the ink accents the fact they are black and white. The pinkish mauve ink is dull and the overall effect is more cheap than charming., Add to that a story that is equally dull. There is a learning opportunity to here but this book is significantly less fun that it should be.

With a graceful shape and a Christmas tree clapper , this silver bell makes a lovely addition to the tree. Engraved with the year, it hangs from a bright red ribbon. The clapper makes a nice clear sound. Overall this is an attractive ornament with classic holiday beauty.

This is a fun match game that includes some nice quality cards. The object of the game is to collect the most animal cards by matching colors and building trains. the animals are a big attraction and the cards are thick and large. Kids can play alone but parents will have fun joining in. A cute way to pass the time.

This is a saccharin exercise in self indulgence. There is nothing new here, it is just a rehash of the same stuff that filled her other books. I found the authors mutual love fest inane and boring. the book itself is a small hard covered tome containing 236  pages not counting the promotional material in the back or the blank pages used for notes. I was hoping for some inspiration but  was disappointed. Nothing new here and even worse nothing relevant. Life may love this book but I don't. Pass.

This lovely ballerina is graceful and beautiful. The picture does not do her justice.  She evokes my childhood memories of annual Christmas treks to Radio city Music Hall to see the Nutcracker Suite. she is a stunning addition to the tree and would also delight any fan of the ballet. She will be cherished as an ornament and a reminder of wonderful holidays past.

These are ideal if you work in a lab or deal with expensive or sensitive equipment. Highly absorbent, they are both lint and static free. My office has a large IT room with expensive electronics. These are indispensable .  While probably more than the average household can use, the 12"x 12" wipes  are durable and protective.

CoQ10 is an all around antioxidant believed to support cardiovascular function. This version by Viva Labs contains a balck pepper extract which is supposed to improve absorption. The small gel caps are easy to swallow and I've experienced no unpleasant side effects. I do't have any conditions so it is hard to gauge the efficacy of these tablets. Perhaps the fact that I've developed no problems is a tribute to their effectiveness.  viva Labs is a reliable company and I've been, thus far, pleased with their products. If you are interested in trying CoQ10, this is a good place to start. Consult with your doctor if you are on any medications.

To paraphrase Ronald Reagan, when it comes to dog food, don't trust and be sure to verify. While my brother is recovering from surgery I am caring for his dogs. Both have packed on the pounds and could afford to lose some weight. to that end, I thought this food might be a tasty solution. The copy indicated that chicken was the first ingredient. It is not. Corn is. And while no doubt tasty and filling, it provides minimal nutritional value. Chicken is the third ingredient. That being said the low odor kibble is just under 3/4 of an inch and is easy for both the  ninety pound shepherd and the seventy pound chow to handle. They seemed to like it although they didn't dive into it with the same gusto they do with Fromm's or Merrick's.I have yet to observe any negative side effects from their consumption. It is still to early to tell what if any impact it will have on their weight.While the thrity pound bag is convenient for multi-dog households, unlike the easy open bags I've come to expect with premium foods, this one is pasted shut.Good nutrition is key to good health. While this corn based kibble is appealing to the dogs, there are superior nutritional choices available.

These gummies are a great way for people who can't or do't like to swallow to get a dose of vitamins. One serving consists of two gummies. Each serving has 20 calories and 4 carbs. The fruity flavor is pleasant and palatable. The taste is described as "orange punch". I didn't detect much orange but did recognize the fruity punch.  They have no bitter after taste and provide a decent dosage of vitamins. since they look and taste like candy, keep out of children's reach. They do contain fish oil the expiration date on my bottle is 11/16.

With the right program, even an amateur can create a polished production. This software offers a generous menu of features including live screen capture and auto ducking. I had no problems loading it but found it slow at times. Free training is available for thirty days. It is worthwhile, especially for amateurs and I do wish it was free for the life of the software. Although I am far from mastering all of its features, it does have plenty to inspire. It is a good program for folks with a working knowledge of editing software.

Stress can take a toll on physical and mental health, relationships and performance. Nicely written, this book is a gentle guide to alleviating stress by incorporating simple techniques. Experienced meditators will be familiar with many of the exercises. but lest you fear this is packed with airy fairy new agey silliness, it is not. It is grounded and although there are most definitely touches of Buddhist philosophy, it is not trying to sell you on any particular dogma. there is a good section on non-violent communication and the author demonstrates a good understanding of the challenges confronting the average person. I especially liked the inclusion of an index of the meditations and exercises. This is an easy way to learn how to defuse stress before it defuses you.

This is a simple heart with the word love written in golden script. a small oen heart dangles from the top . It is accented with a red ribbon and hangs from a gold tassel. It is simple expression but still quite appealing. It is about 3.5 inches high. this is the type of ornament that can be used for many occasions including valentine's Day. It doesn't scream Christmas although the sentiment is certainly appropriate.If the ornament happens to break you can find some consolation in the Lenox Lifetime Breakage Replacement Program. In the event you break a piece, they will replace it, if it is  in stock, at 50% off the current suggested retail price. You are still responsible for shipping, handling and taxes and you must register the pieces. the program is available as long as you own the object.

Clearing bathroom clutter is always a plus and this product succeeds in doing that. It may be affixed to the wall  with adhesive tape or screwed in. I opted for sticking it as I prefer not to mar the shower tiles (Also the hardware is not included. there is a hardware checklist though..) So far the tape has held but  time, moisture and weight may take a toll. Unfortunately, it has  a cheap appearance that disappoints. The dispensers need to be rinsed and primed before using. Even then thick and creamy items such as conditioner still tend to jam. So it is probably wiser to put more fluid items like liquid soap and shampoo in the dispensers.The caddy itself has a nice shelf and razor storage. The hooks are convenient and there is a small towel bar. I do like the concept but am unimpressed with the overall execution.

Life is too short to drink bad wine and this sturdy tote will insure you get it to where you are going. Standing thirteen inches tall with a 4.5 inch diameter, it should accommodate most wine bottles. It is well insulated and the zip top functions smoothly. there is an adjustable strap for easy carrying. I loved the red plaid pattern. It is stylish and attractive. But probably the most thoughtful element is the inclusion of a corkscrew/bottle opener/foil cutter with its own integrated carrying pocket on the outside of the tote. How often have you reached your romantic in the middle of nowhere picnic location only to realize you've left the corkscrew at home? The corkscrew itself is solidly made of steel. It is initially a bit stiff but i imagine it will loosen up over time with use. Nicely designed this is an essential of any wine loving friend. It would also provide a creative wrapping for a gift of wine.A complimentary/discounted product was received for the purpose of testing, evaluation and review.

I travel frequently for business and these packing cubes are wonderful. Made from durable,moisture and scratch material, they are puncture proof. the lid is clear letting you see clearly. The zippers run smoothly without snagging. The pack of three comes in your choice of color: gray, midnight blue or red. I got the red and it is a beautiful, strong vivid shade. The three sizes should meet most packing needs. when not on the road, these serve well as home storage. I am very pleased with this set.A complimentary/discounted prouct was provided for the purposes of testing and review.

This feature laden program is great for pros but a bit more challenging for amateurs like me. Installation was hassle free and there are, quite frankly, almost too many options. It is easy to become overwhelmed. The feature I use most is the auto ducking which suppresses background noise so narration and dialogue come through . The free training is helpful but I think they should provide it for the life of the product, not just thirty days. Unless you are a pro, it is unlikely that you will master all the ins and outs in thirty days. That being said, this is a comprehensive program especially beneficial where photography is either a profession or a passion.

Music narrates the story of Frankie Presto, a brilliant musician. Surviving a precarious early life, he comes to the states with the secrets of his success, a guitar and six magic strings. Life like music consists of sweet and sour notes,sharps and flats. Frankie finds fame and fortune , love and hate, forgiveness and redemption. Interspersed are the musings of famous musicians inspired by Frankie and his mystical gifts.I am somewhat mixed on this book. On one hand, it is easy to become engaged with Frankie and his odyssey. On the other it was long and choppy, with the narration jumping around. There are too many characters. The author is most definitely a music lover but the namedropping got tiresome. Physically the  book itself is relatively small (5.2 " x 7.2") and thick with deckle edges and 466 pages.. I found it clumsy to handle. It is, essentially, a sweet story about the music of life. .

who says trash bags have to be ugly? the colors are lovely pastels. green, blue and pink they are perfect for the office or bedroom as well as the kitchen or bath. The material is thin but strong. I experienced no leakage from wet coffee grounds but use caution with sharp objects. They will penetrate the material. They are nine gallon bags so they are great for lower capacity situations. Overall, a colorful solution.A discounted product was provided in exchange for evaluation and review.

This kit capitalizes on the popular 3D trend. It contains five 3 D drawing pens, a plastic sheet, a spotlight that requires AAA batteries that are not included, a guidebook, building accessories. It is fussier than I anticipated and the ink has an unpleasant chemical odor. I was expecting five different colors but received two greens, two reds and a yellow. The pens are not refillable and do not draw in the air. The plastic needs to be cured by shining the uv light on them. Unfortunately, it takes an inordinate amount of time to fully dry. But it would have been worth it if the end result was impressive. It wasn't. I imagine with patience and practice it would get better. But unfortunately it was smelly, messy and ultimately disappointing. I do like the concept but the execution was far from stellar.

Both my mother and my brother have been directed by their physicians to take vitamin D. Since her stroke my mother has difficulty swallowing and my brother just hates to swallow pills. these chewables are the solution. Organic and vegan they contain 2000 IUs of D3 along with both a mushroom blend including reishi, shitake and maitake and an organic food blend with flax, broccoli, cauliflower, carrot and spinach. It has a fairly palatable berry flavor. While the taste lingers it doesn't have the artificial and unpleasant after tones that accompany artificial flavors and sweeteners. Garden of Life is a company I've relied on especially for their digestive enzymes. this is a good way for those who can't or prefer not to swallow supplements.

I love almond milk but hate paying supermarket prices for it. I also like to know exactly what is going into it. these nut bags are excellent. The material is firm, the mesh is fine and they are reusable. Multipurpose, they can also be used for yogurt and cheese as well as cold brew coffee. they are food grade certified and BHA free. You can download a free ebook from the manufacturer's website. I am impressed with the quality of these bags and am quickly finding the indispensable.A complimentary or discounted product was provided in exchange for an objective review.

I received a single snug fitting cap in black. It came packaged in a thoughtful zipped plastic bag. The cap is very snug and might be too small for someone with a very large cranium or really big hair. that being said, once on it stayed. The ear pockets are comfortable. Made of silicone, this cap is strong and durable. It has a neutral unisex design making it ideal for men or women.I received a complimentary or discounted product in exchange for an unbiased review.

This fractionated coconut oil is superb. Packaged in an amber bottle, it absorbs quickly. I use it to make a hair conditioner/scalp tonic by combining with essential oils. It has no odor and leaves no greasy residue. My mother has very dry skin but is sensitive to fragrances and chemicals. This product is a wonderful moisturizer, imparting softness without irritation or unwanted fragrances or additives.  A free ebook with tips for use and recipes is available to download from the manufacturer's website.  If you are looking for a natural multi-purpose oil with a long shelf life, this one should exceed expectations.I received a complimentary/disconted product in exchange for an impartial review.

I love the graceful shape of the pendant. A smidge over one inch long, it is attractive without being gaudy. There are five small blue and five small champagne stones with smaller white diamonds dotting the twists.  The shimmer is subtle; you won't be blinded with bling but there is definitely some sparkle. The stones are natural and untreated. The silver chain is adequate, a tad thin with a much appreciated lobster claw clasp. It is double boxed for impressive presentation. This is an attractive elegant piece with an interesting shape and color combination.

this book is delicious in appearance and in contents. Hard covered it features beautiful colored photographs  of each recipe. the writing is good and the directions are easy to follow. Even the most healthy conscious, occasionally craves dessert. There is a good and interesting assortment here including a bacon and brew muffin that uses bacon and beer, hummingbird mini bundt cakes, raspberry spice buns,  a goodly assortment of cookies, pies, puddings, frozen desserts and cookies. There are no exotic ingredients. Both the nutritional information and the amount of time needed, hands on and total needed, are provided.But lo-cal  may not necessarily translate into healthy. I was a bit surprised by her vigorous defense of Cool Whip Lite as an ingredient. Yes it cuts calories and fat content and is addictively sweet and creamy. but it also contains high fructose corn syrup and hydrogenated vegetable oil  along with artificial flavoring xanthan and guar gums, pollysorbate 60, sorbitan monsterate and sodium polyphoshates. It is not used in all the recipes but a number including some pies, cheesecakes and eclair filling.  Not saying that it will kill you but I would rather a smaller serving with natural ingredients than a chemically induced dessert, no matter how delicious.That being said, this is an attractive book that delivers great flavor without breaking the calorie bank.

Made from sunflower seeds, this is a pleasingly smooth spread. It has a mild but distinctive flavor and is a tad sweet. It looks like peanut butter and spreads easily.The on the go packets are a convenient way to enjoy a healthy snack on the road. There is a free downloadable recipe book on the manufacturer's website that contains some good recipes. While this is a terrific product for those with nut allergies, it is tasty enough to be enjoyed by virtually anyone.

I've always been a light sleeper.My sensitivity to light and sound are exacerbated by frequent travel and irregular hours. This terrific sleep mask is extremely comfortable. Lightweight, it has enough padding to and softness to feel great without adding weight or heat. There are recesses for the eyes and a contoured nose. The elastic fits without digging in or tearing your hair. It effectively blocks light in all positions. this set comes with a set of standard issue orange foam ear plugs. While they don't completely mute all sound, they dull it sufficiently. A complimentary ebook containing tips and suggestions about getting a good night's sleep may be downloaded from the manufacturer's website.  I am delighted with this product. It is small and light enough to slip in a briefcase or bag. I use it at night, for naps and to enhance my meditation practice.I received a complimentary or discounted product in exchange for an objective review.

These wool balls are a boon to those with allergies or perfume sensitivities. Six of the balls come packaged in a cute drawstring bag. Tossed in the dryer they leave items soft and fluffy without cloying fragrances or greasy build up in dryers. I was impressed with their performance. My mother has extremely dry skin and multiple chemical sensitivities. The wool balls left the clothes delightfully soft but free of any irritants.. The balls are reusable and odor free.  The bag can be hung in the laundry room making this a convenient and economical item.I received a complimentary product in exchange for an objective review.

This ornament captures Mickey's gleeful anticipation as he heads off for some winter fun. Made of porcelain, it is carefully painted. The red sweater and green scarf evoke the holidays while the gold touches add a touch of luxury., Mickey's grin is infectious. This is a fun ornament that will be cherished by Disney fans.

Although you may be tempted to give these the brush off after encountering the rather pungent PU odor, give them a chance. I found the odor dissipated quickly after opening and shampooing the brushes. The range of ten brushes is good, you will have one that will work for just about every make up need. the brushes are attractive with a kabuki style. The handles are wood in an aluminum tube. One of mine was slightly bent but it did not affect usage. The brushes themselves are quite soft and I observed no shedding. When a Mormon leader is found murder, shocking secrets are revealed. these secrets challenge the judgmental and unforgiving perceptions of the insular Mormon community and sends busybody housefrau Linda bumbling into the police investigation. Linda, of course, has many issues of her own. Married to the long suffering and indulgent Kurt, she is suffering her first tastes of empty nest syndrome. Nosy and gossipy, she uses her position to snoop. But not all trespasses are forgiven and some are life threatening.I did not care for this book. The writing is sophomoric and the chattiness detracts from the little suspense. Linda is one of the most annoying characters I've ever encountered. She lives a fifties lifestyle while espousing progressive positions that  wildly diverge from her conservative community's stated values. She , of course, is compassionate and understanding when it comes to gay and transgender issues. What could have been an intelligent examination of how religious institutions grapple with changing social mores seemed more like a cheap attempt to exploit hot button issues. I am not a Mormon and cannot speak to either their theology or practices. However, the reactionary, paternalistic, judgmental group here only begs the question why anyhone wold would voluntarily stay in such a church. To the author's credit, there were a few twists among all the descriptions of what people were eating. but this is not a book I could, in good conscience, recommend.

this is a very cute kitty. Soft, plush and completely huggable, she is activated by pushing her paws or the plastic heart on her chest. She sings and speaks short phrases in English and Spanish. The music and voice are cheerful and the volume is adjustable. the Spanish portions are a bit spare but this is more a toy than a teacher. Still it is a fun introduction. Kira is adorable. She is gold with black spots and has a sweet phase. I am not sure what type of cat--leopard? bengal? oncilla? It doesn't really matter because she is delightful. The three required AA batteries are included, gracias. Spot clean only.

this book will help students prepare for the TEAS V test. It is nicely organized opening with diagnostic tests.Math, science, reading and grammar are each given separate sections. These sections are divided into  subsections,namely learn, strategize, apply, guided practice, independent practice and "rekap", a checklist that highlights the main points of each section. My favorite portion of this book is the "Kapsnap" at the end. This section summarizes al the skills, steps, strategies and equations presented in the earlier text. It is a fast refresh and very helpful.  There are some diagrams and overall, the book provides an adequate review of the subjects. it is a good refresher and a great adjunct to lessons or classes.

It seems that we have more devices than charges and they all need charging at the same time. These colorful little charges work as expected. They charge efficiently and are cheerful in appearance. This is a convenient set for travel. It includes an eye mask, ear plugs and an inflatable pillow. the mask and the pillow are made of a thin, somewhat coarse velveteen material.Both had a strong plastic odor. I found that hand washing with Woolite and a few drops of fabric softener eliminated the odor and softened the fabric. (Dry flat. These items should not be machine washed or dried, ironed or bleached.) The mask is thin with no recesses for the eyes. However, it was comfortable and blocked the light. It has an elastic band which does stretch however if you have a large head or very big hair, it may be too snug. The pillow inflated without issue and was surprisingly comfortable. I though t it looked small but it curved around my neck providing comfort and support. The ear plugs are the standard orange, relatively soft and smooth. They do dull outside noise.This is not a bad set for the price. I would have preferred more padding in the mask and softer material. But all the pieces function well making this a worthwhile set for travel or home.I received a complimentary or discounted product in exchange for an objective review.

The set includes all the knives for your everyday kitchen tasks plus a peeler, scissors, and a sharpening steel.  The quality is amazing as well.  A set like this could be a great wedding or anniversary gift, but I purchased my set for myself!!  I love it and I love the way it looks on my counter!I received this item at a discount in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

The chains are a perfect length for a younger girl and they are easy for them to put on and take off!  What little girl doesn't love pink too?? It is a soft plushy fur on one side, and a lambswool type fabric on the other.  I had to chase my critters off of it in order to take the video of it!  They are happier to sleep on this mat instead of laying on the furniture!!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

This is a fantastic little device!  When you receive it, it pairs easily with your phone and once paired, it can be plugged into any aux outlet such as your car stereo, in your boat, your home stereo, etc and it will play music through your system.  It also allows you to take phone calls through the receiver and they are hands free as well!  The receiver comes with instructions and a USB charging cord.  I have been using it daily in my car and I love it!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

I love this product and uses it with my other Retseliney acne products.  I use this moisturizer after the face wash to eliminate any drying out of my skin.  I have adult acne, but dry skin, it's a weird combination but the Retseliney products get rid of the acne and keep my skin moisturized!  These products all smell fresh and are super easy to use!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

This tweezer set really is the only set you'll ever need!  It has three tweezers with three different tips, straight, pointed, and slant.  The tweezers come with a faux leather case so you can take them along in your purse or travel bag.  They are very well made and are not only for home use, but can also be used in the salon.  I tend to lose single tweezers so having a set like this is perfect for me!!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

So I'm sure if you're reading this, you're skeptical like I was, but this stuff really does what it says.  The one important part of the product is that it actually draws out the bacteria that will cause odor.  You may think that this product is silly, or something you don't need, but trust me, if nothing else, prevention is golden!  It is hard to spray if you can't see what you're doing, but I found that if I spray it on a washcloth or even paper towel, you have much more accuracy in placement.  It is super easy to rinse off, and it really does freshen for a couple days before you need to re-apply.  I am a believer, and you will be too!!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

These bags are great quality and are so useful!  I make jewelry and sending things to people in these classy little bags really makes people happy to receive them.  They have drawstrings to pull the top together so they work great for giving small gifts too.  They would make great favor bags at showers, weddings, or birthday parties too!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

I have tried various eye firming creams, but I have to say I like Retseliney's line of products the best!  The firming cream works quickly in plumping your skin and tightening the crows feet around your eyes.  It also is amazing on bags under your eyes.  When you apply it to your eye bags, they lighten, tighten, and become almost invisible.  The cream smells nice too.  It has a light fresh scent and I love that I only have to use a little bit each time.  It absorbs quickly and doesn't leave your skin greasy!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

These Leis are so cute and are perfect for our friend's upcoming summer in winter party!  The flowers are high quality and very colorful!  They are threaded on the leis alternating with long beads.  I can't wait to wear them and dream of warm weather!! They are guaranteed to be a hit with kids as well, weather at a birthday party, or in a dress up box!  They are made well and will withstand playtime!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

These bags are awesome!  We live about 45 minutes from our closest Cosco, and love shopping there.  I am so happy to have these bags, it's so much easier using them instead of having to take a cooler whenever we go.  They are large enough that you can put a large quantity of meat or frozen items, or even hot items in them and they stay cold or hot!  You receive 5 bags and they don't take up much room, so you can take them wherever you go so they are ready to use!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

I have used dry shampoo in the past and was never really happy with the brands I'd tried.  I was anxious to try this set by Luseta.  I like to sleep as long as possible in the mornings, so I don't always have time to wash my hair in the morning before work.  I tried this product a few days and I'm happy to report that it works very well!  It is amazingly weightless, something other products I'd tried weren't.  It is easy to use, you just spray it on and style.  It has a light lavender scent.  i did not know there was dry conditioner, so that was a huge bonus for me!!  It also has a light lavender scent.  It can be used to add shine and smooth out flyaways or frizzies.  I take the conditioner spray to work and when it is dry inside, I am able to calm my hair frizz down!!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

This is an amazing moisturizing oil! I originally purchased it thinking I would use it on my skin after showering now that winter is right around the corner.  And, I did, and it is amazing!  However, it can also be used in your hair!  I have fairly long hair that frizzes easily.  I use a few drops of the oilve and jojoba oil and run it through my hair and the frizz is gone!!  The oil smells great, it has a light, fresh scent that isn't heavily perfumed like so many other body oils.  I do use it after I shower and it absorbs quickly and leaves my skin soft and smooth!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

These bat wall decorations are fabulous!  They come with two sided tape circles so you can easily stick them wherever you want!  The wings can be bent so they look like they are flying away.  The quality is nice, they are made of a lightweight plastic.  They are easy to place and the stickers stick pretty much anywhere.  I have a couple on my bathroom mirror, and even the steam from showering doesn't make them unstick!!I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

These reusable k-cups are fantastic.  My mother has a Keurig 2.0 and I purchased these cups for her.  She loves the machine, but really wanted to save money by not always needing to buy Keurig branded cups.  This allows her to use her own coffee and she can choose how weak or strong she wants it to be.  They have hinged tops and they are super easy to clean.  She just rinses them out and lets them dry on her dish drainer until she needs them again!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

"God's Kingdom" is my introduction to the works of Howard Frank Mosher. I found the collection of short stories about the same family in the North East Kingdom of Vermont very well-written and for the most part entertaining and thoughtful by turns. In many ways the collection reminded me of a great favourite, "Olive Kitteridge," but the latter was more engaging as I felt a connection to the often unlikeable Olive that I did not experience with Mosher' s Jim Kinneson. With the exception of the first story, "Blooded," Jim just did not come to life for me again until the final story, "God's Kingdom". So often to me he seemed a detached observer in a family of eccentrics. The most vivid characters are the minor ones, with less emphasis on Jim, his father, and even his grandfather, who was so engaging in "Blooded". There are many passages dealing with the near mythic character of Pliny Templeton, who was a former slave and connection to the areas abolitionist past. The greatest strength of the collection is the beautifully writing that takes the reader deep into  the heart of nature. It is lyrical writing, a celebration of the natural world, evoking a place that has always been special. The best people are those in awe of nature, the worst are those who fail to feel the magic of place.

I found "Bradstreet Gate" to be a major disappointment, with unlikable characters meandering through the years with no real point. I found myself skimming to the middle when I finally gave up and knew I had no interest in continuing. This is one of those novels where many will praise it highly and others will struggle to finish it. I really cannot recommend it.

A wonderful assortment of Swiss made milk chocolate arrives in a beautiful presentation box suitable for gift giving without additional wrapping. There is a small booklet attached to the ribbon on the box that has a picture of the individual chocolates with a brief description of the filling. I sampled one of the hazelnut filled pieces and it was creamy with a nice strong nutty flavor. One of the caramel filled pieces was equally creamy but the caramel flavor was more subtle. The pieces are small, in that you can eat a chocolate in one or two bites. Here in America we are more accustomed to larger pieces, but this assortment might be a good choice for those who love chocolate but need to limit the amount they eat. I would love to try this in dark chocolate!

I have been a fan of football since high school when my family gathered in front of the television every Saturday to watch Notre Dame play. Later, I became a fan of professional football, and, as has been the case with many, slowly started to come to the realization that many retired players were starting to age mentally much faster than men in the general population who had never played the sport. As a fan of the game, at first I did not know what to believe, as the NFL had doctors who claimed that the alarming reports coming from researchers outside the football community regarding concussions were untrue.A few years ago, I watched a PBS report on the program "Frontline" that went a long way toward making me a believer that concussions were the cause of the horrific mental problems experienced by former NFL players. It was my introduction to Bennett Omalu, the pathologist who made the breakthrough discoveries that struck fear into the hearts of two NFL commissioners and others at the highest levels of the game. Doctor Omalu' s findings on the physical signs of repeated brain trauma began when he studied the brain of former Steeler player Mike Webster, who had died of a heart attack after several years of exhibiting bizarre and often violent behaviour. The brains of other dead NFL players exhibited the same findings, and the conclusion was that these injuries were the result of repeated concussions the players had experienced in their professional careers."Concussion" is in some ways a memoir of Dr Omalu, his childhood and youth in Nigeria, Africa, and his education and career in America, working in the office of the Pittsburgh Medical Examiner. If your interest in the subject of concussions and the NFL is your primary reason for reading the book, you might find yourself skimming the details of the doctor's life. But I think that would be a mistake, as those parts are interesting on their own, but also because they illustrate or of the reasons many had difficulty accepting Omalu' s findings -- a built in racial or cultural bias against an outsider who could be frankly annoying in his defense of his findings. It took the doctor quite a bit of time to understand the place of football in American culture and to grasp the fact that the NFL was not going to embrace his discovery.The author does an excellent job of relating the various points if view regarding this important topic...how the NFL came to be seen in a similar light to Big Tobacco in its denial of medical evidence; how Omalu' s lack of understanding of American culture and his race made him less credible to many even though he possessed multiple college degrees; and the tragic stories of ruined players told by their survivors. I highly recommend this book for those interested in this subject and how the persistence of a few dedicated researchers helped current and future generations of players fight the powerful NFL. I was less interested in the story of the fall of Omalu' s mentor at the M.E.'s office and I also felt that the doctor himself came off as a much more sympathetic character in the "Frontline" program than he does at times in the book. But, I certainly understand his frustration and his bewilderment over being rejected many times for reasons that had nothin to do with his expertise.

This utterly delightful Christmas cup by Lenox is going to be my special little mug for hot chocolate or tea during the holidays. No, I don't know if the whimsical little pocket on the front actually has a function, but I am treating it as a decoration. The pocket is low enough on the cup that a left handed person can use it just as easily as a right handed individual --- the pocket does not interfere with drinking out of the cup. My fingers are average and I did not have any trouble slipping them through the handle. Since I do not have a dish washer I cannot comment on care other than to say the cup washed and air dried beautifully in a dish drainer. The companion pieces are available on Amazon, and I think they would make a beautiful Christmas tablescape. The cup arrives in a colourful holiday gift box. While 8 or 12 would make a wonderful present for someone who does quite a bit of entertaining, two would make a nice gift for a couple, or one for an individual. The original review was for a single cup that had a pocket on the side, not for the cups pictured.

MS Fiorato' s novel provides a backstory to Shakespeare's play "Much Ado About Nothing," giving the reader the beginning of the love match of Beatrice and Benedick. For those who love the play, it is a rare treat. It is also a treat for those of us who are not regular readers of the Bard of Avon. I enjoyed the adventures of the characters, the dialogue was well done (not what I call foresoothy, in that it did not mimic Shakespeare's language, but was pleasant to the ear when I read it out loud), and offers an interesting theory of Shakespeare's "lost years." My only criticism is that I felt it was a little too long at over 400 pages.I highly recommend this book for readers of Shakespeare and historical literature and romance.

Other than being made of recycled materials I did not find this planner to be special enough to be worth the additional cost. Due to being shipped a padded mailer instead of a box, the planner arrived  with the corners bent back and creased, indicating that it might not be sturdy enough to withstand a year's worth of daily use. It has standard calendar pages for each month, followed by a diary or appointment section for each month. The art work is nice with attractive watercolour butterflies on the cover and on selected pages inside. The pages and cover are acid free and should look new, or nearly new, for many years. It is 100% recyclable, including the wire binding.

This book by paper artist Hannah Viano is absolutely stunning. Ms Viano cuts out her designs from black paper and it appears they are then mounted on colored paper. The cover illustration is a perfect example of her work throughout the book and one of my favorites. All of the designs are taken from nature and the artist does not, for the most part, pick the expected: "H" is not horse as one might think, but for herring, and the fish swirl in a circle on the page.Ms Viano dedicates her book to parents who let their children run a little wild, climb trees, and jump in puddles, which was the way I was raised (although they didn't know about the tree climbing) and the way I raised my son as well. We both drank from the garden hose and survived! This book would make a good present for adults and children. I would suggest giving it as a baby shower gift along with the diapers and onesies

"Speed Kings" is really three books in one: a collective biography of the 1932 bobsled team and the world in which they came of age, the 1932 Winter Olympics, and the remainder of the book about World War II. If you are looking for a pure sports book on the Olympics, this book is not the one. It does give a history of the sport of bobsledding, which had its origins in Europe at the turn of the 20th century, and, as others have remarked, about one - third actually deals with the Olympics. I think the main difference between "Speed Kings" and another recent sports book, "The Boys in the Boat," is that the latter deals with people that the reader can easily relate to, while the former deals more with playboy types. I found myself doing a great deal of skimming, whilst, I will admit, stopping to read more gossipy entries, such as those on  James Jay O'Brien and his obsession with a now mostly forgotten silent movie star, Mae Murray. I think this book will have appeal for the right audience, but for those who were hoping for a tighter focus on the 1932 Olympics it might be a disappointment.

Being a woman of a certain age, actually a few years more than a certain age, I know that products such as Vichy Vichy Elixir are not going to give the same results as an invasive cosmetic procedure. But they can give some temporary positive results when applied, such as softer feeling skin and the minimizing the appearance of lines and wrinkles. That is certainly the case with the Elixir, as upon application I noticed that my lines were not as noticeable. The Elixir has a nice feeling on the skin because it is not greasy. I use the dropper to deposit the Elixir on the palm of my hand, then use my fingertips to apply it to my face, forehead, and neck. There is only a faint scent which disappears upon application. Using the dropper will make this 1.01 fluid ounce bottle last longer.

"Carrying Albert Home" is a silly book that I struggled to finish.  I have read other books by Homer Hickman, and I was also taken by the cover art, so I kept thinking the book was going to improve as I continued reading. It did not do it for me. I could not stand the character of Hickam' s mother Elsie. Hopefully Elsie was not as distasteful in real life as she is portrayed in this book, or else Homer and his brother would never have been born. I am guessing some artistic license was employed in the author's portrait of his parents and what definitely seems to fit what we now call a dysfunctional family. How much truth there is in this account of returning a gift alligator to Florida is beside the point, as the book falls into the category of picaresque genre literature, which you either like or you don't. I think this book is for devoted fans of the author.

In the final book of the trilogy of 100 years in the life of the Langdon family the author takes a rather heavy-handed approach to contemporary issues. I found the characters harder to connect to than in the previous novels, and there is not much in the way of levening humour that might have made the book a more enjoyable reading experience. Jane Smiley does have a particular political and social agenda that she is pushing hard in this book, and while I share many of those views, I am not particularly fond of didactic novels. After reading the trilogy I will probably take a break from Me Smiley, although I admire her ambition and talent.

One of my two cats has a sensitive stomach and she does very well on a grain free food, whether it is a wet food, such as Fancy Feast, or a dry food. I mixed the Rachael Ray Nutrish in with their current green pea and duck dry kibble and they made an easy transition to the new food. Only time will tell if this Rachael Ray product will become their new favourite, but I am optimistic that this will be the case. Cats do not need grain, and had I been aware of this sooner I would have made the transition to grain free food months ago.

I am giving this exploration of slavery outside the United States in the early years of the Republic four stars because of the importance of the subject matter. The connection of John Quincy Adams and the slave trading families of the north deserves to be told and the author has thoroughly researched the subject. However, the book is a struggle if one is not an historian and reading just for general overall information.A good addition to the book shelf of a history professor or a more serious student of the period, the average reader would have benefited by a slightly more personal hand.

This book is a brief but excellent examination of Jewish law from Abraham to the present. Alan Dershowitz is a professor of law at Harvard University and a well-known author of many books, magazine articles, and essays on law and politics. Here he examines the evolution of legal principles beginning with the Hebrew Bible accounts of Abraham and Moses and their "negotiations" with God. One of the most interesting chapters of that first section is the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah and the concept of how many good people had to be present to stop the destruction of the cities. That actually has continued down to the present day with the concept of how many guilty people could  be set free in order to keep one innocent person from being imprisoned or executed. The magic number in examples continues to be ten..."better 10 guilty people go free than one innocent person be convicted." The author goes on to explain how differences of opinion on this concept would differ from an authoritarian society to a liberal one. The second half of the book looks at some well-known Jewish lawyers, including some who are our contemporaries. The book is written in a very approachable style, and includes extensive notes. I recommend this book for those interested in the law, religion, or both.

It is encouraging to know that some famous authors got off to rocky starts with their earliest stories. The several short stories by the teenage Truman Capote that make up this collection are very forgettable, and a couple are in my opinion particularly so, such as the opening story, "The Parting of the Way," with a cliche ending one could see coming from the beginning. It is not that the writing is particularly bad, because it is not, but the subject matter and the predictable conclusions show an immaturity that I remember from the stories I wrote in my youth. And, even for short stories, they seemed rushed and incomplete. The story of the little boy, Teddy, neglected by his parents and denied a dog to assuage his loneliness was the sweetest of the stories, and, while again one knew how it would end, was probably the most satisfying and my personal favourite. I doubt I would read any of these stories again, which is certainly not the case with Capote' s mature works.

Chaya Deitsch has written a very fascinating account of her early life growing up a Lubavitcher, a member of an Orthodox Jewish sect where she never felt fully comfortable from an early age. Much of her childhood was spent going back and forth between her maternal grandparent' s home in the  Crown Heights section of  New York City and the parental home in Connecticut, where her father's family had their plastics business.In many ways Chaya' s childhood was not much different from many non-Orthodox Jews and non-Jews...she had a television, a stereo, access to whatever books she wanted to read from the public library (just no books on Christmas), went to a co-ed school until the end if 8th grade. Her modest clothing was bought from expensive stores, and she apparently never was  tempted to eat shell fish and pork products. But it was clear that her freer life in the suburbs was different from the life if her cousins in Crown Heights. Attending services with her father was more an attempt to bond with him that out of any particularly religious need.Ms Deitsch' s inner rebellion centered on longing for a life outside the traditional Hasidic community....she wanted a university education, when she thought about marriage it was something that would happen much later and certainly not an arranged one at age 18, and she wanted a career. These longings began in childhood, and one of the criticisms if the book is that too much time is spent on her pre-teen years while the years when she actually began to make meaningful changes is crowded into the last quarter of the book. The author began, however, to lay the foundation for her "escape" to a different life when she seriously wanted to emulate the strong women in her family who had defied both the Nazis and the Soviets. She was fortunate to have parents who loved her and wanted the best for her, but who were bewildered by her needs, needs she didn't share until she was ready to attend Barnard College instead of marrying. But they supported her desire for a high education and did not disown her. The book is well written, in the nature of most memoirs recreates some conversations that we have to take with a tiny grain of salt years after the event, and the details of a life most of us will never know is fascinating.

While Joby Warrick spent quite a bit of time on the role of America in the rise of ISIS, he spent very little time discussing the role of the centuries-old conflict between Sheites and Sunnis.This information is crucial to understanding the issues of the Middle East and it is one that Westerners such as I struggle to grasp the significance. I am keeping this book to go over again, as thus conflict does not seen to be going away in the foreseeable future.

I have been a fan of Thomas Pitt over William Monk, therefore I have read almost all of the Pitt books and just selected novels out of the Monk series as they sounded interesting. "Corridors of the Night" is actually William's wife Hester' s story, which is perhaps why I did not find it terribly compelling. Once it became clear that experiments on the waifs Hester found in the hospital whilst on night duty were going to be a major focus of the book, I found my interest to flag. And that other waif, Scruff, with his dialect that becomes almost too much for me throughout an entire novel, was also a major player. He is the Monk series version of the London housemaid in the Pitt series, to represent the very, very lower class folk. Perry has balanced the two series with similar characters, including the major couples, William and Hester and Thomas and Charlotte. Both men have major issues on the job but happy personal lives with intelligent and sympathetic women they adore.I was disappointed to realize that a mystery involving the early days of blood transfusions was not as interesting as I had hoped. I think this book will be a natural for devoted fans of the Monk series, but for those new to the series I would recommend starting with the first book, "The Face of a Stranger."

This was my first experience with Cafe Diario K-Cups and I was very pleased with the quality of the product. In the interest of disclosure, I do not drink my coffee black but rather with sweetened flavoured creamers. I prepared an 8 ounce cup with my Keurig, took a small sip of the coffee black and found it to be very robust but not bitter. With the coffee creamer added it was a very pleasant cup of coffee with the strong flavour I like tamed by sweetener. I think those who enjoy strong coffee made in a Keurig will find this their cup of Joe..

Those of us who love liquid coffee creamer and especially the Pumpkin Spice flavor consider September to be the start of the "most wonderful time of the year," as the song goes.
