The large industrial size shelf stable Coffee-mate is the latest in a line of holiday themed creamers. It will be good unopened on the shelf for several months and, once opened, good without refrigeration for at least 30 days. I did not find the flavor quite as intense as the refrigerated version, and one skimpy pump is hardly adequate to be a serving. This is a common problem, as I don't know of anyone who considers a teaspoon full, or even less, sufficient to sweeten a cup of coffee. It took me three pumps to get the flavor I wanted, for total of 75 calories. The carb and sugar count was 15 mg each. The pump was easy to assemble and insert in the bottle...it cannot be removed once in place. Because it is a tall bottle when the pump is in place, people with limited kitchen space may find it difficult to find the perfect location. I think this is a good product to keep on hand for situations where a refrigerator is not handy, such as a camping trip.

A year ago I had an aluminium tortilla press that ended up going to the local Goodwill Store because it was impossible to get anything other than a tiny tortilla suitable for a doll's tea party. This is totally different! The cast iron press is very heavy, and the plates are pre-seasoned, although I did use parchment paper for a better release of the tortilla. The handle must be assembled, and I found the pressure I needed to exert was much more than I needed with the lighter weight aluminium model.Tortilla presses are really only for making corn tortillas, as flour tortillas are rolled with a rolling pin. My suggestion is to make sure you have allowed yourself plenty of time when you use this for the first time, read all information on making tortillas prior to beginning, and have all your supplies at hand. Making tortillas by hand is not for the faintest of heart in my opinion, it is not much cheaper than buying a good brand at a grocery store or specialty store. But it is rewarding to be able to produce a decent product...

A lovely book that would make a perfect gift for a person who enjoys fishing and nature. James McClintock is an excellent writer who has the ability to draw one in to his appreciation of nature and his respect for the fish, many of which are immediately released back into the waters. In examining the problems that are now occurring due to climate change, it presents what he sees without sensationalism. One of the most touching passages had to do with an issue I had read about previously...how warmer weather has resulted in an increase in ticks that can be overwhelming to the moose population. Each chapter takes place in a different locale, which may create some envy or inspiration! I intend to keep this book in order to dip into it from time to time when I need an escape but cannot get to a fishing pond.

This is a fairly fast moving historical romance that one can easily read in a day. As a debut novel there are some awkward sentences and some overuse of cliches ("the silence was deafening") but by and large these are things that can be expected to improve as Ms Campbell continues writing.The author is commended for not setting her book in the overworked Recency period but rather setting the book in 9th century England, with conflicts between Saxons and Vikings. It has been awhile since I have seen a good Viking romance, which used to be a staple of the historical romance genre. The characters are appealing, particularly our Saxon heroine, Avelynn, and the noble Viking, Alrik. The dialogue is realistic, walking the line successfully between being too modern but not full of awkward "foresoothy" phrases in an attempt to sound like we imagine people talked in the 800's. As an FYI, there are several scenes of explicit sex, but nothing to create too many blushes. This book appears to be the first of a series.

Warning: Spoilers includedThis book would have worked far better for me if the main characters of Loretta Young, Clark Gable, and their daughter Judy Lewis had been presented under fictional names. Yes, most people of a certain age, or with a deep interest in the movie industry, would have recognized the story, but Adriana Trigiani has chosen to use the real names. Part of the problem is that we then have fictional conversations and scenes that probably never happened which are going to be taken as the truth.I have to confess, I have never felt the Trigiani magic which so many experience reading her books, and turned out to be no exception. The writing is workmanlike but not literary, the dialogue is reasonably realistic, and the best parts are the sections dealing strictly with the movie industry and Hollywood during the Golden Age. However, the nuns at the orphanage in San Francisco of the early 1930s sound more like post Vatican II than accounts I have read of the abusive maternity homes of the period.SPOILERS: Those of us who have read the book by Judy Lewis and Young' s account of her life know that Loretta Young seemed much more concerned with protecting her image than Ms Trigiani indicates. She accused Gable of "date rape, " which was not revealed until after her death. There is no way this can be proven 80 years after the event. But, per Miss Lewis's statement, her mother called her a "walking mortal sin," which is just cruel and inexcusable. They were estranged until Miss Young' s death. All of this information was available to Ms Trigiani.

Ah, how does one review toilet paper without sounding slightly silly? This is an excellent product that certainly lives up to its hype, but then I have always liked Charmin. I was surprised at how strong the tissue is, considering that it appears to be thinner than many other brands. One can expect to use much less of this toilet paper than you may generally require to clean up, which in the long run is going to make it more economical. It doesn't leave bits of tissue clinging to you either. This tissue is guaranteed to be safe for both plumbing attached to municipal sewers and to septic systems.

Witch Hazel? I haven't heard that term for ages, so I did not know what to expect from this hand cream as I associated witch hazel with an astringent. I couldn't have been more wrong, as this hand cream almost instantly gives the appearance of smooth, supple, and youthful skin. Using just a pea-size amount, I can moisturize both hands and have the results last for hours. And it does this without being greasy..I immediately picked up a book and none of the lotion transferred to the paper. The scent is very subtle and will not interfere with with other perfumes or lotions.

This is not just for young adults, but rather for anyone from teenagers on up who want to experience and explore what life was like in the concentration camps of World War II. The author has culled personal accounts of existence in a Belgian facility that most have probably never heard of before finding this book. The stories are of prisoners from all walks of life and are very personal and intimate. The book is filled with photographs of the present day Breendonk as well as archival photos. The afterword provide a record of the fate of the prisoners, which is something that I welcomed as I became more and more involved in the fate of certain people. The reading level is 8th grade on up..

This is a nice, low-key memoir written by a 60 year old man as a tribute to his 95 year old father. Stuart Stevens grew up in Mississippi, the son  of politically liberal parents at a time when the south, and indeed, the nation, was involved in the struggle for equal rights for black Americans. It was not totally clear to me if the white Stevens family had suffered in any meaningful way for their liberal views, although the younger Stevens was sent to Virginia for some of his pre-university years. The younger Stevens eventually got into politics, and was apparently slightly more conservative than his parents, as his last political work had been with the losing 2012 Romney campaign. Feeling lost and adrift he wanted to spend more time with his elderly parents, particularly his father. Never having lost his love for college football, the SEC, and Ole' Miss, Stevens decides to approach his parents about taking in all the Ole' Miss games during the next season.The slim volume explores the bond that football had created between the Stevens father-son duo when the son was in grade school, their loyalty to one team that never wavered over 50 years, and the attempt to reconnect and recapture the magic of the past. By and large, the attempt succeeded and is beautifully captured by Stevens. There is much humor in the book, particularly when Stevens relates his mother's attempt to over dress them in 90 degree heat with equal humidity, to encounters with fans of Ole Miss', to road trips, to fascination with hot dogs. There are also serious examination of integration, the retirement of a Confederate battleflag and rewriting of Dixie, the ultimate integration of the college and the team. The Stevens men had always been close, even when separated by miles, so the bonding related in the book was not perhaps as dramatic had they been estranged at some point, but that is one of the,reasons I liked this book so much.....the genuine love and respect between the two men just shown through beautifully. Recommended for football fans and lovers of memoirs that don't contain alcohol and drug fueled feuds and last minute reconciliation. Just quiet and thoughtful reflections.

This is the sort of horse related set I would have loved to have had as a child. I selected this hoping my granddaughter would enjoy it and we set it up upon  receipt. Not being a horsey girl, and near the top end of the age range, she thought it clever but had no interest in playing with it. The manufacturer gives the age range as being from 36 months to 15 years, and I think this is not accurate on either end.For 3 year olds I think the difficulty is they would need adult assistance and supervision setting it up as some of the pieces were small for little hands. Without being set on a table or other sturdy surface I think it could be challenging for the youngest children to play with as they would need to be very gentle. It is not made for rough play. On the highest end of the age group, the teenager would have to be really in to riding and it would be more appropriate as a display piece.Why then 5 stars?  The reasons are the pieces are hand painted, extraordinarily detailed, include English rather than western tack, and in the hands of the right age group would supply hours of fun. The price points are fairly reasonable that the accessories could be added for a total riding stable for under $175.00. As the child becomes older, the horse and rider could become display pieces. This set encourages imaginative play that is often missing in many contemporary toys.

The Raifords return in this second book in the Rex Burns series about a father-daughter private detective firm that started with "Body Slam." While I do appreciate the unusual setting, a very large tanker, it also means rather long passages where nothing much is going on and the duo is actually working apart. The mystery is so-so, the writing pretty straight forward and workmanlike, dialogue is realistic. My biggest complaint has more to do with the main characters, who are somewhat lacklustre for private detectives. Perhaps they will become more developed in future volumes,which I do intend to read as they become available.

I did not know quite what to expect in this one volume treatment of the last full year of World War II. The book is a door stop at being more than 500 pages, but the subject area to be covered is equally huge. Jay Winik looks at the various allied countries and their respective leaders, and also devotes much time to what was happening in the Nazi concentration camps. 71 years later we know the outcome of these issues, but the author is still able to generate much tension and excitement with his writing, which is very approachable for the average reader as well as those more versed in the subject. As someone born in the very last year if the war, I had a father who was a veteran of the Pacific Theatre, and, I was to find out many years later, the cousin of  men who died in service in the invasion of Italy, the Battle of the Bulge, and on the USS Indianapolis. In many ways, WW II was similar to the American Civil War, in that many, many families were touched due to the number of those who served. I highly recommend this book to those who are looking for a one volume treatment, well researched and well written.

Very interesting and well written story about India before the beginning of the modern era, told from the point of view of an educated and compassionate young man who wishes to improve the status of women. The book has a beautiful literary style and realistic dialogue, only slightly marred by the use of terms that are unfamiliar to western readers. The character development proceeds realistically and traditional customs are treated with respect even as they are seen as outmoded. I think this is a book to read slowly and savor.

This book is a natural for fans of Agatha Christie! Science writer Katherine Harkup has selected 14 different poisons that Miss Christie used in her novels and devotes a chapter to each. Ms Harkup devotes much time to the scientific properties of each poison, it's use or probable use in real life, and how it was employed in the works of Miss Christie. This is not a how to do it book for would be prisoners, but a reasonably serious discussion of poisons in history and literature. But those new to the novels should be aware that some spoilers are included, and they are generally not announced. The scientific aspects do have a tendency to drag on a little for those of us not particularly thrilled by chemistry, but over all this book is a good addition to the library of a serious fan of the mystery genre.

While I read this book in a little over an hour I am an adult reader, and I think this book might be a little advanced for an average eight year old to read on his or her own. The sentences tend to run on and are in some cases a little convoluted. As a book sold in a National Park bookstore I think it would be appropriate for the adults to share as a night time read before the family heads out into the Great Smoky Mountains....but as a book just to pick up and read outside the context of a trip, I am not so sure. Fairly lacklustre with little excitement.

The usual cat caution is being observed whenever a new food is being introduced, however so far so good. Both cats have eaten it,  although neither is wild about chicken cat food. I like the fact that it is grain free and a pate form, as my kitty with the sensitive stomach cannot eat food with grains and likes smooth food rather than bits in gravy. No upset stomachs so far.

Since I have not read the other books in the series (16 in all), I do not know if it is typical, better, worse than the preceding books. It has an interesting premise, but the writing....oh, my. Convoluted sentences, with many French and German vernacular expressions that mainly are various ways of saying excrement. I am not sure if I want to go back to the beginning to see if the writing style has changed over the years...it could have evolved, after all...I honestly cannot recommend this book to those who are not already fans of the series.

This book has received rave reviews all over the Internet but I found it to be tedious and of little interest due to a very unlikable heroine. Georgia Ford breaks off her engagement due to a misunderstanding with her fiance, that while shocking on the surface is something that could have been worked out. Georgia flees back to the family vineyard, where much to her dismay she finds out her father wants to sell the property. The rest of the novel is taken up with the bossy young woman giving out unwanted advice to everyone while she decides if she wants to reconcile with her fiance. Georgia is really a pill in my opinion. In real life you would flee her...and being a character in a novel you have the option of fleeing her by closing the book. She seems to be the natural inheritor of the title TSTL, short for Too Stupid To Live, where the heroine operates constantly against her own best interest. The setting is the best part of the novel and the dialogue is fairly realistic.

Be warned:  Mary Buser's memoir of her days at Rikers is very depressing to read. The author started out as a very idealistic social worker intern, and ended her career in the system years later still with a sense of idealism but in her own way as beaten down as any inmate she tried to help. Unfortunately, her career ended a decade and a half ago, so the memoir in some ways seems a little late to the party. However, solitary confinement, covered in this book, is still being used in many major prisons, even though it has generally been discredited as an effective form of punishment. The book is well-written and compelling, and deals with social problems that still plague us in 2015, even though the national crime rate as dropped. We are still the only first world nation with a death penalty and we have not yet come to grips with how to keep guns out of the hands of the mentally ill. I recommend this book for those interested in the judicial system, and perhaps interested in social work. Not, however, for the faint of heart.

As soon as I received the Slumberjack I opened it up and tried it out on my bed. I think this bag is going to be just perfect for the two purposes I intend to use it for: some late summer, early fall camping and to have it available this winter in the event of a power outage. Two years in a row we had a power outage in the coldest weather and we lost our heat for a few days. Even with blankets piled on, the nights were very cold. This bag should be the answer as it will keep one warm down below 20 degree and it does not get down that low in the house. The bag is very attracive in plum and gold. It has a pouch for a pillow to make it comfortable for one's neck and head. I am only a little over 5 feet tall and the bag is for women up to 6 feet tall, so I do not expect it will have any fit issues for a woman of average build up to the maximum height requirement. I cannot address any issues regarding cleaning the bag.UPDATED 10/12/15: Last night I opened up the bag and put it on my bed to use as a comforter. It worked fine as a single layer on a cold night. I was a little worried that it might move around too much as I slept as it is 100% polyester, but it did not. On a cool to medium cold night you probably will only need the opened bag over you without an intermediate layer. It doesn't have a drape when placed on a double bed or larger.

What would you pay for a book that could give you all of the answers?  What if it could not be purchased, but only shared.  That is the premise of this little volume, a book about a book.  A seeker finds a master, a man whose title, old fool, belies everything he is not.  The master possesses a book of life which might reveal truth, or not...... And the seeker learns a little from it.New age literature?  Yes of course.  Complete with neo liberal assumptions?  Again, almost a given.  (I'm not sure if the skeptic in me was more annoyed by the blind repetition of global warming assumptions or the utterly unscientific belief that solar and wind can produce meaningful amounts of power, but either way I was a bit turned off by this portion of the book.). Yet, I can't help but feel that this book conveys a basic truth about our existence.  Questions and curiosity are what drive humans.  In Anne Rice's first and best book, Interview with a Vampire, Louie realizes that it is his anxiety about not having answers that keeps him from literally withering away.  But Louie's questioning nature is a human, not undead attribute.  Similarly, when we fall into routine and fail to question life as it comes, we become like the undead, living, but not truly alive.And if this be new age thought, then great.  Let's have a little more of it.  Three stars for occasional trite ness, and a half star extra for great photos from the British Museum.

So you want to hike the John Muir Trail.  Which guidebook to get?  There are really only two that are up to date, the Wilderness Press edition and this little book from the British outdoor publisher Cicerone.  I own both books, but have a slight preference for this one.  Printed on glossy paper with sharp full color pictures this should whet your appetite for the trail.  But it is also lighter than the Wilderness Press volume which has grown in size and weight over the years.  And amazingly enough, this book packs in more as well.As one might expect, the book is geared towards an international visitor to the states, but a lot of the information in it will be useful to those traveling from other locales in the US.  Major airports, public transportation (and the lack thereof to and from Yosemite and Whitney Portal, and the issues with mailing supplies are all detailed in this book.  The book also suggests a reasonable, and quite doable schedule for your trip and even helps you navigate your way through the almost Byzantine system of camping and hiking permits you need to obtain for the trail.  Finally, it includes decent color sketch maps of the route.  Readers should know however that the author intends that you use this guide in conjunction with the excellent map set sold by Tom Harrison.The John Muir Trail is one of the classic American hikes.  Mile for mile it offers some of the most spectacular scenery in the world.  If I were planning for another trek on the Muir Trail, this would be my guidebook of choice.

I will start this review by noting that I am a climate skeptic, which most readers of this book will call a "Denier" (capital d for emphasis) so those who do not want their fundamental assumptions challenged should simply vote this review unhelpful now, perhaps leave a scathing or threatening comment and move on.  And with that said, this is a interesting book that asks some serious questions and deserves  a wider readership than it is already receiving.In brief, Marshall is convinced that climate change is a "fact."  He carefully defines climate change as the likelihood that temperatures will rise 4 degrees Celsius in the next century or so, and then asks why large numbers of people are resistant to these facts.  He concludes that we have an evolutionary adaptation to resist fears about the distant future.  Our brains, he argues, are hard wired to reject immediate costs for long range benefits.  He cites a variety of studies in evolutionary psychology to defend this claim, most notably a famous experiment which showed that people, if confronted with a hypothetical disease (for which a vaccine was available) that killed only 1 in every thousand infected, would pay $200 for the vaccine.  But the same people would need $10,000 to be infected by the disease to study the vaccine.  In short, people are more risk averse in the short than long term.  Marshall then interviews a variety of skeptics and finds to no one's surprise that these conclusions from evolutionary psychology are born out.The above problem is aggravated by fact that humans also tend to band together in groupings that reinforce their own belief systems, and in an age where information is widely available on the Internet, this trend is actually reinforced.  So much is available that we can literally select our own reality.  And we do so, often using the same mythic images to construct our narratives.  Both believers and skeptics of global warming are inclined to creating conspiracies about their opponents, compare them to Nazis, and focus on their moral failings.  (Some of these latter narratives are so powerful that even as Marshall recognizes them for what they are, he still feels obliged to come up with an apologetic.  It is rather hard for us lower middle class skeptics to appreciate the sincerity of the jet setters who tell us to use less.)Having identified the problem, Marshall then suggests a series of solutions.  His main point is to recognize and acknowledge the cultural barriers that divide people on climate change and realize that the same narrative will not work on every person.  He suggests instead that advocates for new policies based on climate change need to adopt narratives that meet the values and (presumably) hard wired belief systems people have.  After all, he notes, the 1970s were not so bad, and we drove less then, so what have we to fear? How's that for a "conservative" narrative?  (Some of us have different memories of the 70s.)All this is well and good, and will undoubtedly give advocates for political action hope that they will eventually be able to change the minds of "Deniers" out there.  (Failing that, it will be easier for those who agree with the hypothesis of this book to dismiss with their less "evolved" brethren.  To his credit, that is never Marshall's actual intent.)  But the problem with this book, and indeed nearly all popular books on evolutionary psychology, is the matter of what Archimedean point the author (and to judge by the other reviews here, the all too confident readers) are standing on.  Essentially the point this book makes boils down to this:  some people don't accept scientific evidence and rational argument because they are hard wired to do so.  But if some people are hard wired to do so, what gives the author such a privileged position?  How do we know that they aren't subject to "hard wiring" that makes them see "facts" that aren't there.The above point may sound rhetorical, but it's not.  At the beginning of the book, Marshall asks why the victims of wildfires in Texas, and hurricane Sandy, are so loathe to attribute their disasters to Climate Change.  Why indeed?  What is to Marshall overwhelming proof that we are hard wired to reject science, is actually evidence of shoddy science.  And let me be very clear on this for any reader who does not keep up on the scientific literature:  there is absolutely no evidence that hurricanes are increasing in strength or numbers over the last 50 years.  None.  And in fact the opposite is true.  We know, and this is the "scientific consensus" of specialists in the field that they are not.  (The situation with wildfires is a bit more complex.). So why is Marshall so keen on "denying" science?  A critic might suggest, "He must be hard wired to do so!"And indeed it is very easy to make the claim (one could even write a whole book about it) that those who believe in global warming do so because of evolutionary belief systems.  After all, humans have always believed in apocalypse, despite the fact none of them ever come to pass.  So, while it is comforting to dismiss the argument of your critics as hard wiring, doing so is not advisable.  It undermines the very basis of rational discourse and the "facts" you claim to base your own position on.But Marshall's question remains.  Why do so many people reject the facts of climate change?  Comfortable as it may be to invoke evolutionary psychology or a conspiracy of "Big Oil" money interests, neither of these explanations holds weight.  Although the answer will not be comfortable for the left, the likely reason is because their "facts" are nowhere near as well founded as they think they are, and their solutions, which oddly enough almost uniformly reject nuclear power, are even less effective.  In short, if large numbers of people disagree with you, that is quite possibly a sign that you are wrong.  How can you know?  Read the actual evidence for yourselves.  You may be surprised to find that the people you thought were ignoring the scientific literature are actually reading it more carefully than you.  They may even be actively involved in writing it.  But be sure to read this book too.  If you read nothing else, and you share a left wing perspective, it will make you feel better about yourselves.  And if you don't share that perspective, you will find just how incredibly shallow the answers of true believers like Marshall are even when they ask serious questions.

The famous El Camino trail in Spain may soon have a North American counterpart.  If, as expected, Pope Francis makes Father Junipero Serra a saint, then Trekkers may soon take to pilgrimages along the California coast (and slightly inland) to visit the missions and Fr Serra's burial site in Carmel.  Already some Trekkers are trying this and marking off routes.  This book covers the Southern California missions and suggests a largely urban hike along bike paths and back roads.I liked the idea behind the book and the route seemed relatively easy compared to the more traditional wilderness treks popular among Appalachian and Pacific Crest trail hikers.  The author, Lutz, has a preference for the European style of B&B hiking and it shows in his hotel recommendations.  It is possible to do the entire Southern California section of his proposed El Camino Real Trail without ever camping.  That can make for lite packs and a fun, if expensive walking vacation.I'm intrigued by the route and idea.  I love visiting the missions for their history, grandeur, and sacred space.  But like most American hikers, my preference still lies in Wilderness.  So I'm adding this route to my bucket list aand hoping I get a chance to do this pilgrimage in my own backyard.

I read as much trail literature as I can, and I also dabble at the edges of the long distance hiking community, but no writer I've read in the last decade can compete with Carrot Quinn.  She has the gift of descriptive writing.  Readers can see what she sees on the trail and in her life, but like another great outdoor writer, Hemingway, she does not burden the reader with interpretations of the experience.  She leaves that for the readers to discover for themselves.  We are treated to snippets of conversations, visions of beauty, intimacy, pain, solitude, fear, and friendship, but no real interpretation.  And unlike Hemingway, we are not force fed some serious overarching theme which we are meant to reflect on.  Indeed, I think in some cases Ms. Quinn is herself not able to come to terms with her own experiences and the reader is deftly left with the same ambiguity she feels.Thru hiking can be a profound experience.  The very austerity of the trail can create mystical and transformative experiences for hikers.  But those experiences rarely translate well to written or spoken language.  Instead we are often told of how hard the readjustment to everyday life is after a thru hike at the end of a hiking journal.  Similar to the metamorphic return from the mountaintop, these experiences often signify loss as hikers seek to return to the "real world."  But Quinn has made a conscious decision to not return.  Instead, hiking remains her life, summer and winter.  Although I doubt she would consider this a pursuit of grace, in part because that language smacks of a traditional Christianity which has not been kind to her, it surely is.  And it is a grace that extends beyond her book into her hiking blog, the only one of hundreds which I subscribe too.  So get this book, sign up to receive blog updates, and prepare to be amazed by the depth and feeling that Quinn, the best hiking author of this generation conveys.

Long distance hiking is very much a young persons game.  As I approach 50 I find fewer and fewer people my age on the trail, and last summer, while hiking on the AT, I was briefly chastised by a hiker who noted my old pack didn't fit as well as it once may have and, "at your age...."  But I've got nothing on G. William Jolly, the author of this book.  Jolly decided.to take up distance hiking at the age of 71 when he walked most of the Washington section of the Pacific Crest Trail, from Bridge of the Gods to Harts Pass.Hiking in one's seventies offers a fairly unique opportunity.  Many young writers find, or almost find, themselves while hiking the trail.  Jolly, by contrast, knows who he is and doesn't experience any profound changes, though an infected big toe does figure prominently in the final 20% of the book.  But he does find the trail offers him a lot of time for reflection on his life.  He thinks of the father he never had, and the step father who passed away too soon, discusses his turbulent relationships with his brother, and with God, and he finds time to share in the revels of his more youthful trail companions, even if often from a distance.  (Growing old, he notes, is rather like growing invisible.  We are seen less and expected to just retire from the social scene.). But Jolly refuses to just fade away.  Instead, he walks, albeit slowly, along some of America's greatest pathways.  Alas, this book only covers Washington.  He has also since hike much of the Northern California and Oregon sections of the PCT, and at the age of 73, hiked the John Muir Trail.  There is probably another book in there, and I left this one hoping for more.

Ventura County is far more diverse than you might imagine.  It contains some of the nicest parklands and hiking in the greater LA area, and it is relatively uncrowded.  And if you want to hike there, many miles of trails beckon, from developed urban parks to wilderness along the Sespe River.  This little book by John McKinney will guide you to 24 of these hikes, many of which are quite short and accessible to even to moderately handicapped people, as my wife will attest.  But it has one significant drawback, about which more shortly.First the good:  all 24 of these hikes can be done in a day and several, like Rose Valley Falls, a real scenic gem, can be completed in under an hour.  Indeed, readers looking for a quick stroll after a day on the beach or at work will find ample opportunities with this book which includes several hikes in and around Ojai's open space preserves and in Ventura parks.  Even local botanical gardens receive some attention.But the book also includes some challenging hikes like the ascent of Nordhoff peak.  Happily McKinney includes some options for those who want a shorter route on these trails.  Finally, those hoping to try their hand at a short backpacking trip will find multiple options as several of these trails, like Pine Mountain, pass by backcountry camps.  I've hiked ten of the routes described here and in general I can say that McKinney's mileage and sketch maps are accurate.With so much going for it, one might ask what could be lacking in a book like this.  Of course a small guide will not be comprehensive.  (The best comprehensive guide to the area, by the way is Robert Stone's Best Dayhikes, Ventura.). But, because this guide is so brief, it is very inexpensive, especially in the Kindle edition.  If you are just visiting Ventura for a few days, or regularly pass through on your way elsewhere, then it is an excellent buy.  Still, I would like to have seen a few beach strolls.  Also, hikers should be aware that, although they are not in Ventura county proper, the best access to the Channel Islands, one of California's best, and least visited national parks, is from Ventura Harbor aboard concessionaire Island Packers.  And those islands represent the best day hikes to be had in the region.  Still, for the price, this is a nice guide.  Get it and have fun.

I have purchased every edition of Afoot and Afield, Orange County.  And I have loved every one.  I no longer live in Riverside, so I don't get out to Orange County for hiking as much, but when I do, I try to take this book along.  Recently updated by David Money Harris, the best of the current Wilderness Press authors, this book includes over 30 new hikes, mostly in recently opened lands previously held by the Irvine Land Company and now open for public recreation.  Due to recent wildfires, a few of my favorite hikes, most notably Laurel Spring, are no longer here.  But the vast majority of the classic hikes are still here:  O'Neill park and Caspers Wilderness park still receive a lot of attention.  And the coastal section of the county has been revised and considerably expanded to include several hikes along local green belts and within smaller preserves that protect what is left of southern California's coastal wetlands.  (The photo is from one of these, the Back Bay Nature Preserve in Newport Beach.)But the biggest change to the book is not within the pages at all.  Harris has for years been developing a free hiking app, etrails, which is designed predominantly for Pacific Crest Trail hikers.  The app includes route descriptions, embedded topo maps, and the option, if you want to seriously cut into your iPhone's battery life of locating yourself on route.  It is a nice feature of for the PCT, though that route is fairly well signed.  But in his most recent update, Harris added a brief Orange County section that mirrors the book.  Descriptions are limited, and you are still well advised to buy the book.  But many Orange County trails, especially in the more urbanized areas, are interlaced with a slew of side routes, use paths, etc.  And in places where trails are disconnected and loops require short meanders on surface streets the satellite mapping feature of the app that accompanies this book is particularly valuable.  As I was field testing the new edition, I decided to hike the Back Bay Loop, nearly 10 miles, around Newport Bay. It was beautiful, but the route description in the book was fairly complicated, and the variety of paths were only incompletely signed.  I found the mapping feature of the accompanying app absolutely invaluable while hiking.  Finally the app has the added benefit of giving precise mileage (to the nearest tenth) while many hikes in the book simply round to the nearest whole mile in the written description.The bottom line then is that if you live in or near Organge County, or are willing to drive a bit to get some spectacular spring coastal walking, this is the book to get.  Harris is faithful to the book format that made Jerry Schad's Affoot and Afield series such a popular collection for day hikers in Southern California.  His additions to the book and the accompanying latest etrails app make this a great find for hikers and outdoor enthusiasts in the area of Orange County.

Maps in the National Geographic's "Trail's Illustrated" series are usually among the best available for hikers.  This one is no exception.  Clear and easy to read, it's scale is broad enough that you can follow nearly any trail among the many great parks in the area and at the same time locate yourself relative to any of the other recreational areas nearby.  Several trail systems connect, and the map also shows the full Skyline to the Sea Trail, the pre eminent hike in the Bay Area.  Of course, it features point to mileage for all trails and other recreational routes, is GPS compatible, and includes more hikes than the title implies.  Besides Big Basin and Santa Cruz proper, Butano Creek, Henry Cowell Redwoods, Castle Rock, Ano Nuevo Preserve, and Sanborn Skyline Park are among the many great places you can hike using this map.  The map does not, however, cover the northern end of the range.  Still, this is a wonderful place to explore.  I was pleased to see it included the public lands around Lexington Reservoir, and I will be visiting there on my next trip to the Bay Area.  Highly recommended for dedicated hikers.

If you are a hiker, there are two things you absolutely need in a map.  The first is a good detailed elevation profile.  There is no substitute for a fine topographical map even in the GPS age.  The second thing you need is mileages on trails between points.  This map is a 5 star product on the first point.  It is a one star product on the second.  Lacking point to point mileage, it is essentially worthless.  I was personally shocked when I noticed this.  National Geographic usually puts out a better product.  Of course, the map is GPS compatible and covers a wide area, so I will average the two ratings and give it three starts.  But I was hoping for better.

Unbelievable.  Genuine Leather and well under $10.  This wallet features a separated bill section, eleven card holders, one with a clear plastic cover for ID, and a zipper sealed compartment for change, keys, etc.  In all this is a fine product for the price.  But I just love the leather smell and having a wallet that actually holds all the cards I seem to have accumulated.

Loreen Niewenhuis begins her description of a thousand mile journey by noting that she divorced her husband before she began to walk. At that point, I almost stopped reading the book. I thought one Wild was plenty. A whole new hiking genre of people getting over their former relationships on the trail seems a bit much. I didn't want to read another "I found redemption on the trail" book. Happily, the first two pages is where the comparison to the still very popular "Wild" ends, and despite the fact that Strayed got more publicity, this little volume by Niewenhuis is by far the better book. The author's true love is the Great Lakes region, and it shows on every page.As trail literature goes, this slim volume has surprisingly little actual detail about the hike. Yes, at times the author was hot. She was also concerned about the possibility of being stranded on Manitoba Island as the winds picked up and made a ferry crossing unlikely. But this book is really an exploration of the Great Lakes and their history and the hike is simply the vehicle for presenting the fascinating stories of Tecumseh, Nicola Tesla, the salmon who have overcome significant environmental hazzards to become nearly self sufficient in the lakes. Niewenhuis has a keen eye for detail, and the readers will be treated to the scenes as varied as frogs atop a dead, but not yet decaying, deer (the frogs are there for the flies and quite fat) or vivid descriptions of mines and mine tours including those in Copper Harbor. Virtually everyone will learn something new. I did not know, for example, that Lake Erie is only about 5000 years old, a virtual blink of an eye in geological time. Nor did I know that the street I grew up on, Manitou, is a Native American word for Great Spirit. In all, readers following the journey can learn a lot about the region and incidentally be treated to a great adventure laced with nice doses of humor.But in one sense, the author does undergo a transformation. No, she does not overcome dramatic personal failures or guilt. She never felt that to begin with and rightly so. But in the process of walking with minimal possessions she becomes, in her own words, "more me." Her life is focused, and she has time to reflect on just what is most important in her life. In the end, of course, she decides the land she traverses is itself an important part of her. But friendship is also important, and as she walks the final miles of her trek towards Niagra Falls, she is joined by many others who cheer her on. Not every hiking story needs to be about changing your life. But the best ones do involve new personal understanding. And perhaps that is what real redemption is. This book captures it perfectly.

Hiking in eastern Sierras of California can be a challenging exercise on multiple levels.  On the one hand, elevations are high and trails are (often) steep, so don't expect to move as quickly as you do on a trail in California's coastal parks.  On the other hand, there is so much to choose from and many of the hikes are known only to locals, so finding the perfect route is a bit difficult.  This book resolves both of these problems.  No, you won't hike faster, but the elevation profiles and detailed route descriptions at least give you a hint of what to expect.  And the hikes described include little known trails (I have spent considerable time in the eastern Sierras, and I was not familiar with over a dozen of these hikes) that offer a lot of spectacular scenery in return for your effort.  But readers of this book should be in good shape.  Most of these routes are not for beginning hikers or casual walkers.  An all wheel drive vehicle with high clearance is also a good choice for those wanting to explore the trails in this book.What to like.  Reading this book is almost as good as hiking the trails themselves.  Every page is a plate, and the many photographs are sharp and whet one's appetite for the trail.  I personally like the color coded chapters, the aforementioned elevation profiles, and the authors' consistent hike ratings, from easy to very strenuous.  Each of the 50 hikes also includes an introduction, discussing what to expect on the trail, some vital statistics of mileage and start/end GPS coordinates, and often sidebars on local or natural history.  Driving directions are detailed and, based on my experiences, accurate.  Route descriptions are far more descriptive than found in most hiking guides, and topographical maps for each hike are a real plus.On the other hand, there are a few minor flaws with the book, none of which were sufficient for me to lower it a star on my review rating (some productions are so beautiful that one can overlook a couple mistakes) but they deserve some mention.  First, the editors at KD publications missed a few things.  The description of the drive to the Boundary Peak TH refers readers to a photo on p. 211, but the picture is actually on p. 213.  At least an entire page of text simply vanishes between p. 266 and p. 267.  Fortunately, these pages refer to the history of the town of Independence and not any particular hikes in the region. (I love Independence, however, and would have liked to see the full commentary.) Other little grammatical errors occasionally appear in the text.  From a strictly geographical perspective, readers should know, as my review title points out, this is a guide to the High Sierras east side, not the whole of the range.  You will not find hikes north of the June Lake Loop here (no northern Yosemite, for example).  Still in all, I was so thrilled by this original guide that even the little flaws often found with a small press cannot drop the high ratings I have given the book.Hiking the eastern Sierra's highest passes and lake basins, to say nothing of the steep use trails in the White Mountains, is a challenging business.  A good guidebook should introduce you to the best of the region and help keep you safe while you explore.  This guidebook is not merely good.  Even with a few flaws, it is great.

And south of Sonora Pass and highway 108 lies the Emigrant Wilderness.  This is where California's Sierra Mountains really begin to change their character.  The granite fault block range is still the bedrock of the mountains, but extrusive volcanic outcroppings become much more prevalent.  Of more import for the early settlers traveling to California, the mountains are also lower here and somewhat more easy to traverse.  (Still, wagon trains over Sonora Pass used a rope and pulley system to lower their possessions off the steep grade.) And if you want to explore this area, you will find it with surprisingly few changes in the ensuing century and a half.  Yes, Hwy 108 is paved, but its gradiant still reflects the wagon route in many places, and the only developments are small resorts.  Outside this narrow band of pavement, all travel is still by foot or horseback, and you will want a good map for it.  Of the several choices available, this one by Harrison is probably the best.The map is constructed on a 1:63,360 scale, which means each inch represents a full mile, but this scale shows not only the whole of the Emigrant Wilderness but also part of the Hoover Wilderness, much of northern Yosemite, and the southern tip of the Carson Iceberg Wilderness.  Of greater import to hikers, it shows the main access routes to the Emigrant Wilderness which is generally not very accessible in the way some more popular wilderness areas are.  As with all recent Harrison Maps, this one is printed on a synthetic plastic paper which is waterproof and tear resistant.  Trails are clearly delineated as is topography with contour lines at 80 foot intervals.  And of course, you can use this map in conjunction with your hand held GPS unit, should you need to.Honesty compells me to admit that I have mostly just hiked around the edges of this wild area.  Accessing the heart of it was on my summer "to do" list, but things just did not work out this year.  When I try again, this map will be my main source of information on the trail.

Mary Austin's 'The Land of Little Rain' is one of the classic works of American naturalist literature.  A short collection of essays, the book basically describes, in vivid detail, the desert landscape and its influence on the people and animals that inhabit it.  While America has produced some great writers of nature, Thoreau and Muir come to mind here, Mary Austin has no equal.  Thoreau is writing more about himself than the land he explores; Muir is selling conservation, not fairly describing what he sees and experiences.  Only Austin truly captures the land and describes its denizens in such copious (and exquisite) detail.So why do literary critics, including Terry Williams in her forward to this book, have such a difficult time capturing the essence of Austin?  I think the problem is that for the most part, you have to experience the desert to some degree before you can appreciate what Austin writes about it.  And modern critics generally don't do that.  They recognize (they think) some ideas in Austin that they sympathize with:  environmentalism, early feminism, native American rights, etc, but they then try to interpret Austin along these lines and fail dramatically.  Yes, you can quote mine Austin and find, as Williams does, some support for the 1994 Desert Protection Act.  But Williams wants to make Austin a modern environmentalist (and incidentally excoriate congressman Jerry Lewis for opposing the act) and the truth of the matter is that Austin probably would not have liked what successors have done in her name.  Her essay on the "pocket trapper," a hard rock miner always hoping to find a good strike, presupposes the opportunity for men (and women) to lose themselves chasing desert dreams, an opportunity the 1994 act explicitly forbids.  But it is in losing oneself in the desert that one eventually finds meaning and new perspectives.  The miner, Winnenap (Shoshone medicine man living, and dying in exile among the Paiutes), Seyavi (Paiute basket weaver), and a whole host of other characters who populate pages of these short essays all come to this understanding, aptly summarized in the conclusion of the title story:  you are of no account in the world.  Your very existence is effectively the result of grace.  In the desert, you see and experience this reality more clearly than you can anywhere else.Sadly, the desert Austin writes of is vanishing, largely at the hands of those who claim to be its protectors.  "Liberal" "environmentalists" and "conservationists" are busy plowing it up to create the new "green" industries of tomorrow.  Already much of the Mojave has been flattened to make way for solar energy plants, euphemistically called "farms." And while valley fever has risen proportionately with the destruction of the landscape, the California poppies, which used to put on a spectacular display every spring, have been increasingly displaced. Indeed, my wife who reveled in the poppy bloom every spring found nearly none this year. So it is with the plants and animals on the desert hills that have been leveled in regular plots and covered with roads for wind "farms."  And nary a word is offered in protest of this desecration.  But Austin does offer us some measure of hope.  The desert, she says, changes men and not the other way around.  Hopefully it will recover from the rapes of the last decade as those who work in it come to see their destruction for what it is. If not, all that will remain of the desert will be the words of Mary Austin, and few among her future readers will be able to understand them.

Richard Louv, in his classic Last Child in the Woods identifies the basic problem among children today:  they are suffering from nature deficit disorder.  The solution is fairly simple; get them outside.  But how do you do that?  Veteran outdoor author and hiker Jeff Alt, famous for his Appalachian Trail memoir, A Walk for Sunshine has an answer.  Get your kids hiking as soon as possible.  How soon is that?  Well, two to three months is fine (get a nice stroller or carrier) and get them outside.  In fact any age is fine, but sooner is better than later.  And as the subtitle strongly implies, your goal is to keep it fun.  After all, the authentic outdoor experience you are offering your children is in direct competition with the latest virtual worlds offered by the on line gaming experience, and the health of your child (and you) depends to a great degree on your child willing choosing a smart balance between the healthy authentic wilderness experience and the addictive alternatives our world offers them in copious volume.What this book offers is a how to guide for getting your child hiking at every age.  Suggestions range from activities that your child will enjoy on the trail to what sort of equipment and clothing you need to purchase.  Trail choice and length is also discussed, as are the basics of backpacking and emergency first aid.  The book does have a clear east coast bias, in part because Alt lives there, so examples seem to come predominantly from the Great Smokey Mountains and Shenandoah National Park, but moderately knowledgeable westerners will be able to apply his ideas to their own (altogether superior) outdoor options. The actual hiking situations Alt describes are universally applicable.On the whole, I thought this was a good book, in part because I like Alt's somewhat self depreciating writing style, and mostly because I think the topic he addresses is the most important one in American child rearing today.  It is all too easy to leave child rearing to the latest device (there's an app for that too!) but kids need to be engaged out of doors.  And with education moving away from the truly authentic towards a techno driven "common core" (which ironically comes with dumbed down content standards) the opportunity to raise truly well rounded children is declining.  Parents need to pick up the slack teachers like myself are increasingly leaving, and this requires active engagement with your child out of doors.  Jeff Alt's recent book is a great "how to" guide for making this happen.

Channel Islands National Park is one of the least visited parks in the country.  Not being able to drive right up to the Islands plays a big part in the relative lack of visitation, of course, but it also leads to some of the charm.  If you want to see these Islands, you need your own private sea faring boat, or you need to pony up for a passage on one of the boat concessions to get out there.  But that is half the fun.  The other half, of course, is deciding what to do once you are on the Islands, and unlike nearby (and popular) Catalina Island, you do not have the option of a resort or bed and breakfast.  What you do get is camping, hiking, kayaking, scuba adventures, and the alternative of just hanging out at the beach, sans southern California crowds.  You also have a decision about which map to take.  For years, the only real choice was Franko's, a nice recreation map of the area.  He showed all the trails, and covered alternative activities, especially scuba diving, one of his favorite sports.  But as of 2012 Franko is not personally producing maps anymore and his work was more focused on water sports in any event.  This 2006 Trails Illustrated Map is on the whole a better product, especially for those of us who enjoy hiking and sightseeing.  It is larger, provides more detail about the trails on each island, and includes up to date regulations for each island.The features I like best about this map are the numbered trails with point by point mileage.  Instead of just saying it is about 8 miles from Cuyler Harbor (depending on where you land at San Miguel) to Point Bennett, this map gives mileage between all significant stops along the way.  It also provides numbers to every major destination on each island with a key describing each hike.  An extensive text also provides recreational information specific to each island.  Camping regulations, contact information for island transportation concessionaires, and where the best wildlife viewing is available are all included with this map.  Whether you plan on a half day hike atop Anacapa, or an overnight on Santa Cruz or Santa Rosa, this map shows all your options.  On the whole then, the Trails Illustrated Map is my new primary source for Channel Islands Park recreation, especially since the older Franko maps will not be updated by the original author.  Get this one, and go see America's own Gallapagos Islands.  If you are lucky, you will be rewarded by an encounter with an Island Fox, seeing an Elephant Seal, or just taken aback by how much open space there is here so close (and yet so far away) from the bustling metropolis that is southern California.

Want high alpine scenery in southern California?  Want to explore this area on foot far from the nearest major road?  Then you want to visit the San Gorgonio Wilderness in the San Bernardino National Forest.  The San Bernardino Forest has the distinction of being the most populated forest in the United States.  Small cities (Big Bear and Lake Arrowhead) are complemented by little townships and trails in these areas are more of the short nature trail variety.  But as soon as you leave the small village of Angelus Oaks to the west, or escape Big Bear and head over Onyx summit to the east, you are in some of the wildest country in California.  State Hwy 18 traverses above the Santa Ana River, but well below the high summits in the range, all of which must be explored by foot, and all of which are found on this new map by Tom Harrison.The 2012 edition of this map, which is what Amazon is actually selling, has a number of good features compared to earlier maps of the same area.  It is up to date on mileage.  Many of these trails have been reworked since they were first built by Depression era CCC crews over a century ago, and they now have a more moderate grade.  They are also a little longer, and the new map reflects this.  The route from Fish Creek, for example, is correctly portrayed on this map as 20.8 miles.  With a contour interval of 80 feet, and a scale of 1:47,520, this map is very readable.  It is, like all recent Harrison maps, also printed on a synthetic plastic paper which is tear resistant and waterproof.  And of course, if you are one of those hikers who absolutely needs a hand held GPS unit, this map is compatible with it.  So get the map, pick up your permit, and go explore the wildest part of southern California on your next available weekend or day off.  This area is too good to take a pass on.  And take this map with you.

Every so often, I wish I lived in San Diego County's extensive backcountry. It is beautiful.  Largely chaparral, the area also features true desert and mountain forests, and you can find something to do there year round.  In the hot summer months, Mt. Laguna and the Cuyamaca Mountains offer relatively cooler hiking in evergreen forests.  In the winter, those same places offer skiing, or you can explore the nearby Anza-Borrego Desert.  And in between, the foothill areas from 1500-4000 feet in elevation, the majority of the backcountry, blossom and offer great hiking, biking, off roading...whatever your outdoor pleasure.  Indeed, my wife's great love is sketching wildflowers and spring in the San Diego backcountry offers multiple opportunities for that.  So you would think a recreational map covering this whole area would be a great idea, and you would not be alone.  Tom Harrison agrees and has updated his mid 1990s map with this 2012 color version on water proof tear resistant plastic.  It shows a lot, but therein lies the problem.Basically, in order to show all the San Diego backcountry, Harrison has to use a pretty big scale, 1:125,000.  This is two to five times the scale one would ordinarily use for a topographical map.  It means one inch is roughly two miles and contour intervals are 200 feet.  Put another way, this map will help you find general recreational areas, but it will not help you explore the trails you find there.  Some are not even on this map; others are so portrayed as so tiny that you will really only use this map to find their trail head.Having said that, there are still a lot of nice things to be said about this map. Part of the joy in exploring the San Diego backcountry lies in finding those special recreation spots in this vast land.  A map like Harrison's makes this task far easier; certainly less time consuming.  It's nice to know when you stay at Agua Caliente Regional Park (some of the nicest hot springs in southern California) that you are close to the multiple trails in Mountain Palm Springs.  Daring (or foolish, your call) cross country hikers can use this map to complete a "Canada to Mexico" ecosystem trek, from the top of Mt. Laguna to Vallecito Regional park.  And if you are hiking the Pacific Crest Trail in San Diego county, and I have done so more than once, this is a good map for you.  Harrison's trail includes point by point mileage and it is accurate!  Still, I would recommend getting more detailed maps at major recreation areas like Mt. Laguna, Cuyamaca Rancho State Park, and for the Anza-Borrego Desert.  There is only so much a map like this can convey and when it comes to exploring the area around hiking trails, less is sometimes more.

I recently picked up a copy of Jeffrey Schaffer's 'Carson-Iceberg Wilderness,' last printed in 1992.  This is but one of dozens of Wilderness Press titles that Schaffer, a consummate field geologist, topographer, and hiker produced for what was then the premier outdoor press for the western US.  I've read many of these books, and used them to plan vacations.  And taken these books for granted.  Imagine an outdoor guide that devoted extensive chapters to the physical geography of a region, ecosystems found within each microclimate of the guidebook, fishing opportunities, hunting, and of course hiking.  These used to be commonplace, in part because the writing of Jeffrey Schaffer in books like this one established it as the norm for outdoor writing.  And as I read this book, I realized just how much outdoor writing has changed since his "retirement" from active guidebook writing.  This book will likely not see another edition, and that will be a tragedy.It should go without saying that this is still the definitive guidebook to that underused section of the Sierra south of Lake Tahoe and north of Yosemite.  Here volcanism is much more prominent than in the "high" Sierra, and lakes are comparatively fewer, but this is still beautiful country, overlooked by most hikers except the growing number of PCT hikers who get to experience this wonderful land on their way to Canada.  Since the guide was printed, fishermen (who still dominate wilderness users in this area) are no longer allowed to fish in several streams where dwindling populations of Lahanton Cutthroat Trout, a rare and protected fish, still exist.  But even the chapter on fishing still contains valuable information on how to enjoy success in this sometimes difficult area to fish.  Finally, you get Schaffer's hand drawn map with meticulous attention to each and every turn in the trail.  Few outdoor authors can match his skill in this area.But what I as reader really enjoy about Shaffer's work is that his natural history chapters are not simply a recapitulation of what one can find in popular science treatments.  Schaffer, from his earliest books to his latest always utilized his own personal research, even when it conflicted with recognized authorities who did their work in the library and not in the field.  Thus he notes that the idea meadows are glacial lakes which have filled in is essentially a "geologic folk tale."  Of course, as he notes, given enough time and a drying climate, this will eventually happen, but lakes in the region are only 15,000-30,000 years old and in that entire period have only accumulated about a foot of sediment.  His evidence?  His own field research on lake sediments as opposed to the "models" that still dominate scholarship in geology.  Nor is Schaffer shy in noting what should be obvious, namely that what little warming has actually occurred recently is nothing compared to what earth has experienced in the past.  We are, he notes, in an interglacial period and in all likelihood it will be brief. Another ice age is far more likely than continued global warming.  No doubt the scientific "consensus" will disagree, but I would put my money on Schaffer's actual field research in the long run.  And if you want to explore this stunningly beautiful and relatively lonely region, you would do well to put your money on any edition of this book you can find. Guidebooks like this are just no longer written and not only will you discover a beautiful landscape, you will also learn more about the country you plan to hike.
A philosophical treatise on the future of AI that's probably too academic than what it needs to be.

I thought this book had something to do with *open*, spill-proof coffee cups that you could *carry* to work. Then I found out it was about guns. The author should be much clearer with the title next time.

Makes as good a case for preserving civil liberties and individual privacy against government interference as I have read, and you don't have to be of any particular political persuasion to appreciate the argument. Also excoriates the mainstream media with righteous, smoldering contempt for toeing the party line and publishing only "government-approved" material. Greenwald appeals to mainstream reporters to revert back to the press's original role, which was to act as an independent bulwark against government actions, not as a tool in bed with the Washington elite. Greenwald sometimes sounds a little too shrill and self-righteous in his denunciations of the mainstream media - and he is also a bit unfair in neglecting the contributions of the few dissenting reporters in conventional media sources - but if anyone has earned the right to scold it's him.The first part of the book in which Greenwald meets NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden reads like a thriller, but the second part defending the essence of privacy and freedom of the press is actually more interesting and valuable. The fact that Snowden - a relatively lowly contractor with a high school diploma - could actually listen to any phone call or read any email he wanted really attests to how easy high-tech spying has become. The scale of surveillance unearthed by the Snowden documents is stupendous and is a striking example of what has been called "technological solutionism"; you take the easy way out and collect everyone's data simply because that's the path of least resistance. However as members of Congress with access to the data themselves confessed, this "collect it all" policy has not been responsible for the prevention of a single terrorist plot since 9/11. All it does it erode individual rights and embed the national security state more deeply in our lives.For me, the most striking argument that Greenwald makes in favor of privacy is regarding its value as a driving force for unleashing human creativity and intellect; no Einstein, Picasso or Beethoven would have been able to do what they did if they constantly feared that someone was watching them. Privacy is not just about safeguarding our intimate moments or being able to express dissent, it's about being able to have the peace of mind to work and think in solitude so that human beings can achieve their highest potential. It is this most valuable human trait that government surveillance really tramples on. Important reading for all world citizens, independent of political affiliation.

In this book Nicholas Wade advances two simple premises: firstly, that we should stop looking only toward culture as a determinant of differences between populations and individuals, and secondly, that those who claim that any biological basis for race is fiction are ignoring increasingly important findings from modern genetics and science. The guiding thread throughout the book is that "human evolution is recent, copious and regional" and that this has led to the genesis of distinct differences and classifications between human groups. What we do with this evidence should always be up for social debate, but the evidence itself cannot be ignored.That is basically the gist of the book. It's worth noting at the outset that at no point does Wade downplay the effects of culture and environment in dictating social, cognitive or behavioral differences - in fact he mentions culture as an important factor at least ten times by my count - but all he is saying is that, based on a variety of scientific studies enabled by the explosive recent growth of genomics and sequencing, we need to now recognize a strong genetic component to these differences.The book can be roughly divided into three parts. The first part details the many horrific and unseemly uses that the concept of race has been put to by loathsome racists and elitists ranging from Social Darwinists to National Socialists. Wade reminds us that while these perpetrators had a fundamentally misguided, crackpot definition of race, that does not mean race does not exist in a modern incarnation. This part also clearly serves to delineate the difference between a scientific fact and what we as human beings decide to do with it, and it tells us that an idea should not be taboo just because murderous tyrants might have warped its definition and used it to enslave and decimate their fellow humans.The second part of the book is really the meat of the story and Wade is on relatively firm ground here. Wade details a variety of studies based on tools like tandem DNA repeats and single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that point to very distinctive genetic differences between populations dictating both physical and mental traits. For me the most striking evidence that something called race is real comes from the fact that when you ask computer algorithms to cluster genes based on differences and similarities in an unbiased manner, these statistical programs consistently settle on the five continental races - Caucasian, East Asian, African, Native American and African Aboriginal. Very few people would deny that there are clear genetic underpinnings behind traits like skin color or height among people on different continents, but Wade's achievement here is to clearly explain how it's not just one or two genes underlying such traits but a combination of genes - the effects of many of which are not obvious - that distinguish between races. The other point that he drives home is that even minor differences between gene frequencies can lead to significant observable differences because of additive effects.  Wade also demolishes the beliefs of many leading thinkers who would rather have differences defined almost entirely by culture - these include Stephen Jay Gould who thought that humans evolved very little in the last ten thousand years (as Wade points out, about 14% of the genome has been under active selection since modern humans appeared on the scene), and Richard Lewontin who perpetuated a well-known belief that the dominance of intra as opposed to inter individual differences makes any discussion of race meaningless. As Wade demonstrates through citations of solid research and interviews with leading geneticists, this belief is simply erroneous since a variety of genetic clustering methods do seem to point to the existence of distinct races.The last part of the book is likely to be regarded as more controversial because it deals mainly with cognitive, social and personality traits and is much more speculative. However Wade fully realizes this and also realizes that "there is nothing wrong with speculation, of course, as long as its premises are made clear", and this could be part of a scientist's credo. The crux of the matter is to ask why genes would also not account for mental and social differences between races if they do account for physical differences. The problem there is that although the hypothesis is valid, the evidence is slim for now. Some of the topics that Wade deals with in this third part are thus admittedly hazy in terms of evidence. For instance there is ample contemplation about whether a set of behavioral and genetic factors might have made the West progress faster than the East. However Wade also makes it clear that "progressive" does not mean "superior"; what he is rather doing is sifting through the evidence and asking if some of it might account for these more complex differences in social systems. Similarly, while there are pronounced racial differences in IQ, one must recognize the limitations of IQ, but more importantly should recognize that IQ says nothing about whether one human is "better" or "worse" than another; in fact the question is meaningless. Wade brings a similar approach to exploring genetic influences on cognitive abilities and personality traits; evidently, as he recognizes, the evidence on this topic is quite slim. He looks at the effects of genes on traits as diverse as language, reciprocity and propensity to dole out punishment. This discussion makes it clear that we are just getting started and there are many horizons that will be uncovered in the near future; for instance, tantalizing hints of links between genes for certain enzymes and aggressive or amiable behavior are just emerging. Some of the other paradigms Wade writes about, such as the high intelligence of Ashkenazi Jews, the gene-driven contrast between chimp and human societies and the rise of the West are interesting but have been covered by other authors like Steven Pinker, Greg Cochran and Gregory Clark. If I have a criticism of the book it is that in his efforts to cover extensive ground, Wade sometimes gives short shrift to research on interesting topics like oxytocin and hormonal influences. But what he does make clear is that the research opportunities in the field are definitely exciting, and scientists should not have to tiptoe around these topics for political reasons.Overall I found this book extremely well-researched, thoughtfully written and objectively argued. The many researchers whose work Wade cites makes the writing authoritative; on the other hand, where speculation is warranted or noted he usually explicitly points it out as such. Some of these speculations such as the effects of genetics on the behavior of entire societies are quite far flung but I don't see any reason why, based on what we do know about the spread of genes among groups, they should be dismissed out of hand. At the very least they serve as reasonable hypotheses to be pondered, thrashed out and tested. Science is about ideas, not answers.But the real lesson of the book should not be lost on us: A scientific topic cannot be declared off limits or whitewashed because its findings can be socially or politically incendiary; as Wade notes, "Whether or not a thesis might be politically incendiary should have no bearing on the estimate of its scientific validity." He gives nuclear physics as a good analogy; knowledge of the atom can lead to both destruction and advancement, but without this knowledge there will still be destruction. More importantly, one cannot hide the fruits of science; how they are used as instruments of social or political policy is a matter of principle and should be decoupled from the science itself. In fact, knowing the facts provides us with a clear basis for making progressive decisions and gives us a powerful weapon for defeating the nefarious goals of demagogues who would use pseudoscience to support their dubious claims. In that sense, I agree with Wade that even if genetic differences between races become enshrined into scientific fact, it does not mean at all that we will immediately descend into 19th-century racism; our moral compass has already decided the direction of that particular current.Ultimately Wade's argument is about the transparency of knowledge. He admonishes some of the critics - especially some liberal academics and the American Anthropological Association - for espousing a "culture only" philosophy that is increasingly at odds with scientific facts and designed mainly for political correctness and a straitjacketed worldview. I don't think liberal academics are the only ones guilty of this attitude but some of them certainly embrace it. Liberal academics, however, have always prided themselves on being objective examiners of the scientific truth. Wade rightly says that they should join hands with all of us in bringing that same critical and honest attitude to examining the recent evidence about race and genetics. Whatever it reveals, we can be sure that as human beings we will try our best not to let it harm the cause of our fellow beings. We are, all of us, human beings first and scientists second.
Light, breathable and non-smelling fabric. I have worn it in the gym for about a month now and am quite satisfied. A perfectly adequate work-out tee.
This product is effective for inducing a small time window of concentration (about 45 mins). But it burnt my throat so badly that I just could not use more than one.

I have little to add to the positive reviews of this book. Robert Caro is a national treasure who has done all of us a great service by writing what will undoubtedly go down in history as both one of the greatest political biographies of all time and a seminal study of power. The level of research in this book is truly astonishing, spanning almost forty years and constituting a book in itself. Nobody can ever top this work.What I found deeply disappointing about the series is the subpar writing. Perhaps the most egregious transgression is the way in which Caro begins every third paragraph with "And". Almost every middle school English teacher warns against doing this. Doing it occasionally is fine, but Caro completely goes overboard with it. In addition his style is extremely rambling. Almost every section contains sentences in which the asides often exceed the main points in length. The other problem is repetition; Caro is so obsessed with giving us every tiny detail from LBJ's life that he will bend over backwards every few lines to tell us the same thing - usually something about LBJ's character - in ten different ways. This sometimes makes what is undoubtedly a historic biography tedious and annoying to read.I would still definitely recommend the book and its successors, simply for the level of research and the amazing narrative about the man and his times that Caro brings us. It's a superlative example of what someone who dedicates his or her life to a single pursuit can achieve. But at the very least you should brace yourself for some subpar writing before embarking on this 3000 page journey (which will become even longer with the fifth volume). My advice: Ignore this aspect of the writing, and contemplate what the books have achieved.
