"Valley of the Girls" has a good premise, mashing up the Ancient Egyptian elite with Gossip Girl-like teens. Some fun stuff there, but the ending has the wrong feel, too much of a classic Twilight Zone vibe. "Two Houses" is a riff on classic ghost stories set on a drifting spacecraft, but is lacking in any kind of spark."Light" has a lot of potential, its protagonist works at a Florida warehouse full of people who have fallen into a coma-like slumber of unknown origin. It's a recognizable present, but one in which  alternate "pocket" universes have been discovered, and are travel to them is commonplace. Again, some interesting possibilities that never cohere over the 40+ pages. If you're a big fan of strange short fiction, you could definitely do worse than dip into this book -- but you might do better trying one of her earlier ones.

Heard good things about this author's spy novels, so I picked this one up. Wish I'd done a little research first, as it builds upon an earlier book (A Foreign Country), set about two years previously. That book introduces the protagonist and a number of the relationships that prove pivotal in this one. It's not that you have to have read the other book first, but this one would have been much richer had I had the earlier experience with the characters.The story involves the death of an MI6 agent based in Turkey, and the subsequent investigation. It's a little soap-operaish, as the dead spy had a long-term affair with the woman now running MI6. Since she doesn't want that relationship dredged up, she turns to a sidelined disgraced agent whom she is friends with, trusting him to keep mum on that aspect of the dead man's life.What follows is a plot that's quite heavy on the tradecraft of investigating, tailing, and uncovering a traitor, woven in with the redemption of the disgraced agent and his falling in love with a beautiful younger woman. It's a kind of uneasy mix -- not quite as deep as the classics of Le Carr, but not as fun as the entertainments of Fleming and the like. Smoking and drinking seem to serve as substitutes for character development, with the exotic backdrops as window dressing. It's not a bad book, but it's not particularly good either. Maybe if I'd read A Foreign Affair first, I would have been more invested in all the goings-on.

It's long been my contention that workplaces are underutilized material for fiction, considering the ripe array of characters and intricate psychology that they usually contain. This short (you can read it in under two hours) Swedish book takes a modern white-collar workplace and by introducing one extreme character, mines veins of dark comedy. The story revolves around some kind of government agency known as "The Authority," where some kind of files or forms are reviewed and coded. Bjrn is a new member of one unit, housed on a floor in an open office plan.He's an irritating, officious, (possibly sociopathic) prig, with zero social skills, who immediately makes all his colleagues uncomfortable. As an early example, when he sees a child's crayon drawing tacked up by a colleague's desk, he can't fathom why anyone would display such an inept work. Indeed, he finds himself so distracted by his the mere presence of other people and their individual tics, that he can't get his work done. That is, until he discovers a mysterious empty room in the hallway, a room that instills inner peace and mental clarity unlike any he's had. In that room he can perform great deeds of bureaucracy, becoming a shining star.The rub is that the room may or may not actually exist -- a question that throws the entire office into chaos. I suppose one could read this as an interesting treatment of ontology and the nature of truth -- but I'm not convinced it's actually that interesting. Most of the time "Kafkaesque" is used as a lazy $10 shorthand substitute for "odd" or "strange." However, in this case, the author is so deliberately invoking the tone and themes of Kafka that it's actually a fair usage. So, if that's your pleasure, definitely check this iteration out.

I have no idea of where, when, or why I picked this 40-year-old sci-fi book up, but as I've making my way determinedly through my stacks of unread books, it came to hand the other week, and I breezed through it in a few hours. Actually, I'm not sure if calling it sci-fi is quite accurate, since it it has some features of fantasy (swords, warring queens, barbarian Norsemen, a bloodthirsty dwarf, an order of knights, etc.), but since it takes place on what seems to be a far-future Earth, millennia after some kind of post-industrial ecological collapse, and ancient technology figures prominently in the plot, sci-fi seems appropriate. I'm sure that if I were more well-versed in sci-fi, there's a precise label for this particular flavor of subgenre.In any event, the story concerns a warrior-poet who has retired from the elite brotherhood of knights he once rode to glory with. However, when the young queen is threatened by a rival from the northern lands, honor compels him to wearily strap on his sword and ride forth. The upshot is that the invaders have managed to find and activate some kind of ancient warrior-bots that give them supremacy on the battlefield. The old knight must seek out some of his old fellow-knights and embark on a quest for the ancient knowledge required to counter these terrible devices. A lot of the basic elements feel familiar, and I'm sure those more well versed in fantasy and sci-fi could embark on a great deal of "reference-spotting" of where certain things were borrowed from as well as what it influenced. For me, it reminded me of the classic Dungeons & Dragons module "Expedition to the Barrier Peaks," which has a similar mix of swords and lasers.The book is a little unusual in that it's told from the perspective of the old knight, whose best days are long behind him. So, there's a whole history to the land and him and the other characters that gets alluded to, almost as if the book is actually the last in a series (Harrison would go on to write a number of books and short stories set in this world). The other thing that's distinctive about the book is the writing -- it's written in a very particular style, one that combines the florid and archaic with the modern and idiomatic. But instead of its feeling pretentious or forced, it feels fresh and of its own style. It's also kind of existential in a Blade Runnerish way, as the heroes refer to great past deeds and things they've seen, but also speak often of having wasted their lives.Finally, one of the key virtues of the book is its brevity. While some of the characters were a lot of fun, and others were left undeveloped (such as the main villain), it's nice to read a sci-fi book that's on the short side. I feel like every new sci-fi book I'm interested in is in the 400-500 page range, and suffers from bloat. It's distinctive enough that I'll probably read another in the same setting, just to see how it compares. Worth trying by those with an interest in the sort of new-wave sci-fi of the late '60s and early '70s.

This debut novel about an Air Force fighter pilot in the Korean War was heavily based on Salter's own experiences. He flew a hundred F-86 missions during his 1952 tour and kept a detailed diary, which he drew heavily upon for the book. The story revolves around a seasoned pilot with a good reputation who is assigned to a combat zone for the first time. Although confident of his abilities and eager to prove himself, it's hard to become an ace (a designation awarded after five confirmed "kills") when the enemy doesn't come out to engage. As the story progresses, he grows more and more frustrated when his missions fail to result in enemy contact, and a brash younger pilot starts racking up the kills. (One of the most interesting aspects of the book is how the bureaucratic aspects of confirmation of kills plays out, and the PR benefits of fudging the truth outweigh all others. It's hard not to draw parallels with the "body count" legerdemain that became prevalent a decade later in Vietnam.) In many ways, the book can be read as a reflection on how life can sometimes be unjust in denying able and willing people the opportunity to prove themselves. Although I doubt this was intentional (Salter was only thirty when he wrote the book), it is a potent running theme. In that sense it's a "war" book in setting only, and is worth rediscovery. NOTE: There was a film made of it starring Robert Mitchum, but it's apparently quite different from the novel.

-----------------------As with so many nonfiction books, the subtitle of this wide-ranging guide to soccer club teams from around the world is more hyperbole than accurate description. It is hardly an "essential" guide, there are few "stats", and many of the teams discussed are far from being "among the greatest in the world." Which is not to cast aspersions on the author -- everything I know about publishing makes me confident that the subtitle was massaged into place by the book's editorial and marketing teams. Just don't let it set the wrong expectation for you.What the book actually contains are nicely crafted 3-5 page overviews of major soccer teams from around the world. These generally include the club's origin story, brief history with special attention given to any glory years, and perhaps a story or two revolving around a particular well-known player or incident.Thankfully, the book avoids the temptation to concentrate too heavily on the major leagues or countries. For example, there are only about twelve English teams listed, and these include some not currently in the top tier (Wolverhampton, Notts County, Leeds). There are as many Brazilian teams covered as Italian, and only a smattering of Spanish and German sides. Most European countries are represented by a team, and there is a solid range of teams from South and Central America as well (plus six from America), and a smattering of Asian teams. Unfortunately, there are only two teams from all of Africa.Hardcore soccer fans who are well-versed in the top leagues may find much of the material old news, but I'd definitely recommend this for a teen or adult who is just developing an appreciation for club soccer and is interested in learning a little about the various teams on TV. Especially useful as a companion for international competitions such as the Champions and Europa Leagues.

I hate to use "the Q word", but this debut novel is indeed lightly quirky in tone, while also being sentimental in a way that's just the right side of mawkishness. At the heart of the book is 18-year-old Odeline, a hugely sheltered girl whose mother has just died, leaving her a chunk of money and no ties to anything. Since her goal in life is to become a world-class mime, she quite naturally uses the bulk of her money to purchase an old houseboat on the London canals.Moving into her new home, she quickly establishes herself as prickly, difficult, and wholly lacking in social skills. And while this makes her a somewhat unsympathetic protagonist, the larger issue I had was with the level of her naivet and unworldliness. At many point, Odeline's expectations and reactions read like someone moving to the big city in the 1950s, not the 2010s. If the book had been completely her story, I don't think I would have finished it.Fortunately, it's also the story of the people Odeline meets around the canal, from the dashing tattooed gypsy boatman, to the illegal Eastern European immigrant tending the cafe, to the alcoholic canal warden, and various other minor characters. Their stories are welcome interludes and interruptions to Odeline's story. The other main character is the boat she's bought -- as we get chapters devoted to its construction, use during WWII, abandonment, subsequent restoration, and ill-considered remodeling.The mix of all these elements was enough to keep me reading through the rough patches. One of these involves Odeline's quest to track down the father she never met, a reunion whose outcome is immediately obvious the moment he appears on the page, but the reader must suffer through nonetheless. In the end, it's a fine example of a feel-good, heartwarming story about regular folks of wildly different backgrounds making community and connections amidst the hustle and bustle of the big city. Cynics and misanthropes should avoid.

I picked this up because it's about Palestinians and soccer, both topics I have an interest in. However, I was a little leery of it being a book pitched at teenage readers -- I was worried that it would either be too simplistic, or didactic, or mawkish. Fortunately, it is none of those things -- rather, it is a nuanced story with a Palestinian boy at its center that any reader can relate to.Karim is a pretty typical 12-year: obsessed with soccer and video games, constantly annoyed by his younger sister and older brother, and chafing at life under constant threat of military occupation and curfew in Ramallah. The story follows his new friendship with a refugee boy in parallel with his close friendship with a Christian schoolmate. Their antics are both entirely plausible, and utterly chilling in the stakes that are involved. What the book does best of all is portray the difficulty of trying to live a normal life, let alone build a future, in a place where an outsider's tanks might roll down the streets and destroy your school at any moment. To be sure, I suppose most would consider this a "pro-Palestinian" story -- but it's really a pro-humanity story.

I picked this up while on a trip to Indiana, mainly because when I travel I like to read fiction set in the area I'm visiting. The book's premise also caught my attention -- various colorful characters make their way to a famous annual bare-knuckles cage match tournament where the winner takes home $100,000. Unfortunately, despite it being a quick read, it's boring -- mainly because there is little to differentiate any of the characters or their actions.I have no issue with violence in film or fiction, and have enjoyed plenty of pulpy bloody action stories on screen and page. However, this book is and endless succession of hard men beating the living **** out of each other (and sometimes shooting, stabbing, clubbing, etc.), when they're not buying, selling, or using crank, or engaged in some other equally "shocking" activity (the lone female character of significance is meth-fueled sexpot). Various people have grudges against others, owe each other money, need to mete out revenge, and soforth, but there's nothing remotely engaging about any of it.Actually, what it sometimes most resembles is a video game where one can select from one of about six or seven characters and has to fulfill a series of missions in order to make it to the big showdown. The guy running the titular tournament even has a lair, minions, and associates, just like a video game "boss". The amount of punishment people can take in this book contributes a lot to the cartoony feel -- this is the kind of book where people who are shot will start yelling stuff like "You <effing> shot me -- I'll <effing> rip your liver out and fry it for breakfast!" (not an actual quote, but you get the idea), rather than scream in pain.I guess some readers could be fascinated by the portrayal of the hopeless poor underclass of modern America, but to me it came across more as poverty porn than anything else. (You could, I suppose, read it as all a big allegorical critique of modern capitalist America, but that's a more generous interpretation than I'm willing to give.) The prose style is also kind of abrasive -- there are a lot of sentences and turns of phrases that are ostentatiously ragged. Every now and then, there's a nice turn of phrase or twist of vernacular, but for every one of these, there are nine others that feel overly calculated.The book also features a very light line of the supernatural via one character, and references to this being just the start of something bigger. So I guess there's going to be a sequel, but I certainly won't be reading it.

I picked this up on the strength of its setting -- a retrofuturistic canal-chopped Arctic city called "New Venice." Ten pages in and I was enjoying the author's keen imagination, stage-setting, colorful elements, and playful language. Fifty pages in and I was getting a bit weary of the meandering introduction of the two main characters, a college professor and a city bureaucrat, both of whom may or may not be involved in some kind of underground dissident movement. And by 100 pages, my initial enthusiasm had completely petered out -- nothing was happening...I will grant that when crafting a trilogy in a fantastic setting, authors often need to do some world-building. However, the start of this book suffers from too many details and not enough action. To be sure, there's lot of cool stuff involving mind-altering drugs, Eskimos, secret police, crazy music and crazier fashion, technology, and whatnot. But it's a jumble of elements rather than a story, and I just don't have the patience or time to read the remaining 300 pages to see if anything happens.

This uneasy mix of small town portrait and crime novel never quite settles into something truly satisfying. Set in a small Alaska coastal town, where supplies need to come in via seaplane, it features a pair of brothers supported by a cast of colorful characters. Miles is an ex-Army medic who just wants to live the quiet life after service in the Middle East. As the only person with medical training for hundreds of miles, he knows the community inside and out. Meanwhile, his brother Clive is getting out of jail after seven years, and heads to town with a duffle-bag full of cash.Who rightfully owns the cash is a matter of interpretation, and as with all stories featuring such bags, someone comes looking for Clive and the cash. But that's only one of several threads -- there's Clive's attempt to build a bar for the tiny town, Miles' attempt to carve out a meaningful place in the world for himself, and even a lengthy digression into a minor character's quest to travel to Seattle to meet the Dalai Lama.Only recently published, the book was actually written many years ago, and it has the feel of a first effort -- straining heavily towards being something of an Elmore Leonard joint. But but by trying too hard at doing several things at once, it never hits its stride with any of them. Still, worth checking out if you're interested in fiction set in Alaska.

If you like your crime novels with a heavy does of social commentary, this one set in early 1980s NYC is just the ticket. The book introduces Filomena Buscarsela, a NYPD patrolwoman who, as a female Latina immigrant, is the ultimate outsider. Responding to a toxic incident at a food bank, she stumbles into a strange plot involving a potential environmental coverup by a real-estate developer, coupled with the possible murder of an artist. The story takes her in and out of the seedy East Village punk/new-wave scene as she pokes around for information, conducting an investigation that's way above her pay grade.Although she contains elements typical of the hard-boiled genre protagonist (heavy drinker, self-destructive, sarcastic/cynical cracks, etc.), she remains a refreshing character to follow down the mean streets of Reagan-era America. It's kind of a fantasy plot in a way -- the brown lefty heroine standing up to the corrupt capitalist gentrifiers. The story is OK, nothing special -- the real reason to read the book is for its unabashed politics. Those who have only experienced the cleaned up New York of the last 20-25 years may find much to astonish in these pages, while those who lived it will be reminded of just how bad it was.I'll definitely be seeking out the next in the series -- Soft Money.

I've never heard of World Fantasy Award-winner Joyce before, but the coming-of-age plot of this (more or less) non-fantasy book caught my attention. It's a quasi-autobiographical story narrated by an English teenager who has just finished his first year of college. The year is 1976, and instead of working as a laborer for his stepfather's construction business, David takes a jack-of-all-trades hospitality gig at a seaside resort in Skegness.Lounging on England's east coastline, about 150 miles north of London, Skegness has all the charm of a third-rate destination. The resort is a fading institution, catering to the outmoded variety-show holiday tastes of the working class who are soon to be ground under the heel of Thatcherism. As one might expect from such a setting, David is thrust into a colorful and bewildering cast of coworkers, including a jabbering Mancunian roommate, an Italian tenor, some terrifying kitchen workers, a beautiful dancer, a jolly impresario with a dark side, and dangerously dour cleaner married to a much younger attractive woman. Adventures with all these people ensue, and David learns a bit about life while the reader gets a nostalgic portrait of a bygone time and place.Meanwhile, David is also being plagued by momentary glimpses of a mysterious man with a small child. This is the ghost of the title, and the reader discovers early on that his natural father had some connection to Skegness, and that the man in the suit has some connection to his father. The light comedy and romance of David's adventures complement the heavier tone of the more supernatural storyline, and the combination succeeds. Definitely recommended for those who enjoy coming-of-age plots or fiction set in 1970s England.

This novella (you can read it in one sitting) is a satirical take on what would happen if the second coming of Jesus happened today, in America. The gimmick is that no one in our narcissistic digital era would take him at face value, and so after months of drifting around the country and being arrested for vagrancy, he stages a bank robbery in order to gain media attention to draw the attention of someone who might actually believe.The story is told in short sections by the various people he encounters in the course of this scheme. There's Neil, an average guy whose wife and kids place ever-increasing material demands on him. The small town police chief who locks up the "Jesus Bandit." The bank teller he robs, who believes he is He. The atheist New York Times reporter who flies in to capture the story. And even the evangelical President, who secretly meets with him/Him. Given the brevity of the book, they all come across more as types, than a fully-realized characters.The overall effect is more cutesy than provocative -- but then again, as a nonbeliever, I suppose the basic premise lacks dramatic stakes for me. It feels kind of like the story someone might put together as a final short project in film school. There's no real depth of engagement with the questions it raises. I guess it could have value in some kind of religious education setting as something teens could read and use as the starting point for some kind of discussion.

At this point, there are certainly hundreds, and possibly thousands of Sherlock Holmes pastiches published. They're kind of like junk food of a sort -- hit the spot when you're in the mood for them, but most are unsatisfying on any deeper level. I picked this one up because it had been sitting on my shelf for a number of years, left behind by a houseguest and I can now see why it had been abandoned...The case revolves around two murders at Queen Victoria's Scottish lair of Holyroodhouse, which appear to have some connection to the centuries-previous murder of the titular courtier in the presence of Mary Queen of Scots. Mycroft -- who is apparently a confidante of the Queen -- sends for his brother, lest anything befall Victoria. Before long, we're knee deep in bomb-throwing Scottish nationalists, butlers with glass eyes, and hidden passages in a haunted castle. It's certainly got all the feel and color of a Holmes tale, but it lacks flavor and substance.The book feels like a short story/novella that's been padded as much as possible to get to 300 pages -- lots and lots of dead, talky scenes. It also doesn't have any really great reveals or twists -- and few memorable scenes. The characters are there, the period language is there, and the pages turn, but it's flat.

The box has 8 packets of apple, 4 of Asian pear, and 4 of tangerine. I took a bunch of a hike with some other families, figuring they would be good snacks for adults and kids. The apples were fine, tasted like generic apples, nothing much to them. The Asian pears were slightly better in my estimation, a nice subtle flavor, but I was the only person who liked them. The tangerines were a universal disaster -- six different people tried them, and all six spit them out! Something about the freeze-drying process amplified the tartness and taste to the point where they were just overwhelming. The packets are pretty small, so if you really wanted a proper snack, you're gonna need two of 'em. All in all, not worth it from a taste and value perspective.

I've always known Cristy Road to be a multidimensional artist, playing in bands, writing and publishing zines, and producing amazing artwork. I even commissioned her to do the cover of a one-issue zine I did years ago. However, other than knowing she's a bit of an icon in the queer punk community, and must be a big Green Day fan based on her nom de plume, I didn't really know anything about her. This short-but-striking memoir of her life at ages 11-13 chronicles not only her home and school life, but her raging inner turmoil as she tries to work out her identity.It's a classic story of a kid from a loving, but somewhat repressive cultural context -- she grew up in a Cuban-American family in Florida with traditional Catholic attitudes toward homosexuality. School life is no better, as the misery of middle school in the early 1990s (cruel girls, idiotic boys, hormones everywhere) is further complicated by her inner sense of being different. Like so many alienated kids, Road finds consolation and connection in music -- in her case, the pop-punk of a Green Day tape loaned to her by another outsider at school.As someone who both also found connection through punk (in my case The Clash), and bought Green Day's debut EP, 1,000 Hours, when I was still in high school in 1989, I can completely understand the depth of her passion for her new discovery. So, even though I'm a middle-aged straight white guy and didn't face her agonies about sexual identity and otherness, her memoir still strikes a chord. And of course, her trademark illustrations and text is amazing as always. She's got such a bold, confident and distinctive style -- here sometimes deployed in ways that are more imaginative and grotesque than usual. Highly recommended for teens and tweens everywhere who don't feel like they belong.

For legal razzle-dazzle crime novels, the Mickey Haller series is hard to beat. I loved The Lincoln Lawyer and have been on board for the rest of the series, but this fifth entry left a little something to be desired. In it, Haller is hired by a scrawny man accused of killing a prostitute. It seems he was a kind of quasi-pimp to her -- he set up her web presence as an escort, managed her bookings, and took a cut of her fee. Soon enough, though, Haller has identified another suspect and managed to tie this murder into a whole series past events, including the framing on a mid-level cartel member.More so than in past books in the series, the story really becomes a detective tale, as Haller and his investigator trawl these past cases for connections, and a legal basis to tie what they find in the past to the current defense case. Meanwhile, he also works on trying to salvage his relationship with his daughter and starts up a new romance with a yoga instructor.Connelly's strength is not his writing, its his plotting. For some reason, it's not enough for him to lay out situations so that the reader can very easily infer why people do or say things, Time and again in this book, he has to stop and take a sentence to spell out each and every motivation, as if it hadn't been made obvious in the preceding paragraphs. It's kind of insulting to his readers and I'm surprised his editor didn't go through and fix these.But as complex as the plot is in this case, Haller's success hinges almost entirely on his tricking the villains into doing something very stupid which he gets on camera. It's awfully hard to buy that these guys would take such a large risk over something that, even if brought forward, wouldn't have won the day for Haller. I dunno, maybe I need to go back and reread that section, because it just didn't seem that plausible. One other plot point that was problematic for me is that the case against Haller's client is at least partially built on his having an argument with the dead prostitute about getting his share of the money. It seems like someone savvy enough to build nice online sites would be able to figure out a simple way to do all the payments electronically so that the services being purchased are cloaked.Issues with the writing and plotting aside, it was generally pretty enjoyable, and fans of series will get their Haller dose.

I picked this up because I've always enjoyed Stevenson's fiction, and I'd heard this account of his trip across the United States in 1879 was an outstanding example of travel writing. It is indeed that, but not quite in the way that I expected. His trip was originally documented in three separate publications: The Amateur Emigrant, Across the Plains, and The Silvarado Squatters, which were originally published out of sequence. The Amateur Emigrant wasn't published until after his death due to its potential to bring Stevenson into disrepute. Even then, was controversial due to what was then perceived to be too frank and graphic an account of the lower classes.The version I read is the DaCapo Press 2002 paperback, which includes The Amateur Emigrant, Across the Plains, but not The Silvarado Squatters. The first section takes up about 60% of the book, and covers his ten days of sea passage from Scotland to New York. The second section covers his train trip from New York to San Francisco. There, the story abruptly ends, without the section of his time in California. So, what one gets is a highly detailed picture of what a typical emigrant to America of the time might go through to get there. It's an interesting portrait of shipboard society and train etiquette  but not quite what I was expecting. He has much to say on his fellow travelers, and displays a sharp eye for the mannerism or words that betray a person's true character. But on the whole, I'd say it's probably of limited interest to the modern reader, save those with greater than average interest in immigration to early Gilded Age America.

Lottie is a rich, bratty, brand-obsessed London teenager who dresses (and is drawn) like a goth porn star. When she is arrested for trying to get into a club with a fake ID (has anyone, in the history of ever, actually been arrested for this?), her parents pack her off to the grandparents in the Lake District. Naturally, she has utter contempt for the locals and their town, and recoils in horror at the prospect of being a salesclerk at a small golf store.When a local lady turns up dead in a golf course water trap, with a possibly occult symbol on her arm, Lottie somewhat inexplicably suddenly decides she's Nancy Drew. Unfortunately for the reader, the mystery is somewhat clumsy, and the red herrings far too obvious. And when things take a turn for the supernatural, the book spirals into out of control silliness. The art is fairly simple and mundane (unless you're a 12-year-old boy), and Lottie is completely annoying as a protagonist. Can't recommend this to anyone.

This is a great concept -- when Korean-American teenager Grace Kwon turns 18, something rips in the time-space continuum, and all of a sudden, she's got three new companions: her 6-year-old self, her 29-year-old self, and her 70-year-old self. They aren't the imaginary products of a splintered psyche, they're real walking, talking people, throwing pies at her nemesis, coming on to her drama teacher, and filching her dad's cigarettes.Each is a manifestation or warning to Grace about the choices she is, or might make, but in the mean time, she has to figure out how to keep them secret from her parents while also making sure they are fed and sheltered! The other running storylines are the production of the school play, of which Grace is the lead, and the silent longing of her longtime friend. All of this plays out in a somewhat predictable, but fun nonetheless, version of a teen romantic, coming of age, comedy. There are one or two wobbles, for example, the rather sudden detente between Grace and her lifelong enemy, but nothing too problematic.Definitely worth recommending, and I'm surprised it hasn't been made into a kind of Michel Gondry/Spike Jonez/Charlie Kauffman style film.

In 23rd-century Seattle, 14-year-old Telly spends the bulk of her time in virtual reality, whether its learning in school, or in her online "lair." In this imagining of our future world, we are all members of lairs (essentially MMOish "Second Life" type virtual worlds) catering to our particular interests. Telly's lair is a kind of Tim Burtonesque gothy-steampunky place, where she has two close friends (one of whom is kimmie66). When kimmie sends a virtual suicide note, Telly embarks on quest to find out if the note was real or just roleplaying.The themes of real world vs. virtual world, and the differences and distinctions between them, have been worked and reworked countless times in science fiction. This book, which is presumably aimed at teenage girls, does a nice job of covering this turf in an accessible manner. Telly's search for kimmie66 and her possible haunting by kimmie66's ghost is engaging and feels true. What she uncovers is pretty interesting, and triggers even more questions about consciousness and reality. It's not particularly deep, but it's accessible for young teens and the art is distinctive.

I picked this up because I'm always on the lookout for funny fiction, and the sad truth is that much of what is marketed or described as humorous fiction rarely tickles my funny bone. This debut collection of 60+ "stories" definitely hits the mark in terms of humor, but misses in the area of fiction. That's not to say the contents aren't all made up or fictional, just that it's more like a compilation of situations or premises, ranging from a few sentence to a few pages. In glancing through the acknowledgements, I noticed that the author mentioned being able to test a lot of the material as comedy clubs, doing standup. And that's kind of the feel a lot of it has, very smart, and sometimes dark, longish form standup. There's really only two or three pieces that are of the length and depth one would expect to find in a traditional collection of short fiction. This falls more into the category of microfiction, and there's nothing wrong with that, just don't expect anything that's going to stick to your bones. It's definitely a nice book to have by the bedside table, or perhaps that other room in the house/apartment where one can grab a few moments of quiet to sit and read..., since you can dip into it for a quick hit of quirky (I know, I know, terrible word) humor, and then put it back down and walk away.

Despite the cheesy cover (c'mon Oceanview, you really need to work on your covers, they're awful), longtime crime reporter Michael Krikorian's first novel is a rippin' and runnin' trip down LA's mean streets. With more than fifteen years covering LA gangs for the Los Angeles Times and LA Weekly under his belt, Krikorian is about as inside the gang world as an outsider can get. The story told here is a fictionalized account of a middle-aged vigilante stalking those he feel are complicit in a failure of justice. The protagonist is a very thinly fictionalized version of the author, sharing the same first name, profession, and general interests as Krikorian.When fictional Michael gets shot by an unknown assailant, it sets off a police and media investigation that quickly leads toward Bloods set leader Cleamon "Big Evil" Johnson -- currently serving life without parole at Pelican Bay. The cops and the reporter race to try and make sense of the series of attacks and how they fit into Big Evil's past. The result is a fast-paced procedural with sharp patter among cops, journalists, and gangsters. Plot-wise, it's good stuff, especially for readers with an interest in Los Angeles. Prose-wise, it can get a little clunky at times -- it's evident that the author doesn't have much experience writing fiction.Which raises a kind of interesting point. This might be the first non-historical crime book I've read where basically every character is based on a person in real life, sometimes right down to the same name. For example, you can search the internet for "Big Evil" and read all about him -- including the crime that led to his incarceration, details of which vary only slightly from those in the book. The lead homicide cop in the book is also a real person, as is at least one of the other reporters. It doesn't really hurt or help the story either way, it's just kind of striking how closely Kirkorian hewed to reality.In any event, there's definitely enough to the book that I would read more in the series. This is the first in a projected quartet (Northside, Eastside, Westside) that would continue to create a rich portrait of Los Angeles through the eyes of "Michael" be he real or fictional.

I've been leery of children's cough syrups for a long time, and wanted to stock the medicine cabinet with something non-medicated for quite some time. Picked this up and tried it for the first time last week when our 5-year-old had a light cough. Hard to say if it works works, or the placebo effect kicked in. Either way, the coughing died down and he was able to fall asleep. No issues with the taste from his end (I didn't sample it). So far so good!

I have to admit I snack quite a bit at work, and one of my favorite snack is nuts. So I picked these up to try something different from my usual almonds. These are "glazed" cashews, which means they have that slightly strange dry surface texture you get from certain kinds of candied nuts you get from street vendors in some parts of the world. And these definitely are candied! I have a bit of a sweet tooth and like a ton of sugar in my tea, but even I found these to be borderline too sweet. What worked best for me was to take a package of these and mix them with an equivalent measure of unsalted, plain cashews. That still gave nice flavor without the overwhelming sugar hit. Just to be clear, those little hunks red aren't pomegranate, they're apple infused with pomegranate juice. And of course, like most nut snacks, these are a lot of calories -- so as tasty as these are, avoid if you're looking for a healthy snack.

I didn't love the plotting of the first book in the Leo Haggerty series (Embrace the Wolf), but I did find Haggerty a compelling enough character to pick up this second one. As in the first book, the private detective is hired to find a missing person, this time a 13-year-old girl from an affluent neighborhood near Alexandria, Virginia. Also like the first book, it follows a very traditional procedural path, as Haggerty follows standard methods to trace the girl's whereabouts. This takes him from the innocuous settings of teen life: a high school, a shopping mall, homes, to the sordid: seedy strip-clubs, hot-sheet motels, a bars of Route 1. What's harder for him to discern is why the girl ran away from home, although I suspect most readers will have a pretty keen idea fairly early on.Haggerty's sidekick, a Medal of Honor-winning ex-Green Beret with a personal arsenal rivaling that of any survivalist, is a big presence in the book. One that allows him to tangle with some pretty nasty and violent characters throughout. Haggerty is one of those private eyes who isn't shy of getting his hands bloody if it means getting the job done. One thing that makes this series a little more interesting than others is that there's a nice level of introspection to Haggerty, it's both well written and realistic, not perfunctory navel-gazing. That's probably a testament to the author's day job as a clinical psychologist, and there's real insight there.Another thing I like about the series is that there are consequences -- people get hurt, and sometimes quite gruesomely. The one main quibble I have is that one of the main villains is a huge African-American ex-football player named Leroy, and the combination of details leaves a tinge of racism in the mouth -- but maybe that's just me. The book also has a subplot involving a budding romance Leo has with a freelance writer, which is also handled quite well. All in all, an slight improvement from Embrace the Wolf -- I will now seek out A Tax in Blood to see what happens next.

Don't be misled by this debut author's uptown credentials (New York Times Magazine culture editor, This American Life, GQ), or the hyperbole of the publisher ("genre-busting" and "I promise you've never read anything like this") -- this is basically a competently executed work of cyberpunk. All the tropes are there: the hard-boiled style, the dystopian setting, the antihero protagonist, the immersive virtual reality, the class commentary, the hackers, the dive bars, and of course, the mean streets down which we must travel. Don't get me wrong, it's a decent version of the genre, but from William Gibson's Neuromancer (and even Philip K. Dick before him) to Richard Morgan's Altered Carbon, this is well-trodden territory.The story takes place in a very near-future New York City, which has seen about half it's population and wealth flee in the wake of a Time Square dirty bomb and ongoing spate of subsequent car bombs. (This was actually kind of a problem for me -- I couldn't quite figure out how the economy of Manhattan worked in the book, since the financial sector has completely vacated the premises, wiping out all the supporting economic activity as well, and tourism has gone as well. The city is essentially lawless, but meanwhile the rest of the country seems to operate more or less normally. It works as a metaphor, but not as a plausible setting.) An ex-garbageman known as "Spademan" (nod to Dashiell Hammett) who suffered some kind of loss (no points for guessing what or how) now drifts through life as a hitman. The kind who doesn't ask any questions or care about circumstances, as long as the client pays and the target is 18 or older.As he puts it several times in his deadpan first-person narration, "think of me as a bullet" (a nod to the classic "I am a bullet" line from the amazing film Performance?) -- he is just a tool, and makes no judgement. Of course he is presented with a target which confounds his straightforward rules, and so the story kicks off. Soon enough, he becomes the protector of his target (a trope from the thriller genre this time), and has to enlist the help of his friends to battle the charismatic leader of a mega-chruch (and in another trope, is predictably evil). There's really not a whole lot to it -- some decent action scenes, some decent, terse, hard-boiled writing, a few interesting supporting characters. I guess people who've never been exposed to cyberpunk might find this book eye-opening or refreshing, but I found it kind of predictable and the blend of grimy future with hard-boiled characters and a thriller plot didn't take me anywhere new or interesting.

My son is crazy over these joggers.  The pair he has does not hang down as far in the crotch as the picture but he is fine with that.  They fit him just right and he loves them.  The material is super soft, the joggers are well made with no loose seems and the pockets are nice and big.  If he could wear these every day, he would.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I cannot say enough good things about this beautiful necklace.  The cushion cut acrylic stone pendant looks amazing on the goldtone chain.  This is simple, yet so gorgeous!  Probably my new favorite piece of jewelry.  My husband loves the way it looks on me and so do I.  Pair it with a simple pair of earrings so it won't be upstaged, although I don't think that is possible.  Truly stunning!  Love it!  Also, you can wear this short (as a choker) or longer (like in my pictures). The chain is adjustable. Bonus!  Sample provided for testing, evaluation and review.

This is one of those staples that every woman needs in her jewelry box.  Classic faux pearls look great with so many things.  A multi-strand of faux pearls is a classic statement necklace that takes your pearl game up a notch.  This is a beautiful necklace that will get a lot of wear so make sure you limit contact with water, perfume or body cream/lotion to avoid tarnish.  Comes in a cute box perfect for gift giving.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

So stylish and beautiful!  This multi-strand necklace features cascading chains that are embellished with CZ diamonds.  It gives the appearance of many necklaces and the effect is really eye-catching.  I have not had any problems with the chains getting tangled...believe it or not they hang great with no problems.  I love the way this looks with a simple tunic or with a low cut blouse and jacket or sweater.  Either way you will get tons of compliments.  To make sure it doesn't tarnish avoid contact with water, perfume or body lotion/cream.  Sample provided for testing, evaluation and review.

This is one of the cutest styles I've seen in a long time.  The bow back blouse can be worn with jeans or dress it up with slacks or pencil skirt.  This chiffon blouse could easily take you from day to night with no problems.  The 100% polyester blouse is very lightweight and easy to clean.  It is quite sheer so you will want to wear a cami or something underneath, unless you are comfortable just wearing a flesh toned bra.  It runs a little small so be sure and go up a size to make the fit just right.  I have to add that I absolutely LOVE the royal blue.  Such a beautiful color.  (The last picture is with flash ON so you can see the vibrant royal blue. Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.This Bow Back chiffon blouse is lightweight and luxurious.

I absolutely love the style of this tissue weight cardigan.  It is 100% rayon, soft and comfy to wear, stretchy and versatile.  You can wear it open or tied and get a totally different look.  Since this is so light weight it is not going to do much in the area of keeping you warm, but it really is cute!  It would be perfect to keep around the office in the summer when the office thermostat wars begin.  It runs very small to make sure that you order a size or two bigger than what you normally wear.  Sample provided for testing, evaluation and review.

This is a beautiful red...so vibrant and bright.  I would say a true red.  I used to sell cosmetics behind "the counter" and I would love, love, love to match a lipstick to this red cardigan.  Every woman needs a few cardigans in her closet... a definite staple.  This is the perfect weight cardigan to take you through any season.  It is very versatile and can be worn many ways.  The 60% cotton, 40% polyester blend is lightweight and comfortable, stretchy and easy to wash.  Unfortunately it was way too small for me so I had to give it to my mother.  Be sure to order a size or two up because it definitely runs small.  Sample provided for testing, evaluation and review.

A good black cardigan is a staple in every woman's closet.  The cotton blend (55% cotton and 45% rayon) is very soft.  It is lightweight and perfect for layering.  It is well made with all seams stitched perfectly.  Looks great on.  *NOTE - order at least one if not 2 sizes bigger than you normally wear.  I am plus-sized and it did not fit me.  My loss was my mother's gain.  Looks great on her too.  :)Sample provided for testing, evaluation and review.

Wow!  This is such a beautiful pearl statement necklace.  It is layered with a goldtone chain and CZ crystals.  The acrylic and crystal stones really stand out and, well...make a statement.  I received so many compliments on this last nice.  I stopped by a bridal store to have my son fitted for a tux and a shopper in the store asked if I purchased the necklace there.  She was a bride to be and was looking for something just like this.  She loved it and so do I!  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

This Salad Spinner works fine. I had no problems with it getting the water out of the lettuce.  The strainer fits perfectly into the spinner and it is very easy to use.  Simply put the lettuce, fruit or whatever it is you are washing into the straining basket and add water.  Don't add too much or it won't drain properly.  Put the lid on and hold it down tight (because it does not fasten) and then start turning the crank (this is the fun part).  My kids actually love this part.  Spin it as much as you see fit and then either let it stop on its own or press the stop button.  Pull the strainer basket out, dump the water that is in the bowl and repeat.  The bowl and strainer basket are easy to clean but the spinner lid is not.  Well, you can rinse it well but it is hard to get dry since the water gets inside of it.  The storage lid that I received did not fit.  I contacted the company and they wanted me to send a video showing them what I meant.  I didn't have time to do that so I guess I will just live without the lid, although I really hoped to have a lid for storage purposes.  Product received for testing, evaluation and review.

This is the cutest little butterfly LED tea light holder.  I have one that is about 3 times this size and the two of them are perfect matches.  They will look so cute when the weather is warm enough to sit outside.  Of course they can be used indoors as well and look great as a centerpiece for a quiet dinner, on the mantle or anywhere to add a little whimsical touch (you can also hang it by handle if desired).  The butterfly shapes show up on the wall when illuminated....so pretty.  It uses standard LED tealights (not included).  Would make a great gift for someone who loves fairies, butterflies, etc...  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I'm so excited about these elves!  We have been doing the whole "Elf On a Shelf" thing for about 10 years in my house.  We currently have 2 elves (one that came with the book and one I picked up somewhere a few years ago).  Believe it or not, it is not as easy to find a plush elf as you would think.  These are super cute....so well made and soft.  I can't wait to get them in on the fun around here starting the day after Thanksgiving.  I'm very glad to have a girl elf this year.  Such a fun tradition.

My husband and I both suffer from plantar fasciitis, so we have used our fair share of foot massagers...always searching for the best.  This foot massage roller is right up there at the top of my go to list.  Not only is it lightweight and portable but I can use it on both feet at the same time.  It also will massage the arches and the entire foot at the same time.  BONUS!  The rollers feel great on my feet and really help relieve some of the pain as well as increase circulation in my feet.  I think this would be good for my MIL (she has diabetes related foot problems).  The bottom is non-slip rubber so it can be used on any type of floor.  Great little massage roller.  Product purchased at a discount in exchange for testing and review.

I love this brush.  It works great on my hair...gets the tangles out without pulling a lot of my hair out (like some detangling brushes do).  It is very big and easy to hold (and quite difficult to lose, which is a definite plus considering that my brushes always seem to get lost).  Great for straightening my hair.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

Where were these about 5 years ago when I took my boys to a truck and tractor pull?  They really buff out the noise.  They don't completely eliminate the noise but definitely make a difference.  They are well made, fit great (on my kids' heads AND mine), are very comfortable, adjustable and lightweight.  If my son wants to take these to school for testing time I am sure it would be fine with the teacher and they would definitely help him concentrate by eliminating all of the small distractions that really add up.  We have been using them at home for homework and reading time (one of my boys plays the drums so it makes it hard for his brothers to concentrate when he is practicing).  They come in handy.  Great to have!  Product purchased at a discount for testing, evaluation and review.

1:50 Mins This rug is beautiful!  The colors and floral design is gorgeous...very rich and classy, yet cozy at the same time.  The rug is very well made, does not slid around on my carpet and the corners don't lift up.  I simply vacuum it at the same time that I vacuum the carpet.  Plus, it is machine washable if needed.  Very high quality and looks expensive.  Love it!  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

My father is ALWAYS cold.  We can stop by his house in the summer and he's wearing a jacket and sock hat in the house...I'm totally serious.  He always complains about getting cold at night because his wife is the opposite of him (she's always hot) and has a fan running at night.  I got this hat for him to wear when he sleeps so that he doesn't have to sleep with his sock hat on.  He loves how soft it is and the fact that he can pull it down over his eyes to block out the light if his wife is reading in bed.  Washes easily without shrinking.  Great gift idea if you have a dad like mine.  Product purchased at a discount for testing, evaluation and review.

This looks great on our SUV.  The stainless steel really makes it look sharp, especially considering the wheels we have (which are supposedly nice, according to my husband and all of his buddies).  It was very easy to install; took my husband about 5 minutes.  Plus, since it is stainless steel I don't have to worry about it rusting.  I never realized how big of a difference a nice license plate holder could make until we put this on our SUV.  Purchased at a discount for testing, evaluation and review.

I have very weak nails that split occasionally and don't grow as well as I would like them to.  I take vitamins and biotin daily but like to use a hardener also.  Not only does it help my nails grow but also protects my nails and helps them not be so brittle and split.  Also, if I don't feel like wearing polish, it gives my nails a nice manicured look without having color on them.  So far I like the way my nails look with this product and look forward to the long term results.  Product purchased at a discount for testing, evaluation and review.

I suffer from terrible migraines that are usually triggered by light...so I can't leave the house without sunglasses.  These glasses look great on me.  (Well, at least my husband and I think so.)  They are very well made and sturdy.  The polycarbonate composite lenses are shatterproof and the color is nice and dark.  They are not polarized but provide 100% protection from UVA/UVB rays...so I can wear them knowing my eyes are protected.  The frame is made of plastic and the arms are attached very well.  They sit comfortably on my nose and don't slide at all.  Bonus - they came with a really great eyeglasses holder so they can be protected when not in use (because the bottom of my purse is a very dangerous place for a pair of sunglasses).  I am very impressed.  Product purchased at a discount for testing, evaluation and review.

Honestly the most comfortable pear of hipster panties I have ever worn.  They are a very breathable nylon/elastane blend.  The front and back panels are super soft microfiber that stretches and gives as needed.  They do not ride at all.  Most plus size panties have the tendency to look ugly and not flattering at all.  These are the complete opposite. They are very flattering and stylish as well.  I'm impressed and look forward to buying more in the future.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

0:36 Mins This is by far the greatest thing to hit my house in years.  My kids are fighting over it every single day...and that is NOT an exaggeration.  It was delivered and easy to use right out of the box...it was even fully charged so my kids didn't have to wait to use it.  I am very impressed by how sturdy and durable it is.  It is very well made and easy to learn.  Even my 68 year old father has ridden it a couple of times.  Granted, he's not as smooth on it as my kids but he didn't fall (a definite bonus for him).  The booklet says the safe highest speed is 12 km/h but we haven't gotten it that fast yet.  It goes up hills easily without losing much speed and goes around corners without missing a beat.  At first my kids were very protective of it and preferred to ride it inside because they didn't want to scuff it up on gravel and the pavement.  They are over that, however, and have been riding it around the neighborhood.  I would recommend wearing a helmet with it for ultimate safety.  It takes about an hour to fully charge and that will get you about 3-4 hours of riding time.  This thing is awesome and is going to be one of the hottest items on lists this Christmas.  I highly recommend this model.  We love it!  Sample provided for testing, evaluation and review.

If you love nautical jewelry then you will really want this bracelet.  I gave it 4 stars but it is very small.  The picture is my 12 year old niece's wrist.  As you can see it fits her just right with no extra room.  It is not short enough to wear as a single bracelet but when you wrap it around twice it is very small.  That being said it is well made, sturdy and gorgeous.  The woven bracelet looks great with the goldtone anchor.  It is too small for me but my niece is very grateful to take it off my hands.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

Wow!  This statement necklace is absolutely stunning!  The acrylic gemstones and CZ diamonds look amazing against the goldtone link chain.  This necklace is definitely going to be noticed.  Looks great with so many things and would be a wonderful gift for anyone.  My stepmother would love this necklace....she has quite a collection of statement necklaces but nothing like this.  I might let her borrow it but plan to keep it for myself.  Gorgeous!  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

Every woman needs comfortable seamless shapewear.  This high-waisted panty gives great control to help smooth out any lumps or bumps.  It is very lightweight and comfortable to wear, as well as easy to put on.  (This is much more comfortable than other brands I have worn.)  It runs small so definitely purchase the bigger size if available.  I hand washed mine and let it air dry. I recommend this to women of all sizes.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

What a GREAT bag!  I can't wait to carry it.  I have the pink and the absolutely love the color.  The striped nautical design along with the rope handles are perfect for the pool, beach or for use as a tote to carry just about anything.  It is lined and can be secured by tying the inside.  There is plenty of room inside along with pockets.  I will get lots of use out of this bag.  It is strong and sturdy and very well made.  Love it.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I love these faux pearl earrings. They are smaller than most stud earrings and very delicate. They really add a sweet and feminine touch to any outfit. I plan to give these to my niece because she only wears stud earrings and really loved the size of these. Sample received for evaluation and review.

I have seen these advertised a lot lately and was very excited to try it.  I feel pretty crazy when using it but it really does help alleviate distractions and get comfy when trying to rest.  I have a house full of kids so they have all tried this too.  They love it and think it is the coolest thing EVER!  Great for a power nap or just to "escape" for a break.  Easy to clean too and VERY soft.  Sample provided for testing, evaluation and review.

I ordered this in an XL for my husband.  I know it is meant for compression and slimming but he couldn't get this on.  Instead my teenage son is wearing it and it fits him well (he usually wears an adult medium).  Does a great job of smoothing out his silhouette and he is wearing it under his basketball uniform just because he likes the way it feels and makes him look.  It is well made and holds its shape after wash.  The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because it runs SO small.  Like I said, my son usually wears a medium and this x-large fit him perfectly (and got the job done).  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

Every woman needs a classic pair of pear stud earrings.  These are 5 mm in diameter...perfect size.  They can be worn with just about anything and are great for everyday wear.  When in doubt, you can just about always get away with wearing these earrings.  They can be dressed up or dressed down depending on your outfit.  The back stays on nice and tight and they don't pinch my ears.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I love the tassel trend and the way this goldtone chainlink tassel necklace looks with the black crystals is perfection.  The chain is the perfect length to wear with anything and the gold tassel really stands out under the crystals.  Looked great when I wore it with a white shirt and black blazer.  The chain is nice and strong too.  Love it.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I would definitely recommend ordering a larger size on this shape wear slip dress.  It fits nice and tight, as you want it to, but get the bigger size anyway.  It sucks in and smooths exactly how you want it to.  Great to wear under a short dress.  Looks very sexy on also.  Shape wear is the greatest thing invented and every woman should own some.  Even if you think that you don't need it, trust me...you will love the way you look with it on.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

This statement necklace is stunning!  I love the alternating sizes of acrylic crystal gemstones and the way they look on the antiqued chain.  The color of the gemstones is gorgeous....a very dark blue but could pass for black.  I received so many compliments on this necklace.  Make sure to avoid exposure to water, perfume and body cream/lotion to avoid tarnish.  This is a statement necklace you will want to wear again and again.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I have read that the symbolism behind a tusk is very meaningful to the Buddhist religion.  It symbolizes mental strength, meaning that a person is very wise and of good character.  Safari jewelry like this seems to really be on trend right now.  This faux ivory tusk is nice...it is well made and the chain is very strong.  The tusk is very large and the ivory color looks great with the gold.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I love this faux pearl necklace.  The beads are larger than my other pearl necklaces so they are very noticeable.  Not as small and dainty as some pearl necklaces are, but just as pretty.  The necklace is adjustable so that is a definite plus.  It is well made and the string is sturdy.  Looks great with so many things in my closet.  Every lady needs a good pearl necklace and the fact that these beads are larger make it a perfect addition to my collection.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

Very pretty pair of round acrylic gemstone dangle earrings.  The color says blue but they are very dark and could pass for black if you wanted.  Depending on what color you are wearing they could look dark blue OR black.  They are the perfect length and the size of gemstone is just right to get noticed.  Limit exposure to water, perfume and body cream/lotion to avoid tarnish.  They come in a really cute gift box that is perfect for gifting.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I absolutely love this pair of faux turquoise drop earrings.  I have a pair similar but the acrylic stones are smaller.  These stones are much larger than I thought they would be and I am very pleased.  I can leave my hair down and the earrings are still noticeable.  They have the perfect amount of movement and look great.  Looks great with so many different things and great for everyday wear.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

This is a really cool pair of 360 stud earrings.  They are very on trend right now and perfect for the fall.  The earrings have two different sizes of cubes; one on the front of your earlobe and one on the back.  The color is a beautiful blue.  Even though they are studs they are very attention grabbing.  Comfortable to wear and look great too.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

This is the first time I have had a pair of ear jackets like this.  The acrylic marbled stone and faux pearl contrast and make a great look.  They are very trendy and different and will definitely be noticed.  Very unique and trendy.  They looked great with my jeans, mock turtleneck sweater and boots.  I pulled my hair back to really show them off and received many compliments.  Sample received for testing, evaluation and review.

I love dark roast coffee. It has always been my favorite. We drink a lot of coffee in my house but my husband isn't crazy about dark roast. I snuck some of this into our ground coffee container last week and he actually loved it. He was so surprised to find out at the end of the week that it was dark roast (and I loved proving him wrong). It smells wonderful and is very smooth with very little aftertaste. We like it strong so used heaping teaspoons. Great flavor. Purchased at a discount for testing, evaluation and review.

This is the second massage candle I have owned and hope to have many more of this kind. It is made of soy, so it burns cooler and cleaner than regular candles. The fragrance is so intense and lasts a long time. Since the soy burns cooler it is not hot too touch, therefore can be used for massage.  The oil really soaks into my skin and doesn't leave it feeling too greasy (although it does take it a little longer than lotion to be absorbed).  That is why it is so good for massages....it doesn't dry out too fast.  It is thicker than baby oil in consistency and very moisturizing...feels amazing and smells even better. I am very impressed by this candle and would recommend it to anyone. This would make a great gift for someone that loves candles or for your special someone.Product purchased at a discount in exchange for testing and honest review.
The odor block in these trash bags is the real deal!  Not only that but the trash bags are super strong.

LOVE THIS!  I have an iPhone 5s and sometimes can't really see the screen...especially at night.  My eyesight is getting worse and I have even resorted to using a magnifying glass when certain items won't zoom for me.  (Man, that makes me feel like my Grandmother.)  This product is great!  I am able to mount my phone on it and see things so much clearer.  The magnifying screen is larger and helps more than I thought it would.  I didn't expect much out of this product and I am very pleasantly surprised.  My only complaint is that the magnifying screen doesn't lock in place too well.  I mean, there is something that holds it in place but it doesn't really "lock" in place....and the same goes with the phone.  Not a problem if I am keeping it on a flat service but if I want to lay in bed or anything like that I just have to hold it.  Not a deal breaker for me though because it does a great job of helping me see my phone better.  Sample of product was received for testing, evaluation and review.

I like this brush, it does a good job and helps my son actually brush his teeth better.  He has never been a good brusher but his teeth seem to get cleaner with this brush and that is all that matters to me.  As far as adults go, however...I don't really see the benefit.  It is a smaller brush...seems too small for an adult's mouth to get the job done properly.  I know it is called "Baby Buddy's" but it IS an adult toothbrush.  I don't know, I haven't tried it for myself but I do know that I prefer a bigger brush when brushing my teeth.  As far as my son goes though, two thumbs up.  Product purchased at a discount for testing, evaluation and review.

I have tried many different types of garcinia cambogia over the past year or so...I mean, it IS the hottest thing on the market for weight loss.  Everyone is talking about it...even Dr. Oz, so it must be good...right?  I have to say that I love this product.  This particular brand is the strongest I have taken (1500 mg) and I can tell a difference.  It helps to curb my appetite and makes me feel good.  It gives me energy without jitters (definite plus).  If I would just stick to the plan and be consistent I have no doubt that I would really see results.  It helps me feel full longer so I really don't want to eat as much.  This works...it really does.  Product provided for testing, evaluation and review.

Excellent set of resistance loop bands.  They are portable and easy to take along with me anywhere I go.  They came in a little bag but I carry mine in a make-up bag...that way I don't have to completely fold them up each time after use.  With these bands I can do my exercises anywhere.I recommend these bands for anyone interested in low impact resistance training.  They have really helped me strengthen my core as I've tried to recover from a lower back injury.  I like the 5 different resistances (light, medium, heavy, extra heavy and extra extra heavy).  It's great for any level but it is also good for growth...you can start low and as you get stronger you can work your way up to the harder resistances.  My son also uses these to help recover from bicep tendonitis.  It is nice to have something to exercise with that is so effective, yet takes up little space to use.  We don't have the space for a big workout machine but I have found you can do just about anything with just bands.  I am impressed.  Complimentary sample provided for testing and review.

I'd like to say that I got this to use for boating or something exciting like that.  However, to be honest I got it to harass my kids.  Ok, that AND to corral the baseball team when needed.  I'm sorry but when you get a bunch of 13 year old boys together they can be pretty loud and obnoxious and it is sometimes impossible to get their attention.  We've tried a whistle and a megaphone...both got lost in the noise.  Not this bad boy though...it gets their attention every single time.  It is super loud, ozone safe, non flammable and since it is made of stainless steel we can carry it to practices and games AND leave it in our vehicle and not worry about it getting rusted or corroded.  Good quality.  Did I mention it is LOUD?  Product was purchased at a discount for testing, evaluation and review.

I hoped this would work for me.  I experience a lot of back pain and as a result my muscles tighten up quite a lot.  This often leads to bad posture, which is an easy habit to develop.  I hoped this would help me but honestly, it is just too small.  It is very narrow and uncomfortable for me.  I have read other reviews that say it helped so maybe it is just too small for my body frame.  I plan to give it to a friend in hopes that it will help her.  I purchased this product at a discount for testing and review purposes.
This is THE only stain remover that helps me get baseball pants clean.  High recommended!
These work just as good as Tylenol.  Don't let generics fool you.  Helps my headaches and minor aches and pains too.

This is a watch that can be worn on many occasions with many different wardrobes. The look is classy, with a slightness of showy. It is an above average sized watch with a larger-than-normal leather band. The look, needless to say, is very good.The second hand operates as a stop watch, if you want, being able to go back to the 12 numeral and start a countdown. The date dial is not a roller, rather sweeping hand style.For the quality, the leather band is very nice. Not a shiny, plasticy type leather, instead a large, slightly stiff (at first) leather calfskin material. There is a metal clasp that extends on the last part of each band (usually found on more expensive time pieces) that needs to be used in order to latch on your wrist. This is not the typical band clasp that goes in a loop like a belt.The crystal is 'synthetic sapphire'. I believe the wording for this was 'permitted' to be used in the last few years, because watch makers never advertised it before. Synthetic sapphire is another name for 'flame fusion' really and is not the same as a sapphire crystal in other watches. While the hardness is extremely close, and may have 99% of the same chemical makeup as a sapphire crystal, they are not the same. It is a high quality crystal to be sure, however don't confuse it with what the luxury watch companies put on theirs.The lug is a shiny, chrome-like metal and is not the highest of quality. It feels like and a little hollow. Although this is not a huge deal, there has to be some trade-off in quality because of the fairly low priced paid. I believe it is in the lug. The movement is japanese (quartz) and so far has kept excellent time--as it should. Note that the second hand has a slight 'sweep' and is not an obvious 'tick' like many quartz. It is not as fluid as a rolex...for example (whose automatic movement beats at 8 bps), however it is similar to a watch of 4-6 bps, thus jerky sweeping second hand.**Usually when you buy a watch in this price range you have to replace the band because of the lack of quality on this part. However, know you absolutely do not have to do that here. The band is better than most you will buy aftermarket (not taking into account you would buy a very expensive band).--------------------------Overall, this is a very fine watch at the current price. If you like the look you will be getting a good value. It can be worn as casual, swimming, dressy, or in business situations.

This is a bottle opener in the shape of part of a deer antler. While you may buy this for the hunter in your family, or because you simply like the look, the other reasons why you pay this much for an opener are apparent when you first open it:1. It comes packaged in its own distinct box, wrapped in paper and sealed with plastic -- much like a fine dish, or figurine you might buy.2. It is much heavier than other openers because it is made of solid metal. The metal is thick and does not bend with stubborn bottles.3. The 'chrome' like finish has not chipped and doesn't look like will with prolonged use.While the look of the opener is attractive, the price is on the upper end. However, because of the quality you are getting an appropriate value for the money paid. When someone receives this, they will know you didn't just pick this up in a bargain bin at a local store. This is an opener that you will own for many years.

** I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it **This water bottle is 'almost' there. The Glasstic 2.0 is what I am waiting for.The design, in general, is fantastic. Clear...glass...and fairly sturdy. While you cannot drive over this or really hit it hard on something, it is for the most part shatter resistant for many uses -- including sports, hiking, biking, running, or everyday use. They even ship you a sponge cleaner that allows you to clean deep inside the bottle. All nice touches.However, here are the parts that need to be improved:1. Water spout. The spout that you drink out of is...tiny. If you mouth the entire spout, you won't get any water because no air can escape, it just fills your mouth up. If you 'half-mouth' it, you are doing your best to imitate blowing a trumpet. Drinking should not require you to pucker your lips to the size of a pea to get a continuous stream of water. This needs to be made larger, and/or add some type of air hole so that you can 'mouth' the entire thing.2. Size. Yes this is 16oz, however it is a bit small for me. While the extra plastic covering makes the bottle appear large, the glass portion (that holds your water) is not big. Need more size options for me to use this on a daily basis.All this being said, it is a fantastic bottle...idea. When it is improved, this will be my only water bottle.

** I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it **This is a very well made, and strong, copper bracelet. It has a matte appearance (instead of overly shiny) which makes it a bit rustic.It is more 'low-profile' than many I have tried, and thus fits better for women or men that don't like a more thicker bracelet.The price is about average from what I have found, however I have not felt or seen a bracelet that has the quality of the Lifestyle Plus in this price range. It has not worn or decreased in appearance since owning it for over a month. A great accessory or gift for anyone.

** I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it **Firstly, I will note, most importantly, that my head rarely does well with any over-the-shelf shampoo/conditioners. My head either dries out too much with them or is just irritated too much to use them. Because of this problem, I resort usually to just use baby shampoo. The latter is not my preference however that's what I am left to do.To get straight to the point, I have used this shampoo many many times and have not had any problems with drying out or irritation. The shampoo has a light smell that is clean and fresh (without being overpowering) with a menthol overtone, and leaves my thick hair extremely smooth. I will reiterate that the main effect of this shampoo is softness. I have thick hair and this shampoo didn't weigh it down (thankfully) and allowed my hair to maintain its 'curliness and fullness'. Other friends have also tried this and noticed the same thing -- the shampoo leaves your hair extremely soft and somewhat shiny.As for the conditioner, I rarely use it, however this conditioner did what they all normally do -- weigh down the hair a bit to make it soft and manageable.Having tried many non-expensive, and expensive hair products, this is my favorite over everyone I've tried. A big statement, yes, however it is true. Dumb luck that I would find this from a review product? Maybe...however sometimes surprises come when you aren't expecting them.

** I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it **Two grinder salt and pepper shakers. Many are around and are very abundant. The outside of the shakers exude high quality -- Stainless steel twister and a glass globe where the salt or pepper go. I took the rest apart and will say that everything underneath the stainless exterior is plastic and the grinder is made out of some sort of chalky stone? Probably not a big deal, however I will leave you with that information.Nevertheless, the grinders are heavy, feel well made enough, and work great. As for longevity, I cannot say and would probably err on the side of average to below average lifespan.
