However, as of now they are a very good set and look well in many kitchens.The price is a bit high however know that you are getting good quality -- especially compared to the usual department store products.

** I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it **Firstly, I will note, most importantly, that my head rarely does well with any over-the-shelf shampoo/conditioners. My head either dries out too much with them or is just irritated too much to use them. Because of this problem, I resort usually to just use baby shampoo. The latter is not my preference however that's what I am left to do.To get straight to the point, I have used this shampoo many many times and have not had any problems with drying out or irritation. The shampoo has a light smell that is clean and fresh (without being overpowering), and leaves my thick hair extremely smooth. I will reiterate that the main effect of this shampoo is softness. I have thick hair and this shampoo didn't weigh it down (thankfully) and allowed my hair to maintain its 'curliness and fullness'. Other friends have also tried this and noticed the same thing -- the shampoo leaves your hair extremely soft and somewhat shiny.As for the conditioner, I rarely use it, however this conditioner did what they all normally do -- weigh down the hair a bit to make it soft and manageable.Having tried many non-expensive, and expensive hair products, this is my favorite over everyone I've tried. A big statement, yes, however it is true. Dumb luck that I would find this from a review product? Maybe...however sometimes surprises come when you aren't expecting them.

** I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it **These slip over your ankles to give you support, whether preventative or during injury rehabilitation. I wear a large size Mens shoe and these are a bit too tight for me.I would say they will fit Men's shoe sizes from 7-11.5 US. They will also fit women of any size.While on, they give moderate support however they are not quite as good as my department store bought ankle supports. The price is a bit lower and that helps a bit to not make this a bad buy.If you wear these for long periods of time, they will make indentions on your foot and may become a bit uncomfortable. However, you likely know this if you are familiar with these types of support. Wear socks to help with this effect.The quality is equal to my store bought ones, and the seams are sewed very well. Even stretching them over my big feet, they did not give the impression of tearing or ripping. Well-made.For those in the size ranges that I listed, they are perfectly adequate sleeves to support your ankle and to keep them a bit more protected than without wearing them.

** I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it **This is a review about the 10 pack assortment. The sleeves come in a variety of designs -- all very good and unique. The designs are very intricate and resemble many tattoos that you would see on other people.Each sleeve stretches to fit from your wrist up to about just above the elbow or mid bicep (depending on the length of your arm). The 'skin' color that is the backdrop of these sleeves is a peachy skin tone. From a distance, they look real. However, if you look closely they look fake -- not by much however. To really sell the idea, you will have to wear something on your wrist to cover the end of the sleeve (I used a sweat band), and wear a longer type t-shirt.They fit small arms up to large, muscular arms. The side benefit is that they keep your arm warm (and able to breath as well because of the material).I recommend these sleeves for fun or for trying to really fool people into thinking your arm is full of tattoos.

Not impressed. My main radar detector before this was the Cobra SPX 5500. The latter worked well for a bit, although many many false alerts, however it begin misinterpreting signals (i.e. giving Train signals in the middle of the highway). So far, the DSP9200BT has not given false train alerts, it does seem to give the same amount of false alert readings while driving in town.I currently live in a place that has many radars begin given off everywhere--from traffic monitors, speed detecting Speed Signs, and the multitude of vehicle equipped radars for various purposes. When I drive down the street or highway with the SPX 5500, it is almost always on. Guess what? The same happens with the DSP9200BT. I was initially excited to test out this detector because of the reduction of false alerts. I can say, it appears to be fairly equal to my old SPX 5500, with a slightly better detection range.The display is OLED. While other reviews have said it is difficult to read in daylight, I don't have that view. My SPX 5500 was LED and is almost impossible to read during the day. The DSP9200BT can be read during the day fairly easily (I have bad nearsightedness mind you). The only differing aspect is that the display is washed out a bit--nothing too bad.Detection trigger is minimal -- it sounds out by voice the type of band detected, and shows a 'signal strength' similar to cell phone monitors (increasing vertical bars), where red is the highest strength. It is loud enough to be heard driving with the windows down with the volume up.To truly get all the benefits of the detector, you will need an app on your phone. Personally, this is currently needed to embrace new technology otherwise, it would not be cost effective to include all of the memory, and technology in a self contained radar unit. Thus, to save GPS location red light/speed traps, you will need the phone app -- and it will ALWAYS need to be on. This does not add anything in particular to the detector, itself, as this sort of 'pairing' could be used for potentially any detector. While they make it seem that the DSP9200BT is 'special' because of the integration with the Application, it is not because the app should be available for all detectors.What, then, are you paying the large extra bit of money for? Not much, unfortunately. While the advertisements like to marquee 'Digital Technology' and 'Efficient Algorithms' for 'deluxe' signal processing and semi-intelligent filtering, you can simply test this by your experience. My experience, then, tells me it much similar to my  SPX 5500, which was already giving its fair share of false alerts.I will add that this unit does work, meaning that when there was a cop that appeared to be using radar, it picks it up. Moreover, I will say that the distance detection on this is very good.---------------------------------From the title, you know that I was letdown a bit as the price is high, however the function seems closely equal to my existing, much less expensive detector. I cannot recommend a purchase at face value, without truly dissecting all of the competing detectors. Know that now, you are getting a detector with the 'potential' to maybe become more, however out of the box currently, it is simply my old detector with a higher price tag.

You are inundated with many hiking/camping/touring backpacks out there. From short to long, to waterproof, to heavy duty, they are made in different materials and all come with differing prices. The first reason why you will go with this Kelty pack is because of the comfort. The second is for everything else it does right -- construction and compartments.The pack comes with an adjustable waist band, which slides up/down the metal bracings of the pack. The latter will be able to adjust to where the natural curvature of your back is--thus ensuring proper support when you latch the support waist together. Other backups really don't go this far to ensure a 'precise' level of fit. This reason is why the Kelty is different and why it is comfortable to wear, even under heavy loads. Even loaded with 30 or so pounds, the added weight feels seamlessly connected to your back.The advertisement does not mention that the material is waterresistant, however it is. The material feels exactly like gore-tex--though I would say if it was made of this material, it would be advertised as such. Nevertheless, when having rain on the bag, it does not seep through on the main compartment, keeping all your goods dry.For the compartments:1. The large main one down the center of the pack--holds many things--clothes, blankets, snacks etc. There is a synch tie down to keep everything fairly sealed, along with a main flap to add extra covering security that goes over the entry hole. The flap snaps down so that it won't come undone if climbing/hitting a large gust.2. Waist side 'fanny' packs. On the waist support band, there are two water-resistant pouches to hold keys/phones/wallets.3. 2 side pouches for water bottles made out of mesh material (not water resistant). For my bottles, I was able to hold 4 total (2 on each side).4. A water resistant pouch in the flap itself (that goes over the main entry hole)The overall bag is very lightweight, even with the metal support bars. The quality is very good--zippers zip smooth, snaps go in easily, and everything holds together when fully loaded up. The pressure points are mainly on the shoulder straps which have *3* connections to the pack...so the straps are not attached by just a line of thread. All clasps are made of plastic, as well as are the zippers. I would prefer to have had metal however they don't see to affect anything.----------------------The bag is well made and is comfortable with a lot of weight. Add to this a nice water resistant material and you have a quality pack to do all of your outdoor adventuring needs.

Aside from the obvious usage of snorkeling trips, you can also use these sets for teaching someone how to swim. That being said, if you are traveling or have a pool near by, a snorkeling set is a must have for variety of reasons.This particular set has the same gear as you would expect -- goggles, breather tube, and flippers. The look makes this appropriate for any gender and is very good. My set had a slightly red outer edge with everything else mostly black.When snorkeling, the goggles sit comfortable and no water seaped in after adjusting the straps. Strap adjustment is a big plus here because of an easy access button that allows seamless adjustment.The breathing tube clips into a harness that snaps in with your goggle straps so you can easily remove the breather tube by 'unsnapping' it from this mini harness.The fins offer the same ease of adjustment (with push button adjustment) as the goggles and are very sturdy and well made. There is a piece inside the fin that makes them slightly uncomfortable when using however.------------------------------This set is the best I have used for looks and quality/ease of use. Since they didn't fog and let water in, while allowing you to snorkel, there is nothing to complain about.

:** I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it **Firstly, know this is an amazing value considering the functional ability and price paid. You will not find this value anywhere, period.The general overview is this is an average--slightly below average sized wireless mouse with 2.4G band capability. The notable traits are:1. Very attractive mouse--can be queued to display a lighted red ambiance, or be completely light free.2. Very well made -- no rattling parts inside, compact, buttons are flushed and mouse wheel rolls seamlessly.3. Easy install -- plug and play USB bluetooth receiver.4. Completely silent clicking. This may be a slight deter for you as you may want to 'know' when you click. Know however, that the clicking motion is barely audible and barely noticeable (from click feedback).5. Adjustable DPI.The only downside I found is that sometimes (5% of the time) the connection snags a bit where the mouse pointer either moves too slow or sporadically. For the price, and low occurrence of this issue, this is really trivial at best.----------------------------You will not find a comparable mouse for this price. If you want wireless and silent clicking there is not competition.

** I was given this bag in exchange for my opinion of it **Firstly, the bag is made of faux leather (it says this in the description). However, the quality of the 'faux' and overall bag is better than most bags you will find in department mall stores (of course compared to a similar faux bag). While the company could take shortcuts in some areas of the bag, there are no apparent 'cheats' in quality to be found. The clasps smoothly lock, the belt straps adjusts fluidly, the button snaps snap with little effort and hold strong, and the zippers on the inside zip smoothly without snagging.There is a slightly sheen on the outside of the entire bag which makes it hard to pass off as real leather. However, the bag exhibits taste because it has a subtle classic, antique look to it. It comes off as a carefully designed bag that has purpose--the mark of higher quality manufacturers.Since this is produced from an Asian country, where petiteness is the hot market, this bag is fairly dainty. It is about 8-9" across and is suited more for looks and style than actually carrying ability. It will certainly hold your wallet, phone, and various accessories though it will not hold paper, magazines, books, or laptops. It will hold a smaller sized tablet, though it will not fit an iPad well.-----------------For the price paid, and knowing that it is faux leather, you are getting a good value. When comparing it to typical department stores, you will be impressed with the overall construction. Know if you like the color and style, you will not be disappointing with the craftsmanship.

** I was given this bag in exchange for my opinion of it **The first couple of things that will stick out to you about this leash are the neon-type colors, and the weight of the leash. The cord is a light neon yellow and the base is baby blue. This allows for easier finding should the dog zip off with it--snatching it out of your hands. The weight of the leash, hopefully means better quality innards.The length of the leash is very long and has a silent unwind/wind mechanism. It does not 'snap' back if extended out all the way, thus saving any potential collision with your face. The leash material is a light weight canvas--not thick, and not thin--would say average to below average. The quality of the leash is the weak point, and is probably best for dogs 50lbs or under. Although, if you have a heavier, subdued, dog...this will suit fine.For the price, and compared to store bought leashes, this is a very high value. The leash looks different in a good way and is made well, and is perfectly suited for small to medium dogs.

Firstly, there are roughly two types of lace curtains you see -- the thin kind and the slightly heavy/thick ones. The DII is the former. It is very light weight and thin. As long as you aren't moving objects with rough edges around it often, or using pointed objects where it might contact the curtain, the durability is of no real concern. Durability is in proportion to the amount of handling this will take. Sliding the curtains open/closed will not wear it down however.Since this is a lattice lace curtain, there is not real 'covering' for your windows, it simply adds decoration to a normally bare window frame. Much light passes through and you can easily see in the window at night. I suggest using a solid curtain on the outside so that you can cover the window at night, and leave the lace on during the day.The pattern is a linked 4 leaf flower that repeats over the entirety of the curtain. The pattern is vertical, not horizontal.Overall, this is very comparable, and in some ways worse, than the quality you would expect at a normal department store. If you like the pattern and convenience of shipping, you would do well here if you don't expect heavy lattice.

This is a variable height pet stand. There are two stainless steel bowls that rest on the platform. Two legs snap in/snap out of the base in order to raise the platform or lower it.There are only two heights:With legs - around 12" highWithout legs = 5" highThe entire base and legs are made of average quality plastic. While the bowls are good quality, the base is not particularly. For the price, however, this is not necessarily a bad thing. The overall unit is not heavy and easily transported by anyone.The few problem areas are:1. Flimsiness. The dog platform, when raised, is not completely stable. If you have an aggressive eating/drinking dog, this likely will not stand for long. Of course, without the legs the base is perfectly secure.2. Leg attachment. The plastic legs have to be 'snapped' in place. If you plan to snap/un-snap a lot, the plastic tabs will likely wear.------------------We own another dog stand meant for feeding and it is made out of iron. It also cost 100$, where this costs 1/5 that. For the price, you are getting 2 nice dog bowls and the ability to allow your dog to bend his neck a little less than usual. Not a bad purchase however, keep your exceptions subdued and think about the price you are paying.

This is a bag that is made of thick, slightly stiff, plastic. The plastic makes this entire bag water proof, which is more appropriate to use as a 'wet separator' rather than a bag that can be submerged in water and expected to be kept dry. Meaning, when you 'close' the bag (you do this by rolling up the top and attaching it by velcro) it is not completely sealed.Sounds like a simple bag...and it is. A big sack of plastic. The smell gives off a fairly strong scent of plastic overall and doesn't really transfer to the things inside--after a small airing out time. The thickness of the plastic also prevents any punctures from small-to-medium points (like, say, tree branches, dropping, or heavy objects sitting on top). While this big would rip easy with the appropriate very sharp point, it is not likely to happen by accident, so you can be somewhat rough with it and come out ok.Although you could think of many uses for this bag, I used this for only separating wet items from dry items. For this, it works great. After going swimming, I put swim trunks/towels in it without the need to carry extra plastic grocery sacks around. Know, though, as with any 'somewhat sealed' plastic bag, you must take the wet items out as soon as you can lest mold start to arrive. However, for trips to and from and a general holding place, this bag works well for keeping wet items to themselves.The bag I reviewed was 23L and it is enough to hold many large beach towels, swimming suits/bikinis, and scuba gear (goggles and flippers).One warning is that you should not leave this in a spot directly under the sun and where which the bag can get very hot. Depending on the type of density this bags Polyethelyne plastic is, any temperature range of 230-260 degrees Fahrenheit (110 - 130 Celsius) will cause this bag to melt. Not much of a worry however, if you catch a hot day, on hot pavement maybe it gets to that.------------------------------------What this bag advertises is what you get: 100% waterproof (the material--not when being submerged), sturdy, and portable. For beach goers, and swimmers, look here to consolidate all of your goods.

I have oily skin and not all face creams are meant for every type of face. With the Nia 24, it's common ingredient is really...oil. Oily skin plus more oil is usually not recommended. Since I was testing the product , there was nothing I can do about this.Firstly, it is a fairly oily product. When applying you will have a bit of a sheen to your face. After a while (30 min - hour) the sheen fades so it's not completely shiny, however you are left with a slight luminescence--'glow'. The glow is lighter than my normal skin tone so it is not a darkener.Secondly, the product somewhat plumps your skin a bit so you do have a somewhat noticeable 'youthful' appearance. Whether this is from the retinol..or moisturizer, who knows. However, when you use it, there is a difference in your face = Slight glow + slight tightening + slight plumping of face.I said above that I have an oily skin type, however I my skin is also very sensitive to alcohol based products. The latter makes up the majority of facial creams. The Nia 24, i'm happy to say, did not flare up any of my usual 'sensitivities'. For sensitive skin types, then, this will likely go on easy.----------------In general I would recommend this product for those who feel they have a tired, dry, face with somewhat 'lifeless' skin. This will do well to give you more vibrancy, and moisturize/plump along the way.

This is a book for everyone--those who are not science majors, but see their curiosity peak of any mention of Quantum 'states', and those that do have a background in science. There is not the usual 'dumming' down, nor are a packing of technical jargon and mathematical formulae. If you are interested in Quantum technology, especially in the emerging field of Quantum Biology, I highly suggest you start here.The first chapter begins with a background of Quantum Theory and hits on the most popular phenomena associated with it -- Quantum Tunneling, Super position, and Quantum Entanglement. Thankfully, because this allows you to get the overall summation of why Quantum Theory...or simply Quantum Science is one of the most important topics of science today.The later, and bulk, of the book deals with the author's backgrounds--Quantum Biology. This is a fairly new, and often times neglected field of Quantum Science. This material subject is not something you would easily find in random newspaper articles or magazines--this will likely be your first introduction to the details of it. Know that the possibilities of as equally exciting as with non-trivial Quantum theory relating to particles in space. The content goes into these nascent areas.Writing in the book is a pleasant balance between too short and too wordy. It reads quick, though it is concise enough that there a large amount of material within single sentences--enough to invoke thought throughout. A book for all who is interested in science and where further study in Quantum Theory might take us.

For the price you are expecting a functional necklace--one that is above average compared to what you would expect at a normal warehouse-department store. If I were to pick this up anywhere I would guess it was very similar to customer jewelry.While the stones are scratch free and have a subtle shine that is above average in quality, the clasp and necklace feel poor and wear poor. Having yet to wear the necklace, the gold plating had already worn off the back of the clasp leaving the silver innards to shone through a bit. The necklace itself feels fairly cheap with no real shine or 'slick' feel. Feels like very very thin metal.The overall look of this is classy. The gold and 'earthy' stones give it a natural subdued look which will go well with white, brown, or black blouses. For wearing brief periods it gives a classic 'elegance' to a wardrobe however watch that the front facing part of the necklace doesn't interact with many materials i.e. coats because the plating will wear fast.The quality of the stones here warrant the mid-range price however expect to replace the necklace soon if you plan on having this as your daily/weekly wear.

Before these portable monitors were made you had to be within a hearing distance from your baby--if you were not around the baby that is. This is to always be able to be there for your child if any problems or care is needed.For the busy parent who needs to maneuver around the house, the MBP27T gives uninterrupted streaming and adjusts to make you feel safe monitoring your baby from a distance.Features of this product versus competitors:1. Slightly higher resolution, in color, screen. Not breathtaking, however is similar to streaming video from a popular user-shared video site (YT) at around 240p. You will be able to make out if your baby is sweaty, looks cold (blue-ish face), or has vomited on themselves.2. Great Audio pickup.3. Adjust the camera pan and zoom. Note that you are not 'physically' controlling the camera, however it can adjust digitally within reason.4. Night Vision--able to see a white/green pixelated representation of your baby. Good enough to see if they shaking or awake.5. Built-In ambient thermometer -- inconsistent because ambient air reduces its accuracy.Video streams well all around the house with a low resolution display -- thank clear but pixelated. Not much interference even through walls. Color is accurate however it is washed out a bit. As mentioned above, certainly good enough to spot any foreign substance/object on your baby.This picks up audio very well. Surrounding sounds and noises from your child will blend together however you can even hear the nuance of the baby 'grunting' at themselves (the soft voice babies usually make). You can place this by your bed at night and will be awoken with the slightest increase in volume from your baby.Adjusting picture from the remote is slightly delayed however it works well if you want to see a little closer than what the current view is.Night vision performs as you would expect--brightens the baby up to a washed out 'white/green' color and makes their eyes luminescent.Thermometer, as mentioned in other reviews, is inconsistent because it picks up so much ambient temperature. When only 2-3 degrees matter when taking our body's temperature, it is not very accurate. If you place it on the skin it is usually within a degree or two however, this is not good enough for serious temp taking.------------------------------This offers more luxuries than competitors and is very functional for what you would expect--able to monitor your baby day and night. The MBP27T offers a strong 2.4 GHz signal to eliminate a lot of possible static/interference and allows for portability that others do not. If you want to safely monitor your baby from afar this is a product that will do that well.

For a complete ease of use get this particular George Foreman grill. You will not get a particularly good cooked piece of meat or fish however it will make cooking straight forward and easy.Here is the breakdown:[---Cooking---] 6/10You plug in the grill and it heats up within 5 minutes. There is no heat adjustment. You turn this unit on and intermittently check the food for your preferred wellness of cook.Using an infrared thermometer the heat went up to 500 degrees Fahrenheit or 260 Celsius--it gets toasty.What the benefits are for this grill is that there is a place where grease flows from the meat while cooking. This is slightly healthier and makes cleaning easier. Moreover, there is little steam because the grease runs down. In addition to this, the fact that you can cook really in piece of meat wherever there is an inlet adds to the simplicity and functionality.For an apartment, dorm, or household with little space and/or time the George Foreman will add benefit to your cooking.However, where the grill slacks is in the ability to cook. Cooking meat is not necessarily a straight forward thing. Many people have different preferences and certain meats need to be cooked differently. In this Foreman grill there is not option to adjust heat. While you should know this when purchasing, it does limit what you can do. You cannot sear and blacken the outsides while leaving the inside rare--a steak for example. You cannot slow cook to have meat that is moist and thoroughly browned.The outcome while cooking with this grill is that the bottom piece of meat (I tried steak and salmon) is hard and dark brown while the top is light brown and moist. Many people ate the meats I cooked in this grill and commented that they were hard--which was true.The New York Strip I cooked (1" thick and fit perfectly) did not turn out well. It was shrunken and half-hard half-soft. Although, it did retain its moistness.For the salmon I cooked, again, the bottom was hard and the top was...near perfect. Cooking fish on this Foreman grill is above average--it makes it easy, does not 'break' apart the fish and generally turns out well.[---Cleaning---]9/10With light scrubbing from a sponge and running water every bit of residue was wiped away without using much force. Cleaning goes very well with this grill.-------------------------------------------------This George Foreman grill is sparse on options because it does not have any. Its only setting is basically Medium-High setting (500 degrees), which forces you to monitor the meat being cooked to get a desired outcome because the bottom is hotter than the top. It is an average cooker with great portability and simplicity.

** I received this product from the manufacturer in exchange for my opinion of it **Putting these side-by-side with my 30$ speedo goggles, there was plainly no difference in the quality of the rubber seal around the eye caps or the caps themselves. That's a start.Goggles only suit a couple of functions:1. (the biggest) Sealing properly not allowing water to get in.2. Being comfortable - this does not have anything to do with 'adjusting'. When you have to smash the eyecaps in order to seal (which is normal I'm afraid), any extra additives for comfort help.3. No fogging. I have not personally found goggles that don't fog up unless you use third-party products (a spray or... a naupaka plant--this was mentioned to me when I was in Hawaii, and it works exceptionally well).Based on these points, here is how the Ipow stands.For the first point:These have a bigger seal ring than my speedo glasses and do not suction as much as the Speedos. I did not, however, notice any obvious water getting in. After I took off the goggles they were dry in the inside. I had to really press them in though to get any kind of seal because the eyecaps are quite large. My Speedo goggles have somewhat small eyecaps that really suction on.I would rate this adequate for sealing and not as good as my Speedos.Second point:The Ipow goggles are much more comfortable than the Speedos. The seal ring on the Ipows are thick and cushioned. My Speedo goggles, in contrast, have a small seal that depresses down to the hard edge of the eyecaps--always causing soreness.Excellent for comfort.Third point:Same as any other goggles I have tried. At first they do not fog up however, the more you swim the fog creeps in. Not much creep however I would say around 40%.Again, average and typical for what I have experienced before.Note that goggles are not a universal fit for all. It is better to be 'too small' around your eyecaps than too big because this will let in more water. If the eye caps are not sealing properly and the bridge looks too wide, make sure to change out the nose piece accordingly. For this, just snap the old ones out--this requires moderate pressure.----------------------------These Ipow goggles are function and slightly above average. They are very comfortable and offer a slightly inconsistent seal however, they will be better quality than most goggles you can find in the stores that are less than 20$.

** I received this product from the manufacturer in exchange for my opinion of it **Extended selfies. Extended portraits. An angle over a cliff that you certainly couldn't perform yourself. The previous three elements are what you can do with a phone extender. I laughed when I first saw people using these...until I thought about it for a few seconds. Needless to say they are extremely useful for any setting.Now to the review:[---Quality---]7/10The handle is rubberized which is very good for not being slick or moving the camera around too much. The actual extendable part is made of a moderately thin metal. The latter does not 'glide' like higher quality extendable products I have used. It has a 'rough' feeling extending it, however after repeatedly moving it up and down very fast numerous times, I can say in general it is decent quality.[---Holster---]For the holster (the part that holds your phone), it has very lightly rubberized feet on the bottom held my iphone 5s perfectly in place after installing the orange rubber clip on. To explain more of the latter, it is rubber 'cap' that fits over the top part of the holster that 'clips' on the phone. It helps to keep it more secure. When I first tested this, I didn't use it at all. While the phone did not slide around, after heavy shaking the phone did fall out. With the rubber clip on it did not--even after the heavy back-and-forth.[---Bluetooth---]The handle has a switch where you can turn on bluetooth so that you can 'snap' the picture with the button on the handle. This product will periodically need to be charged as the bluetooth requires a battery -- that is built into this. Note, there is a supplied micro usb cable for this. The bluetooth, moreover, was easy to connect to and comes up as 'jstar'. It was as simple as turning the unit on and connecting. A few seconds for this at most.There was minimal latency between clicking the button on the handle and actually having the iPhone snap the picture. It is close to instantaneous and I don't see this being much of a problem.[---Sizing for Other Phones---]As I mentioned above, I used an iPhone 5s and it fit without any adjustments. The holster, however, has adjusted length and height. I am confident that it will fit any flat smartphone out there, including HTC, Galaxy, and the Note. Also the new iPhone will fit as well. If your phone is smaller than the iPhone 5s then it might not fit if you do not have a case on it.[---Potential Worries---]When I extended this product all the way, there was a little flex at the end and slight instability. While I don't see the potential to break, if your phone is heavy you might have a slightly difficult time getting a 'still' picture. When extended all the way, with the iPhone, even though it was slightly shaky, I was able to take in focus pictures fairly easily.-------------------------------With this product you will get an extendable handle that keeps your phone very very secure. There will be no worry to lose it unless you are using a jackhammer alongside. If you were mountain biking and taking a selfie, I would say the phone would stay secure however, I would keep the handle towards a minimum expansion length. The latter will give you an idea of what it can do for your phone.

You can cross off leaking as something potentially stopping you from buying this water bottle. No real life situation would put this bottle through what I did trying to get one little water droplet to peak it's head out.Shaking, twirling...even making those little upside-down tornadoes in there..., slamming, flipping...juggling. Nothing came out.There is a rubber ball (similar to what is in a whistle) that suffocates the mouth opening whenever you are not depressing the button down. This rubber ball is the only thing stopping the water from coming out unintended. The little ball works.All this being said, this water bottle is exceptional in every area I could see. Firstly, I strongly not prefer to drink out of *any* plastic water bottle. My go-to water bottle is the Klean Kanteen stainless steel bottle. As far as function, aesthetics, and ease of use the Contigo beats the Klean Kanteen easily.The color of the bottle is a very calming sea green that makes the water seem like a crystal-clear paradise drink.The top portion is a engineering feat in its simplicity. Ergonomics were not looked over with this. The button you depress when you want to drink fits formly to your finger and is easy to press. When you press the 'drink button' the water comes out gradually and the volume adjusts to how you suck in the water--very similar to sports type water bottles. So as not to accidentally depress the drink button, there is a locking lever that will keep the button locked in the 'off' position. There is also a lid that goes over the drinking spot to shut out any outside particles.------------------------------How everything goes together in this bottle adds to my impression that nothing is wrong with it. One of the best looking water bottles and one where everything works perfectly. Although it will be hard to turn me away from my bottle-o-steel with the Klean Kanteen, because I do not trust plastic in general whether BPA free or not...you might just see me swinging the Contigo around.

Unfortunately, I can make use of this battery charger many times. My habit of leaving interior lights on does not make me friends with batteries. Because I am usually operating on a tight schedule, i.e. leaving for something at just the right time not to be late, those moments when my battery died forced me to arrive 'fashionably' late. Either I find someone near, knocking on random doors to see who is home, for a jumpstart (this takes about 10 minutes) or I take the battery out and go to a local auto parts store for them to fully charge it (this takes around 1 hour).A battery dying is an easy fix however it is almost always an inconvenient one.With the Forney, you are not going to get an ultra portable carry-on device you can stow under the car seat as it's not meant to be that. It is meant to be your central battery maintenance machine that can keep your car and battery running under situations with time constraints or none at all. Add wheels to this machine and, while it is a marginal size, it is very portable and rolls around easily.[---Construction---]Heavy unit, around 40 lbs, and strong metal all around. If left outside (which is not recommended) I could see this rusting fairly quickly. The cables on this look to be around 8 gauge, however I could not find any documentation on what exactly they are. 8 gauge, if that is what they are, is a good all-around cable however not the most 'optimal' for large trucks/SUVs on a cold, raw jumpstart. It would still likely work however it will probably be better to charge the battery separately outside of the vehicle.[---Charging---]There are many options to charge on this unit. Here is a quick explanation of what you should use (most of this information is also inside the manual as well):2A slow, trickle charge -- the slowest, lightest current. Generally would take around 4-6 hours to fully charge a battery. If you have the time for this, this setting is best for your battery as it does not heat very high as to destroy or 'fry' any components of the battery. Be careful with your time on this setting however because the meter cannot 'read' this low of a charge so you will not know based on the machine whether your battery is fully charged or not--and you do not want to overcharge.10A/40A charge -- In most cases the 40A charge is the best 'medium' out of all of them. It likely takes around an hour to full charge your battery if it was almost fully depleted. This is a fairly safe amperage and finishes fairly quickly.40A/100A for 6V batteries -- Generally only used for antique cars from the 30's. Probably won't use this at all.200A - the 'full' blast charge. This is for a quick jumpstart on a cold engine and cold depleted battery. You should absolutely not overcharge with this setting, or continue to charge for long as it can easily heat up your battery and/or destroy electrical components in your car.Very versatile options available for most situations.[---The Extras---]- There is a timer that you can use that goes up to around 2-3 hours which will shut off when completing its cycle. You will use this feature when you find out more details on your battery and calculate how long it will take based on the particular setting you chose (the chart and calculation is in the manual in full detail).- Auto-Shut off if the charger senses anything 'abnormal' coming from you battery--especially 'cross charge'--where you accidentally hook up the positive cable to the negative terminal.- As mentioned above, a meter. When the meter shows high this means that your battery is low and is taking a lot of the current for a given setting. While charging the battery, and if the meter is showing low, then your battery is almost charged and the Forney will automatically cut back the charge to compensate. Fantastic feature here.[---Assembly---]Yes, you have to assemble the charger when taking it out of the box. For this you will need a hammer and a few common socket tools. Quick and easy to put together however the instructions are 'slightly' lacking when explaining how to put it together. You will easily figure this part out however.---------------------------------------------Because wheeling this charger out to your car (if it isn't very close to your garage) will likely take a long extension cord, I recommend taking the battery out and charging it out of the car. This allows for you to enclose safely the battery and charger. Nevertheless, a portable battery charger is for those that do not have accessible neighbors for a jump start whenever their battery dies or simply wants the ability to quickly, and thoroughly, charge their battery at their convenience and have it as quick or efficient as they like.

This is not your usual 'picture' book you can throw on a coffee table to kill time or entertain guests. The book is part encyclopedia/part art collection. Except the 'encyclopedia' part is not written as a dry edification--it is written from the perspective of the author--all his subjectivity included. While you get a heavy package of information that spans the beginnings of capturing light on material to where photography is today, you get the author's thoughts--sometimes angry, sometimes reveling--about the evolution of cameras and photography. This allows you to view another's strong opinion--a subject Tom Ang is passionate about--where you can agree or disagree. Nevertheless, reading the whole book through will be educational and entertaining.The book itself is big, heavy, and very high quality. The pages are semi-gloss, heavy weight, and in high resolution color. A lot of production went into this book.Visually, you get a book full of large and extremely clear pictures. One of the first 'photos' (in parenthesis because it was more like a 'tablet sensitive to light'--which you will read about)  taken in the early 19th century is in here and although it is somewhat hard to make out, the clarity of it is astounding. Consider perusing through this book as a substitute for an extensive museum tour, which you can do in the comfort of your lap.The organization of this book is simple. It goes from the beginning of when scientists and inventors first discovered how to get minerals sensitive to light. As it progresses through discoveries, cameras, and modern day photography you get snapshots of the representation of the technology and capabilities of the respective era. It will do well to make anyone a pseudo-expert on the history of capturing light to make 'time stand still'.-----------------------------On first glance, I took this book as your common book of photos as it gives brief statements of what occurred during the period. Throw that idea away. This is a definitive book on the history of photography that can be a reference guide in universities, libraries, or museums. It is the perfect bond of informative text and compelling visual aides.

* I received this product in exchange for my opinion of it *Have used this product for a while now and can you give a very good picture of what it does to slightly sensitive, and dry skin (these are my qualities). I don't have many wrinkles on my face however I do have 'laugh' marks between the nose and upper lip. They are more like 'creases' and this is what I mainly used them on. Vitamin C Serum--among other nutrients found in this bottle--is supposed to plump and tighten your skin as well as reduce wrinkles.The experience of the product is that it feels slightly cold going on and it dries very quickly. It feels like a very light facial mask in that it tightens the area that you apply the serum on. After applying the skin feels slightly 'plumped'--it performs as advertised in this regard. For this experience you only need '1' drop to do this.After a while, I want to say I noticed a slight change in appearance for the laugh marks but it certainly didn't 'vanish'. When applying to wrinkles it would certainly aid to make fine ones very faint as it really does 'plump' up your skin around the area you apply the serum on. Sort of a 'mini' spot-facelift. This doesn't mean that your skin will look swollen because it is more in the 'feel' than the look of the 'plumped' skin.------------------As advertised, the product shines up the skin slightly and expands the area that you choose to use it on--for fine wrinkles it will help reduce visibility.

In a good way...Picture yourself going to your everyday department store. Maybe you end up buying some cleaning tools there, that will help or aid your job of scrubbing and...scrubbing. You know that any tool you end up buying, regardless of the price paid, that there will be a weakpoint to it. Whether its entirety is made of plastic--all of them are usually--or works marginally well for one time only.I have never seen this OXO product in a store. If it was I surmise it would be around 30$. It offers nothing comparable to what we are used to when shopping. It is made mostly of metal--the lightweight kind--and is actually usable for short or tall people. The latter because it can extend up to 43". However, this is not your normal 'extension' capability. Meaning, that it extends and you are able to 'lock' in the extension and it absolutely will not move or bend however much force you put on it. This means that it is a quality product. The handle has the same amount of flexibility as my metal shovel i.e....not much.Moreover, the pad that comes on here is strong and resistant. It is thick, not 'fluffy' i.e. a lot of filler to make it look thick, and will clean equal to if you scrubbed by hand. I see no signs of wear on this after multiple uses. The scrubber fits perfectly in the corners of a shower and can be multipurpose in your bathroom--I use it to clean tiles, the shower floor, and around the commode.-----------------------------------------Good products deserve to be known about and exceptional products need to be reiterated so that you always know where to look for when searching for the 'standard' by which other products should be basing their capabilities on. This OXO extendable scrubber needs to be bought by everyone who is unfortunate enough to get the job of bathroom cleaning. I can say this because I am one of those people...With this product...you may actually like doing it---but don't tell anyone.

For a universal car cover, this cover actually fits my Kia Rio hatchback quite well.To use, the cover first needs to have the velcro strips attached to the inside car trunk, cover outside.  Close the hatch & roll the cover over the car.  Covering the car takes no time at all.  The cover comes with weight bars sewn into the front & back to give weight & keep the cover in place.  There is a way to "tighten" the cover so the bars are hooked underneath the car, but they don't tighten completely, so a hard, hard wind can take the front portion of the cover off of the car (the back portion is velcroed in, so the cover isn't blown away).The cover itself is a fairly heavy fabric & it feels like it should hold up well - time will tell.  It is bulky and I cannot get it folded back to the way it came, though.  Stuffing it inside of my car takes up most of the trunk space.  I have yet to figure out an ideal way to store the cover.NOTE:  The Only Unique car cover was sent to me in exchange for an honest review.

I own a GoPro Hero4 Silver & use it both for action video & stills.Pros:  The PolarPro Power pole is well built, handles solidly and holds a charge.  You have be make sure the extensions are locked in or else you may experience slippage.Cons: The PolarPro pole doesn't fold up compactly, and is still a little "weighty" as compared to other sticks.  Additionally, you cannot use the PolarPole as a "battery extender" (on the go) when your GoPro is in its GoPro case (& in use)**.  And last, the PolarPro is not suitcase friendly both because of its size & weight. I travel light, so suitcase space is premium. Extra batteries are less "weighty" and take up much less space.I have played with this PolarPro powerpole for a little over 3 weeks. It is just not an accessory that I grab each & every time I use my GoPro.  I cannot put it in the "must have" accessory category (like extra batteries, which are easy to carry/travel with).**Apparently, there is 3rd party case that exposes the GoPro's ports so the camera can be charged while in its case, but camera exposure is a weakness while action video-taping - way too much possibility of infiltration & damage to the ports/camera.I wanted to love this combo extension/power pole, but it isn't a device that I go ga-ga over.  Hence, 3 stars.

THE DOOR & INSTALLATIONWe installed this garage door opener on a single door garage. It was a replacement installation, so we used existing mounting brackets. We have installed multiple garage door openers (replacement & new installations) & found this unit easy to manage & easy to install.Installation (for entirely new & replacement): FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS. There are pictures throughout that give you specific locations for assembly. 60% of the assembly clips together without hardware. The sensors clip on to the rail track (or there are flanges for optional attachment) & the only thing you need to be aware of is that the sensors need to "see" each other - there is plenty of adjustment. All of this is explained in the instructions.For NEW installations - Wiring: the opener comes with little staples, but these staples aren't very user friendly for attachment to sheetrock (they are short & small & you'll end up hitting your hand because there is no room to hold on to them). We used bigger electrical clamps with longer screws to hold up the wire (where there was more tension) & just used the staples to keep the wire attached to the ceiling. In our opinion, unless you are attaching to wood, the kit staples will not keep the wire secured to the ceiling.Estimated Assembly time for replacement installation: 1 to 1-1/2 hoursEstimated assembly for new installation: 3 hours, depending upon what you need (may need to reinforce garage door)Quiet factor is Good. The opener motor seems to be quieter than the basic Chamberlain units we've installed.MY-Q TECHNOLOGY/SMARTPHONE APPIf you want to be able to open/close your garage door using your cell phone, this opener is equipped with Chamberlain's MyQ technology.  You need to buy a separate MyQ Gateway device in order to do so (at the time of this writing, the Gateway device is cheaper on Amazon than my local warehouse building store).Then you have to download the app to your phone. At this time, Chamberlain offers an iPhone & Android app, but not a Windows app.  However, in the Windows store, there is an app written by a third party called Garage Door Opener & it works as a "wrap".  Also, at this point, the apps are free and there are NO MONTHLY FEES to access and use the Chamberlain' MyQ technology.

** I do not take hormone replacement therapy.  I do exercise regularly & eat a healthy diet. **Prior to taking Doctor's Best Estrog-100, I was regularly experiencing minor hot flushes. About 2 weeks before starting Doctor's Best Estrog-100, I started experiencing long-lasting hot flushes followed by cold shivers, minor, but noticeable vertigo & a little nausea. About every other day. That was enough to bring me to try Doctor's Best.After 20 days of daily use, I do notice a difference.  My more extreme symptoms vanished after taking Doctor's Best (coincidence?) & my more familiar, regular hot flushes are not daily anymore & are hardly noticeable when I do get them.My sleep (interference) has not changed, and I still wake up at different intervals during the night (not due to night sweats - so perhaps this symptom is unrelated).Over the counter herbs and vitamins are always a question because they are unregulated.  I decided to try the Doctor's Best simply to see if they worked as claimed, but I do not take any prescription medications or have any health issues (other than menopausal symptoms), so I did not have to worry about drug interactions.  For me, Doctor's Best seems to work fairly well. The fact that it is 1x/day is a bonus too.

UPDATE (8/14/15): It looks like the replacement filter lasts about 3 month with light use. Light use: filling coffee pot daily, filling steam mop reservoir 2-3x/week, and a daily glass of water (approx. 10-16 ounces).UPDATE (6/1/15): have had to order a replacement filter ($27). Use is minimal - a couple of times/day for water glass fill-ups and coffee pot water reservoir fill-ups (approx. every third day).  There is a noticeable taste difference in the water with/without the filter, so when it was time to replace, a replacement WA ordered.I have to admit that when I first received this Verbatim Water Filtration System, I was stumped as to what faucet to attach it to. Then I realized that my commercial kitchen faucet had enough of a straight spout that the filtration system might be attachable.Following the instructions was easy enough until step 3. I needed 2 people to screw on the attachment because there needs to be lots of pressure to seal the faucet spout to the system nozzle. This is not explained well in the instructions (which make it seem like you just screw the nozzle on and the seal is good).  An installation video showing installation instructions would be helpful. Still pictures of acceptable mounting faucets and what adapters to use would be good too.Once installed, the Verbatim system is mostly sealed - I do have some seepage at the connection to the faucet, but it isn't significant. The system works as described with 3 choices for water. All work well and there is no flow restriction. The display is nice to have because I'm not good at tracking replacement times. If you are, the display isn't a necessary feature.The filter slips easily into the system and there is no seepage between the two. Price the replacement filter before you buy so you know your commitment. The fact that filtered water is a choice rather than always on should extend the filters life.Overall, a nice compact system that has a bit of seepage around the faucet connection. This Verbatim system is definitely worth strong consideration if you are in the market.

The All-Absorb littler pad do absorb urine, but they seem to be a bit thinner & do not absorb as much as the original Breeze pads.  Additionally, they are a little stiffer, so when unfolded, they do not like to stay flat in the litter pan.I will not order again.

My original BP machine is an Omron BP742N.  It has all of the bells & whistles of this Omron BP761 except the easy wrap cuff & Bluetooth Smart.The Omron BP761 stands out for two reasons: (1) easy wrap cuff is truly easier to put on your arm, and (2)  the display is large & very easy to read without glasses.  The Bluetooth is a nice feature to have for tracking progress, but it isn't compatible with all devices.For some, the cuff may be a little too long, but this is designed so there is minimal misalignment, thus more accuracy.  I have a thin, average length arm & the cuff fits fine.  It is much easier to put on & secure than the BP742N cuff (typical BP wrap cuff). For me, the cuff is the reason for choosing to use this Omron over my original one.

These metallic temporary tattoos appeal to a wide age group - teenagers to middle-age.They have a great shine & last quite awhile. My teenage girls & I tried different tattoos on different parts of our bodies.  Instructions are on each sheet & are easy to follow.  All went on easily & did not peel off after application.  The new tattoo is very shiny & truly has a metallic look.With daily showers & daily exposure to covered clothing (legs, arms, shoulder), the tattoos seemed to last about 5 days before starting to fade & disappear.The 4 tattoo sheets give a good variety and are fun to wear.  The metallic is a cool look, and I look forward to seeing other designs in the future.Sktrendz sent me 4 sheets to sample in exchange for an honest review.

Cuffiez leg warmers are medium gray with an off-white crocheted top, accented with 2 off-white buttons.  They are long enough to go over a heel, as shown in the picture, and still show above the boot top.  They are super cute and give a nice finish to your boot, as well as adding another warming layer to your legs.Cuffiez are made of Acrylic, and somewhat stretchable, but would not be stretchable enough for someone with a large or muscular calf - the top crocheted part seems to be the limiting factor.I was given a sample pair of gray Cuffiez to review.  I like them so much, I will be looking to purchase an additional pair in a different color.

I have not tried earlier versions of the LG Electronics Bluetooth headset, so cannot compare this HBS-800 to previous models.  I have used Bose QuietComfort 20i (noise cancelling) headphones, so can compare this HBS-800 to the Bose QC 20i  (borrowed for a trip).Noise-cancelling on the Bose is better than on the LG, and one would expect that given the price-point of both headsets. However, the LG's noise cancelling isn't bad, and, when you use them with music, the performance is not too bad, especially taking the price point into consideration,  The limits on the Bose QC 20i is the 20i is specifically made for iPhones (& has the talk/answer feature), while the 20 is made for Android/Windows & doesn't have the talk/answer feature.  Consequently, Bose headphones are more for a music aficionado (of course, they are Bose) rather than an all-around user who likes all Bluetooth functions, including music.The LG headset paired easily with my phone's Bluetooth. My main phone is Windows & Cortana comes over loud. & clear (Bluetooth functions are dependent upon your phone's capabilities).  The connection stays solid as long as I'm within about 30' of my phone.  Voice seems pretty clear to folks on the other end of my line whether in a quiet room or not so quiet car.  No one ever asked me to repeat myself, which in & of itself gives the LG headset a star.Charging is quick & easy using a micro USB cord.The only drawback on the LG headset is that the buttons are small & not real "tactile", so it is hard to manage them while the headset is around your neck.  The headset's capabilities override this annoyance, but it is an annoyance nonetheless.Overall, I'm very happy with the LG headset.  I had planned to buy a Bose, but think that this LG will be a fine choice instead.

Accurate, Lightweight & Rechargeable.  Perfect.We used the Hammerhead to lay out the walls on our basement finish (from rough plans drawn by an architect friend).  The tool was accurate, easy to use & made the job much quicker and more accurat3 than if we had used a tape measure.The Hammerhead is easy to grip, the numbers are easy to read & settings are simple to set.  We had no issues whatsoever with this tool & it is now a useful addition to the toolbox.The Hammerhead is not just a gadget, it is a very handy tool!

The remote portion of this product was DOA upon unboxing.  I charged it on a wall charger overnight & then on a USB computer port on a separate night.  Nothing.  The green light in the battery lit up while on charge, but when disconnected, the light wouldn't come on - not even flicker.Next step was to call Petsafe customer service.  Their number is printed in multiple locations in the instruction manual, which is nice.  The instruction manual gives hours of operation, but does not state which time zone.  The company is located in KY, so it is probably safe to assume the hours of operation are EST.The fact that the customer service number is printed in the instruction manual is about all that is good about Petsafe's customer service.  As a reviewer of a Vine/Free product, customer service was not helpful at all.  They refused to accept the Amazon sticker as proof of purchase and they insisted they were not part of Amazon's review (Vine) program.Upshot: If you purchase this product, make sure you keep your receipt or customer service will not be helpful at all.Design Issue:The micro plug portion of the USB plug is slightly narrower than standard micro plug bases, so if you try to substitute a different micro USB, you may not be able to fit it properly into either the remote or receiver's micro slot.  Don't lose the charging cables that come with the product.  A design allowing fit for a standard micro USB would be a lot easier & more customer friendly.

While I've always wanted a GoPro, I've never used one or even played around with one until purchasing (justifying the purchase)this GoPro HERO4 Silver. I am a casual user.  I cannot talk/compare in 4k or that kind of description/comparison.  My review is intended for the casual user who wants a waterproof action camera that is easy to use without having to read a thick instruction manual.I chose the Silver 4 because of the 12mp still images, the video quality & the Touchscreen LCD back.  I like the LCD back because that is what I'm familiar with using my digital camera. The touchscreen back is not super sensitive & I have to press hard (through the case) for the screen to respond.  Just remember that the display will lock if left untouched, so you will have to go through the unlock procedure again if you want to change from camera to video or access the screen options (touch top middle of screen & slide finger down - that will get you to the unlock feature, which is a slide down & hold feature).Unfortunately, my digital camera is not waterproof, so I decided that a small, waterproof/water resistant camera should be added to my collection.  Since I was about to embark on a trip that involved ziplining, rafting, parasailing & a rainforest, I decided that a GoPro would be an ideal camera.The HERO4 Silver is a great little camera.  I am still not completely using all of its features - the remote being the next item on my "to-learn" list - but the features I used - camera & video - produced beautiful, clear pictures & video.  I used the clip to place the GoPro on both my zipline helmets & rafting helmet, and I used a homemade modified strap to wrap around my hand while parasailing.  On all, since I wasn't submerging in water below 10', I used the camera housing that allowed for Touchscreen use.Camera battery lasted about 1-1/2 hours because of using the LCD screen off and on.  As stated earlier, I still have to get use to using the remote app. I chose not to with my last adventure because I didn't want to carry my phone on a zip line, a white water raft or while parasailing.I will update this review as I go, but I'm very happy with the camera & video quality of the HERO4 Silver. Downloads to my tablet & computer were simple and no special software is required to view since the files are mp4.Overall, the HERO4 Silver is pretty easy to understand & use - even for those who are not photography experts.

Love the bright colors!  I have 2 neon yellow tags & my navy suitcases are easily recognizable in a carousel/sea of luggage.The hard plastic cases swivel on a pivot to allow you to access the inside compartment, so do NOT try to pry the 2 side apart.  While there is an enclosed paper to write you information on, I folded a business card & my name aligned perfectly with the opening (business card name is on the bottom right of the card).The loop is made of plastic & while I haven't used these particular tags for a long time, my old luggage tag used the same type of plastic loop & that loop held up for years on both domestic & international flights (I replaced the old tag because EVA Air managed to crush my plastic tag).Overall, I love these luggage tags. My personal informant is not visible & the neon tags make it easy to spot my luggage.  Totally worth 5 stars.

Small & fairly lightweight, this cable lock works as a deterrent for the casual thief.  I also use it to lock luggage in hotel rooms - more for a visual that the bag hasn't been tampered with (the reality is that a serious thief would either cut the lock, break the zipper or slash the suitcase).I use the lock on my carry-on roller suitcase & I have never been stopped by TSA in the States. I was required to open my suitcase in a Latin American country, but they had me open the lock myself.There are a couple of downsides to the lock:(1) I found it a little difficult to push the button (with a pointed object) & set the code. The lock is small, the button is small & setting the code required one hand to hold the lock & keep the button pushed down while the other hand set the combo. It wasn't impossible, but I had to find the right tool to push the button.(2) My lock is silver & the lock dials are silver.  The small numbers are black, but not a dark, dark black.  I could not see the numbers without my reading glasses. A small annoyance.Overall, I am happy with the TSA lock, and plan to use it on all my trips, both domestic & international.

This external battery pack has 2 great features not found in most battery packs - (1) it can swiftly charge 2 devices at once & (2) the charging cord's design has 2 connectors (micro USB & iPhone lightning adaptor) combined so you won't lose an adaptor.Charging the external battery is pretty quick. It has 4 indicator lights showing the charge level.  Once charged, the external pack does a fairly quick job of charging devices & putting 2 on at the same time doesn't impinge upon the charging of one versus another.The unit is compact, but it is weighty. I would use it for car trips rather than airplane/suitcase travel.  For airplane/suitcase travel, I carry a single slim external pack solely because of weight.This devise doesn't have a flashlight, but I've never used this feature on any of my external battery packs. The charge indicator lights are OK & give a general idea of charge level. The only external battery pack (single charge) I own that has a read-out showing percentage level weighs almost as much as this 2/1 external pack.NOTE: the Superpak UNU rechargeable external battery pack was sent to me free of charge to use & review. The opinions expressed above are my own and were not directed by the manufacturer.

This Japonesque lip lacquer is a very nice product. The lip lacquer feels substantial and goes on easily with a brush, not a applicator nub. The lip lacquer seems to stay on the lips for about the same time as regular lipstick.The problem with Japonesque is that the color (shade 04) doesn't match the online color chart. With shade 04, because of the color chart, I expected brownish pink. Instead shade 04 is bubble gum pink- no brown at all. Shade 04  would work better for those who prefer pink makeup.

Good design and easy to install.We used this seal when remodeling a basement bathroom where the concrete floor was just a touch uneven. My contractor's first reaction to the Danco seal was that while it looked like it would do a fine job, he wondered about the smaller hole.Installation was easy and the toilet is keeping its seal. Note there is still wax embedded in the ring, so it is not completely wax free.Positive results and easy installation. Time and use will determine whether the Danco Seal merits additional expense.

This AmazonBasics Micro Ultra-Portable Bluetooth speaker is a touch larger than I thought it would be because of the "micro" description.  It measures about 3-1/4" round & about 1" tall.  As compared to an OXA Bluetooth speaker, however, I do prefer the AmazonBasic "disc" design better than OXA's "tower" design because even with the larger size, the disc design seems to be more packable.Performance-wise, the AmazonBasic is a nice little portable speaker.  It pushes out sound nicely & you can distinguish music levels/tones even when playing at the extremes (low/high).Charging is simple (USB to micro USB) & doesn't take too much time.  Charge holds well too, and holds better than the OXA.  Play time for me was just under 4 hours, so about the same as the OXA.Syncing was immediate. My windows phone saw & connected seamlessly to the speaker.Upshot: nice disc design, pretty good sound & quick charging.  For a portable speaker, the AmazonBasics is worth considering.

While not considered "natural tears", Visine Tears Lubricant Eye Drops, Long Lasting Dry Eye Relief, are just as effective as Thera Tears, the brand I normally buy and use.The Visine drops relieve dryness & irritation fairly rapidly.  Other than the "natural" label, the "feel" of Visine is the same as Thera Tears.Thera Tears ingredient: sodium carboxymethylcellulose 0.25% (eye lubricant), so not the same as Visine's ingredients.Packaging-wise, I like the Visine bottle rather than Thera Tears' individual one-time use dispensers.

I recently bought this because my old garlic press broke on me.WOW, I'm wishing I had this one all along!  My last one was so difficult, I really had to put muscle in it to press the garlic.With this OXO, it's easy.  My grandma could use this and easily press huge pieces of garlic with ease.AND it cleans in a matter of second!  I also throw it in the dishwasher and it comes out fine!

This stand is pretty and I like that it has multiple functions, but I think it tries too hard to do too much and fails at the one major thing it's supposed to be good at: being a cake stand.If I just set my cake on it, it's nice.  But the lid doesn't snap in to place, so it can be bumped and screw up a cake decorating job very quickly.It's also not very tall, so you can't fit much more than a 2 (or 3 small) layer cake inside without the lid hitting the top and ruining the icing.

Over the last year or so I've been teaching myself more and more about cake/cupcake baking and decorating.  This tip really revolutionized my cupcakes!  I've got some amazing recipes that always WOW everyone, and with this baking tip I've really been able to up my decorating to that next level.  My cupcakes look like professional store bought ones now!The tip is also sturdy and easy to use.  I toss it in the silverware bin in the dishwasher and it comes out perfectly clean and in perfect shape.Highly recommend!

I used these on a chocolate cake recently and they looked amazing!  My only complaint is the taste - they were very bland and cardboard-like.  I prefer more sugary sprinkles/quins, so I was disappointed in that one aspect.

My 9-year-old daughter is really getting in to these books, so I bought her a few of these dolls for her birthday.  They are very nicely made with gorgeous outfits and come with stands, so my daughter has them displayed on her dresser.  Highly recommend!

My 9-year-old daughter is really getting in to these books, so I bought her a few of these dolls for her birthday.  They are very nicely made with gorgeous outfits and come with stands, so my daughter has them displayed on her dresser.  Highly recommend!

My 9-year-old daughter is really getting in to these books, so I bought her a few of these dolls for her birthday.  They are very nicely made with gorgeous outfits and come with stands, so my daughter has them displayed on her dresser.  Highly recommend!

These support towers work REALLY well!  They're very sturdy and my overactive plants have not even come close to pulling them over or toppling them.My one and only complaint is that they're only about 4 feet tall.  Maybe I'm just having a super awesome year, but about half of my tomato plants (especially my cherry tomatoes) are up over six feet tall now and they kind of sag over the top of these towers.

UGH THIS BOOK WAS SO BAD!I read the first book in this series (Rush) and I kinda liked it. Then I read Fever (the second book) and pretty much felt like "WTH AM I READING?" the entire time. Jace comes across like a creepy stalker and Bethany is pretty much a doormat. I read the blurb for Burn and I was intrigued by the whole concept that Josie has the cajones to tell Mr. Rich Billionaire NO. That's she's not interested in being a doormat for him like Bethany was for Jace.QUOTE FROM BLURB: "Then Ash meets Josie, who seems immune to his charms and his wealth."See?QUOTE FROM BLURB: "He never imagined the one woman to tell him no would be the only woman whod ever drive him to the edge of desire."Yeah, a feisty woman! One who isn't going to let Mr. Rich Guy walk all over her and command her EVERY MOVE.Unfortunately, that's not what happened.The romance part of plot of this book is nearly identical to Fever.Ash sees Josie and falls in insta-obsession. He has a brief conversation with her where he questions her about her collar (apparently she's already in a dom/sub relationship). He's so obsessed with her at this point that he hires people to follow her and stalk her.When he finds out she pawned some of her jewelry, he's SO MAD that her dom isn't taking care of her. He buys her jewelry from the pawnshop and uses it to blackmail her in to going on a date with him.Man, this is so romantic!During the date he tells her all about how he wants to own her and be her dom and she'll have to agree to let him run every aspect of her life. She is a little wishy washy about it and tells him that she needs time to think about it (OMG YOU THINK??).Then she never calls. (YES, GO GIRL!)A week later, Ash is still having her stalked and finds out that someone punched her in the face.He takes it upon himself to burst in to her apartment and tell her that she's moving in with him. (UH, WHAT THE EVERLOVING HECK??)Josie, who is supposedly able to tell Ash "no" and is "immune to his charms" doesn't tell the creepy jerk to get out of her house. Instead she feels "relief" that someone else is there to make all her decisions for her.Hmm... this all sounds familiar. Insta-obsession? Stalking? Girl gets roughed up and guy forces her to move in with him and take over her life? Yeah, repeat of Fever.And all this happens by around page 90-100?I really liked Rush. While Gabe was a little bit neanderthal, I felt like there was a much more equal relationship between him and Mia. I also felt like Mia had a little more freedom, despite the contract.In both Fever and Burn, we get absolute doormat women who can't have a shred of independence. The men are people who would be considered stalkers in real life. Their actions would end up with them in jail. This is just not romantic. This isn't a dom/sub relationship. It's a rich billionaire forcing his will on a homeless women and a completely broke woman getting out of a rough relationship, but calling it a "love" story.This book is CRAP.This isn't love, people. I'm scared for women who think it is. Looking for this type of man will end up with you being controlled and abused.Hell, this isn't even good BDSM!UGH.(Side note: The fact that each girl in each book ends up going out with Mia and her "gaggle of girlfriends" was so eyerollingly stupid by the third book.Mia: "TEEHEE! We all get drunk and then go dancing at a club! Then afterwards we go home and our men will sleep with us in just our heels! IT'S SO AWESOME!!"Bethany:  "HEEHEE!  In my book we all went out and got drunk and I slept with MY man in just my heels too, after Mia told me about how AWESOME it is!!"Josie: "OMG I want you guys that I just met to tell me all about how you sleep with your men wearing just your heels and then I want to get new heels so Ash can sleep with me in just my heels too! TEEHEE!"Men: "You women are too pathetic to do anything on your own, so one of us will babysit you every time you have a Girls Night Out."Girls: "OMG SO ROMANTIC!! Please sleep with me in just my heels!")

I won this book via a Goodreads FirstReads Giveaway - THANK YOU!I'd rate this one a very weak 3 stars. Probably 2.5ish, but I'll round up to three.I love the idea of the plot. I'm a big fan of the childhood friends falling in love later in life trope. And the brothers fighting over the same girl trope. And the sneaky matchmaking Grandma trope.HOWEVER....This book just made it all a little awkward. I really think that Rachel Van Dyken tried too hard to be funny and instead made things over-the-top and weird. For example, Grandma is not just a feisty lady, she wears SIX INCH HEELS (at 85 years old) and brags about her lover.As far as the main characters...Kacey is pretty well written and interesting, but I got tired of her flip-flopping around between Jake and Travis.Jake is horrible. He's supposed to be this womanizer who sleeps with sluts and strippers all the time (ok, perhaps semi realistic for a millionaire 21 year old playboy), but he is also supposedly super charming and Kacey can't help falling for his charm over and over again. I just didn't see it. He comes across like a complete jerk. And I did like when Kacey called him out on his bad behavior, but then she kept doing whatever he wanted her to do anyways - including pretending to be his fiance so that the board of directors would think him serious enough to run the billion dollar company (at age 21).But then Kacey starts screwing around with Travis (Jake's brother) behind his back. I did like the dynamic between Travis and Kacey, where they "hated" each other and pranked each other all the time. I found their banter to be amusing and that's the only thing that held this story together for me. Well, except for the scene where Travis is spitting on Kacey's face. That grossed me out beyond belief and I almost stopped reading right then and there.Another huge issue I had with this book is the AGE of the characters. Kacey and Jake are 21, Travis is 23. The premise of this book just doesn't work with characters this young. If they were late 20's/early 30's I would have bought it. But Jake and Kacey are 21 and supposedly had a fling in college and the timing is just not right. Assuming most people graduate high school at 17-18, they would graduate college at 21-22. Jake is BARELY out of college and his dad (who has to be what, 45-50?) has already retired and left his billion dollar company in the hands of a 21 year old who theoretically has ZERO work experience? Just not logical.Also, Travis has supposedly owned "one of the biggest ranches in the area" for "years" but he also has to be barely out of college. And he did go to college because it's mentioned that he was a college student when Kacey and Jake were in high school.Like I said, the timing is just awkward and off.Last major gripe - the reunion. First of all, other than tiny schools where everyone knows everyone, who does reunions every year? Also, Jake is all super excited about going to his 4-year high school reunion... why? He's a millionaire playboy banging strippers and models. He was a millionaire during high school and grew up rich and popular (so there's no need to shove it in people's faces). So why is he so excited to go? Also, it's only been FOUR YEARS, yet the women are all described as pregnant and desperate while the men (their husbands) are all fat and balding already. These kids are all 21 years old! I'm sorry, if it was a 20 year reunion, maybe those descriptions would make sense.AGAIN, the timing is bizarre.  I feel like this was written as an adult novel, but the publisher (or author) decided to try and capitalize on the New Adult trend and just changed all of the ages.All that said and done, the book flowed well. I read it quickly and kept reading. Lately I've had such bad luck in books and I hate when a book is a chore, and this one wasn't. I even have some interest in reading the sequel (Jake's love story, I believe).I'd say this one is about the quality I'd expect from an e-book $2.99 or less.
