*I was provided a free copy of this book from Netgalley.com (thank you!!) in exchange for an honest review*This is another I have mixed feelings on. I think my hesitation on liking it is based on the fact that when I got to the end, it didn't feel like a complete story. I was left unsatisfied. :(The author did a lot of telling instead of showing. A main example, which drove me nuts, is that Rose is constantly telling us how she uses big words all the time in dialogue. I can't even think of one example where Rose used big words in dialogue. Most of Rose's dialogue consists of "um" and stammering.Jamie was another odd character. I couldn't like him, and I tried. I kept hoping that he would redeem himself. That the whole relationship between him and the mean girl was a fallacy. But it kind of wasn't. He pretty much was dating her and leading Rose on on the side. While the mean girl was stereotypically mean and probably deserved all the bad stuff, but what does it say about his character when he's playing two girls like that?I did appreciate that Rose was willing to stand up to the mean kids and do the right thing, especially like at the party where the girl was passed out, possibly not breathing, and she called 911, knowing that she would be ostracized for it later.  It's commendable and I appreciate that she was willing to do that, knowing there would be backlash from it.I couldn't stand Rose's best friend. She was an awful person who treated Rose terribly all for the sake of being popular. I could see this happening in real life, though, so I can't really mark down for it. I just thought she was a horrible person and I wanted Rose to kick her to the curb and find a real friend. I did like that Rose tried her best, despite risking her own reputation, to help her friend do the right thing (which she never really did).MINOR SPOILERS AFTER THISThe ending was what really left a bad taste in my mouth. Jamie 'kind of' redeems himself by telling off the mean girl, but does that excuse his behavior the rest of the book? I don't think so.I don't want to spoil the end for anyone who plans on reading this, but the end is just... unsatisfying. I can't think of another way to say it. There's no resolution to the Jamie/Rose storyline at all. I guess there are going to be more books, but I feel like each books in a series should feel complete.I'm not sure I will continue reading this series. It wasn't the most awful book ever, but it just wasn't that good either.

I read "Her Best Worst Mistake" (the companion novel to this) and LOVED it. Unfortunately, Hot Island Nights just didn't appeal to me at all. I had trouble buying the progression of Elizabeth and Nathan's relationship.The sex started immediately and seemed to come out of nowhere, and the "feelings" between them also seemed to come out of nowhere. We get some glimpses in to Nathan's mind, and he was not seeming to want anything to do with Elizabeth outside of sex, then suddenly he's confessing all of his fears and life story and crying in front of her? I don't know, it just seemed forced and fast and Mayberry is usually SO much better than this.I also just didn't like Nathan much as a character. I didn't find him interesting or attractive. I liked Elizabeth in "Her Best Worst Mistake" and she really was a complex and compelling character, but Nathan was just kind of a beefcake with PTSD over a car crash. After completely falling in love with Violet and Martin, I was really really hoping that Elizabeth would find someone just as amazing for her and Nathan just bored me to tears. I also hated the constant use of "Betty" and "Lizzy" as nicknames for Elizabeth

I got Reached from the library and it sat here. And sat here. And become overdue by a week. And finally I opened it up and started reading and it was pretty boring.It starts off with all of the main characters split up, working on their own parts of the upcoming "rising." I never found Cassia to be particularly intriguing, but she was downright yawn inducing here. The entire concept of trading poems like they are some kind of rich commodity is downright ridiculous. The entire time we're in Cassia's head, she's waxing poetic about Ky and trading poems (!!!).Ky and Xander both are mooning over Cassia, at least until Xander runs in to another female. The love triangle was not much of a triangle. There was never an option of Ky and Cassia not ending up together, it was just a matter of what would Condie do with poor Xander. Would she kill him off? Would she make him end up heartbroken and alone? Or would she do the ultimate love triangle cop-out and find him his own love interest?I'll give you three guesses and I bet it will only take one!As far as the "Rising" itself... talk about an uninteresting takeover. We spend pages and pages going OMG THE PILOT! He's COMING! THE RISING IS STARTING! Then boom, flip a page and the Rising has already taken over. There's no war. It's just done. And I sat here going 'what the heck?'I'll be completely honest, after that point, I ended up skipping huge chunks of the book and I missed absolutely nothing important. If I can skip 50-80 pages in one huge chunk and I'm not completely lost when I start again, something is wrong with your novel!This series was never that amazing to begin with, but this conclusion is far from epic. I didn't like it at all and I highly doubt I'll read anything further from this author

This book was very boring, with unlikable and unrealistic characters. These teenagers don't act like teenagers, which is a huge pet peeve of mine. I also think the author spent way too much time on side stories and characters, that were also boring, and I just didn't buy the progression of Giacomo and Kate's relationship.  I don't have much else to say other than, don't waste your time.  There's much better out there.

I love this series! Girl of Nightmares was a perfect followup to Anna Dressed in Blood. Sequels often fail to match the hype of the original, but I have to say this one came pretty close.While I liked Girl of Nightmares, it didn't hook me nearly as much as the first. I found myself skimming occasionally and I think that's partially because outside of a few quick visions, Anna was mostly absent in this book. The majority of Girl of Nightmares is Cas trying to get to Anna once he finds out she's in Hell (or what she thinks is Hell).When I started this series, I was a little weirded out by the ghost/human love story, but it totally made sense. I was also nervous about how Blake would end it, but she blew it away. I won't spoil it, but the ending was perfect, absolutely perfect.Parts of Girl of Nightmares bored me, as Cas spends a lot of time traveling around. A new character (Jestine) was introduced, and I didn't connect with her as much as with the other side characters. Outside of these minor issues, the book was great.Definitely will be checking out more from this author in the future!

This book was so terrible I couldn't finish. I made it through about 200 pages, so I think I gave it a good try! Between the juvenile characters/writing, completely nonsensical plot, and the author constantly breaking her own rules, I just couldn't do it.Xavier and Bethany are so wooden and terrible and boring. Bethany is supposed to be an ANGEL who has SPOKEN TO GOD. Like, to his face. I'm an atheist, but I don't mind reading about religious things in novels. There are some great angel novels out there, but this is NOT one of them. Bethany is awful. She and her angel friends are supposedly on a mission to battle evil forces by doing good deeds. Gabriel tells her she is not to make friends or get too close to humans, but apparently part of Bethany's mission is to go to high school. I have no idea why, because we're told that the evil forces are doing things like killing hundreds of people in the Middle East... and God sends Bethany to high school in what is described by the author as a 'sleepy' small town?Bethany of course, instantly starts making friends, going to parties (WHERE SHE GETS DRUNK), having sleepovers, going to the mall, whatever. Basically acting like a normal teenager. Apparently teenage angels are the same as teenage people. I guess I would expect more from a minion of God who is on Earth to battle evil. Bethany instantly falls in love with Xavier, but I don't really get why. After a couple meetings, she just decides to reveal her big secret. Xavier then is all "OMG MY GIRLFRIEND IS AN ANGEL!"  I'm pretty sure she wasn't supposed to go flashing her wings around all willy nilly....That's about where I quit, because I just couldn't take it anymore. For an angel supposedly on Earth on a MISSION FROM GOD, Bethany is surprisingly selfish. She also did NOTHING to further her mission. From what I gather, her entire mission is to do good deeds and so far, she hasn't done even one.I can't remember all the instances of the author breaking her own rules, but the one that sticks out is where she makes sure to mention how angels don't get tired. They could run marathons without breaking a sweat or breathing hard. But Bethany decides to run over to Xavier and starts talking "between breaths" like she's winded. Literally a handful of pages later!Ugh, absolutely terrible. I'd rather read Breaking Dawn again than read any more of this tripe.

I REALLY wanted to like this book. REALLY bad! I love the rock star bad boy romance/erotica books, but this one just fell short for me.I liked the main characters, but everything seemed so rushed. The first time Nick and Lauren meet again he starts making out with her. He hasn't seen her in 15 years, he dumped her to become famous and have groupies, and she doesn't really fight it at all. The book is 90% sex, 10% plot and the plot is weak. I guess I just prefer my erotica to be slightly more deep.If the sex was actually sexy, I could deal with the plot being a little less than stellar... but the sex was kind of weird. Couper uses a lot of awkward terms during sex scenes that are jarring and completely ruin it for me. Anytime there is gushing, it kind of destroys the scene.I probably would have liked this better with toned down and more well written sex scenes, and another 100 pages of character development and plot. For a a short novella, it wasn't terrible... I just think this author's style is not my thing.  I also can't justify paying $3+ for a novella when there are a LOT of amazing full length self published novels on Amazon for $2.99 and under.

This book was almost as much of a roller coaster as the first.When Avoiding Responsibility starts, it's a year later and Lexi isn't speaking to Jack or Ramsey. She's dating some unknown mystery guy and is surprised when Ramsey calls to ask her to Jack's wedding. She is a strong woman and says HELL NO. At first.Then we start flashing back to see what happened over the last year, and we find out about the relationship that started and ended between Lexi and Ramsey.I admit, I was left feeling unsatisfied at the end of Avoiding Commitment. Not because it was a cliffhanger, but because I felt like Lexi just got totally dumped on by the end (by Jack and Bekah) and it felt like the "bad guys" won. The only part of the ending of Avoiding Commitment I liked was Lexi finally standing up to Jack and realizing how poisonous he was to her.Then Ramsey asks her to the wedding. She says no, of course, but then she finds out Ramsey is in New York WITH JACK for Jack's bachelor party. Somehow, Lexi ends up at Jack's party where a drunken Jack begs her to come to his wedding.Of course, Lexi agrees. This part bugged me. I hated that she would agree to go to his wedding to Bekah. There was absolutely no reason for her to go, other than to make herself feel like total garbage. Again.But she does go. And there is a bunch of the same sort of underhanded passive aggressive conflict between Lexi and Bekah, ridiculous sexual tension between Lexi and Jack, and the hint of something really special between Lexi and Ramsey.At the end of Avoiding Commitment I was completely Team Jack, hoping and praying for some sort of redemption in this book.**SPOILER ALERT**That redemption doesn't come. However, I was okay with it. While the end of this book has some loose ends, I felt better about things. I felt that Bekah finally got a tiny bit of what she deserves. I felt like Jack stooped so low that I didn't even want him to redeem himself anymore. And Ramsey stepped up and I'm really hoping that things work out for him and Lexi in book 3. I'm really hoping that Bekah and Jack both end up alone, but I'm starting to realize they deserve each other and will probably make each other miserable.K.A. Linde has a real talent for creating these realistic and flawed characters that you can't help but feel SOMETHING for. Her books also flow so well that you just lose yourself in the pages and suddenly it's two hours later and you're done and you're wondering what the heck just happened.I'm really looking forward to seeing what else she comes out with and she's going on my auto-buy list for sure.

I'm not very good at writing spoiler free reviews, but I'll try here.Opal starts off right around where we left off in Onyx. I hadn't touched this series since I read Onyx, but I was fortunately able to remember enough to not be lost when I started Opal.Katy has finally accepted her feelings for Daemon and they've started what could be termed as a "real" relationship. And I LOVE it! Daemon is so sweet here, especially with his adorable date nights. He's still Daemon, and Katy is still her same snarky self, but together they're just so cute. I don't generally fangirl over book guys, but the Daemon in Opal is really starting to bring it out in me!The plotline with the government and the other aliens is pretty tumultuous here and just keeps getting better and better! There is plenty of action mixed in with all the romantic Katy/Daemon time.Jennifer Armentrout also will absolutely KILL you with the ending. As soon as I finished I immediately went to look up the release date of Origin (the next book in the series) and whined profusely when I saw how long I'd have to wait. UGH KILLER CLIFFHANGER ARMENTROUT! EVIL EVIL WOMAN!If you liked Obsidian and Onyx, you'll like Opal. For me, Opal was like a combination of all the good stuff in Obsidian and Onyx - sexual tension and romance between Katy/Daemon, crazy alien action scenes, government intrigue and mystery, an ending that will leave you absolutely clamoring for more... what else could you ask for?

SPOILERS in this review!At first, I wanted to like this book. I liked that Natalie Sterling was going to be a strong female character who was proud of getting good grades and being a leader. But as you get in to the book, Natalie becomes more and more unlikable. She treats her best friend, Autumn, poorly throughout the book and I was surprised it took that long for Autumn to ditch her. Natalie comes across like a man-hating, slut-shaming feminazi and until the last 2-3 pages I really hated her.We never really get a reason for WHY she acts that way either. There is a prologue telling a story about a freshman girl who dated a popular senior guy for a few months but when she wouldn't put out, the guy dumps her and tells everyone that her vagina smelled like fish. But, we learn this didn't even happen to Natalie. It happened to Autumn. And Natalie uses this traumatic event to keep Autumn away from everyone else at the school but her. She constantly reminds Autumn of the event and reminds her that SHE (Natalie) is the only one who stood up for her. She refuses to allow Autumn to forgive anyone because she is afraid Autumn will find other friends and leave her.Connor was great, but I wonder why he even liked Natalie. She treats him like garbage throughout the entire story. He brings her a bunch of wood from his family's farm for a bonfire. When it rains, he takes it upon himself to pack up all the wood and get rid of it for her. Instead of thanking him, she acts like a witch and tells him she doesn't need a man's help and could do it herself. After they sort of start seeing each other in private, he brings her a bunch of stuff for Thanksgiving baskets (that she's putting together for student council) and she acts like a complete witch again. Even when they're together in private she is terrible to him. I just don't see the appeal.Spencer was an interesting character. She is the counter to Natalie's uptight feminist ways and she wants to prove to Natalie, and everyone else, that slut shaming is bad too. She does this by calling herself a "Rosstitute" (mix of the school name and prostitute), letting a boy take a naked picture of her, and otherwise acting like a slut. While I agree with her overall point, I think she goes way overboard. If my 14 year old was acting like that, I would be very disappointed in her.I think the overall moral of the story was good. I like when a book has a bigger meaning and purpose other than the typical YA romance (will they or won't they get together?). I think the point was supposed to be for Natalie and Spencer to both realize they were going to extremes, and that meeting somewhere in the middle is probably a better option for both of them. I think that point got across.

This Eau de Toilette comes in a very cute heart-shaped bottle.  The bottom is glass and the top, the lid, is plastic.  I had no trouble at all getting the top off - just takes a twist.  I did have a bit of trouble getting the bottom of the bottle out of the clear plastic inserts that nestled it into the box because it was quite tight, but I only had to do that once.  The box itself if clear red plastic so that you can see the red bottle inside.Okay, this is an attractive spray, but scent is what is important.  I do like it, but with some caveats.  It is floral, as I expected.  It is also kind of sweet, an old-fashioned scent.  I reminds me of those boxes of talcum powder women used to use.  For my sense of smell, it is a little too sweet for everyday use.  However, it is nice for those days when you're feeling romantic and frilly rather than cool and sophisticated.  This is a light-hearted fragrance, bringing to mind butterflies and gardens rather than woods and musk.It takes only a spritz, and it lasts quite a long time on my skin.  My husband likes it on me, perhaps a bit more than I like it on myself.  It is not going to be my everyday fragrance, but it is a nice change of pace.

From the first page, I loved Elsa's grandmother.  And I loved the very precocious almost-8-year old Elsa.  So why does Elsa have to tell people her grandmother is sorry?Lots of different people, all somewhat odd people, live in the apartments where Elsa lives.  And, as in all good fairy tales, and this is a fairy tale intertwined with reality, some are not quite what they seem at first impression.The writing, as in Backman's A Man Called Ove, is gorgeous.  The story is imaginative.  There are monsters and superheroes and everyday heroes and not-so-normal people.  Of course, Elsa is way too bright to be almost-8, but I don't care.  This is a charming, engaging story, and a delight to read.

This review is for the antler alternative from Nylabone.  I was concerned about getting only one bone when I have two dogs, but I needn't be.  Unfortunately, the reason is that neither dog seems to like this antler very much.  They were pretty excited when I opened the package.  I gave it first to the bigger dog,  The front of the package doesn't state what size dog this is for, but the back, once I got the product, stated "Recommended for dogs:  Up to 50 lbs/25 kg."  A photo of the back of the package would be helpful to see on the product page.My larger dog is pushing 50 pounds.  My smaller dog is a little less than half that.  So, I gave the treat to the bigger dog, and he was happy to get it.  I gave a different treat to the smaller dog, and the bigger one immediately dropped the antler to go see what other treats were on offer.He didn't go back to the antler, but when I handed it to him, he chewed on it for maybe 30 seconds at the most.  When he abandoned it, I gave it to the smaller dog.  He chewed on it/played with it for maybe 15 seconds.  Since then, it has been ignored.This is a hard chew-type toy, not a consumable.  If your dog manages to chew a piece off and swallow it, you are supposed to contact your veterinarian.  It can be hand washed with warm soapy water, and then rinsed, according to the instructions.  It is "WITH CALCIUM AND MINERALS!" but no ingredient list, probably not required because it is not meant to be consumed.  But I would like something a little more definitive than "WITH CALCIUM AND MINERALS!"But that is moot if my dogs won't chew on it.  Unfortunately, they give it two paws down.  Your dogs may have different opinions, but in this house, it is just another thing to step on in the middle of the night when I'm barefoot.

When I ordered these sports bras, I admit that I thought I was ordering a different style, a racerback style I'd bought in the past.  So I was disappointed when I opened the package, that is until I tried them on.  I like these better.They are a nice, heavyweight fabric and they fit very well.  They give moderate support to the well-endowed among us, perhaps not enough support for jogging, but good for most activities.  If I were young and skinny, which I am not, I'd have no qualms about wearing these without a shirt over them.  Alas, that would not be a good look now, but the coverage these provide is quite good.These regular straps look better under most of my tops than the racerback style does.  I'm going to order more.

My husband often grills fish, and I thought these pans might help with that task.  And they do.  They are lightweight, and hold a fillet or two, or a relatively small whole fish.  And they are nicely no-stick.  However, I'm not sure it is worth getting a special product for grilling fish.  Until we got these pans, we made a little tray out of aluminum foil with the sides turned up, and buttered the bottom.  That works just as well as these pans, and is more versatile because you can make whatever size you need.  And of course, that is cheaper.These are handy for grilling, for camping, and when you don't want to blacken a pan over the grill.  For inside cooking, I don't see much advantage over a reusable pan.  The instructions say to "place the Reynolds Bakeware Fish Pan on a permanent baking pan with 1-inch sides."  For light fillets, we don't do this, but doesn't that kind of defeat the whole purpose?  You still have to use and wash a permanent pan.These don't come shrink-wrapped, just have a band of plastic around the 3 pans, holding them together, and with a label sticky-glued to the top pan, so I did lightly wash them before use.  However. be aware that if you wash these, be very gentle because the non-stick coating does wash off.These pans don't fit into my toaster oven, which is quite a small one.For this household, we're going back to buttered aluminum foil.

I was given this product for review.These lights are tiny, but very cute.  The solar is nice so that you don't have to mess with electrical outlets.  You do want to put them in a place where you are going to keep them, because like all tiny lights on long wires, they do tangle easily.  However, for permanent fairy lights, they are quite nice.  I prefer the steady light rather than the optional blinking.I have a similar set that started losing ability to hold a charge after less than three months.  This solar setup looks the same, just with a different style of light, so I am going to have to wait to see if these start failing to hold a charge.  If so, stringing them only to have to take them down and replace them is going to be a disappointment.  But until I know, I do like these little fairy lights.

I was given this product for review.There are lots of reasons to wear a faux diamond ring instead of a real diamond ring.  Diamonds are ridiculously expensive, and their mining is exploitative and eco-destructive.  Maybe you don't want the good stuff stolen when you are on vacation, or maybe you just can't afford the good stuff.At any rate, if you want the bling of diamonds without all the negatives, this is a good alternative.  The set is quite attractive and nicely made.  The bands are somewhat squared off rather than round.  The size fit me as I expected.  If you want all-out bling, wear both rings,  If you want something a bit more subtle, just wear the single band.  Either way, it's a nice look.

I've heard about A Town Like Alice for years, and finally got around to listening to it.  While it was interesting, and while I liked it, I don't sing its praises as many do.The story was intriguing, starting off with a misogynist attitude disguised as protection.  The attitudes in this 1950 book were rather startling  the casual disregard of the abos, the indigenous Australians, and the acceptance of cruelty  stealing animals and leaving them penned without food or water for days to break them.  Of course, there was the brutality of war, but our attitudes  toward that haven't changed much  brutality is still acceptable.  Women, except for the lead character Jean Paget were too much portrayed as spineless simpletons.  Jean though was tough.  Very tough.  I liked her entrepreneurial spirit.I got really, REALLY tired of the phrase, Oh my word!  Over and over and over....But what caused me to like this book less than I would otherwise was how it devolved into a hasty romance.  I expected better.  While this novel was based on real people, there was historical inaccuracy, so read it as a novel, not as fictionalized fact.  Entertaining, but not a favorite.

Eating a jelly-filled doughnut takes concentration.  That's our introduction to the protagonist, a private investigator, Sam Blackman, who has trouble getting to court with a clean shirt.  This mystery, set in Asheville, North Carolina, is full of local atmosphere.  A ghost tour of Asheville's famous hauntings is supposed to raise money for two tragically orphaned children.  But things, of course, cannot go as planned.There are lots of red herrings in this story.  There is also an underlying message, or at any rate, a question about justice.  Is winning more important than justice?  Apparently.The characters are fun, the mystery is fun, and I really enjoyed the atmospheric settings.  I had to admit I got a laugh out of one chaplain's description of what he called the Prosperity Gospel:  Jesus is my boyfriend and he's going to buy me presents.  But no, this isn't a religion-bashing story.The book is relatively short, and an entertaining, easy read between those longer, heavier stories.I was given an uncorrected proof of this book for review.  The quotes may have changed in the published edition.

The first time I sprayed this solution onto my tongue, I thought it tasted horrible.  I didn't mind it on subsequent uses, so perhaps the first time was a bit shocking and I just got used to the taste.  The solution does seem to work very well.  The active ingredient is cetylpyridnium (sp?) chloride, different from the active ingredients in the mouthwash I have on hand.I have a fairly high gag reflex, and I can't use this too far back on my tongue without triggering that reflex, but it doesn't cause a problem for the front 2/3s or so of my tongue.The little nubby head works well, too.  Used on the Philips Sonicare handle, it vibrates just as the toothbrush head does, of course.  Is this head more effective than gently using the toothbrush head?  If this head is better for some reason, why don't they just include a similar area on the back of the regular toothbrush head, and sell the solution separately?  I used another electric toothbrush that did include the tongue scrapper on the back of the regular head, and that means I didn't have to switch out heads all the time - just use the other side of the toothbrush.  Switching heads is inconvenient, and I imagine very few people have two handles so they don't have to do that.The instructions that came with this state that you should rinse and repeat for a total of three times.  If you routinely clean your tongue, I don't think 3 times is necessary.  I didn't see the instructions until I was putting the box in the recycling bin.  The purple paper at the back of the box, which I thought was just part of the packaging, is a little instruction pamphlet.It would also be nice if this came with a little protective cover, as the brush heads do.  I don't want to just stick it in a drawer with no cover.At the time of this review, I can find replacement heads on Amazon, but not replacement solution on its own, just this kit.  To me, it would be wise to include the tongue scrubber on the back of the regular toothbrush and sell the solution separately.  That would eliminate all the negative aspects of this helpful but not entirely practical product.  If the company is afraid that the solution wouldn't sell if done this way, they could include a small sample of the spray with the original handle and head, so people could have a chance to try it, and buy replacement solution as desired.

If you want to read this Jame Smiley trilogy, the Last Hundred Years trilogy, you'd better hunker down and get read for a long story.  None of the book are short.  And you'd better bookmark the family tree pages.They really should be read in order.  Some trilogies have second or third books that can stand on their own without reading the previous book(s) but this is not such a story.  It builds on the others to an extent that you would lose much of the importance of this book without the others.The series is about family, mostly a farming family that branches out.  But it is about much more than that.  It is also about the issues, the politics, the concerns of each era.  Golden Age convers 1987 through 2019  so a little look at the future, too.I loved the first book, Some Luck.  I enjoyed the second, Early Warning, but not as much as the first.  This latest one is a complex and lovely end.  I didn't love it quit as much as the first book, but more than the second, and even though I didn't love it is much as Some Luck, it is still, in my opinion, a five-star novel.However, it was a challenge for me to read.  There are so many characters, a cast of thousands.  Well, that is an exaggeration, but it doesn't seem like much of a stretch.  I bookmarked the family tree and had to keep referring back to it.  Is so-and-so a cousin or a sibling?  Who did Cousin Whatshername marry?The characters are complex and interesting, if not always lovable.  None of them are flat, one-sided.  Some were unlikable, one of them especially so, some were charming, but they were all different.What I liked as much as the story of family was the way the story of that age was woven into the story.  This one covered politics, of course, and climate change, and GMO crops, and Monsanto practices.  Housing market collapse.  Corruption.  Lots of corruption.  And references to real people in the news these days, or over the last few decades.If you like long, involved family sagas, this one is excellent, and worth the time it takes to read it and its two precursors.Jane Smiley's writing is wonderful, mixing the sometimes esoteric with the mundane.  One of the more likable characters, Henry, is thinking about the Justinian Plague, the Dark Ages, the Battle of Badon, and several other deep subjects in a long paragraph, and the next paragraph is, in  its entirety,He found a parking spot.I was given an advance reader's copy of this book for review.  The short quote may have changed in the published edition.

I got these earrings in the white gold color, and am pleased with them.  They are pretty and dainty.  Sparkly enough to add a little bling but small enough to not be ostentatious.  The settings are sturdy and even, not sloppily done.  The only reason these are 4 star instead of five is because they are completely flat, something I couldn't tell from the illustrations.  I expected a little bit of a curve, and think they would look better if they did have that small amount of curve.  Still, for affordable earrings, these are quite nice.I was given  these earrings for review.

For those who like disposable dusters, this one is very good.  The 360 design means there is lot of surface for dusting, an improvement over the older, blue refill Swiffer duster I have.  The yellow part is exceptionally soft.  It doesn't just move the dust around; it picks it up.  The handle is like the old one, not exceptionally sturdy but certainly adequate for light dusting.  The refills are easy to slide on, but of course, they are also easy to slide off.  If you are an "enthusiastic" duster, you might find yourself sliding the duster back onto the handle after it starts to slide off.  At least I do.This seems kind of a lightweight for heavier duties, like dusting wood blinds.  It does work, but just seems a bit on the flimsy side.  And I still am going to do polishing, wet-dusting, oiling the old fashioned way now and then.  Where this really excels is a quick dusting between the heavier chores.  I can do the whole house in almost no time, and give it a fresher look, certainly good for when that unexpected company drops by.This starter kit contains one handle and two disposable duster pads.

These puzzles range from simple ones to tough ones, and I like having that variety - the easy ones for when I want a quick break from doing something different and the harder ones for when I have time to work a bit longer.  There are some "Samurai Sudoku" puzzles, too - 4 9X9 grids with a 5th grid intersecting part of each of the others.  I'd never done those before, and I like them.The binding is quite good.  I usually tear out the pages as I am done with them, and the binding holds up well for that.  The paper is good for writing with both ink and pencil, and it is sturdy enough to stand up to erasing.When I first got this book, I thought that perhaps the puzzles, two to a page except for the Samurai ones, might be too small.  I admit to sometimes jotting numbers in the bottoms of the squares when I am stumped.  I can still do that with this book, despite my initial reservations.I use those little Post-It arrows to mark the first empty page of each section so it's easy to find the degree of challenge I want at the time.  Little built-in tabs would have been nice but that would probably have made this not such an easily affordable book.  I don't know if this book comes in different volumes, but if it does, I'm going to get another one when I get  close to running out of these puzzles.  For me, doing these puzzles is very relaxing.

I've had the more traditional type of Nylabones in my dogs' toybox for years, and I've had many dogs, my own and foster dogs, over those years.  Sometimes the dogs like to chew on Nylabones, sometimes they don't.  At any rate, I thought these dental chews sounded like a good idea, so wanted my dogs to test drive them.On the plus side, the dogs really seemed to like them.  And the ingredients don't seem to contain anything bad,  And perhaps they are really good for their teeth.On the negative side, they disappear in an instant.  There are only three treats in the package, each with three prongs, for "up to 9 treating occasions!"  There is no obvious marking on the front of the package about what size dogs these are for, but in tiny print on the back, it says "For dogs up to 30 pounds, feed up to two medium chews per day."  These tiny treats are apparently "medium," but it would be nice if that were marked on the front of the package.I now have one dog several pounds under 30, and one dog several pounds over 30.  I would not give only one "prong" to even the smaller dog.  One prong is tiny, and I can't imagine it working well for the average "small" dog, like mine.  I actually am afraid he would swallow it whole because it is so small.  So I gave both dogs a full treat, three prongs, leaving one treat left in the package.  And I immediately started breaking down the cardboard box the product was shipped in, to put it in the recycle bin.  The larger dog was done with his treat before I got the box broken down.  Okay, he is too big for these treats , even though that is not obvious from the packaging.But my little dog should be just the right size as long as I give him the whole treat instead of just one third of it.  It took him only a few seconds longer than the larger dog -- all gone within less than two minutes.While these are treats that my dogs appreciate, they are not practical for keeping their teeth clean.  For the vast majority of us who have dogs, we simply cannot afford to give a $3+ treat, or two of them, to our dogs every day. At current prices, giving two treats a day to each of my two dogs would be over $400 a month.  Just one treat - still over $200.  And as treats, there are more reasonable options.  I'm afraid this won't be a staple in our household.

The first time I used this hand cream, I thought the scent was too strong, and not one I especially liked.  Now that I've used it many more times, the scent has kind of grown on me, and I don't find it objectionable, although I'd prefer if it were unscented.Despite that, this is a truly excellent hand cream.  It takes just a little bit to make my hands feel soft and protected, and that effect lasts!  I like that it contains NO parabens or phthalate.  It is not unreasonably priced, especially considering that it seems concentrated, so it doesn't take as much as with some more watery products.  It is not so thick that it is difficult to spread, just not watery feeling.  I can feel it on my hands, but they don't feel greasy or oily, just soft.This hand cream is a keeper!

When I first chose this book to read, I didn't realize that it is the second in a series, but it doesn't matter  it worked quite nicely as a standalone.  However, I am going to read the first one, Caught Dead, to get more background.A woman commits suicide.  Or is it murder?  Rick Van Lam is a PI, but he is also a dust boy, a mongrel, a maligned mixture of Vietnamese and Caucasian blood not much accepted by either race.This is not a gory mystery at all.  It skips the violence of so many mysteries.  The woman whose mystery Rick is hired to solve is not especially likable; even her niece who wants her death investigated is ambivalent about her.I liked that the characters were not all good, not all evil.  As mysteries go, I was more curious about the resolution of it than empathetic with the person who died.I loved the Vietnamese references  the culture, the mouth-watering descriptions of food, the rituals and attitudes, especially as practiced in the U.S.  The protagonist, Rick, is self-effacing with a sense of humor, mostly directed at himself.  I appreciated reading about his early life, abandoned at a Catholic orphanage when he was 5.The explanation of frozen men, those souls so damaged by what happened during the war that they are just waiting to die, tugged at my heartstrings.For me, the end was wrapped up a little too neatly, too much explanation came too easily, but I still enjoyed the story.This book has a nice combination of intrigue and heart, and doesn't rely on violence to tell its story.  It's a series I'm going to keep on my radar.I was given an advance reader's copy of this book for review.

Although I love reading Shakespeare, his works are not easy for me, and I spend a lot of time thinking, hmmmm, I wonder what that means.  And I keep my trusty guide to Shakespeare nearby.  When I learned that there is a modern retelling of The Winter's Tale, the first of a new series, I couldn't wait to get my hands on it.The Winter's Tale is one of the plays I haven't read yet,  The Gap of Time starts with a synopsis of Shakespeare's story, and was quite helpful to me.  (I do have The Winter's Tale in my to-read stack now.)Except for the plot, this retelling is thoroughly modern.  There are cell phones and video games and iPads.  Everything normal.  The characters, with slightly modified names, and the plot are straight from Shakespeare.And I loved this book.  Absolutely loved it.  There was a violent, brutal, graphic bit that was hard for me to read, but S. himself certainly didn't shirk from violence and occasional raunchiness.  I started out reading this book.  I ended up savoring it.How can you not, with Interval writing like Perhaps it began when the moon splintered off from the earth, pale, lonely, watchful, present, unsocial, inspired.  Earth's autistic twin.Although I had heard of some of the author's other books, I had not read them.  Now I'm just going to have to, not because of the Shakespeare but because of her writing.Apparently, Hogarth is going to have a series of Shakespeare plays, retold by modern authors Margaret Atwood, Tracy Chevalier, Gillian Flynn, Howard Jacobson, Jo Nesbo, Edward St. Aubyn, Anne Tyler, and of course, this one my Jeanette Winterson.  If this first one is any indication of the quality, I'm going to have to get my hands on every single one of them.I was given an advance reader's copy of this book for review.  The quote may have changed in the published edition.

I am more of a novel reader than a short story reader, but I loved the author's A Constellation of Vital Phenomena so much that I couldn't wait to read these stories.And to me, it read more like a novel than just a collection of short stories.  The stories are all interconnected, and loop back and forward through stories of characters I've come to love.Mr. Marra's writing is extraordinary.  Without being flowery, it is remarkably, beautifully descriptive.  The characters are both hopeful and resigned.I didn't mark passages as I was reading, so I flipped the book open at random to look for an example.  The first thing I read:Back in my room, I scanned my modest belongings.  Bottles filled with dusk light stood in the corner.  The long-rotting carcass of my academic career sprawled across the desk.  And then, There I was, Napoleon's height and I couldn't even conquer the apartment WC.  I slipped the two pickle jars into the duffle, the Polaroid into my pocket, and then slipped myself out the door.There is a painting that keeps reappearing, censors who fail to properly censor, and a mix tape to be used only in case of emergency.  Ballerinas and brothers.These stories are not a straightforward telling of a story, but tell a story they do, in a winding, meandering path, sprinkled with humor and soul, and all the more beautiful for the journey they take.I was given an advance reader's copy of this book for review.  The quotes may have changed in the published edition.

I was given this product for review.These kraft paper tags are heavyweights.  I was afraid they might be lighter than they look, but no, they are quite sturdy.  I was also afraid that some inks, especially felt tips like fine line Sharpies, but cause bleeding on the paper, but that has not happened.They are very cute for homey-type gifts, and on gifts of homemade foods, adding a nice down-to-earth touch, especially when used with the enclosed jute strings.  If you want to fancy them up just a bit,  try using a bit of thin velvet or satin ribbon for a touch of class.  It does have to be thin, because the holes are relatively small.  However, there is room to punch a bigger hole in the tags.While I have just written on mine, they would be fun with stickers, especially letting the kids decorate them, or with glitter pens.  These are quite versatile and nice quality at a reasonable price.

This novel, which has received quite a bit of attention, almost lives up to its hype.  Characters come and go, and you are never quite sure if any character might make an appearance later in the book.  Well, except for one little girl.  And the food is always a star player.The beginning was wonderful, with characters that immediately drew me into their story.  I got a bit bored when some teenage romance went on a little too long for my taste.  And I hated the deer hunting part, but I know that doesn't bother most people as much as it bothers me.Some of the characters morph into different people, at least superficially different, when we meet them again.  Most are kindhearted if not always wise.In the beginning, there is quite a bit about lutefisk:"...caught one, pounded it, dried it, soaked it in lye, resoaked it in cold water, and done the careful cooking required to make something that, when perfectly prepared, looked like jellied smog and smelled like boiled aquarium water."And a character, being bulled, "...reminded herself that all of these boys would be changing her oil someday.""[....], in her brain, pushed [....] out of a window onto a stone courtyard, and watched as dogs ate her body."To counteract that, "After decades away from the Midwest, she'd forgotten that bewildering generosity was a common regional tic."There are some fun recipes in here, most like dishes one would take to a Lutheran potluck.This is one of those novels that when I put it down after the last page, makes me sigh with contentment.

For people like me who love stories about old books, old libraries, old tales, this novel is delightful.  The beginning, a tiny abandoned child, drew me in immediately.  His story is interspersed with a modern-day story about someone who was unexpectedly sent an old book that may have something to do with his family.There are mermaids who drown, carnivals and hustlers, tarot cards, people more than a bubble off normal, a touch of curse and supernatural, and too much water.  There is a lot of love and caring, and a little hate, some sadness. I cared about the characters, I cared about the slowly revealed story, and the writing is lovely.  What's not to love?

I've used Granite Gold daily cleaner and Granite Gold polish in the past, and have been reasonably happy with both of them.  However, lazy sod that I am, I didn't like having to go over my counters twice.  Well, actually three times because I'd first wipe them down with a wet cloth to get any crumbs and detritus off.This product combines the best of those two products in one easy step.  Well, two - I still wipe off any crumbs first.  This product is easy to apply and easy to buff.  Water drops bead up on the surface, as they should.  I use the polish as much to protect my stone as to polish it.My countertops are made of a slab of quartzite, a natural stone (different from the quartz countertops that are manufactured from ground quartz and resin), and I'm a little paranoid about damaging them.  They are not polished to as high a shine as some granite is, and I don't expect this polish to create a shine that is not there.  I do expect them to "freshen up" the shine, and to provide some protection.  This product does both.However, this two-in-one product does not provide quite the protection of a different brand of heavier polish I often use.  It is a thick liquid, and is applied with a cloth, and then buffed.  And buffed, and buffed.  It really works well, but it is also a harder, more time consuming job.  I am going to continue to use that heavier polish occasionally, but like this Granite Gold Clean and Shine for my more frequent cleaning and polishing.  Because I'm lazy.The bottle I got does leak a bit out of the top, near the trigger, when I spray, but I think I just got a slightly defective bottle.

This is a story of a poor little rich girl, Rosemary Kennedy, the hidden Kennedy.  Being rich isn't going to solve all your problems, and could just contribute to making them worse.Starting with a horrific birth practice, Rosemary's life was never easy.  Especially in a family that honors competition and winning above all else.This is also a story of a girl, and then a woman, whose life should never have been as it was.  Even after her traumatic birth, it could have been so much better for her.  But we certainly don't want to be embarrassed by a child who is "dull" when her eight siblings shine.  My gosh, it was hard to live up to the Kennedy name.The story is straightforward in its telling.  Rosemary's story is anything but straightforward.  The poor child was bounced around so often that even a normal child without mental disabilities would have trouble coping.  And then there was the traumatic and ill-advised surgery, barbaric.Some of the children were very good with Rosemary, especially Eunice.  It seems Joe, Sr. threw money instead of love at the problem.  Rosemary adored her father, and would do anything to please him.  And Rose, Rosemary's mother, was not very honest about her daughter when she sent her to different schools, and was not honest in her memoirs.  When things got tough, it seems her first action of choice was to take a vacation.Some of the people who took care of Rosemary sound wonderful, and I'm glad Rosemary had those people in her life.This book caused me some anger, and much sadness.  I lost some respect for some people.  Fortunately, things have become better when working with people with mental disabilities, but we're far from winning a gold star.I was given an advance reader's copy of this book for review.  Even the advance copy contained some lovely photographs, which I am sure will be even better in the finished, published edition.

I was given this product for review.I, personally, think these bully sticks are rather disgusting and stinky.  My dogs beg to differ.I have the 12" thin sticks, thinking they would work for both my small and my larger dog, and they do.  I was hoping that I could break them in two, giving the larger dog the larger pieces, but these are not to be broken.  Or cut with kitchen scissors.  Or cut with a knife.  However, my hedge clippers work just fine on them.  These things, even the skinny ones, are tough!My dogs love them.  They last quite a long time, lots of chewing time in them.  The only other things I've given my dogs in the past that last so long are rawhide chews, and I no longer will give them those.  Treats are usually one-bite, 3-second things, and plastic-type chew toys are not as interesting or satisfying to them, and I can't blame them for that.They do come in a resealable bag, which helps with the odor, but I keep them in a utility closet, not in the pantry with other foods.  Not a necessity, just the way I prefer to do it.I've resisted buying bully sticks in the past (you do know what part of the animal they're from, don't you?), but now knowing how much my dogs like them, I will continue to get them for them despite my squeamishness.

I'm a fan of IZZE soda, so was excited about trying this flavored sparkling water.  And it is quite nice - lightly flavored, just a touch of sweetness, and great ingredients.  The only ingredients are carbonated water, cane sugar, natural flavors, and citric acid.  And a measly 10 calories per bottle, with no artificial sweeteners.  And it's organic.I like the mandarin/lime flavor best, and then the blackberry pear.  While I like the raspberry/watermelon flavor, I thought the raspberry overpowered the watermelon, and didn't like it as much as the other flavors.  I was wanting a stronger watermelon flavor.While I am not a big soda drinker, when I do drink soda, I like IZZE or the occasional old-fashioned root beer.  I am more of a water drinker, and I do like lightly flavored waters or fruit/veggie infused waters.  This brand satisfies my tastes but I'm afraid that it generally is too expensive to drink much of it, at least on my budget.  I don't mind paying more for a good soda, but one soda now and then, big taste and flavor for the money, does not have a budget implication that drinking these sparkling waters for hydration have.  While I will continues to drink IZZE soda now and then (and it's delicious), I think I'll stick to other ways to add flavored water to my water intake.

In war, as in this book, reality bumps head-on with perceptions, and a skewed reality.  There are some parts of this book that I really, really hope are the author's imagination, but I fear they are not.Part autobiographical, part fiction, real characters, whatever this book is, it is brutal and unsettling.  It is not an easy book to read unless the reader is a sadist who enjoys cruelty.Despite that, I am glad I read it.  First published in 1990, 25 years ago, it is still a valid look at a brutal war.  And a look at how that war changes soldiers, how it sometimes steals their souls and replaces it with cruelty.  Or perhaps, for some of those soldiers, the cruelty was already there, looking for a socially acceptable way of practicing it.The author can write, no doubt about that.  And there are many examples of the things these characters, these people carried, physical and emotional."He carried a strobe light and the responsibility for the lives of his men.""They carried all they could bear, and then some, including a silent awe for the terrible power of the things they carried.""They carried the common secret of cowardice barely restrained, the instinct to run or freeze or hide, and in many respects this was the heaviest burden of all, for it could ever be put down, it required perfect balance and perfect posture."The story about a flight towards Canada, dodging a draft for a war the author didn't believe in, was as touching as the stories of the fighting, the death, the despair in Vietnam."I passed through towns with familiar names, through the pine forests and down to the prairie, and then to Vietnam, where I was a soldier, and then home again.  I survived, but it's not a happy ending.  I was a coward.  I went to war.""In many ways he was like America itself, big and strong, full of good intentions, a roll of fat jiggling at his belly, slow of foot but always plodding along, always there when you needed him, a believer in the virtues of simplicity and directness and hard labor."There are so many other quotable parts of this book, but you get the idea.  This powerful book, more truth in it that I would like to know, has lost none of its impact over the years.

I am a fan of essential oils, and I love lavender essential oils.  I've bought several bottles over the years, and this one is my favorite so far.The oil is organic and the flowers are from France.  The smell is lovely, more floral than the lavender oil I last used.  I find it very relaxing and comforting.  I use it mostly for aromatherapy in a little diffuser and for using when cleaning house.  A few drops sprinkled on my mop pad before I steam mop makes the whole house smell good.  My husband was told to use a bit of it for his allergies, just dabbed under his nose, and he says it seems to help, but I can't vouch for that.  He also used it before going to bed, and he said that he slept well, better than usual.  I could smell the oil, too, and it was so nice as I was falling asleep.A 15 ml bottle is quite small, about a U. S. tablespoon, but that is the nature of essential oils.  The current price point of this bottle seems very reasonable to me.  A little oil goes a long way.  And it can be combined with a less expensive carrier oil when you need a less concentrated oil.I have not used products from Sabai Wellness before, but if this little bottle of organic essential oil is typical of their products, they have a new customer.I was given this product for the purpose of review.

It took several uses for me to decide what I really think of this product.  On my hair, it does offer minimal increase in shine, the main reason I wanted it, but not as much as I had hoped.  The upside of that is it doesn't make my hair feel dirty as do some products meant to add shine.  Perhaps I would have different results if my hair were color-treated, permed, or especially dry.It does offer some help in styling, although not as much as products meant specifically for styling.  I find I prefer other products when styling my freshly washed hair.I do like the way this gives some extra oomph to my already styled, dry hair.  If my hair has lost some of its style during the day and I want to freshen the look but don't have time to wash & style, this product works well.  It helps me pull my hair into little separated strands without using anything as heavy as a gel or wax - I want separation, not spikes.Also, it seems quite similar to a product my stylist uses, but is much more affordable.  And the scent is quite nice.While this isn't a favorite for my hair, I think the differences in makes would be more visible on hair drier or more damaged than mine.If you like this type of product, I'd suggest giving this one a try before spending much more at your stylist's shop.

I have a love/hate relationship with the Southern United States, so not surprisingly, I have a love/hate opinion of this book of short stories, mostly very short stories, most if not all previously published.  One of my very favorite is the author's introduction, a love song to the South.  Many of these stories, true stories with maybe just a touch of exaggeration here and there, are relaxing and casual and as comforting as an old pair of shoes.Having said that, there was too much repetition, too much sameness to too many of the stories.  If I had to read about cracklin's one more time, I would have wanted to do someone bodily harm.  (Figure of speech - I am not out to harm anyone, cracklin's or not.)Some of the stories were saccharin sweet, too sentimental for my tastes.  The stories were not usually serious, but there was one about the BP oil spill that was dead serious, and oh so sad.The author and his family are white, and the stories were about mostly white people - there is very little here about racial conflicts.  Well, except for one story that was about football.  Too much football for me.The ones that caused me the hate part of my opinion had to do with casual cruelty.  I hated some of the fishing stories, I hated that telling me about ripping the lips off a red snapper is supposed to be entertainment for me.  I didn't think that going into "the defining element of great Southern literature," the dead mule, was entertaining.  And I hated the expression, "enough money to burn a wet dog," even if it was just used as an expression.So, while some of these snippets of life in the South were wonderful, there were some that I would have preferred skipping.I was given an ebook copy of this book for review.  I believe it is an advance reader's copy, but I can't find that notation on it, so the quotes may have changed in the published edition.

Both of the adults in this household are fans of good mustard, and neither of us like this one.  It is too sweet without enough mustard kick to it.  The sweet/hot combination can be great, but only if it is done right.  The texture was a little strange too, like natural peanut butter that has been stirred but not refrigerated.Unfortunately, this bottle of mustard will probably make its way to the back of the refrigerator in ignominy, only to be eventually rediscovered and discarded.(I bought my bottle at the local grocery store.)

Despite not being especially naive or uninformed, it never ceases to amaze me how incredibly cruel, cowardly, and monstrous humans can be.  It also amazes me how brave and generous they can be.  This book showed both sides of that human-nature coin.The author writes of the time of the German invasion of France during WWII, and of the avenue of spies, a very affluent neighborhood in Paris where some of the worst of the worst that Germany had to offer took over the homes.  And the story of an amazingly brave American, Sumner Jackson, and his courageous wife, Toquette, and son, Phillip, who lived cheek by jowl with these same monsters, and who were unflinching part of the resistance.It is always appalling to see how easily France at that time just rolled over and showed their underbelly to the Germans invading their city, and how many of their political and governmental leaders collaborated with the enemy.  "That night the lights did not go on in Paris. The unthinkable had happened.  The Nazis had taken over without a shot being fired."  DeGaulle "implored patriotic Frenchmen to join him in London and continue to fight the Germans."  In London.  And yet on D-Day, when the Allies were saving France, "From Vichy, Marshal Petain called for all patriotic Frenchmen to remain neutral.  French blood, he stressed, was too precious to be wasted in this fight."  "The French were to play no part in liberating themselves."The bravery, cunning, and perseverance of the members of the resistance, both French and non-French, is in start contrast.  Phillip, as re reminisces, was a boy and then a man with never a chance to be an adolescent.Author Kershaw pulls no punches in describing the horrors of the time.  However, this is a relatively short book, not drawn out, and it packs a wallop in less than 250 pages of text, not counting notes and bibliography.<spoiler, if there can be a spoiler in historical nonfiction>  Phillip who went on to live a long life and continued to enjoy hunting, amassing big game "trophies."  It also amazes and saddens me that someone who has seen so much death and cruelty in his life can inflict the same on animals who want nothing but to be left alone to live their lives.I guess we never will learn.

If you want deodorant only, no antiperspirant, this is a decent solution.  Like all AXE products that have made their way to our household, this one has a strong scent, that familiar pine tree+ scent, but it is rather nice, and not so strong as to be overwhelming.  My husband has been using it for a few days, and I tried it too, just so I could get a firsthand feel for it.It's not an antiperspirant, so it is not going to protect against wetness, only odor, and it seems quite good at that.  The deodorant vs. antiperspirant/deodorant is a personal choice, and most people know which they prefer.  The stick is somewhat translucent, not as solid-feeling as those white sticks, and not as soft as a gel.  It glides on very easily, not draggy at all.It has a slight stickiness when it goes on, but not as sticky as some other deodorants. The stickiness takes a few minutes to go away, but it does go away.The reason this is not going to be a keeper in our house is that it makes my husband's underarms itch.  This is probably some sort of allergic reaction, but he is not generally an allergy-prone person and has never had a reaction to any other deodorant, so this is very unusual for him. He continued to use it to see if the first time was just a weird coincidence, but no - itching after every use.This seems a good product for those who like the scent (and you never know until you try it personally), who want only deodorant, and who don't have an adverse reaction to it (which is probably the vast majority of users).

Both of my dogs like this weight management kibble, but then they like about anything.  What is especially nice is that I can give a little more of this to my chunky boy than if it were regular food, and he doesn't feel deprived because he has finished his breakfast/dinner while Perfect Weight Dog is still chowing down.  Those "Why don't you love me - you gave him more" puppy eyes are hard to take.I mix my dogs' kibble with home-cooked chicken and rice or canned food, and add water.  This kibble does have a lighter feel to it, and gets soggier faster than the non-weight management kibble.  However, if you have a dog with a weight problem, if he is anything like mine, the food doesn't stay in the bowl long enough for sogginess to be an issue, and it probably wouldn't bother the dogs anyway - just the humans feeding them.In my opinion, Nutro foods went downhill for awhile, but they have made improvements, and I trust them again.  The product description states, "The very first ingredient in this nutritionally complete, low-calorie, natural diet dog food is U.S.-farm-raised Chicken," and that is reassuring.  This does have quite a bit of grain product in it, but I think that is what makes it more filling.This is quite a good product for the chunky dog in your life.

It's interesting that some users think this provides heavier coverage while others think it is too light.  It's all in the eye of the beholder.  I think it provides moderate coverage, a bit heavier than the foundation I was using before I tried this.  I think the coverage is perfectly adequate for anyone who likes that moderate amount of coverage.For me, the finish was too matte.  It seemed to emphasize little wrinkles and flaws rather than disguising them.  For me, this one by the same manufacturer works better: Maybelline New York Instant Age Rewind Radiant Firming Makeup, Creamy Natural 200, 1 Fluid Ounce.  While I don't like a foundation to look oily or too shiny, too much matte effect is not flattering.As far as the Superstay claim, this foundation really does last.  It doesn't melt off and disappear as foundations tend to do in the Arizona heat.  When I put it on in the morning, there is still plenty to wash off at bedtime.Although I usually use a moisutrizer under my foundation, I first tried this on freshly washed skin just to see how it works.  It felt a little "draggy" to me, and didn't go on as smoothly as I would have liked.  After than, I tried it several times with my normal moisturizer, and it went on just fine, and had more even coverage.This particular color (Natural BEige) is about one shade too dark for my skin tone, and a bit too orangey for me, but of course, that all depends on the tone of your skin and whether you know what color works best for you in  this line.While I will use this product when my skin is a little tanner than normal, I won't get it again despite now knowing what color to get.  It's just not right for me.

The two adults in this house have both tried this product, and neither of us especially like it.  We both used it on moderately dirty hair, the day after shampooing for one of us, two days for the other.  Neither of us noticed a cleansing effect.  I thought it actually made my medium-length hair look dirtier.  It didn't seem to do much of anything for my husband's short hair.It did provide a little volume and lift to my hair, but there are products specifically for that that can do a better job.The scent is masculine and could be pleasant, but much too strong, and it lingers for quite awhile.  While a little scent would have been nice, this was overwhelming and in-your-face.This doesn't, in our cases anyway, "refresh" hair.  My husband said, "You give this a star rating, don't you?"  When I said yes, he said, "Tell them, 'Oh my stars, just go wash your hair!'"I like some Axe products, and some fall short of the mark.  This one falls short.

I don't like to know too much about a book before I read it, but knowing that this was about some secret, strange library or book sounded like it would be right up my alley.My first clue that this might not be quite what I expected came with the table of contents, and the chapter names.  Some funny, some irreverent, some just odd.  For example, Chapter 2 is called "Buddhism for [Donkey Butts - different word to prevent robo-censorship].  I wasn't offended but some might be.It started out creepy and just got creepier.Although this is not, thank goodness, another zombie book, there are dead ones who are still functioning, at some level anyway.  There are gods, gods in disguise, and battles for supremacy.  All of that could have been quite interesting.I couldn't empathize much with the characters except for perhaps badluck Steve, and Erwin, and I liked them quite a bit.  The characters under control of Father...not so much although I did like Michael.And, of course, the lions; I liked the lions.The students had lessons to learn, each with a specialty, and dire consequences if they tried to find out about someone else's specialty.What I didn't like about this book was the high level of violence and cruelty.  Towards people, towards children who were still children despite their age in years, towards animals.  And torture, too.  Nope, not my cup of tea.  I like creepy; I don't like explicit violence and unrelenting cruelty.Despite that, and trying to overlook that, the story was somewhat interesting but too drawn out for the story it was telling.  And if the reader is too young or susceptible to nightmares, it's gonna cause them.I was given an advance reader's ebook copy of this book for review.

Note:  This review is for the shampoo/conditioner dual package.I've used shampoos before that don't strip my hair of all oils but also don't leave it feeling as clean as I would like.  While the not stripping part is important, so is the having clean hair part.  So, I was somewhat skeptical when this shampoo didn't leave my hair "squeaky clean" fresh out of the shower.Those concerns disappeared after my hair was dried. My hair, fine-textured anyway, is quite soft and shinier than it has been using other shampoos.  Very shiny.  I love that.I use both the shampoo and the conditioner.  It doesn't take much of either to get the job done, so these bottles last a long time.  The products both smell wonderful - kind of minty plus other scents, very pleasing but not overpowering.  There is good lather, even with my very hard tap water, and the products rinse out well.  I assume some of the helpful oils are left behind, which helps make my hair so shiny and soft, but it did not feel at all oily or greasy.  It's still clean and shiny on the second day, and I could go a third day but I don't like washing my hair that infrequently.This is the nicest shampoo and conditioner I've used for quite some time, and it's the one I'm going to stick with.  I'd not heard of this brand before, but now I'm a fan.I was given these products for review.

I often drink fruit smoothies for breakfast, and this hemp powder is a great way to add some extra protein and fiber.  I don't use whey protein powders, and I get enough soy in my diet without adding that protein powder either, so this hemp powder is a nice alternative.It actually tastes good.  I've even tasted it straight out of the bag, and although that is not the way anyone would choose to routinely eat it, the taste is pleasant.  It does add a nutty taste to my smoothies, almost almond-y.The powder is very fine, and it blends well.  I prefer to use only a half serving in my relatively small smoothie, but I think a full serving would work for those who use a full 8 oz. liquid, plus whatever else they choose to add.The only drawback for me is that there is a slight powdery feel to the powder when it is in smoothies, not quite gritty, but still a texture against the tongue.  Including it in baked goods would work very well, I'd think, but I don't bake much in the summer.I like Viva Labs, and like that this product is organic and non-GMO.I was given this product for review.

I really like this mousse.  It is easy to use, it smells nice, and it gives my hair more volume and I can add curls that actually stay, something of a feat with my fine-textured, mostly straight hair.Having said that, for everyday use, I prefer Suave's similar product, Suave Professionals Mousse, Luxe Styling Infusion Soft Touch Curls 9 oz, which has a hold factor of 2 instead of 3 that this one has.I like this one for when I am doing more styling of my hair and want a less casual look, because it does hold better.  But that comes at the cost of a slightly sticky feel.The similar product gives good style while still leaving my hair feeling very soft.They are both very good products, from a company that provides good value, and I would recommend either.  Which you choose depends on the degree of hold you are looking for.

We are into the downsizing part of our lives now, but still sometimes need to staple a LOT of sheets together. Previously, we've used a Acco 131 heavy duty stapler for big jobs, but it's a foot long, 2 inches wide, and 7 inches high, so my wife hates the space it takes in our office.This stapler, by contrast, is almost exactly the same size as our much-loved Boston Model 55 staplers, and works as easily, just with a 5/16" deep staple rather than the usual 1/4" ones.If necessary, this stapler could entirely replace all of our other staplers. It works fine for stapling up to 50 sheets, and also works for stapling together only 2 sheets, although in that instance the ends of the staple overlap, so we'll likely continue using our Boston Model 55s for stapling only a couple of sheets together.The Rapid S50 "SuperFlatClinch" staples supplied for review are very well made, and work easily and reliably. They are required for the 5 year warranty on the stapler, so do plan on ordering some with the stapler.Definitely recommended for any use where high capacity is needed and storage space is limited.

Having once broken a Kindle by dropping it, I was eager to try out this protective case for my Kindle Voyage. On arrival, the initial challenge was figuring out how to install my Voyage in it. Unhelpfully, the instructions are packaged INSIDE the sealed case, meaning you have to first figure out how to open the case without ruining it BEFORE you can read the instructions on how to open and close the case. Here's the key bit: there's a wide spot in the upper right corner of the case, By twisting a dime there, you can start opening the case, and then work your fingernails around the rest of the edge. The second problem is that the instructions say to clean the case and Kindle with the included microfiber cloth before putting the Voyage into the case, but no microfiber cloth was included. Oh well, didn't seem to be a problem getting the Voyage into the case without doing that, and everything still works, so perhaps that doesn't matter.The next thing I noticed is that the front screen cover still works as a touch screen, but is too flexible to have prevented that other way I killed a Kindle once - by unknowingly leaning an elbow on its screen under a piece of paper. I'm not sure that problem can be solved and still have a touchscreen, so let's all just be careful with our elbows near Kindles.Finally, the case doubles the weight of the Voyage. It's nice that I can now read in a hot tub, should I ever wish to do so, but I'm undecided thus far on whether I'm really willing to hold twice the weight every time I read, just to avoid replacing a broken Kindle. It occurs to me that a 3 year warranty against such disasters costs the same as this case, but adds nothing to the weight of the Voyage, and covers breakage by errant elbows.For now, I'm leaving the case installed. If I decide to remove it later, I'll update this review.

My wife recently requested a clock for our yard, so on arrival I mounted this in the shade of our patio fence, and we are both very pleased at the result. This very affordable clock is extremely legible, includes a red sweep second hand for added precision and for timing events shorter than a minute. We can easily read it from any room facing the patio, and from anywhere in our back yard. Is the clock waterproof? Who knows? The box says there's a manual inside, but I couldn't find one. It rains here only very rarely, and never snows, so we're giving it a try. Apart from the specs, I can't see why a manual would be needed. There's the usual thumb wheel to adjust the current time on the back of the motor mechanism, and a place to insert a AA battery. That done, it just works.Update: Dropping to 4 stars because the clock occasionally loses track of time, perhaps once a week. Fixing it is a simple matter of using my thumb to spin the hands back to the current time, but it's now happened several times, and would be a problem if the clock is either inaccessible, or must be relied upon for accuracy.The clear plastic dial cover will provide a lot of protection, but I still expect to have to occasionally vacuum out dust, spiderwebs etc., which won't be a probem. Everything seems sturdy and accessible.As for accuracy, the label on the back goes out of its way not to promise any (no jewels, and no adjustability beyond current time), but it's a quartz movement, so should be fine for our needs.The warranty is only for 6 months, and requires a $6 fee and proof of purchase, so if you have any problems, I'd suggest returning it to Amazon within the 30 days allowed instead.In short, a well designed very affordable clock that is working very well for us.

This is my third set of FRS/GMRS 2-way radios in 2 years, not because the others have failed, but rather because they have been so useful at an orphanage where we volunteer that we donated both other sets for use by staff. As radios, all were "35 mile" versions, which means they really work up to a mile away in an urban area, and all three had about the same range. The differences I've noticed are mostly in how they feel in the hand, how well they hook to a belt, and how many buttons have to be pushed to get anything done - with having to pull out the manual yet again an all too common problem with my two earlier radios. Of the three models, these new radios are my favorite.This pair of radios feels good in the hand, has a much improved belt clip that: 1) works, 2) does not get in the way when using the radio hand-held, and can be removed easily if unwanted. That means I actually use the belt clip, unlike on either of the two previous radios. Battery life is improved: 12 hours, rather than 8 on the similar Motorolas I bought 2 years ago, and water resistance is now up to IP-54 from IP-51 (but still don't dunk it in a bucket.) The built-in LED flashlight has its own button and works well.Another improvement is that I can activate everything I care about without having to dive into menues. That was the kiss of death with the radios I bought last year. They had a handy "dualwatch" feature to monitor 2 channels of interest, but made it almost impossible to activate, and turned the feature off every time I turned the radio off and on again. My favorite improvement on this radio is that getting into and out of NOAA weather mode takes only one keypress of the Mode button.The other big improvement is debatable: USB micro plug charging. Both my earlier pairs of radios came with a charging base that worked fine. Even so, I prefer the USB micro plug charging, as it eliminates my having to carry an extra charger for them. I already have a Photive 50 watt 6 port USB charger with lots of short charging cables ending in USB micro plugs. That lets me charge both of these, 2 cell phones, an iPad, and whatever else we have along, all from a single device. I can also leave the two tiny chargers that came with these radios in other locations where they might be needed, and also use them to recharge almost all my other small electronics (by adding a Cozy brand USB Micro to Lightning adapter as needed.)The one feature these still lack, that the professional radios at the orphanage have, is the ability to quickly and easily switch between a primary and a secondary channel. The orphanage uses one channel for calling and brief messages, and then switches to the secondary channel for extended conversations. None of the radios I've owned can do that well, but this pair comes closest. To change channels from 16 to 18, just press the menu key, then press the up key twice, then hit the menu key 9 times. It's still a lot of key presses, but takes only a few seconds and no need to find the manual.
