The 3 piece stakes fit together neatly. A battery compartment for an AAA battery is easy to use.  It fits into the stake and has a switch for battery or solar use.On the top is a swivel device with a wire shaped kind-of-like a horseshoe that suspends a lifelike butterfly that flutters like a butterfly and revolves in a circular route around the top of the device.My colorful butterflies are red and yellow and are mounted in flower pots mounted at the top of rails all around my deck.It is amazing how such simple inexpensive little colorful devices like this are so enjoyable to watch.  I smile every time I look at them dancing around the flowers.I love these butterflies and think you will too.Enjoy!

I have been using this shampoo for several decades and was thrilled to find it in this size and bargain price on amazon.com.I have not experienced dandruff since I first started using this T/Gel.My wife says that it has a slight tarry fragrance for a short time after use, but I cannot smell it.My only problem in the past is how hard it has been to find a large container in local stores; however, that problem has been solved.I recommend this product without reservation because it is the only dandruff shampoo that I found that works.If you have a dandruff problem, my best guess is that this product will work for you too.Enjoy!

After reading a trusted friends review on this product early last month, I immediately purchased two of these 10-feet K-bles for my wifes new iPhone 6 and am so happy that I did.The short cable that comes with her iPhone is fine when she is sitting in her easy chair with a charger on the end table; however, the outlet is too far away when she is in bed or at work.  This thick and quality cable solves that problem perfectly.Although we have not experienced any problems with this product, it does have a warning label on the box that: Apple is not responsible for the operation of this device or its compliance with safety and regulatory standards.  Please note that the use of this accessory with iPod, iPhone, or iPad may affect wireless performance.We have been using this daily for more than a month now and are extremely happy with the quality and length of this product.Enjoy!

In July of 2013 while reading Alex Kavas the Maggie ODell series action-packed thriller Stranded, the author  introduced us to an intriguing new character, Ryder Rye Creed that I hoped would his own series.I was thrilled to learn that the flawed, former marine character, who then owned a Florida based company with his partner, Hannah Washington called Crime Scent K9 is now the star of his own Alex Kava series.Ryder rescues and trains abandoned dogs like Jack Russell white terrier, Grace to track cadavers or missing people in various settings.Silent Creed is the second book in this series, but is enjoyable as a standalone; nevertheless, as soon as I discovered the Ryder Creed series, I ordered the first, Breaking Creed.The author smoothly merges two storylines involving Colonel Abraham Hess, a brilliant biologist and 55 year Army Medical doctor and our governments clandestine experimentation and use of biological and chemical weapons on friendly forces and other innocent civilians in preparation for the likelihood of an enemy attack on America using biological and chemical weapons.On the Washington, D.C. front, the four-term senior Senator Quincy from Illinois is using his junior colleague from Florida, Senator Ellie Delanor as a token woman member on a congressional committee played for voters while secretly sabotaging witnesses seeking government compensation for the disabilities they suffer as a result of clandestine government experiments.Meanwhile, in Haywood County, North Carolina a devastating mud slide has swallowed up a classified Department of Defense research facility leaving unknown hazards and a wasteland of destruction, dead and missing people in its path.Ryder was hired by his former marine nemesis, Lieutenant Colonel Logan, to search the site for 45 missing survivors or cadavers.Maggie, an FBI agent is reunited with Ryder when her boss/boyfriend Benjamin Platt assigns her to the site as a trusted agent to represent government interests.Creed and ODell work together and fight their romantic attraction to each other while they uncover clues that put them in the path of natural and contrived perils.As with her other thrilling action-packed mysteries, Silent Creed is a well-written and entertaining tale that is believable, intriguing and engrossing.The vividly descriptive settings are first-rate while the character development is fantastic.  Even Ryders intelligent dogs have interesting personalities.I can hardly wait the read Breaking Creed and the next in this riveting series!Enjoy!

The Shark Rocket is a powerful hand held vacuum with a 15 inch power cord that weighs just 3.7 pounds with dimensions of 9.6 x 4.9 x 13.6 inches.The hose and unique cleaning tools make it ideal for cleaning upholstery, stairs, quick spot cleanups and the floor mats and interior of your car.The crevice tool, two way access bar brush and dusting tool are great accessories around the house, office and car.I owned and operated a commercial cleaning company for years and sure wish this handy crme of the crop portable hand vacuum was available when I needed it in the past.I highly recommend this vacuum for vacuuming walls, curtains, furniture and the other jobs than I mentioned.This quality product is well-worth the price!Enjoy!

Folks, Zoe Diva Select creamy buttery Arbequina and almond apple Cornicabra Extra Virgin Olive Oil are the best that I have ever tasted.Thoroughly mix a solution of two tablespoons of Cornicabra to one tablespoon of Balsamic Glaze in a bowl.  Wash and quarter a couple handfuls of large ripe cherry tomatoes coating them with the solution in the a bowl, cover and refrigerate until they are cold.Turn the gas grill on high, high, high settings.Coat your thick filet mignons on both sides with a thin coat of Arbequina and season.While searing them for 5 minutes on each side punch fork holes in your large washed bake potatoes, put a thin coat of Arbequina on them, seal them in plastic wrap and throw a couple of them in the microwave for 8 minutes.Cut about an inch off the bottoms of fresh asparagus, salt and pepper them and wrap them in tin foil with a teaspoon of butter and drizzle with Cornicabra and place them on the grill.Turn the grill to medium, low, medium and grill the steaks to the desired temperature for 2 to 4 minutes per side.Plate your tasty steak, potatoes, asparagus and tomatoes and enjoy a delicious meal enhanced by this gold award winning extra virgin olive oil.Enjoy!

Run You Down was my first exposure to author Julia Dahl.  This 279-page novel is written from the perspective of a mother, Aviva Kagan, housekeeper and her daughter, Rebekah Roberts, a New York Tribune reporter, who do not know each other.  This tale leans heavily on Jewish terms, culture and rebellion.I found the need to take notes on the key elements to understand the interrelationships between characters, follow the storyline early on and slowly unravel this unusual, yet well-written mystery.Sam Kagan, Avivas youngest brother was sexually and mentally abused; however, silence for the sake of religion and family honor trumped justice.  His best friend since childhood, Pessie Goldin loved him as he did her; however, he discovered a man, Ryan Hall that he loved is a different way.Ryan, like Sam hated the family circumstance that he was born in.  Ryans father and brother are intolerant hatersdangerous anti-Semitic racistswho would never tolerate his sexual orientation.Pessie, married Saul Katz, a retired NYPD officer turned private inspector.The crux of this mystery centers on unraveling the circumstances of Pessies deatha suicide or murder and why--and developing relationship cultural and family relationships.I struggled at the onset, but quickly became intrigued and immersed in this unusual yet believable tale and learned a lot about the Jewish culture in the process.I recommend this author and story to those that are patient, open minded and willing to piece together a carefully unfolding mystery.Enjoy!

Taylor Stevens is one of my favorite authors.  I am not only amazed at the obstacles that she overcame during her childhood, but am more in awe of her ability to unfold riveting tales with intriguing characters that hold my interest from beginning to end.The Mask is one such tale.  Protagonist Vanessa Michael Munroe is a flawed woman who easily transforms to a convincing male persona. Though she and Miles Bradford have a special bond and romantic relationship, they are able to separate their missions from their personal lives.In this case Miles, owner of Capstone Security Consulting accepts a security assignment in Japan where he is hired by an Executive of a major Bio-medical/technology companyALTEQ-Bio to uncover a spy responsible for stealing trade secrets.Withholding information from Monroe, Miles comes under attack from ALTEQ Security, the spy and the mob and is convincingly framed for a murder of an innocent employee.Enter Monroe, a master assassin and Miles subcontractor, replacing him while he is under wraps.A variety of bad guys underestimate Monroes brilliance, skills and willingness to die fighting for her cause.This action packed mystery kept me on the edge of my seat rapidly flipping pages from beginning to end and completely satisfied with a well-written novel.I wholeheartedly recommend this book to those who enjoy a riveting, action packed well-written mystery with intriguing characters.Enjoy!

Wild Berry + Tropical Skittles taste great and come in a neat 9-ounce resealable bag.With 160 calories and six 1/4th cup servings containing 29-grams of sugar per serving, I definitely am not helping my diabetes by eating these tasty treats.Five stars for being so delicious minus two stars for having too much sugar plus another star because I ate them anyway.Eat these tasty morsels in small quantities or as much as you want at your own risk.Enjoy!

Recently, I was invited to try this product in exchange for my fair and impartial review.  I am glad that I agreed.At my age, jump roping or just jumping for that matter is a challenge. Nevertheless, I gave it my best and was more than impressed with this unique product.This is not the run of the mill one size fits all jump rope. It is an adjustable state of the art high-grade high quality light and durable state of the art ultra-speed cable jump rope that is the cream of the crop.It has rope handles that turn at a 90 degree angle prevents tangling and promote light weight ultra-fast spinning that promote an extraordinary workout.It rolls up for compact storage in its convenient portable nylon bag.I am thrilled with this with this state of the art, portable fat blasting exercise product and I think you will be too!Enjoy!

Recently Ohuhu sent me an invitation to receive a handful of products in exchange for an honest review. This 9 inch Survival Paracord Bracelet with Flint Fire Starter Scraper, Whistle Survival Gear was one of those products.As a first time users of this type of product, I was pretty disappointed to find the instructions and probably utility applications are all written in Chinese characters.Nevertheless, I used some survival skills of my own to search the internet for a like product with English instructions and found a product thatappears to be identical.If you are a novice, you may be asking yourself--what is Paracord? It is a military quality cord originally used as suspension lines of U. S. parachutes with a minimum breaking strength of 550 pounds with a cord diameter of about 1/8th inch.In the case of this product, when the 9 inch bracelet is unwoven it measures 9 feet of 7 woven strands contained in a nylon sheath.  Each of the 7 stands are woven from 3 finer stands that have a variety of uses including fishing line while the sheath itself could be used as a combustible fire starting source.This survival bracelet houses a steel blade in the female portion of the clasp capable of cutting the Paracord; however, its primary use is a striker to be scraped across the magnesium post housed in the male portion of the clasp.Note that the magnesium post comes painted with a black substance that needs to be scraped off first to prepare it for sparking when scraped against the steel striker.The base of the male portion of the connecting strap also houses a whistle capable of making a loud noise.If you are interested, instructions on reassembling the unwoven bracelet are available on "Utube;" however, it seems unlikely that a user would desire to reassemble this product given the relatively inexpensive replacement cost.To be fair and balanced, despite the lack of English instructions, I have found that this product is significantly less expensive that those packaged elsewhere with English instructions.I am happy with this useful product and wholeheartedly recommend it as a survival tool for outdoorsmen with the caveat of one doing their homework to obtain English instructions to learn its full utility prior to use.Enjoy!

Recently Ohuhu sent me an invitation to receive a handful of products in exchange for an honest review.  This Universal Mop Frame is one of them.This durable product is made from ABS (Acrylonitrile butadiene styrene), a strong and rigid material with the toughness of rubber. It is commonly used in household products and is the same material that computer keyboards and Legos are made from.It measures 16.2 x 2.8 x 3.4 inches and weighs 1.2 pounds. It comes with a package of 6 plastic screw mounts and 6 screws.This industrial gray product has well-made slots to hold up to 5 mops, brooms or items with similar sized poles. It also has 6 convenient retractable hooks.I mounted mine just inside the garage wall outside of the entrance to my laundry room.  It took me about 5 minutes to mount it using a power drill/screw driver, rubber hammer and a Phillips-head bit; however, a large nail, a regular hammer and a Phillips-head screw driver might take a little longer to install but would work just as well to mark and make 6 holes into the wall suitable to insert the plastic screw mounts and attach the universal mop frame to the wall with the 6 screws that come with the product.I hang 3 microfiber mop handles, a broom and a toilet plunger from mine and use the hooks to hang washable replacement microfiber mops.What I like most about this durable product is that it provides a safe and handy easy to find location to store household tools that I prefer to keep in the garage.My wife and I are happy with this product and recommend it whole heartedly for its unquestionable utility.Enjoy!

Recently, I received two unsolicited gifts from the San Francisco Salt company in appreciation for reviewing one of their products in the past.One of the two gifts is an attractive, 6 ounce Bamboo Jar with a swivel lid and a hidden magnetic locking device.  The other is a 5 ounce pouch of French Grey Salt.They came with a brief historical synopsis and usage suggestions for each product.The salt is hand-harvested using skills and methods perfected by salt workers over the past millennia.I can understand why this flavorful seasoning is favored by many top chefs around the world. My wife and I use salt sparingly to enhance the natural flavors in a variety of dishes--for example, meats, soups, sauces and more.We store this salt in the 6 ounce Bamboo Jar in our kitchen where it is convenient to add a pinch to boiling water while cooking pasta, eggs or seasoning dishes.We enjoy the mild flavor of this French Grey Salt, will continue using it for seasoning and will pair it with the 6 ounce Bamboo Jar as unique gifts for friends and family.My wife and I are thrilled with these surprise New Year gifts and I bet you will be too!Enjoy!

Recently, I received two unsolicited gifts from the San Francisco Salt company in appreciation for reviewing one of their products in the past.One of the two gifts is an attractive, 6 ounce Bamboo Jar with a swivel lid and a hidden magnetic locking device.  The other is a 5 ounce pouch of French Grey Salt.They came with a brief historical synopsis and usage suggestions for each product.Bamboo is a durable "Green" product that flourishes on little water without fertilizers or pesticides and has been known to grow up to 8 feet in a single day and is said to be stronger than oak.This sleek modern container blends perfectly with my kitchen dcor and is convenient for adding a pinch of salt while cooking and preparing dishes; however, the manufacturer also recommends it as a jewelry container and suggests many bathroom uses--for example, a receptacle to hold bath salts, body scrubs, shower salts, muds, creams and soap.My wife and I are thrilled with these surprise New Year gifts and will likely buy more as unique presents for friends and family.We love this inexpensive, clean and useful refillable jar and bet you will too.Enjoy!

A Fine Summer Day is the 16th and latest Inspector Ian Rutledge mystery series written by an extremely talented mother and son team writing under the pen name of Charles Todd.I have read many books in this series; however, this book presents a younger version of Inspector Rutledge set in June through December 1914 England prior to the protagonist's war time military service.If you are new to this series or a longtime fan, this is a must read. In this episode, the young Scotland Yard Inspector is assigned to several difficult cases that keeps him on the road where he is able to spend little time with his fianc and faces added pressure and little support from a demanding and unreasonable supervisor in a time of diminishing manpower as Scotland Yard loses personnel who are eager volunteering for wartime service.Ian has developed extraordinary skills connecting the dots where others have failed. He suspects a connection between vandalized graves and unsolved murders that he believes are the work of a clever adversary using the same very personal modus operandi to somehow convince unlikely suicide victims to drink deadly poison in the dead of night.  These seemingly unrelated victims from various towns are mounting.While Ian is an astute investigator, the antagonist has comparable skills.The mystery revolves around discovering the link before the killer strikes again.  Suspense builds as victims fall while the odds of identifying and bringing the perpetrator to justice are slim.The Charles Todd writing team are a joy to read.  They really know how to build suspense, develop strong and believable characters and keep the reader immersed and engaged through their descriptive well-thought out writing style.Like the many other tales in this series, I was thoroughly entertained by this spellbinding tale.  I bet you will be too.Enjoy!

I have mixed feelings about Michael Sears Jason Stafford mystery suspense novel Long Way Down. It is a fast-paced action-packed thriller chuck full of twists and turns that held my interest and kept me guessing.Protagonist, Jason Stafford is an intelligent, flawed and likeable character patiently raising his autistic son, Jay.  Heather is a PhD Candidate, Heather who specializes in autism spectrum children and has a calming effect on Jay.A talented financial investor, Jason served two years in a federal prison for insider trading. Jail time enhanced his skill set with instincts and savvy street smarts that when coupled with escape and survival skills learned from his new found associate, Ben McKennas, have narrowly saved him from certain death at the hands of an army of mercenaries and assassins time after time while Stafford uses all of his skills to protect his son and his fiance, Wanda Skeli Tyler out of harms way.Jason is hired to help biofuel engineer Philip Haley, multimillionaire CEO of Arinna Labs secretly developing a clean alternative energy source by finding out who is trying to derail him by framing him for a federal crime.The closer Stafford comes to proving Haleys innocence, the greater the threat to Jasons life.The reason I have mixed feeling about this story is that toward the end, the tale begins to feel a bit forced and unrealistic, but for me, straw that broke the camels back was the unwelcomed insertion of what felt like the authors personal political agenda.  It distracted, annoyed and ruined the integrity of the story for me.To be fair and balanced, I am sure that my pet peeve is not shared by many readers who might add a star greater than my measure of satisfaction with Long Way Down.

The T.S. Shure Pictorial Map of the World is a colorful 24" tall x 35" wide laminated poster with a grommet in each corner, making it easy to mount on a wall with thumb tacks.While I am not likely to use the 56 illustrated stickers that come with this map, with the help of her mother, I am sure that my two year old great niece would love to place a sticker over Juneau, Alaska to mark where they live. Although the United States is not detailed enough to include Arizona, a sticker pinpointing Phoenix where her cousins live might also be fun.From an adults point of view, I am not impressed with this poster as a world map; however, from a childs perspective, it may be helpful for parents and elementary teachers to pique their interest in rudimentary world geography.The hand drawn and lettered illustrated landmarks and topography could spark playful interaction with children with a side effect of educational entertainment.When my son was a toddler, my wife and I used two interactive educational placemats to spark his interest.  One was a United States map that identified each state and its capitol city the other identified the planets in our solar system.This fun filled interactive educational entertainment was an effective source of joy during that magical time in my familys life.  Likewise I am sure that this pictorial map of the world will be useful for parents and teachers to produce an environment that is fun for children while they learn.T. S. Shure also makes a Pictorial Map of the United States.  Both of these maps would be ideal gifts for my great nieces and I bet that you can think of little ones who would be entertained by these too.Enjoy!

One Man Standing is the 6th and latest book in the Ben Blue series written by Lou Bradshaw.  I have really enjoyed this series and impatiently wait forward to the authors next episode in this creative old western saga.I would recommend that readers start with the first four books in this series prior to reading this one.  There are numerous characters developed in those books that will make this book much easier to follow.In this tale, J L Tate is further developed from previous books in this series and plays a major role in this one.  In fact, he narrates chapter 19 which start at 88% in the Kindle version where he unintentionally mirrors similarities of Bens deceased adopted brother, Andy.In this episode, a clandestine serial killer stalks and kills three victims in Patchwork, New Mexico.  One of those victims is Joe Tucker, a key character from an earlier episode.Ben Blue puts on his U. S. Marshall stare and joins local Sheriff Nelson and Texas Ranger Spade Carson who is working undercover using the name Dale Carter.  They are working together trying to find the mysterious killer who we later learn has killed 10 other victims somehow connected to a confederate prison camp during the civil war.In this episode, Ben turns to his Mexican allies with the help of Juan Domingo and Enrique, characters from earlier episodes who tell him to seek out Tomas Menendez, a village elder who has his finger on the pulse on the goings on in that community.Suspense builds and bullets fly leaving a wake of bodies as Ben and company unravel motive and connections that put him, Tate and Spade in peril against great odds against vicious killers.This was another flowing, well developed, fast-paced, action-packed, quick, easy and intriguing read that kept me on the edge of my seat from beginning to end through wee hours in the morning.This has been both an entertaining and spellbinding series that has held my interest and left me anticipating the next episode in this series.For those who like this genre, I wholeheartedly recommend this series.Enjoy!

Write and Publish a Short Story: From Writing to Publishing a Short Story is a 35-page guide by Cole Bishop that provides useful tips, suggestions, sources and instruction describing how to write short stories, get help and learn how to get them published.  He talks about structure, elements, techniques, platforms, character development, practice and other helpful information that will increase the likelihood that writing short stories will be read and published.Bishop provides numerous websites, sources and recommendation that I was unaware of to help develop writing and editing skills to help the writer make their short stories the best that they can be, put them before the public, publish, market and sell your creations.I enjoyed this book and will not only read it several times, but will also become familiar with the sources and sites provided and follow Cole Bishops recommendations.Enjoy!

PROSLighter than standard, non-CNX KeensGood constructionNice lookGood finishCONS:Less support than standard KeensMinimal padding in the footbedFlimsier soleFit is slightly narrower than standard KeensThese are good shoes.  Good but not great, like my other pairs of Keens.On the bright side, the CNX line lightens up the entire weight of the shoe.  Whereas the shipping weight for my last Keens--a pair of lace up Dillons--was about 15 ounces, these weight in around 9.9 ounces, nearly 1/2 a pound lighter and you can feel the relief easily when lifting your feet.  The overall construction and production values are about equal to the standard fare Keens these days.  That is to say, Keens are not nearly as well made as they were five or six years ago and don't nearly last as long, but they are still reasonably good shoes.In terms of the fit though, the CNX line has less room in the toe box than standard Keens.  This doesn't translate into needing a larger shoe size, though, as if I sized up these would be too big.  The styling of the front of the shoe is more narrow and less flared, giving less side to side wiggle room.  The amount of leather above your toes is also a little more scant, as the dome of the toe box isn't as rounded.  This in and of itself is not necessarily a deal breaker, just not what I was expecting in a Keen.The major issue for me is the sole of the shoe.  The sole is contoured rubber with a tread pattern, and superficially looks like the old-type Keen, but is far thinner.  The thinner sole offers far less impact protection for those of us who are on our feet every day.There is padding inside, but the foam insert--though reasonably comfortable--is not as thick and protective as one might expect after buying Keens for many years.  What with the thin sole and thin padding, you can feel the contours of the ground beneath your feet.So if you are the type that use Keens at the workplace because you are running around all day, these wont afford the same kind of impact protection you are used to.  They are not bad for casual use (and that is what I use these for now, rather than work), but if your feet are tortured every day because you are constantly standing or on the run, you will feel it in your feet, ankles, and knees at the end of the day.  (The warranty on your joints seems to expire at age 30--I never felt bad with any shoe at work until after that and finding Keens was a godsend.)But, all in all, it's not a bad looking or bad fitting shoe.  The thin sole does take away a lot of weight and it does add to the flexibility of the shoe.  This is not a bad thing, once again, for casual use but it is very different from what I expected when buying a Keen for work.I can't vouch for the longevity of this pair, but if my other recent Keens are any indication they will not last as long as my original Keens.  When I first bought Keens many moons ago in 2005 or therabout, they were robust shoes that would hold up for two or even three years of hard use.  In recent years this has not been the case.  The production values and the quality of the materials have gone down (especially, I think, since the inventor of the shoe, Martin Keen, left the company).  They shoes are still of reasonable quality but the soles seem to wear down after about a year of use and the uppers don't seem to maintain support as well.  The fact that the prices have gone down over time may have something to do with this.  I sense more foreign rather than domestic production and the use of inferior materials compared to when the company was founded as the reason for this.I'm still good with this company, though, as they have a product that fits me (Keens are great for those of us with wide feet) and their products still hold up pretty well and their form tends to follow function.  But given my wide feet and padding beneath my feet, I won't be buying any more of the CNX line.In conclusion, these are more of a lightweight fare than their thicker soled, more rugged, standard Keen cousins.  I would not buy from the CNX line again, but for lighter duty and the right person, these shoes may be a good fit.

PROS:Easy to useRemovable, dishwasher-safe grill platesCeramic, anti-stick finish really works wellLarger than standard sizeBack hinge adjusts to the thickness of foodClean up was easyCONS:Edges of grill not as hot as centerTemperature is not adjustableSmall power cordSimple instructionsThe George Forman Removable Plate Grill is a larger than standard size electric grill.  It works well for what it is and removable, dishwasher grill plates make it easy to clean.  It is the kind of kitchen device that only does one thing, but it does it pretty well.The grill comes packed with a drip tray and a set of instructions.  The appliance is not compact, with external measurements of approximately 16"x11"x 5" in its greatest dimensions and weighing in at about 9 pounds.  The device is stable on a counter.  The top part is hinged at the rear, with a base that is heavy enough to prevent it from tipping backwards.  One frustrating aspect of the machine is the power cord, which is a mere 2 feet long, meaning that you better locate the grill on a counter where there is an outlet close at hand.  The production values are not what you might expect from the highest line of appliances--this does not have the precision edges of the latest iPhone.  However, the construction seems quite solid.  It is mostly constructed out of heavy duty plastic, but you get the idea that this is the type of gadget that is made to take a bit of abuse and shrug it off.  I can't vouch for the longevity, having only used it for about 4 weeks, but so far it looks like a device that will hold up for the long haul.The machine simply plugs in--there is no power switch--and heats up to temperature within 8 minutes.  You can start grilling once the green power indicator light turns on.  Food is placed on the grill plates which are angled down towards the front of the machine.  The free-standing drip tray is placed in front of the grill to catch drippings as the food cooks.  I had imagined that the drip tray might make a mess if it was moved from the front of the machine.  However, in practice this did not happen.The minimalist instruction manual gives you some idea of how long to cook a 6 ounce salmon steak, 4 ounce burger, 6 ounce, chicken breast, or 7 ounce beef steak, so that they are rare, medium, or well done.  However, these are ballpark figures and didn't seem all that accurate.  With a little experience, though, you will learn how long to cook different food items on the grill.  As advertised on TV commercials, this is easy and the drippings do come off of the food, ostensibly reducing the fat content of the food.  Quite surprisingly, meats didn't dry out and seemed to stay juicy.  Turkey burgers are always a bit more challenging than beef, as they toughen up too much if you cook them too long.  Once I got the timing right, they came out flavorful.  Even veggie burgers and hot dogs cooked quickly and easily.Both top and bottom grill plates are heated and, quite nicely, the rear hinge adjusts to the thickness of the meat.  All this allows the grill to accommodate food items that are approximately 1 1/2" thickness and cook them rather quickly.  The weight of the top plate is enough to hold the food in place without unduly squashing it. This model does not have an adjustable temperature.  In practice, this didn't seem to make much difference for me. The ceramic coating worked as well as Teflon for me: nothing seemed to stick to it, even without the use of cooking spray.On the downside, the actual, total cooking surface is approximately 12" x 6 1/2".  For me, this was only large enough for two normal sized burgers (or three, slightly small 3" burgers.  This is okay, but means that this 'oversize' version of the Foreman grill is really not big enough to quickly cook dinner for more than two or three people at a time.This is further complicated by the fact that the actual heating element is located under a metal plate and is only 9" x 3 1/4".  Although the edges of the grill pleads are heated by conduction, they are not as uniformly hot as the center of the plates directly over the metal heating plate.  This means that the heating is a bit uneven--food on the edges of the grill is not kept as hot as the food in the center of the grill.  You can certainly rotate food on the grill while cooking, but it is simply easier to avoid cooking at the edges of the grill, which further limits the quantity of meat that you can cook at a time.Clean up was easy, given that the plates are detachable and that the ceramic coating virtually rinsed clean.  As an added bonus, they are dishwasher safe.  As with any of these kinds of kitchen devises, there are nooks and crevices that need to be cleaned with a damp cloth, as the base cannot be submerged.  Nevertheless, detachable grill trays are really the key to a quick and easy clean up.Oddly, the company adds little value here.  The box makes a big deal about the George Foreman Weight Loss Challenge, but this amounts to 4 PDF downloads: a getting started guide, meal plan guide, very basic exercise program, and work sheets to track your progress.  That's not to say that very basic things cannot work, but the hype on the box seemed to indicate more than was delivered.  Recipes are included with a meal plan--on most days only dinner requires the use of the George Foreman Grill. (You can find more recipes for your grill on websites unofficial web pages.)One thing that is important to remember is that unlike cooking on an actual grill, the George Foreman Grill will not add a specific grill-like flavor to your food.  When you grill your burgers over charcoal and mesquite, even unadulterated beef gets that barbecue flavor.  If you are cooking on an electric grill, you will have to make sure you spice things appropriately.On the whole, I was impressed that the grill was quick and easy to use.  If you are a family of two or three, this grill might just hit the spot.  High points were that it is easy to use and easy to clean up.  The most pertinent negatives were the small grill real estate and uneven heating at the edge of the plates.Generally, this George Foreman Grill delivers what it promises to do and does it well, but it is another one-trick-pony type of kitchen gadget.  If you like cooking this way and cook this way often, it is a good investment.  If you only grill meat occasionally or like that authentic outdoor barbecue taste, you may want to skip this one.  But for the right person, this is a reasonable investment.  Recommended.

At Home in Exile: Why Diaspora Is Good for the Jews, is Alan Wolfe's attempt to reconcile Jewish existence outside of Israel in the era of Zionism.  His purpose is similar to one of the principle aims of the Mondowess web site, "To offer alternatives to pro-Zionist ideology as a basis for American Jewish identity," but Wolfe goes much further.  Wolfe wishes to turn around what he calls the "more than a century old argument' that the Diaspora is 'the wrong place' for Jews to live. The book is clearly and carefully written, but will almost certainly ruffle feathers on both sides of the fence.  For some, Wolfe goes too far by deemphasizing the importance of the Jewish state and for others he will not have delegitimized Israel enough.  For me, the book was an engaging, interesting, and, at times, a painful read but was always thought provoking.The fact that the author is not at all used to writing about Jewish issues and instead of just testing the waters by getting his toes wet jumps straight into the water commando-style, makes this one worth the price of admission.  Although extremely well read, some of Wolfe's insights--especially in understanding the complexities of the religious, Jewish world--seem fresh but callow.  To be sure, the book has some very interesting and controversial ideas that are mixed in with more mundane and prosaic thoughts.  Moreover, Wolfe is a complex thinker and kicks around a lot of ideas in only 226 pages of prose.  This makes this a very difficult review to write.I can't possibly cover all the ground that Wolfe has covered, but will try to highlight some of his basic theory and what I found to be some of the more problematic aspects of the book.WOLFE'S THREE DIMENSIONAL MODELIn Wolfe's model of the Jewish world, Jews appear align themselves along three separate domains: particularism/universalism, religion, and Zionism .  The particularists are insular, only concerning themselves with internal Jewish affairs.  Particularists are only concerned with the outside world in so far as how the outside world affects the lot of the Jews.  Universalists, on the other hand, see the world as a more fluid place.  They are interested in internal Jewish affairs and but also how Jewish affairs affect the outside world.  Universalists are interested in how they can improve the greater good for the entire population, not just Jews.  The second domain is that of religiosity: Jews may either be classified as religious or non-religious.  Religious Jews see their Judaism as a reflection of their religious life, whereas the non-religious consider themselves Jews by circumstance, culture, or ethnicity.  The final domain is Zionism.  Zionists feel that Jews are cannot be complete Jews unless they live in the land of Israel.  Accordingly, Zionists may feel that it is improper, if not immoral, to criticize Israel in any capacity. The opposite of this point of view would be the non-Zionist point of view.  Non-Zionists believe that Jews can lead fulfilling lives within or without of Israel.  Non-Zionists also believe that Israel can and should be criticized along conventional, moral lines.  (Note that the opposite of Zionist, here, is not 'anti-Zionist.'  Jewish anti-Zionists may be a subgroup within the category of non-Zionists, but anti-Zionists represent only one flavor of Jewish, non-Zionism to Wolfe.  Being a non-Zionist does not require one to harbor antagonism towards the state of Israel, but at very least requires a certain ambivalence towards the Jewish State.)Hence, the original Zionists whose actions helped found Israel as a state (e.g. Hertzl, Jabotinsky, Weizmann, Ben-Gurion etc.) were particularist, secularist Zionists.  Whereas mainstream, Orthodox Jews in favor of the Israel might be described as particularist, religious Zionists.  Yet, Wolfe describes some significant players in the American Reform movement (Reform rabbis who agreed to the Pittsburgh Platform, Rabbi Stephen Wise, etc.) who can be described as universalist, religious non-Zionists.  He even points out a number of influential Israeli, universalist, secular non-Zionists.  Nevertheless, Wolfe fails to point out that there are some very insular, ultra-orthodox Jews called the Neturei Karta (Aramaic for 'Guardians of the City) who are opposed to a secular, Jewish state who one might describe as particularist, religious non-Zionists.  These may be contrasted to Wolfe and other like-thinking academicians, who are best described as universalist, non-religious non-Zionists.I suppose it is of no great surprise that Wolfe feels that the best of choice here is to be a universalist, non-religious non-Zionist. The main thrust of the book seems to indicate that this is the best way for Jews and the Jewish State to win friends and influence people.  He proceeds to make his argument along historical, emotional, and statistical lines purporting, among many things, that a secular, non-Zionist, universalism:  harbors good will; helps Jews integrate seamlessly and in comfort within the diaspora; makes complete sense in a world where, Wolfe states, there is no longer any significant anti-Semitism;  assures ethical checks and balances that will actually increase world-wide acceptance of the State of Israel; and that universalism--even at the extremes--may change what we think of as Jewish peoplehood but will not eliminate it.SOME JEWS DEFY CHARACTERIZATIONOf course there are some interesting paradoxes that Wolfe does not bring up.In spite of Wolfe's notion that there is an overwhelming dominance of Zionism within the world's Jewish population, less than one half of the world's Jewish population actually live in Israel.  And there is no indication that this will change in the foreseeable future.  There are probably many reasons for this, not the least of which is that most Jews tend to avoid the extremes within Wolfe's three dimensional classification.  They may tend towards particularism, but unless they live their lives within a single, separatist sect, also harbor inherent universalism.  They may donate large sums of money to their synagogue, for example, but they may also decide to donate money to the Jewish National Fund, the March of Dimes, or the Sierra Club as well.  They may be fervently religious, but may also immerse themselves within secular issues as well (the two are not necessarily mutually exclusive).  Jews may categorize themselves as Zionist, but that does not mean that they are blind or turn a blind eye to problems in Israel policy.  Being a Zionist, doesn't mean that you support further building of settlements or incursions into Gaza.THE DIASPORA AND JEWS--A MORE COMPLEX EQUATIONI will limit my discussion to topics where there is actual data that can be interpreted, although there are other assertions that Wolfe makes with more sociological arguments that could also be challenged.One thing that Wolfe makes clear--and this is absolutely true--is that Judaism may have preceded the Diaspora but Jews worldwide have been shaped by it.  For example, Abayou, Abdala, Barcelona, Hadad, and Tawil may not sound like Jewish names to an American ear, but they are perfectly acceptable Sephardic Jewish names, names that draw on the prevailing culture surrounding the Sephardic Jewish community.  Wolfe doesn't bother to go back this far, but the Talmudic academies of the diaspora in Sura and Pombedita (modern day Fallujah), founded somewhere around 200 BCE, were well known to have surpassed the scholarship of the Talmudic acadamies within the Land of Israel.  This is one of the reasons why the Babylonian Talmud is considered more authoritative than the Jerusalem Talmud.  Anti-Semitism of the diaspora whether in Europe, the Middle East, or elsewhere was detrimental but also galvanized the Jewish people into cohesion, whether the Jews in question were religious or not.  So the argument that the diaspora has indelibly influenced Judaism is not a spurious one.But the manner in which the diaspora kept Judaism alive, the delicate balance between acceptance and discrimination, is side-stepped by Wolfe.  Wolfe purports that mixing with other ethnicities and religions does not pose a serious problem to Judaism.  He argues--quite oppositely--that intermarriage ('universalism in miniature') will bring new members into the Jewish fold.  Of course, the data from A Portrait of Jewish Americans conducted by Pew Research quite coldly contradicts Wolfe's assertion.  According to the poll, 67% of Jews who do not identify themselves as having a religion, report that they will raise their children `Not Jewish.' That is, devoid of Jewish identity. Only about 30% of those characterized as `Jews of no religion' would raise their children with some semblance of Jewish identity. This contrasts vividly with those who feel as though they are Jews by religion who raise their children with some aspect of Jewish identity 93% of the time. Moreover, 37% of intermarried Jews would raise their children as `Not Jewish.' This compares to Jews marrying other Jews, of whom 96% would raise their children as Jewish by religion.To recap: in an open society such as the United States, the Jews most likely to perpetuate Judaism are religious Jews (of any franchise) who actually marry Jews.  This contradicts Wolfe's hypothesis that secularism and universalism will keep Judaism alive, albeit in another form.  If the Pew data is correct, the future of Judaism lies in the hands of the religious and particular rather than the secular and universal.  The most secular and universal statistically fail to perpetuate cultural or ethnic Judaism effectively.  I am saddened that the Jewish population is shrinking. But the idea that the secular and universal do not perpetuate Judaism well is not so disturbing to me, as the perpetuation of a kind of genetic Judaism smacks of racism and eugenics.  However, the idea that if you wish to practice Judaism effectively as a religion, you need a commitment and shared goals with a life partner (who was born Jewish or converted to Judaism), shows a commitment to faith and a way of life that is neither racist or eugenic in nature.Along the same lines of strange interpretations of statistics, Wolfe's report of the death of anti-Semitism is greatly exaggerated. Clearly, of course, he looked over the galleys of his book well before the July 2014 and Operation Protective Edge with the subsequent protests that have taken Europe by a storm.  But perhaps I exaggerate: Wolfe warns that the particularists always believe that anti-Zionist or anti-Israel sentiments are inherently anti-Semitic. Having issues with Israel, Wolfe argues, does not necessarily mean that someone is anti-Semitic: one can be virulently anti-Israel and not harbor ill will towards Jews. At least, in theory...The problem is that if you look at the actual situation on the ground, the `anti-Zionist' or `anti-Israel' protests in Europe have overwhelmingly been anti-Semitic in nature. It is difficult to call a demonstration `anti-Zionist or `anti-Israel' when the protestors are demonstrating in front of a synagogue or Jewish museum rather than an Israeli embassy. Among the very many unfortunate events in Europe this past summer: in Brussels, four people were murdered in the Jewish museum and a synagogue was firebombed; in France, `anti-Israel' protesters tried to force their way into a Paris synagogue and targeted demonstrations in front of synagogues and Jewish owned shop; a London theater refused to have a Jewish film festival and a major London supermarket removed kosher food from its shelves because they were afraid the presence of kosher items would incite a riot; in Germany, protestors had to be prevented from attacking a  synagogue in Berlin and Molotov cocktails were thrown at a synagogue in Wuppertal.  As Deiter Grauman, president of the Center Council of Jews in Germany, stated in an interview with CBS, that it was unthinkable to hear, "... people here chanting--a roaring mob chanting--Jews to be gassed, to be slaughtered, to be burned." The people are chanting anti-Jewish slogans, not just anti-Israel slogans.But the universalists might tell us that we are our own worst enemy: that it was Israel's actions stirred up latent anti-Semitism.  The problem is you can't have it both ways.  If anti-Israel does not equal anti-Jewish, Jews should not be globally blamed for the actions of the Jewish State.  The Jews of Europe did not sit in on Natanyahu's cabinet meetings and decide how the Israeli army would respond to a missile barrage or when to attack Gazan tunnels.A 2013 report of a survey conducted by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (carried out between September and October of 2012) showed that almost 1/3 of European Jews considered emigrating because of anti-Semitism. The percentage in France and Hungary was 46% and 48% respectively. All this before the recent purely `political,' `anti-Israel' demonstrations. This might be discounted as simply paranoia.  An ADL poll of the general population from 2012 showed a rising anti-Semitic sentiment throughout 10 European, as compared to a similar poll conducted in 2009.  Quite interestingly, the Europeans polled reported that violence directed against Jews was felt to be a result of anti-Jewish feelings rather than anti-Semitism in 6 out of the 10 countries.  And if that doesn't clear up the ambiguity, in a rally in front of a Switzerland synagogue a woman carried a sign reading, "Every synagogue is an Israeli embassy."These incidents are not just about Jew baiting by 'immigrant' populations within Europe.  Native Europeans are becoming more successful with their own brand of anti-EUism, anti-immigrantism, anti-Zionism, and anti-Semitism. In Greece we have LAOS and Golden Dawn; in Hungary Jobbik; in Bulgaria the Greater Romanian Party; in Slovakia the Slovak National Party; in Wolfe's open and beloved Britain we have UKIP and the BNP.  These parties are not composed of disruptive 'immigrant' populations.  These parties are composed of native Europeans who buy into this mix of Islamaphobia, homophobia, anti-immigrant sentiment, racism, and--of course--anti-Semitism.Sadly, anti-Semitism is not dead yet.  When British former Chief Rabbi, Sir Jonathan Sacks--an accessible and moderating voice within Orthodox Jewry who Wolfe quotes frequently--wrote in the Wall Street Journal that he entered this past Yom Kippur with, "... a degree of apprehension I have not known in a lifetime," because anti-Semitism has returned to Europe and, "Never again has become ever again,"  Rabbi Sacks was not exaggerating.  This is not some particularist conspiracy theory or an over-call by European Jews that just misses the point.  It is, however, an illustration that sitting in a plush, academic armchair in the cosmopolitan, American city of Boston and declaring anti-Semitism as no longer relevant is a critical misread of the situation or at very least premature.What is interesting is that anti-Semitism also seems to shape Jewish identity. Anti-Semites see us as strangers in strange land and don't particularly want us here. They also remind us that as Jews, our fates are seen as intertwined with Israel whether we like to believe it or not. `Free Gaza' slogans (often accompanied by swastikas) have been emblazoned on synagogues and Jewish monuments world over. Even if Jews are at home in the Diaspora, anti-Semitism--overt or latent--associates Jews with Israel.  The same force that rails against Jews and Zionism actually forces Jews towards particularism and Zionism.On the bright side, I am happy to agree with Wolfe that this not the Europe of the 1930s. Governments are lending police protection and taking steps to prosecute protestors who vandalize or become violent. Additionally, prominent government officials in all these countries have harshly criticized anti-Semitic protestors and in some cases (such as Angela Merkel of Germany) taken part in rallies against anti-Semitism. Still, it is crystal clear that the undercurrent of anti-Semitism still exists in Europe. It has not gone away.SOME CONCLUDING THOUGHTSAs with many hot-button topics, there are very few Jews who haven't already addressed this issue and made up their mind already.  To think about it another way, approximately 6 million Jews live in Israel, which is still less than half of the world's Jewish population. Particularist or univeralist, religious or non-religious,  Zionist or non-Zionist, Jews in the diaspora do not seem to have a problem living outside of Israel and it's not as though they haven't thought about it.In this respect, this book doesn't have much of a captive audience: Wolfe's arguments are inherently secular and non-Zionistic in nature.  It is difficult for me to see that the book will be considered very seriously by the bulk of religious and secular Zionists, who will discount Wolfe's arguments out of hand.  (This doesn't mean, however, that they will not use Wolfe's arguments as a foil.)  Additionally, the book will have little impact on Jewish anti-Zionists, who already firmly agree with Wolfe's premise and do not require nuanced arguments as they too have already reached their conclusions.  So the book may definitely cause a brief kerfuffle within Jewish circles, but is unlikely to start a serious debate.It will appeal, however, to a narrow stripe of academics who, in spite of already being set in their opinions prior to reading the book, still like discuss these kinds of things.  This is a pity, however, because the major purpose of a book such as this is not so much to strike up controversy as to strike up a real, intellectual conversation about a pivotal issue.  This is why I still hope that Wolfe's book will garner a larger audience.  What Wolfe discusses herein are largely articles of faith within the academic community and within the larger Jewish community.  Intently reading this book may not make much of a difference in terms of one's own conclusions about Zionism and the diaspora.  However, it will help the reader place the opinions of others into context.  This might not open the floor for a true debate, but I do have hope that it could open the door to true dialogue.

In the early 1900s exhibiting humans to be gawked at as thought they were animals was a common practice in side shows at fairs and amusement parks.  In her book, The Lost Tribe of Coney Island, Claire Prentice brings to life the story of the Igorrotes, a Filipino tribe imported to the United States for the purposes of such an exhibit, and describes their fate in a compelling and sensitive manner.A group of Igorrotes had been a popular attraction at the 1904 St. Louis Exposition in 1904.  The manager of the Igorrotes for this short exposition was a Dr. Truman Hunt, who had lived in the Philippines amongst the Igorrotes and knew them well.  Given the success of the exhibition, Hunt switched hats from medical doctor to impresario and decided to bring a group of Igorrotes back for an extended tour of the United States.  Hunt would pay the Igorrotes monthly more than they could make for a year of work in the Philippines and in return he would get the lion's share of the profits from the tour.For a short while, things seemed to go as planned, but rather quickly it all unhinged.  Truman would end up keeping the Igorrotes in America for well over the agreed upon year, exploiting them,  and would end up extorting their money.  To make matters worse, Truman was not only duplicitous, he also had major skeletons in his closet.Prentice takes us through the Igorrotes American journey which started with promise but eventually descended into madness.  Using a multitude of primary and secondary sources from the time, Prentice puts this amazing journey into the context of the times.  She documents Truman's descent from impresario to shameless promoter to charlatan to petty criminal.  Prentice not only confronts the inherent racism of the day but is also able to highlight the humanity of the Igorrotes.  The narrative makes the reader question the notion of civilization, as the 'primitive' Igorrotes come out in the end as far more measured, rational, and fair than their American hosts.  She highlights the heroes, who try to chase Truman down and bring him to justice, as well as the villains.Although there are plenty of lessons to be learned from this small slice of history, Prentice is never pedantic.  She paints a clear and honest picture of the Igorrotes without being insultingly sentimental and avoids being overly judgmental of Americans in the early 1900s. (There were those in the government who wanted justice for the Igorrotes, but they were few and far between and there was, at most, only a tepid response from the public, who would have been outraged at the treatment of the Igorrotes had racism not figured into the picture.)The book does sag a bit in the middle, as the Igorrotes wander about North America, but in general Prentice is otherwise engaging throughout the narrative.  The writing style is more journalistic than historical, but this treatment works well for a story such as this.All in all, the book was a fast, easy, and educational read for me.  Prentice brings the turn of the last century to life in all its glory and ignominy--a virtually unknown chapter in American history that we can still learn something from.  Recommended.

Scandal, sex, secret lives, coverups, drugs, murder, blackmail, outlandish parties, and stars behaving badly sure sound like the hallmarks of our modern-day superstars.  But long before the deaths of Natalie Wood, Tupac Shakur, Notorious B.I.G, and Marylin Monroe and long before the shenanigans of Mel Gibson, Lindsey Lohan, Britney Spears, Paris Hilton and their ilk, trouble was brewing in Tinseltown.As William J. Mann attests to, in his brilliant book, Tinseltown: Murder, Morphine, and Madness at the Dawn of Hollywood, the stars were wreaking havoc in Hollywood from its very beginnings.  Mann's book vividly recounts the unsolved murder of film director William Desmond Taylor in 1922, and follows the trails left by three significant women in his life.Mary Miles Minter, Mabel Normand, and Margaret 'Gibby' Gibson were all movie actresses and were all connected to Taylor at the time of his death.  They, and their host of colorful associates, were all considered suspects at the time.  Taylor and each of these woman all had their own checkered pasts and secrets that Mann brings to life in his thorough history that reads like a thriller.Along with the murder mystery, Mann serves up an excellent and detailed description of the nascent film industry.  Although it is difficult to imagine at this point, the jump from nickelodeons to movie theaters led to an explosive growth in the business of motion pictures.  Similar to the .com boom in the late 1990s, this business was speculative but offered the potential for astronomical profit for those who succeeded.  Those who succeeded, however, became incredibly wealthy.  And the very wealthy always have a need to protect their investments.  If that meant being unscrupulous and trying to sweep a scandal under the rug, so be it.Mann not only has a knack for narrative, he also vividly describes the various characters involved in the plot.  Moguls like Adolph Zucker (founder of Paramount Pictures), Marcus Loew, Louis B. Mayer, Samuel Goldfish, and Archibald Selwyn dominated the market by both making movies and building movie theaters in which to view the movies in.  These moguls and movie companies had a vested interest in keeping the movies squeaky clean, by keeping scandals under wraps.  Mann brings color to these black and white moguls and their stars and is able to pop them out of the celluloid and into three dimensions.Mann's research is also meticulous: Mann scoured through studio files, transcripts, newspaper reports, listened to recorded interviews, weather reports, movie footage, and clearly went on location to view the murder scene and other sites so that he could describe them in such detail.  In spite of the complexity of the case and the sheer number of characters involved, Mann's narrative is always clear and I was never confused as to where things were going.For some readers, the extensive descriptions of old Hollywood, the studio system, side stories (for example the Fatty Arbuckle murder trial), and details about early movie censorship  and blackmail scandals may be too much for some readers.  However, I  felt that all this material was relevant, engaging, and had a true impact on the murder case.  For my part, I read this all with rapt interest; however, it might be a bit much for someone who is not a film buff.Additionally, this was my first exposure to the story of the murder of William Desmond Taylor.  Those who are more familiar with the case (there is an incredibly detailed website devoted to this case) may quibble with Mann's handling of some of the details.  There were actually even more people involved in the investigation than the many who are noted in Mann's book and there are clearly differences in opinion regarding the sequence of minor events.That said, this book is a sheer pleasure to read.  These were some of the fastest and most engaging 428 pages of prose that I have ever read.  It is one of the few non-fiction books that I just couldn't put down.  Highly recommended.

PROSGood soundValue for the priceAugmented bass and crisp treble works for most pop musicComes with three sizes of eartips50 inch cord3.5 mm jackCONSCannot handle large dynamic rangeVery muddy or missing midrange soundsPoor for classical music, jazz, or more complex musicSo-so build qualityEartips are difficult to exchangeThis one nabs 4 stars because you are not going to get a better set of earbuds at this price ($6.99 at the time of this writing) anywhere but amazon.  The sound quality is mediocre is you compare these to the latest Beats cans (>$300) or even my middling Altec Lansing MZX652s (~$70), but you can't expect perfectly balanced sound for around seven bucks.  Obviously, you cannot expect audiophile performance at this price, but for earbuds in this range, the Amazon pair delivers.Inside the box, you will find the earbuds themselves and 3 sizes of noise isolating silicon eartips.  The earphones are simple, generic-looking things.  The housing is shiny black with simple white letters for 'R' and 'L.'  The silicon eartips and the rubbery, plastic cord are in a dull black finish.  The length of the cord from buds to plug are a generous 50 inches. On inspection the cord isn't the most durable.  It is thin and you get the sense that it's not up to taking a lot of torture.  The earbuds are able to be interchanged, but this isn't something you'll want to do a lot.  They are easy to remove--just pull.  But replacing the new eartip is a bit of a challenge.  You have to turn the flange inside out and try to push the flimsy, narrow connecting end on to the receiving end on the earpiece.  It takes some trial and error but is doable.The 3.5 mm jack might be a turnoff to an audiophile--they'll want a 1/4" audio jack for high end sound.  But given the price and given that these buds are strictly meant for light travel and the mp3-iPod set, this is actually not an issue here.The sound is in the solid to good range.  The buds are meant for pop music and deliver a crisp treble and pretty good (and loud) bass.  Played at a moderate volume, there are few problems, but if you turn up the volume the treble still can get a little tinny and deep bass seems to bottom out.For the most part, though, if you are mostly listening to a typical 4 or 5 piece pop band, you'll still hear the best of the lead guitar, lead singer, drums, and the boom of the bass.  If you want to think of it in terms of the Beatles, this is a fine headset to listen to 'Come Together' (even the awesome Aerosmith version) but not so much with 'I am the Walrus' (even the quirky but amazing Zappa version).The major problem with the sound quality, though, is that you are missing a lot of mid-tones and what you get in the mid-range is pretty muddy.  This makes these buds particularly unsuitable for jazz and classical music.  There's just too much going on the mid-range here and the bass is out of proportion to the treble.  Jazz listeners will not be all that satisfied here as you'll miss a lot of layering in the sound.  Mingus' Moaning just sounded... well, too much like moaning.  You only hear lows and highs and there's a hollowed out mess in the middle where a lot seems to be missing.  Even fooling with a software equalizer didn't make the sound any better.  Classical music is equally a mess.  Mozart's 25th in G Minor came across as too flat and bland and in forte sections you only hear the top and bottom well.  Brahm's Rhapsody in D Minor (solo piano) just sounded--well bad. The earbuds just couldn't take the dynamic range of the piano without losing the middle and fraying during the forte.All-in-all, though, you won't get a better pair of buds at this price.  You won't get audiophile quality but for in-the-pocket, mp3 listening you could do far worse.  There's a lot of value packed in here, given the low price, which makes these definitely worth the price of admission.  Not for the audiophile, but recommended for the casual listener.

LEGO Architecture: the Visual Guide by Philip Wilkinson in collaboration with Adam Reed Tucker, is an elegant coffee table book that displays all 22 of the LEGO Architect and Landmark Series--LEGO models of masterpieces of world architecture from 2008 to present.The book starts by introducing the Architect Series of models and describes the goals of the artists.  There is a timeline that shows when each model kit was introduced, brief profiles of the artists, an overview of the creative process, and a visual glossary of lego parts.  There is also a handsome two-page 'cityscape' where photographs of all the models were placed side by side to make a LEGO skyline.The format of the chapters on each building is pretty simple: generally, each kit is introduced with a large photograph of the completed model itself, a quick blurb about the reason for the choosing the building and the LEGO artists approach to building the model, and a side box with a small picture of the actual building including baseball-card style statistics.  The second part is devoted to a display of the model at different angles, with text that highlights important features. Often, there is also a mock up of the box.  The third section is an exploded view of the building that gives you an appreciation of how the it is constructed. Finally, there is a section devoted to pictures of the actual building with highlights describing the architect, the intended vision of the architect, innovative features of the building, and often a description of how it fits into the surrounding landscape.The photography of the models is superb.  This is especially true of the exploded view of the building.  This really gives you an idea of how the models were conceived.  Whether they are more schematic or more detailed, this view really gives you an idea of the genius of the LEGO model builders and a real appreciation of the art that goes into translating a brick and mortar building into a plastic LEGO kit.The lead LEGO artist in the architecture series is Adam Reed Tucker himself.  He designed 11 out of the 22 kits, with Rok Agolin Kobe designing 10 models (at least one in conjunction with Jorn Kristian Thomsen), and  one (Villa Savoye) designed by Michael Hepp.As with any endeavor, some models are more successful than others.  Some are highly schematic (such as the Willis Tower or the John Hancock Center) and some are far more detailed,such as Fallingwater, the Robie House, or the Imperial Hotel.  Realize, however, that these models were actual kits that were to be sold to the public: the artists couldn't use infinite numbers of LEGO bricks to construct the models.  Fewer bricks meant that compromises had to be made in terms of realism.  The curved roofs of Sungnyemun Gate would have to be flattened, the Guggenheim would lose some of its sloping curves, and the concavity of Marina Bay Sands would have to be squared off.  The goal, however, was that in spite of those compromises, the final model had to be instantly identifiable as the building it represented.  Overwhelmingly, the artists were successful in this.The models are truly beautiful things to behold and the expert photography makes them pop.  As an added bonus, you get a brief overview and history of each building.  Granted, this is not architecture text book, but if you enjoy LEGO and beautiful buildings this one's for you. Although not made specifically for children, this book might serve as edutainment for a child that is already interested in LEGO but hasn't even thought about architecture.Kudos have to go out to the art director Lisa Lanzarini and design manager Ron Stobbart for putting together such a beautiful and visually engaging book.  The layouts are stunning and do justice to the buildings.  Sadly, I was able to find credits for the photographs of the actual buildings but could not find credits for the brilliant photographer(s) whose stunning images of the LEGO buildings really make the book worthwhile.Finally, this book succeeds brilliantly on the coffee table.  Sure, it has that big-picture-book attraction, but the fact that it's  LEGO-art gives it that quirky, never-quite-seem-something-like-that, intellectual-fun quality that just makes guests want to pick it up and open it.  Just the type of conversation piece that a coffee table book should be.  Recommended.

[FULL DISCLOSURE: I received a device from LifeCHARGE so that I could do this review. Note, however, that the review was not vetted with LifeCHARGE prior to posting and my opinions of the device are based on my experience with it over the past couple of weeks.]PROS:Mat based charging (no need to plug phone in)Adds 2200 mAH battery so you never run out of power during the dayHigh production valuesExcellent fit and finishStylish caseConverts lightning port to more common microUSB portCan charge or synch with iTunes through microUSB portProtective lip around front of case is tall enough to protect the screen from scratches when placed face down on a counterBuilt in overcharge protectionIncludes extender cable for recessed headphone jack portCONS:Adds weight and heft to your iPhoneRecessed headphone jack port, requiring included extender cable for most headphone jack accessoriesSomewhat deep reach for ring/silent switchHeats up when charging phoneBack of the case is smoother than the sides and not so grippymicroUSB out has its advantages, but is not compatible with most iPhone-centric accessoriesUSB wall plug not includedQUICK OVERVIEWThe LifeCharge InAir Power Case is fine case for your iPhone 5S that will more than double your air time.  It can be charged either via USB or via the included mat, protects the iPhone as well as any back case, and has high production values.  The major compromise with this case is that it makes the iPhone larger and heavier.  However, for those who need the extra battery life it works incredibly well.INSIDE THE BOXInside the box you will find the case itself, charge mat, a micro-USB cable, an extension cable for the headphone jack, and a set of instructions.USING THE CASEAfter aligning the lightning connector, the phone easily snaps into this one-piece case. This is a back-type slip-in case, so the front of the phone is completely exposed.  Back-only cases generally offer little front screen protection.  However, unlike many, the InAir Power Case has a nice rubberized lip around the entire phone that can protect the screen from scratches if the phone is set face down on a counter.  I have one of those thin, glass screen protectors on my phone and even with this in place the lip is high enough to prevent direct contact.PORTS AND SUCHIn the front there are vent holes for the bottom facing microphone and speaker.  Note, there is no muffling of sound during phone calls and I have not noticed any distorted or decreased sound with ring tones or when playing back music over the native, iPhone speaker.On the bottom of the case, you will notice that the lightning jack has been replaced with a microUSB port and that the native headphone jack is visible, but is now quite recessed.  The transition from lightning port to USB is probably a good one.  MicroUSBs power most handhelds and accessories nowadays and the cables are much cheaper than lightning cables, so I absolutely respect the choice made by the LifeCHARGE designers.  In testing, I was able to charge and synch to iTunes at native speeds through the microUSB port on the case.  The downside of the microUSB port is that if you have iPhone specific accessories (a speaker laden dock, video out cable, or credit card reader, for example) that rely on the lightening connector, you will have to remove the iPhone from this case to use them.  The recessed headphone jack is more problematic: they do supply you with the extension cord, but it's inconvenient to have to carry around an extra piece of equipment so that you can connect to peripherals.The left side of the case has a nice rubberized cover for the volume controls that works perfectly.  The ring/silent switch has a cutout, which means digging in a bit to switch this on or off.  The cutout is generous enough, but it's still a bit difficult to switch on and off if you have larger fingers without long nails.  The rubberized cover of the on/off switch on the top, perfectly aligns and is easy to use.The back of the case has a generous, oval cutout for the camera and flash.  It is large enough that the case does not obscure the flash and there is no visible framing of pictures.  The back has the look of faux leather and there is even faux stitching on the periphery. Rather than looking cheesy, this gives the case a rather classic appearance. I would have preferred if the back of the case had the same grippy feel as the more rubberized sides.  It is a bit slippery, but otherwise felt fine in the hand.  There are two, tiny, widely spaced metal contacts on the back.  There is also a button at the bottom to activate charging the phone flanked by four, tiny, blue LEDs that indicate the charge level.CHARGING/BATTERY FEATURESThe major feature of the case is the integrated battery, which can either charge on a mat or via the microUSB port.  The case is not exactly an induction charging case, as the phone is not charging due to a magnetic field.  Instead, there are two exposed contacts on the back of the case that align with the two metal plates on the charge mat. But given that the contacts are tiny and that the metal plates are quite large, you don't need any specific aim.  You just plop the phone on the mat and it charges.  No fuss, no muss.The mat itself weighs only about 2 ounces and is 4 7/8" x2 13/16" x1/4".  It is a simple plastic affair with to large, smooth, silver contact panels on the front and rubberized feet at the bottom so that it stays in place.  It connects via a microUSB cable (included) and can connect to any USB power source.  Note, however, the company did not include a USB wall plug.  The phone easily rests on the panel face up.  So long as the two metal and you can note that the phone is charging when you see a little blue light escape from the underside of the charge case.  This is enough to let you know the phone is charging but is faint enough that it will not prevent you from sleeping at night.I am still surprised at how much I really enjoy charging on the mat. It's not that pluggin in a cable is really such a pain, but just placing the iPhone on to the case without having to push a cable into place is completely effortless and is somehow liberating.  Even more liberating was the 2000 mAh battery capacity.  The native iPhone 5S battery is only 1560 mAH, so the iAir more than doubles your capacity.  The iPhone battery is supposed to last for `10 hours of talk time,' but in real time use with extensive use of LTE or GPS etc., your iPhone 5S will lose power more quickly.  I'm lucky to eek out a days worth of iPhone time if I don't charge the thing at lunch.  With an extra 2000 mAh at the touch of a button, my days of worry are over.Note that when you set the case on the mat, the case will completely charge your iPhone first, before it charges the case's own internal battery.  Also note, that the battery has overcharge protection built in.The battery does not just kick in when the charge on the phone is below a certain percentage (this might be a nice feature to add to the next generation of LifeCHARGE cases).  You have to manually push the back button and hold it in and you're iPhone will start to charge.HEAT WITH CHARGINGThe battery heats up when charging.  This is a perceptible, but not overwhelming, amount of heat. The iPhone 5 itself can generate a fair amount of heat when you use the GPS features or a lot of LTE.  The warmth you feel with the charging is similar to this.  The case doesn't have great ventilation per se and I had concerns--especially in the heat wave we've been having--that the phone might overheat, but it didn't.  (My iPhone 4 would sometimes overheat and shut itself off when it was on GPS for prolonged amounts of time, but I have never had a problem like this with my iPhone 5S and certainly not with this case.)SIZE AND HEFTOne of the reasons you might have bought the iPhone 5S in the first place is because Apple is able to fit an amazing amount of hardware into an impossibly small space and light form factor.  Apple tries to make the iPhone as svelte and light and possible and when you add a battery case--this one included--you definitely add to the heft factor.The case adds about 3 ounces in weight, increasing the total weight to about 7.5 ounces.  This is a whopping 40% increase in weight.  The case also increases the total dimensions of the phone to 5 3/8" x 2 1/2" x 1/2", up from the native dimensions of 4 3/8" x 2 1/4" x1/4" (about a 37% increase in volume, for those who like these kinds of calculations).  You will definitely feel the difference in hand and in your pocket.  It's almost like having a Galaxy Note 3 or Lumia 1520 in your pocket, without the advantage of a larger screen...There are no two ways around it: you will compromise your iPhone's svelte figure and light weight by adding this (or any) battery case.  The thing is, we do this kind of thing all the time.  Apple works hard to give us the highest quality screen with vibrant colors and retina resolution... and to save our investment we cover it with a screen protector that blurs the resolution and washes out the colors.  We buy Otterboxes to protect our iPhones from drops up to 6 feet, but then make it larger than starter Android phones from 3 years ago.Sure, the iPhone will now be solid in your pocket.  But if you need power like I do, you won't care.  If you want to go out on the town for some haute cuisine and need your iPhone to slip effortlessly into your suit's breast pocket, don't use this case--fully charge your iPhone and buy a simple case (or let your iPhone go commando).But if you are doing a days work and truly need the power, this case will bring it.  No more carting cables wherever you go, charging in the car between locations, or hooking the phone up at your desk at lunch.LONGEVITY:I cannot vouch for the longevity of the device, as I have only used it for about 2 weeks. If there are any significant problems in the future, I will post them.CONCLUSION:Although it definitely adds heft to my iPhone, this case is a winner.  For a back-type, snap-on case, it adequately protects the iPhone, it can charge via a mat, and it more than doubles the battery life of my iPhone.  Recommended.
