Cathedral of the Wild, by Boyd Varty, is a memoir about growing up on a nature preserve in the South African bush.  It is a wildly interesting tale told in short vignettes by a master story teller.  The book really shines in the last 100 pages, where adversity strikes in the idyllic African Bush.I first learned of Boyd Varty when I was quite randomly came upon his TED talk while surfing the net.  Varty had spoken at TED after hearing about the death of Nelson Mandela, a Varty family friend.  Varty's talk was not only starkly honest and heartfelt but he really wove together the many difficult issues in South Africa with his own life's work--nature conservation and education--in an incredibly eloquent and passionate way.  When I saw his book offered on my Amazon Vine list, I grabbed it.The book is written as a series of vignettes that cover the founding of his family's Londolozi Private Game Reserve from its beginnings, as a family hunting ground, to its present incarnation, as a luxury nature preserve where the safaris are for tourists and the hunting is done with cameras instead of guns.  The place was founded on Varty's grandfathers' love of hunting and nature.  Londozoli's fate was sealed when Varty's father and uncle noted a decline in native animal species, decided two switch gears, bring the land back to its natural state, and bring back the animals.  A private nature reserve was a very strange notion at the time, but the Varty family's activism and deep love of the land has motivated them to replicate the Londolozi experience elsewhere.  The Varty's were also antiapartheid activists and they always hired and interacted equally with the local Shangaan tribe.  This is why Londolozi was chosen as one of the first places Nelson Mandela went to recover when he was released after 27 years in prison.The first third of the book is devoted to interesting stories about the founding of Londolozi and growing up in the wild, African bush.  Given that most of us have never experienced this kind of life, it is inherently interesting material. However, encounters with elephants, leopards, hippos, crocs, and other bush staples can't alone buoy the narrative and there is a limit to how far you can go describing the humorous crises that can occur when running a luxury nature preserve.  Still, Varty has a knack, however, for telling a good story and his writing style is incredibly rich.Still, the nearly idyllic bush life and the growth of Londolozi from a raw sketch of a park to a major, luxury safari compound can only go so far.  About two-thirds of the way into the book, I was really wondering whether this was going to turn into a 300 page promo for Londolozi.  But, thankfully, it didn't.As Varty grows up the perils of his family increase as they are beset with a number of tragedies.  Whereas the first part of the book recounted the halcyon days of Londolozi and Varty's youth, the last third of the book is gripping as the Varty family is gripped by adversity, and the legendary mettle that Boyd Varty described at the beginning of the book is tested.  Both Varty himself and his family seem frighteningly rudderless for a while, until they are able to get themselves back on track.There are certainly controversies that don't quite come to the surface in this book.  Varty's uncle John, is definitely a controversial figure with his unorthodox methods of filming nature documentaries and his more recent tiger preservation project. (The endangered tigers are on a preserve in Africa, where they are a non-native species. The idea being that they will be allowed to thrive on a preserve and later reintroduced to Asia at some point as the tiger population dwindles.)  On the one hand, the Varty's ecotourism model has served nature well, but--I imagine--it has also served the Vartys well and there are those who might contest their conservation as entrepreneurship.  At very least, nature is preserved for only those who can afford to pay to see it.  The Vartys certainly provide a living for the many Shaangan that they hire, but there's still an Apartheid cloud that hangs overhead, as blacks, as a rule, did not own land under Apartheid.  Even now, nearly 70% of land is owned by the white population and about 25% is owned by the state (15% 'black communal areas' and 10% 'other state land'), according to the latest figures I could find from PLAAS.Still, it's hard to make a mark in this world without stirring up some controversy.  And it's hard to fault the Vartys for wanting to make a living; and if they do so and at the same time save the planet I'm all for it.  Moreover, the Vartys were white, antiapartheid activists when such a thing was not only rare but dangerous, and they continue to act as activists when it comes to racial equality and conservation.  They also have been instrumental in creating an organization that brings education to the poorest of South Africans.  They may be controversial, but even after a little research it is clear to me that this remarkable family does what they do with a pure heart.Boyd Varty's book really gave me an appreciation for what it was like to grow up in the bush and the need for activist conservation using unique and sustainable models.  It is a worthwhile and interesting memoir and a great read.  Recommended.

A Spy Among Friends, by Ben Macintyre, is a fascinating look at the life of Kim Philby, brilliant charmer, doting father, scion of the British establishment,  and one of the most successful Soviet moles in the British secret service.Macintyre traces Philby's life from boyhood growing up in the shadow of his father St John Philby, an accomplished writer, explorer, British ambassador, and intelligence officer; to his schooling at the Westminster School and Trinity College at Cambridge; his days as a reporter; and finally his rise and demise in MI6, the British intelligence service.Philby was a communist sympathizer during his college days and was recruited to become a Soviet agent by first wife, Litzi Friedman, in the 1930s.  As a newspaper reporter in Spain at the time of the Spanish Civil War, he was able to feed information to the Soviet Union.  He was encouraged by the Russians to give over sensitive information regarding German troop movements to ingratiate himself to the British.  Eventually, this helped Philby segue into a position as a British secret service agent.  By 1939, the British had entered the war and Philby was recruited by MI6 after he, "dropped a few hints here and there," to the right people.Macintyre is able to weave together the diverse elements of the story and present a compelling narrative that reads more like a thriller than a history.  He gives just enough background so that the reader can understand context, but does not let it get in the way of the narrative.  He uses the parallel life of Nicholas Elliot--Philby's best friend, classmate in Trinity College, and fellow spy who eventually became a director at MI6.Macintyre skillfully explains how Philby's subtrefuge.  How Philby was able to truly live a double life; how he ingratiated himself to the higher ups in MI6, all the while feeding huge amounts of sensitive information to the Soviets. Philby was able to hide in plain sight, using his incredible charm, social position, and by playing on the existing friction between the two major parts of British intelligence (MI6 and MI5, roughly the equivalent of the CIA and the FBI in the United States), .  Even as overwhelming amounts circumstantial evidence compounded, Philby's circle of friends--including Nicholas Elliot and James Angleton, counter intelligence chief of the CIA--continued to protect him.One major shortcoming of the book is that there is a certain sterility to the narrative, as Macintyre does not appear to use any living, breathing sources of information.  He relies  almost solely on secondary sources of information. You don't quite realize what you are missing until you read John Le Carre's afterword.  Le Carre basically recalls a number of meetings he had with Nicholas Elliot before Elliot passed away.  He quotes extensively from Elliot and within the span of 14 pages you realize that although Macintyre does an adequate job of describing Elliot, Le Carre's descriptions and quotations really help you understand the essence of who Elliot was.  Sure, most of the players of that time period--including Philby himself--have died. However, there are plenty of people who are alive today that knew him and whose more intimate knowledge of Philby might have allowed Macintyre's already rich description of Philby (and others) to pop out of the page.Nevertheless, I found this book to be a gripping and engaging read.  More like a spy novel than a history book, it fleshes out a dark and embarrassing period in the history of British intelligence.  Recommended.

***UPDATE (10/1/2014): I have bumped up the review back to 3 stars.  I had a few go-rounds with Mr. Coffee customer support via email but they did, in the end, agree to take the French Press back to determine what was wrong with the defective button and offered to replace the item.  As my French Press was received as a demo model to review on Vine, I did not ask for a replacement.  This was not the smoothest customer support I have ever received--it took about 2 weeks for a resolution--but in the end Mr. Coffee did the right thing.  As far as I know only one other reviewer so far had problems with the button.  Once again, it is not clear to me whether this was a problem with the demo model or a more pervasive problem with the product line, but I have to give kudos to Mr. Coffee for standing behind their product. (I will leave the rest of the review unchanged.***NOTE (9/15/2014): In light of present problems, I cannot recommend the Mr. Coffee BVMC-FPK33 at this time. I initially posted this as a 3 star review and because of developing problems I have now downgraded it to a 1 star review.  Initially, the temperature/start button simply stuck occasionally and needed to be wiggled a bit to be activated.  After 3-4 weeks of regular use, the pot is now temperamental and only intermittently works.  I am in the process of contacting Mr. Coffee customer support and, depending on the answer I get, I may increase the star rating back to the original 3 star rating. It may be that my demo model came from a bad lot of coffee pots, but I can only judge the product in the basis of my present experience. I will leave the rest of the review unchanged until I hear back from Mr. Coffee.***PROS:StylishBoils 1 liter of waterNo loss of coffee temperature while brewingFrench press parts are easy to disassemble for cleaningAnti-boil dry detection for safetyKeep warm function for three temperatures 112, 160, and 195 FCONS:After 3-4 weeks, the kettle only intermittently works-->as above contacting customer supportNo cup measurement linesNo grips to remove lid after boilingSticky temperature buttonMy old standby hot pot can boil up 1.7 liters of water with nearly the same counter footprintNeed to clean the carafe and (take apart and clean) the filter apparatus if you have used the press to brew one kind of beverage and then want to use it for hot water or another beverageQUICK OVERVIEW:The Mr. Coffee BVMC-FPK33 2-n-1 is a combination electric hot water kettle and French press.  The pot functions as expected in terms of boiling water but the French press function is not necessarily as convenient as I would have thought.  I have enjoyed using the press but do have some reservations about whether combining a hot pot and a French press is the best way to go.  The major plus of making French press coffee in this apparatus is that you don't lose heat during the brewing stage.  The major disadvantages--and the reason for a lower star rating--are the awkwardness of pouring coffee grounds directly into hot water, the fact that the device is electric which makes cleaning a little more of a challenge, and an intermittently sticky center button.THE APPARATUS:In the box you will find the base, the hot pot itself, and the lid with the integrated French press apparatus.  The coffee pot is quite stylish, with modern aluminum accents.  At the bottom of the hot pot, you will find the temperature control button.  Most of the inside of the carafe is made out of tempered glass, but the exposed hot plate on the bottom is metal.To use the hot pot, you basically fill it with the desired amount of water and press the center button.  The pot takes about 6 1/2 minutes to boil a liter of water (212 F). When the water is ready you will hear a 'click' and the red LED will flash over 195 F.  By default, the hot pot will maintain the temperature at 195 F and shut off the hot pot automatically after 25 minutes.  By pressing the center button multiple times you can specify a lower  holding temperature.  If you do not want to boil the water first and only want to heat it up to 112 or 160 F,  you can specify this by pressing the button multiple times at the outset.  If you are heating to a lower temperature, the pot will automatically shut off after 60 minutes.When you remove the pot from the base (to pour the hot water), the pot will shut off.  If you want to keep the water warm after this, you simply press the center button to specify the holding temperature.  So long as the water is warm enough, the apparatus will not reboil the water--a nice feature especially when you are brewing coffee and would not want it to reboil.  As an added safety measure, there is an anti-boil dry detection feature, where the pot will not heat if the water level is too low.MAKING COFFEE:Making coffee is fairly simple.  You boil the water and wait at least 30 seconds so that the water is not actively boiling.  You remove the lid and put in the desired amount of coffee.  The instructions state that you then press down on the plunger such that the grounds are completely submerged in the coffee, but it makes more sense to me to stir the grounds with a tablespoon (as you do in a standard French press) before you replace the top, to ensure that the grounds are all uniformly and thoroughly moistened with water. They do not specify an extraction time, but usually this is around 4 minutes. After about 4 minute you press the plunger to the bottom and your coffee is ready.(Note: amounts of coffee used and extraction time can vary given your taste and the type of coffee used.  It takes a bit of experimentation to get the perfect cup of coffee.)The instructions for brewing coffee are, of course, by the cup.  They suggest about 2 tablespoons of coffee per 6 ounce cup of coffee, which seems to be something of a standard.  Please realize that you will need to have coffee that for French Press coffee, you need to grind your coffee more coarsely than for drip coffee.  If you use a standard, drip coffee grind, a lot of grounds floating in your coffee that passed through the mesh of the French press.  The instructions state that you need a 'coarsely ground' coffee but do not explain this any further.MAKING TEA:Basically, you can use this to brew tea or any other brewed beverage.  The water is boiled, tea leaves are placed in the carafe, you stir, replace the lid, and let the leaves steep over time.  You then press the plunger down and pour out the tea.  Ratios of amounts of tea leaves to hot water and steeping times vary greatly between different varieties of teas.  It may take a little experimentation, but brewing tea works quite well in a French press.  As above, you must clean the device thoroughly between uses if you are using a different type or tea or brewing coffee, as lingering tea leaves and residue caught in the filter will alter the taste of boiling water or the next brewed beverage.PROBLEMS/GRIPESFirst and foremost, there is the issue as to whether this combination is truly necessary.  You can buy an inexpensive and higher capacity hot water pot and a reasonable French press separately for less than the current price of this model.  A separate French press is easier to clean, as it has no electronic parts and can be immersed in water.  Note, however, that Mr. Coffee press definitely keeps the water up to temperature while brewing so it also has its own advantages.Cleaning is relatively easy, but given that the device is electric, you cannot submerge the base and have to be careful about keeping water inside the carafe.  For the most part, you can give the carafe a quick rinse, but after a few press uses, you will probably need to clean with a little soap and water.  Once again, not a major problem, but you have to make sure you don't get the outside wet.  As to the plunger apparatus, it comes apart like a conventional French press.  You might give the plunger apparatus a good rinse every once in a while if you were using a standard French press, but if you intend to use this device as a hot pot, using the water to make tea or hot chocolate, and do not want a residual coffee taste, you will have to clean it thoroughly in between uses. That said, if you want to use it to brew tea from leaves or coffee from grounds, you will have to clean it thoroughly in between. Once again, not any more difficult to clean than a regular French press, but given that it is also used as a hot pot, this makes me less excited about using the device as a coffee maker.The apparatus only came with one lid.  It would have been nice if they supplied an extra 'boil water' lid.  If you unscrew the bottom of the plunger assembly and set it aside, you can easily boil water in the device without the whole coffee press screen in place. Without the plunger screen/spring and without the need to leave room for the volume of the coffee grounds,  you can actually fill the device with more water (safely in my testing, although not recommended by the manufacturer).  As above, if you only use the device to brew coffee or one kind of tea, this is not such a big deal.  But if you are using the press for hot water after you brew some coffee, a second lid would allow you to boil plain hot water without having to thoroughly clean the filter apparatus in between.The only measurement line inside the pot is the 1 liter mark--this is majorly inconvenient.  Because it also serves as a coffee pot, I would have expected that there would have been cup mark lines (e.g. 2 cups, 4 cups, 6 cups etc.) so that you could accurately measure your coffee to the cup without having to use some kind of external measure.  (For the record, I believe that there are about 5.6 six ounce cups and 4.2 eight ounce cups in a liter--so a liter is not a very precise way to determine cups of coffee.)There is something quite inconvenient about removing the top of a pot of boiling water, having to add grounds, and then stir.  This is compounded by the fact that the dome atop the press doesn't have any contoured grip to pull up--you basically have to pull up on the French press handle.  This is not particularly difficult, but it is a design flaw nevertheless as this is how Mr. Coffee intended you to use the pot in the first place.I have had minor issues with the central button.  I used the pot for about one week and the temperature control button intermittently sticks.  I have not used the pot for anything other than boiling water/making coffee and it has not been exposed to any sticky substances.  By carefully gripping the sides of the button and wiggling it, it seems to work well again, but this has happened several times.(For some true, coffee aficionados, this pot would be inadequate for making French press coffee.  In order to brew French press coffee 'correctly' you are supposed to place the dry grounds at the bottom of the coffee pot first.  You then 'bloom' the coffee by either pouring in just enough water thoroughly moisten the coffee or by filling the pot half full.  You then stir until the coffee grounds are fully moistened, fill the balance of the pot with hot water, and stir again.  Personally, I don't think that this is a major issue.  Perhaps I use inferior coffee and/or don't have the taste buds that can tell the difference, but the coffee tastes the same to me whether it is 'bloomed' at a separate stage or pour all the water in at once and stir.  Nevertheless, for some, this might be an issue.)CONCLUSIONS:In general, the Mr. Coffee Electric French Press works as you would expect.  It is nice to look at and brews a fine pot of coffee.  Still, I am not convinced that this device is a perfect marriage between hot pot and coffee press.  There are some rough edges in the design that could have been better, especially given the price at which this device is currently being offered.  For the right consumer this two-in-one device might hit the spot, but most would be better served buying a hot pot and a French press separately.

PROSReady in under a minuteCan accommodate widths up to 12.5"Easy to useSelf adjusts to thicknessQuickly switches between hot and cold laminationBack up button to correct errors in feeding should they occurResponsive touch sensitive buttonsSafty/powersaving 'sleep mode'StylishExcellent customer supportFellowes stands by their productCONSHeavy at 14 lbsHas a large footprint 20"x6.75"x4.5"OVERVIEWThe Neputne 3 125 Laminator by Fellowes is a well made, fast, and easy to use product that does exactly what it is meant to do.WHAT'S IN THE BOXThe laminator comes well packed in the box with a set of instructions and a starter pack of 10 Fellowes Enhance 3 laminator pouches.  In order to set up the laminator you simply snap on the wire exit tray and plug it in.LAMINATOR ITSELFThe laminator itself is handsomely made.  The front and back of the machine are plastic and the top is graced with opaque silver plastic that has a dull sheen that makes it look like it is covered in aluminum like an expensive kitchen appliance. Apart from the on/off switch in the back there are no other physical buttons.  The three touch sensitive buttons in the front light up when the machine is powered up, lending a space-age quality to the laminator.  On the left  is the Standby/Power button, in the middle is a hot/cold laminator button, and on the left is the reverse feed button.Note: the laminator itself is pretty heavy, weighing in at 14 lbs.  It is also fairly large at 20" wide and 6.75" deep, and 4.5" high--this has quite the large footprint.  (Given its size, my kids were jokingly calling it the 'sheepinator.')When you power the machine on the buttons light up.  After activating the touch sensitive standby/power button the machine starts to heat up.  It appears to default to the hot lamination mode, but this can easily be disabled by touching the hot/cold lamination button.  The touch sensitive buttons are responsive and worked perfectly.As a safety feature, the machine has a sleep mode, which will turn off the heat and place the laminator on standby after 30 minutes of inactivity.USING THE LAMINATORThe laminator beeps to signal it is ready and for hot lamination this takes less than a minute.  You simply place your items for lamination in a laminator pouch and it passes through the machine in seconds completely and perfectly laminated.  If you need to stop and redirect the pouch, you can hit the reverse, remove, the pouch and refeed it into the machine.  The machine auto adjusts to the thickness, so there are no other settings. The machine can handle Fellowes' 3, 5, or 7 mil thickness pouches which come in a variety of sizes and finishes.  The laminator can accommodate widths of up to 12.5."Using the supplied pouches, I laminated a variety of things on regular paper, thicker paper, collages using construction paper, and even photographs.  All came out perfectly and the process was effortless.CUSTOMER SUPPORTThe first laminator I received for testing would not power on.  I contacted Fellowes' customer support via email and got an answer within 24 hours.  They shipped out a new laminator to me no questions asked (it arrived in 7 days) and gave me a UPS return label so I could return the broken laminator.Customer support was prompt and professional.  I was impressed that they not only responded so quickly but that they truly wanted to solve my problem promptly.  In my experience this is stellar customer support and few companies try to resolve problems so quickly.  Customer support and a company that stands behind its products 100% definitely adds value.CONCLUSION:If you are looking for a larger sized laminator that is simple and easy to use, this one fits the bill.  Fellowes has gone out of their way to keep things simple and functional.  As an added bonus, they have excellent customer support and stand by this product.  Recommended.

PROSCertified by AppleLonger than the OEM cable by about 8 inchesSame dimensions as the OEM lightning cableSlightlyThe Belkin Apple Lightning USB ChargeSync cable is a worthy replacement for your iPhone, iPad, or iPod original cable.Comes in six different colors (green, blue black, pink, purple, red, and white)CONSOddly, Belkin didn't include all new iPhone 5c colors except for yellowBelkin's cable seems just a little more hardy than Apples.  Production values seem to be high, and there seems to be a better overall sturdiness/hardiness than the original Apple sync cable.  The cable sports the same dimensions as your original, Apple lightning cable, so there is no worry about whether it will be compatible with Apple approved cases.Belkin offers their cable in a variety of different colors, so if you are sporting an iPhone 5c you can match the cable to the back of your iPhone or if you have a colorful case for you iDevice you can match up the aesthetics.  (Strangely, Belkin left out yellow--one colors that are part of the iPhone 5c lineup.  I suppose you could get white or a coordinating color if you have the yellow 5c model.)Belkin's cable is 1.2 meters, as opposed to Apple's which is 1 meter.  Basically, you get nearly 8 inches of extra length if you go with the Belkin.I have used the cable for both charging and synching.  Everything seems in order.  As to the longevity of the cable, it is hard to say after only using it for a short period of time.  I will update this review later if I have any problems.All-in-all this product could work well as a replacement or extra lightning cable for your iDevice.  Recommended.

PROS:High quality scans up to 600 dpiConnects easily to iPhone and Android appGreat job with textServiceable job scanning picturesUp to 600 dpi scanning via computerUp to 300 dpi scanning via handheld or tablet devicesPC or Mac can save to Google Drive, SugarSync, WebDav, or direct to email or a printerIncludes ABBYY image conversion and Presto BizCard software extras for Windows usersCONS:Clunky WiFi set up for MacNeed a Windows or Mac computer to set up WiFiNeed a WPS capable router to use with your local Wi-Fi networNo Linux and Google Chrome apps/set upIf connection set up wizard aborts, the only way to get back into it is to reinstall the 'Epson Scan' software (both Windows and Mac)--time consuming and very, very frustratingSome crashing of manual set up on MacGood resolution scanning pictures but overall colors washed out and loses contrastAC adaptor sold separatelyGoes through AA batteries quicklyLimited to 300 dpi resolution when scanning via iOS or AndroidiOS and Android apps will not save directly to Google Drive, SugarSync, WebDav, direct to email, or output directly to a printerNo add on software for OS X usersOVERALLThe Epson DS-40 is a fine portable scanner by Epson.  The high points of this scanner are its portability and ability to easily and accurately scan text documents.  Low points include a clunky set up for the iMac, a somewhat washed out appearance in photo scanning, and lack of drivers/software for Linux or Chromebooks.  Nevertheless, this is a convenient, portable solution.WHAT'S INCLUDEDInside the box, you will find the scanner itself, a USB cable, carry bag, quick start up guide (both English and Spanish versions), set up CD, 4 AA batteries, a calibration sheet, dry cleaning sheet, and wet cleaning sheet.  All of this is handsomely packaged in the box.THE HARDWARE ITSELFThe scanner itself is about 11 1/2 inches long and accommodates paper sizes up to size.  A guide can be moved to the maximal setting at Letter but also has convenient stops at A4, B5, A5, and A6.  The guide, however, can be positioned at any size.  The construction is all plastic but feels solid. It is mostly a dull finish but doesn't attract noticeable finger prints.  The stick-shaped scanner's look is somewhat cheaper than you would think and the design is more practical than beautiful; nevertheless, form follows function. On top, there is a gray power button and a blue feed button.  Three LEDs indicate battery status, WiFi, and feed.  On the front you will find a toggle that allows you to go between Wi-Fi, AP, and USB modes.  The connect button for WPS web setup is in the back.There is a port for an AC adaptor, but this is not included with the bundle. (Note: the USB cable is only for hooking up directly to another device and is NOT a charge or power cable.)DIFFICULT SET UP FOR MEI am an old hand at setting up printers and scanners.  This kind of thing is never for the faint of heart and is rarely straightforward.  In general, Windows set ups are easier than Mac set ups, not because the Mac is a difficult machine to use but because the Mac software--I think--is usually more of an after thought for companies who are mostly marketing to business clients--the type that mostly use Windows.All that said, the set up for iMac reached a new low in clunkiness.  It was way too much trouble  took way too long to get the DS-40 hooked up to my Mac and way too much trouble.  (For the record, I was installing the software on a 21.5 inch, Mid 2011 2.5 GHz Intel Core i5 with 12 GB of 1333 MHz DDR3 running OS X 10.9.4 and completely up to date.)The included CD has software for all versions of Windows from XP on forward and OS X software from 10.5.8 to present.  My main computer is a Mac.  Install was simple and straightforward.  After inserting the CD you click on the icon and away you go.The problem that I encountered, however, is that the Wi-Fi set up for the DS-40 comes at the very end of the install and--for whatever the reason--I couldn't get my iMac to recognize the DS-40 on Wi-Fi.  I tried automatic WPS recognition, I tried WPS with PIN, I tried updating my router drivers.  I tried rerunning, start and restart or the router and my iMac--no dice.  I even tried installing the software on VMware Fusion Windows 7 and still the computer wouldn't recognize the scanner.  To make matters worse,  there was no back button or place to install the DS-40 other than going through the entire set up procedure.I gave it a rest for the night and tried again in the morning.  Still no luck and no way to connect a PC via AP mode.  USB mode posed no problem, but I really wanted to get the Wi-Fi going.  Before giving up, I flipped on my iPhone and downloaded the Epson app.  I was able to connect he DS-40 to my local network on the first try.  I then did the set up/install from soup to nuts and voila! My iMac finally found the scanner. After that it was smooth sailing.In the process of installing the scanner the night before, however, I ran down the batteries after an intense couple hours just trying to set up the scanner. Note to self: wherever you go bring extra batteries and Epson should have included the AC adaptor with the bundle.I also set up the scanner anew using my Android tablet and was similarly successful.  I was able to set up the scanner, off network, via its own Wi-Fi signal, using AP mode with either the iPhone or Android app.  (This AP mode will not work with a PC or Mac.)USING THE SCANNERScanning was simple and intuitive.  The on screen scanning software for the iMac is basic but functional.  Once the scanner was up and running scanning was easy.  The feed seemed to work well, you just need to be careful to have enough clearance behind the machine so that the scan goes through.Prior to scanning, you can choose the type of file you want to save to (PDF, JPEG, TIFF, or PNG). If you choose PDF or JPEG there are compression options as well.  You can choose the resolution (200, 300, 600 dpi or a custom level of dpi between 50-600). There are few post processing options in the document capture software, other than rotating the final picture.Text scanning was excellent and the quality was fine for all kinds of text sizes at 300 dpi.  The DS-40 was competent at scanning photos at 600 dpi, but less than ideal.  In comparison to similar scans using my Brother Printer (MFC J8700W--not exactly a superstar) set at 600 dpi resolution, the actual quality of the resolution pixel for pixel was better with the DS-40.  Sadly, though, photographs scanned with the DS-40 lost contrast and appeared washed out and flat in comparison to the Brother scans.  So, in spite of the better pixel for pixel view at high magnification, the Brother produced a far better, overall picture quality than the DS-40.Whether scanning documents at 200 dpi or 600 dpi, color, gray scale, or black and white, the scanner worked quickly.  The delay, however, occurred on the computer side where higher resolutions took longer for the computer to compile.As above, the scanner functioned well whether using it with a computer or handheld device.  Realize, however, that handheld devices can only scan up to 300 dpi, whereas a computer can take full advantage of the DS-40's 600 dpi capability.I scanned a variety of media from plain paper to magazines to photos.  The DS-40 seemed to handle the different thicknesses of paper well without any hitches.  If you obstruct the outflow, however, you may get a smear artifact on your scan of the image.I was more than satisfied as to how the device handled itself whether scanning from a handheld device or the computer.MORE SOFTWARE FOR WINDOWSOn Windows you get additional software including ABBYY Fine Reader Sprint that allows you to convert scanned images to various formats. Fine Reader will convert images to Word, Excel, PDF, or to e-mail and in doing so will use OCR to convert any letters to searchable and editable text.  Generally, this functioned quite well.  (Realize, though, that this is a basic version of the software and will not perform any advanced options or convert PDF files to other editable forms.)Windows users also get Presto! Biz Card, a software package that allows you to easily and automatically scanned business cards to a computer address book.  I did not try this package, but the interface looked a bit outdated.Sadly, iMac users do not get these any extra software packages.CONCLUSIONThe DS-40 is a competent, portable scanner.  The set up via iMac was challenging for me, but once set up I was quite satisfied with what the Epson had to offer.

PROSEasy to useAccurateFits wide range of arm sizes from 9" to 17"Large LCD readoutCONSBatteries not includedNo AC adaptor available--battery operated onlyNo time stamp on blood pressure readingsNo backlightNo connectivity options to computers or handheld devicesThe Omron BP710N 3 Series Upper Arm Blood Pressure Monitor is the most basic and affordable automatic blood pressure cuff offered in Omron's latest lineup.  Although it is not chock full of features, it will definitely do the job--it is an easy to use, accurate, and affordable way to monitor your blood pressures at home.Inside the box you will find the basic unit itself, the cuff/tube assembly, full instruction guides (in English and in Spanish), and a quick start guide (in English on one side, Spanish on the other).  Batteries are not included and the set up doesn't come with a carry case.  More importantly, there is no AC cord included and there is no power jack on the device: this is a batteries-operated-only device.The unit itself is smartly compact for such units.  Assembly is simple:  you put four AA batteries in the bottom compartment of the unit and plug the arm cuff into the main unit.  The cuff is simple enough to place on either arm.  You cinch it until it is lightly snug and then secure it using velcro.  You then twist it so that the tube leading from the cuff is directly over the inside of your elbow.  This isn't so bad, but on my old Omron, the HEM-711 DLX, the cuff itself was more rigid and easier to place.  This isn't a deal breaker, it just makes the cuff little more difficult to place. The lower line cuff is on the less expensive model, but for people who have lost some dexterity it may be worth it to spend the extra dollars and opt for one of the two higher line models with this 'Easy-Wrap ComFit' model.Checking your blood pressure is as simple as pushing the button.  You press, wait, the cuff inflates, deflates, and the monitor shows your blood pressure and pulse in large 3/4 inch numbers.  If there is an error the cuff notes this.  Additionally, it will display a heart shaped symbol if you have an irregular heartbeat and a movement symbol if you move your body during the measurement.The cuff keeps a record of the last 14 readings, but there is no time stamp/clock on this model, so you will have to mark down the times and dates on your own.  If you want more memory or a time stamp you will have to look for a higher end model.  There is also no connectivity (via Bluetooth, WiFi, or USB), so you cannot offload blood pressure readings to a spreadsheet on your computer.There are not a lot of bells and whistles here, but if you want an easy and accurate blood pressure measurements at home, this cuff appears to be accurate and will do the job.  Recommended.

PROSA quick and easy cleanGreat substitute for damp moppingRefills are reasonably pricedCleaning fluid refills come in different formulations for different applications and in different scents to suit your tasteEasy to useEasy to assembleCONSBatteries not includedMinimal supplies includedNot suitable for overly tough floor cleaning jobsThe Swiffer WetJay Spray Mop Cleaner Starter Kit is a good way to clean your hardwood, tile, or linoleum floors.The kit comes with the Swiffer mop itself, a 500 mL bottle of cleaning fluid, 2 Swiffer pads (one regular and  and 'Extra Power Pad' with a blue strip of Mr. Clean Magic Eraser in the middle), and an instruction kit.  Batteries are not included.The mop itself is mostly preassembled.  The handle folded into three pieces that snap together quickly.  You have to supply 2 AA batteries.  You can then snap in the bottle of cleaner fluid, velcro on the Swiffer pad, and you're ready to go.Swiffering is really damp mopping. Before Swiffering--similar to mopping--you have to make sure that you have swept or vacuumed well before you begin.  Larger chunks will not stick to the Swiffer pad and, if there is too much dirt on your floor, you will make mud when you wet it that will be hard to Swiffer.When you press the button on the handle, the cleaning fluid shoots through two jets on the sides of the Swiffer head.  It shoots about 2 1/2 feet ahead of the Swiffer and the spray is just about as wide as the Swiffer head itself.  You then mop.  There is a 'scrubbing strip' in the front--like the kind of scouring pad for dishes that is gentle enough to use on teflon--on the front that can be used to loosen very stubborn stains.The regular Swiffer pad is just a simple pad.  The Extra Power Pad with the Mr. Clean Magic Eraser is more suitable for stubborn stains, such as scuff marks on linoleum.  In home testing, the pads worked pretty much the same.  I tried both on some scuff marks and the Magic Eraser pad maybe did a little better.  But the scrubbing strip worked better than the Magic Eraser in my home tests for removing scuff marks and anything that was really tough to remove required the use of the scrubbing strip anyway, so I'm not sure how truly different the Magic Eraser experience was.  Depending on how dirty the floor is and how much you have to Swiffer, you may need to change pads frequently.On the upside, this is a very quick and convenient way to clean your floors.  As a side perk, kids love the motorized spraying action and at least for the first two weeks are more willing to help you clean the floor just so they can use the Swiffer.  Swiffer cleaning fluid refills also come in a variety of formulations for different surface types and in a variety of scents.  There are also a number of different Swiffer pads to choose from.  Refills are also reasonably priced.On the downside, I'm not sure why the Swiffer needs to be electronic.  The older versions with a mechanical spray trigger were not harder to operate and did not need batteries.  The kit also comes with only barebones supplies: 1) two pads will not get you too far; and 2) the size of the Swiffer cleaner is 500 mL--less than half the usual size (1.25 Liters) of a Swiffer cleaner refill.  I guess you could look at the supplies as bonus items included with the Swiffer Wet Jet, but 10 pads and a normal sized refill would have been more to my liking.All in all, the Swiffer WetJet was effective and worked as expected.  If your floor is an abysmal mess of dirt and grime, you will need to vacuum and take out your old fashioned mop and bucket for a thorough cleaning.  But if all you need is a superficial clean, you can use the Swiffer as you would when you damp mop.  It is an easy and convenient way to clean your floors and is definitely worth the investment.

VINE CUSTOMER REVIEW OF A FREE PRODUCT(see http://www.amazon.com/gp/vine/help for more information)[NOTE: I received this product through the Amazon Vine program.  As it was sent to me in error, Amazon removed it from my list and did not require me to post a review.  Therefore, the product was not marked as coming from the Vine program.  The review was not vetted with Amazon or RCA prior to posting and the opinions of the device are based on my experience with it over the past month.]PROSSimple dehumidifier70-pint capacityEasy to operate2 fan speedsCarry handle on water bucketEffectiveOptional drain hoseTimer functionCONSNeeds to be emptied frequently on humid daysUnit beeps loudly when the bucket is removed for emptying (no way to stop this)No remote controlNot Energy Star certifiedThe RDH705 is a basic, competent dehumidifier for up to 4500 square feet.There was the obligatory removal of tape to prevent shifting during shipping, but other than this the unit arrived completely assembled and ready to go.  The unit does come with a set of instructions.  (Make sure you remove the plastic drain attachment from the water compartment before operating and DO NOT remove the styrofoam float which monitors the water level.)The unit itself is compact enough, given what it does.  It stands on mobile castors about 23 inches high and is about 15.5 inches wide and 11 inches in depth.  It is not a light weight piece of equipment at almost 40 lbs, so the wheels are a welcome addition.  This is a larger capacity dehumidifier; the tank holds 70 pints (2.1 gallons) of water.  The water compartment slides in and out easily but also snaps into place to prevent accidental spillage.  As the unit is self-contained it can move anywhere you have an outlet.If you want continuous drainage so you don't have to empty the water compartment periodically, you can use the optional drain attachment.  To attach the drain, you simply remove a rubber stopper on the back of the unit and screw in the drain fixture.  The hose with this attachment is only about 6 3/4 inches long, so you will need to buy an adequate length of plastic hose to attach.  This drains by gravity and NOT by pump, so you have to make sure that you use a floor drain that is lower than the unit to achieve adequate flow.The machine powers on via a control panel at the top (there is no remote supplied with this unit).  There is a power button and the fan can be adjusted to two speeds (Turbo and normal).  When powered on the unit can certainly be heard.  Using an iPhone app it appears to throw off about 60 dB on the low fan setting and 63 db on the low setting at 10 feet. My average window air conditioner throws off around 70 dB depending on the fan setting, so this is about twice as quiet as your average air conditioner. (dBs are note a linear scale; 70 dB is about twice as loud as 60. To give you an idea, 60 dB is about the range for normal conversation.  70 dB is like driving in the average car.  A normal, quiet home is about 40 dB.)The unit seems to do a fine job of dehumidifying.  On some hotter and more humid days, however, the container will fill up rather quickly.  On one of the scorching, >90 F days with 80% humidity, the container filled to capacity within about 5 hours.  The machine stops dehumidifying and beeps when the container is full.  As above, it is simple to empty and there is is a convenient carry handle on the bucket.The unit effectively dehumidifies, so long as you place it correctly in a room.  It needs to be able to access enough airflow so that air can circulate through the unit.  You cannot put the unit in a closet and expect it to work.  If you place it in the basement, it would probably function best in the middle of an open space.  If you are using this in your living room, it can be placed in a corner, but  needs to be far enough away from the wall to have sufficient air flow.Additionally, the unit has a timer function so that it will automatically turn off after the set time.I am pleased with the performance of this dehumidifier.  It isn't the fanciest unit or the unit with the most options, but it does its job well and at the time of the writing of this review appears to be priced competitively.

As Edgar Walsh--Pearl S. Buck's son and manager of her literary estate--states in his excellent forward to this book, The Eternal Wonder is a literary find.  Buck died in 1973 with her estate in shambles.  The manuscript was taken from Buck's house and somehow ended up in a Texas storage unit.  When the storage unit was abandoned, its contents went up for auction and the manuscript was serendipitously found.It is not clear exactly when Buck wrote her final novel.  What is clear, though, is that Buck was a perfectionist and this novel is far from her usual level of perfection.  Walsh and the publisher worked together to edit out some of the more obvious kinks, but otherwise the novel was left untouched. Buck was clearly not finished with this manuscript and the lack of polish is evident.Still, the book is definitely a diamond in the rough (or perhaps a better metaphor in this case, an uncultured pearl).  It contains the same soaring themes that you might find in Buck's many works: the burden of being different, the individual who is both part of society yet alienated from it, the evils of oppression of minorities and women, cultural clashes between East and West, and others.  It takes us from the United States to the far East; while Buck herself clearly revels in rather than criticizes the clash of cultures, Buck's characters are forced to struggle with their differences.In spite of it's flaws, Buck's characteristic voice echoes throughout the book and you can almost hear her voice, too, somewhere in the background lamenting that she didn't have a chance to polish the book before you had a chance to read it.  Transitions between settings and segments of the novel are a bit choppy.  Although she wraps up the story, the denouement is all too quick.  But this unfinished quality does have its own allure, as you get a better idea of the process by which Buck might have written her novels.The story, from the outset, is a bit contrived. The novel follows the life of Randolph (Rann) Colfax, a genius from birth.  Of course, writing about a character who is deemed a genius is easier said than done. It is easy enough to state that your character is a genius, but it is far harder to concoct actions and dialogue that bear out this fact. Rann often states a conclusion that is rather pedestrian whereupon another character remarks that Rann is clearly exceptional.  Buck certainly has Rann accomplish a lot by the end of the book; however, a lot of his adventures seem propped up and--if we just observe what Rann does and says-- Rann comes across more as being more precocious than being a true genius.  My guess is that Buck knew this and might have buffed up these aspects in subsequent drafts.Buck has her protagonist one-up Stephen Dedalus: Rann's life story begins before parturition.  Prior to reading this book, I wasn't aware of my bias against novels that initiate their narrative in utero.  It seems more than a bit contrived and may have been one of the parts that Buck might later have scrapped or rewritten so that it would be more compelling.  The book then takes us through Rann's coming of age, the development of his sexual identity, his struggle to define himself, and finally deciding on his path in life.The book is less timeless than some of Buck's other novels.  Her choice to set this in her own era probably accounts for some of this.  The book might have seemed more inflammatory had it been released in the late 60s or early 70s.  Buck's ideas of racial and ethnic equality are, thankfully, no longer radical.  Her descriptions of Rann's sexual coming of age, which might have been scandalous when the book was written, are tame by modern standards.  And yet, even while Buck was forward thinking, some of her mores--which were definitely considered quite liberal during her lifetime--are still entrenched in the 1950s and 60s and these fall dissonant on the modern ear.Although the prose retains Buck's classical elegance, the dialogue is often stilted and some characters, such as Rann's mother and father, are not more than cardboard props for the novelist.  In this book, characters channel Buck with blatant sermonization of Buck's thoughts and philosophies.  If Buck were to have to done a later revision, you might imagine that some  of the paragraph length dialogue might have been cut back and the sermons might have been replaced with shorter, more subtle dialogue and actions that demonstrate rather then orate Buck's philosophies.  Additionally, she would definitely have fleshed out some the characters--including the protagonist.Flaws aside, I was still duly impressed with the effort here.  I was hooked by the book for two reasons.  First, it is just amazing to have unearthed a heretofore unknown novel from a major 20th century author.  Second, the book offers a rare look  into the building process of a novel.  Finally, I'd take this first draft from Buck over many third or fourth drafts of other authors.  The book may not be perfect but its still a great read.

Gutenberg's Apprentice, by Alix Christie, is a historical novel about the printing of the Gutenberg Bible.  Christie, a letterpress printer herself, mixes her own knowledge of the printing process with the handful of known facts, and stirs in a healthy dose of fiction.  The result is a lushly written novel that, although slow at times, really gives the reader the feeling of what it must have been like to live in the 15th Century when moveable type was invented.The major players are Johannes Gutenberg, the mercurial genius himself; Johann Fust, Gutenberg's patron and financier; and Peter Schoeffer, Fust's adopted son who becomes Gutenberg's apprentice.  [Note: historically, Schoeffer was not Fust's adopted son.]Christie's protagonist is Peter Schoeffer, the ambitious, young scribe.  After learning his trade in Paris, Schoeffer comes back to Mainz, only to find out that Fust wants him to eschew the trade he has learned, work with Gutenberg, and learn about this newfangled thing called printing.  We follow Schoeffer through his initial resistance to the project, his woes of working with the occasionally volatile and always unpredictable Gutenberg, and finally his mastery of the press.As the story is framed by the reminiscence of an elderly Schoeffer, we know from the outset how the story ends: Gutenberg loses his printing press to bankruptcy and Fust buys out the business with Schoeffer as his partner, forming the first successful printing house Schoeffer & Fust.Christie's writing is, no doubt, a thing of beauty.  The prose has an archaic ring to it, as though you are reading a translated history from the 1400s.  She also has a knack for capturing the sense of wonder that her characters have for the invention of moveable type, a feeling that we might compare to the invention of the internet today.  Moveable type changed everything.  It was a radical change and was immediately recognized as such.  What people couldn't predict was how vast its influence would be in such a short time.Given the subject matter, though, the book flounders a bit.  The general plot is simple: Gutenberg and company must race against time to complete the bible. For one, the money is running out.  For another, the Church authorities have an inkling that something is up and it seems clear that they want to shut down the presses.  And while their beating the clock, they have to invent all the techniques needed to successfully print things.Christie throws in a few side plots and a little romance, but since we know the ending, the mystery isn't whether the get from point A to point B but how they get there. (We know at the beginning that Gutenberg has a falling out with Schoeffer and Fust and the bible definitely gets printed--or at least I'm pretty sure of it because of its Wikipedia entry).  Additionally, as much as a modern reader realizes the impact of the printed word, it's hard to get as jazzed up about it as characters in the book do.Although there are parts of the book that I had to push through a bit to read, I thoroughly enjoyed it overall.  If you are interested in the subject matter and a historical novel of this time period, Christie has written a compelling book that definitely leaves an indelible mark.  Recommended.

The Tombow Mono Professional Drawing Pencil set comes in a blister pack with six 'extra-refined' graphite pencils and a 2.3 mm precision eraser.  A carrying case is not included.The pencils from hardest to softest are 2H, HB, B, 2B, 4B, and 6B.  (The HB pencil is usually about the harness of your average, #2 pencil, but there are no universal hardness guides and pencils can vary from manufacturer to manufacturer.)The variety of hard and soft leads is reasonable for someone who is just starting out.  However, until you have developed your own style, it makes sense to buy a set of 12 pencils.  There is a Tombow set on Amazon that does not come with an eraser but has 12 pencils in a plastic box that might serve you better. It's nice that they concentrated on the softer leads, as that is where I end up doing most of my drawing because I enjoy blending.I sharpened the pencils with a conventional sharpener (some prefer to use a craft knife).  They performed as expected and compared favorably to my reliable Staedtler set. The leads seem of appropriate hardness and the pencils feel good in the hand.  They are hexagonal so they don't roll away too quickly on a flat surface and have the right feel of an artists pencil.The eraser is a reasonable point eraser.  Obviously, at 2.3 mm this is not an eraser for large areas.All and all, this is a fine set of drawing pencils for the beginner.  Those who are more serious will probably want the set of 12.

PROS:SimpleConvenientReally does cut down on prep timeChops and dices to uniform sizesMuch safer and easier to use than a mandolin type slicerEasy clean upEasy storageComes with helpful cleaning toolIntegrated measuring deviceCONS:Not for large jobsVeggies need to be cut down to size before they can be used in the deviceNot suitable for softer fruits, vegetables, or cheeses or veggies that are too pulpy (e.g. soft tomatoes)Very fibrous, not so crisp sweet potatoes were a bit of a challenge (but a crisper, less dense variety worked famously)Cutting blades are not meant to be cleaned in dishwasherLess versatile than a mandolin slicerSturdy, but not heirloom kitchen device qualityThe Freshware Onion, Vegetable, and Cheese chopper is a simple kitchen tool that just does the job.There is really nothing all that fancy here: basically the device is a simple hinge.  You select from three cutting grates: large squares, small squares, or slices.  You select one of the grates and place it on the base of the device, place the food on the chopper blade, and push the hinged lid closed.  This forces the food through the grille and--voila--your food is chopped.As an extra bonus, there are measuring lines drawn on the side.  If you tilt the device on end, you can see if you have enough, say, chopped onions without having to use a measuring up.Is this genius?  No.  Is this new, innovative, and oh-so-different than anything out there in the market? Absolutely not.  However, the chopper is simple, easy to use, and light weight.  Whether you are making sweet potato fries, chopping onions, or cutting harder cheeses in cubes or strips it is simple and just works.  This is an easy to use, easy to clean, device that doesn't take up a lot of room, but might save you a lot of time.The device could probably chop just about anything but, for me, worked best on larger more solid types of food.  Potatoes and crisp sweet potatoes worked exceedingly well. (Note: very fibrous sweet potatoes that weren't so crisp didn't work well in the system.  For some reason they were trouble.  However, another crisp and seemingly less fibrous variety worked famously in the machine.  You may have to experiment at first with what works.)  If you want strips or slices you give them one pass.  If you want cubes, you put them through for a second pass.  Solid fruits, such as apples and firm pears worked well too. Onions were diced with one pass.  Note, however, firmness is key. If the onion is on the riper side, it still works, but there can be some slippage.  Celery, carrots, and parsnips all worked pretty well, but were less convenient as you need to cut them in strips that fit on the chopper blade and you can't really stack them.Certain veggies, such as tomatoes, didn't work as well.  Sure, if you have a more solid beefsteak tomato without a lot of seed or pulp it would probably be okay.  But if your have a less meaty tomato that has a lot of pulp/seeds, you will pulverize more than you chop.  The same goes for ripe pairs, bananas, softer cheeses etc.  Softer things that don't hold their shape don't work as well.Given the incredible sharpness of the blades, there was little slippage of the food while chopping.  With a tiny bit of pressure, the food anchors quite well.  The sharpness of the blades is also key when it comes to ease of use.  You do have to apply some pressure for things like hard, firm, white potatoes to initiate the cut, but so long as you put a little of your weight into it wasn't a problem.  Once again, if the blades should become dull, this might be a bit of a chore.Clean up wasn't bad at all.  The bulk of the device can easily be cleaned in soap and water and--I believe--is even dishwasher safe. There is a cleaning tool that will help you easily pick food pieces from the top of the device, where there is a square pattern that helps prevent slippage.  Without the tool, this would be difficult to clean.  The blades are dangerously sharp. There is a thick plastic frame around each, so handling isn't a problem.  They generally rinsed clean well, but as far as I can tell, the blades themselves are not dishwasher safe.  Be very careful when cleaning to avoid injury.  (The blades are razor sharp the way blades on a mandolin slicer are sharp.  The thing that makes this device safer than the mandolin-type slicers is that everything is covered while you are doing the chopping so you don't expose your fingers to injury the same way.)Blades can be stored in the bottom of the closed chopper.  This is nice, as it means that there are no exposed sharp edges to snag and cut you if you are reaching for the device in the cabinet.One caveat: this is not the device you would use for industrial sized cooking.  The area of the cutting blades is small and some larger vegetables need to be cut down to fit the size of the cutting surface.  Additionally, you have to be careful about vegetable height, as the vegetable can't be too tall for the hinge.  But if you're preparing dinner for 1-8 people it worked just fine.  Another issue: the effectiveness of the chopper really depends on the fact that the blades are razor sharp.  They will likely become dull over time and if that happens the device will be close to useless.  The device--with the exception of the blades themselves--is made of hard plastic.  This is not an heirloom kitchen device that you will pass on to your children, but in practice seemed sturdy enough for the job at hand.On some level, this is a 3-trick pony: it slices and cuts strips in two sizes.  It is easy to discount this as yet another superfluous kitchen device, but the fact that it is small, easy to use, and does the job quickly make it a real asset and something that I used far more than I ever thought I would.  Simple things like chopping up onions for sauteeing: just strip the onions, stick them serially into the device, and--bam--you are done.  No lengthy dicing and the size of the chopped onions is uniform.  The same was true of making fries or cubing cheddar.  It was all much faster than usual and actually justified the time it takes to clean up the machine afterwards.I'm not a person who likes buying a kitchen device for every little chore, but although it's repertoire is limited, this one actually seems to work well and has become a go-to device in my kitchen.  Surprisingly, I like this device and see myself using it a lot in the future.  Recommended.

PROSFine shave--up there with the best of the electrics at a great price pointBetter foil shaving system than last iterationCan be used corded or uncordedBlades are easier to clean than last modelHead be cleaned under water5 minute quick charge featureDigital LED charge meterCompatible with international voltagesCONSLarge/BulkyLouder than Panasonic and Braun modelsFit and finish not quite on par with Panasonic and BraunNo carrying case providedCostly replacement foil at this point in time (over time, this will likely go down)OVERVIEWThe Remington F7-7800XCD Mens Shaver is a fine electric razor.  It rounds up the top of Remingtons mid-line range of shavers and definitely does the job as well as any electric razor. I last reviewed a Remington razor in 2009 (the F-5790, which is still available on Amazon as of this writing), and since that time Remington has made a number of innovations to improve its product line.  The result is an easier, faster shave and the shaver is easier to clean.IN THE BOXIn spite of the manufacturer number F7-7800XCD, the box is labeled F8.  Im not sure exactly why this is, but Im happy to round up.  Inside the box you will find, the shaver itself, a small stand, the power cord,  a small cleaning brush, and a cover for the shaver.  No carry case is provided, as you might find with other manufacturers.The shaver itself is true to Remingtons more modern design trend.  The shaver is long and has an ergonomic curve.  The bulk of the shaver is made out of black plastic.  All of this is sturdy enough, but this is not heirloom quality. The assumption is likely that you will replace the razor in 4 or 5 years.  Atop the shaver is the pivoting foil.  In the F7/F8 line this pivots front to back (in the higher FR line it also pivots side to side).  The stand is attractive enough and has little more heft than a coaster.  I was concerned that there would be a lot of balance problems, but the engineers clearly designed it with the shape and center of gravity of the shaver itself in mind; once attached, the shaver and base are surprisingly stable.The cord is upgraded from the last time I had a Remington.  The plug end is shaped like an oblong cylinder now and it is far lighter and smaller than my old Remington cord.  Happily, the cord can either attach to the base for charging or directly to the shaver.  The trend these days in less expensive electric razors is to have either a cord or a base but not both.  Corded is good, because it means if the shaver is not charged you can still plug it in and use it while it is charging.  A base is good because it gives you a place to park and charge the shaver while not in use.  Kudos to Remington for going retro and supplying both.  Of note, this shaver does adapt to international voltages (but you will need the proper adapter).This model has an amber LED light indicating the charge.  Full charge is indicated when the LED lights up to 60, as a full charge yields 60 minutes of shave time.  It takes 2 hours to charge fully, but you can do a 5 minute quick charge if you are in a rush or just shave with the cord attached.The cleaning brush is the simple type with shorter bristles at one end to clean the foil and longer bristles at the other end to touch up the rest of the shaver.  The included cover is opaque, black plastic, instead of the usual clear acrylic.  No issues here.Fit and finish on this shaver is pretty good, but it doesnt live up to the fit and finish on Braun models or Panasonic models that Ive used in the past.  The seams are less smooth and the overall feel is less solid and more plasticky.SHAVING EXPERIENCEThe shaver is easy to use, you simply turn it on and rub it against your face.  Unlike older models with a two or three foil array, this is a two foil model with an Interceptor component in the middle which has a more trimmer-like action.  This array takes care of the longer hairs, making them shorter and more available to the foil part for shaving.  The pivoting head is a nice touch, but in practice makes little difference while shaving.  In past models you could activate or deactivate the pivoting.  Here it pivots all the time, but once again this doesnt seem like a big issue.I found that the new blade array did make for a faster shave.  Unlike the old Remington, this was more comparable to my Panasonic shaver.  Although the results were on par with the Panasonic, the shave was a little rougher on the skin.  For those not used to using an electric razor, you do get used to this.  However, given its more gentle tendency, the Panasonic would make for an easier introduction to an electric shaver.The Remington is certainly louder than my Panasonic, but not as loud as my older Remington.The flip up trimmer is located in exactly the same place as it was on the previous model.  The trimmer works just fine, but given its location and the size of the shaver itself, it takes some practice to see where you are going.  If the trimmer popped out farther away from the shaver or was located at a higher level (impossible, because of the pivot) there would be fewer problems with visibility.NOTE: you need to change the blades/foil every 6 months to a year.  The foil itself for this model costs $24.99 at the time of this writing. This is a little pricey, as it does not include the replacement blades.  (For reference, the total cost for replacement foil and blades for my old Remington is $18.16 at the time of this writing.)  My guess is that this is a new model and that the price will go down.CLEANINGAlthough this is not a wet-dry shaver (dont use in the shower or with shaving cream), the body is sealed and the head of the shaver may be rinsed with water for cleaning.  Remington has taken a cue from Panasonic and increased the space between the cutting blades and arranged them more in loops.  The result is that the shaver is much easier to clean.  You generally can take of the foil cover, rinse under the tap, and let air dry.  Given the new blade design, I havent even had to use the brush for cleaning.  Very convenient.Unfortunately, they have not changed the design of the head array.  If stray hairs get caught in the sides and corners of the head array, the foil will not snap on.  If this happens, you simply need to clean out the wells and sides of the head piece and this will correct the problem.  My Panasonic does not have this problem because the bottom of the head assembly is generally flat and stray hairs just wash away.CONCLUSIONRemington has made some advances that make this shaver better than their last iteration and on par with the competition.  Remingtons shaver is still bulky, a little noisy, and lacks the fit and finish of its competitors, but it now gives a comparable shave at a much lower price point.  Its well worth the look.  Recommended.

PROSOrganized new interfaceImpressive fidelity with importing office documentsEasier editing capabilitiesCan add video, sound, 3D components to documentsMore 'windowslike' in behaviorFully functional form fillingFully functional form creationIncredible OCRNo crashes during testingCan save directly to Dropbox, Evernote, or Nuance CloudCONS:Still note quite a fully integrated windows programClip art is very basic/early 2000s type of stuffSome problems with editingOccasionally wonky commenting/annotating featuresNo PDF data collection featuresOVERVIEWNuance Power PDF standard is Nuance's latest iteration of its PDF manipulation software.  Nuance has ramped up the interface and made some major improvements, making this edition a winner.Power PDF replaces Nuance's PDF Professional line, a very powerful and competitive package with an incredibly clunky interface that didn't always play well with windows.Adobe will still be the go-to program for the true power user--it simply is at the cutting edge and is the gold standard in the field. But in terms of ease of use and the features that most people want, Power PDF will get you there--in style--for about 1/3 of the price you will pay for Acrobat Pro. (Don't let the 'standard' in Power PDF's title fool you: it's feature set is more akin to Acrobat Pro than Acrobat Standard.)THE LOOK AND FEELUnlike PDF Professional, Power PDF looks slick, like you are opening another Microsoft Office program.  Instead of a clunky, old-fashioned ribbon, there is a new tabbed interface.  Nuance takes cues from Microsoft, giving it simple, non-skeuomorphic set of icons that are easily recognizable. But it's not just the look, the menus are organized--something sorely lacking in Nuance's last offering.Now, I realize that some people really hate Microsoft's new tabbed approach, but when you are used to it from Office since 2008, it keeps things uniform and familiar. Moreover, the thoughtful organization makes it easier to find features.WORKS MORE LIKE A WINDOWS PROGRAMNuance's last offering really didn't behave like a Windows program.  For example, in the past, you had to open everything from the menu bar and cut and paste was often iffy.  Here you can simply throw your Office document into the PDF Professional window (or on top of it's menubar icon) and it just opens it.  Additionally, the style of the window matches Windows 7 and 8.1 much better.Not all is quite perfect in paradise, however.  You can open multiple documents, but they all reside in different windows.  And the style of the window fits in better with Windows' standard, but the fit is not perfect.  Still, everything is placed where it should be and the style is a good enough fit to prevent icon confusion and dissonance.In practice, almost all PDF manipulation programs (Adobe included) behave in a somewhat alien fashion compared to usual Windows programs.  It is unclear why this is, but it happens to be true.PDF CONVERSIONThis can now be done with a right click of the mouse and a simple save.  Even better, you have several options for right click conversion, including three different quality levels (standard, draft, publishing), company confidential, tagged PDF, MRC compression, or save as a searchable PDF.  Or you can just throw the document in the Power PDF window and edit before saving.The results are actually some of the best I've ever seen.  I tried converting many different kinds of documents and the fidelity was actually stunning.  Most processed to PDF without a glitch, whether they were Word, Powerpoint, or Excel.  Colors were unchanged and even layered graphics/text came out to near perfection.EDITINGNuance has actually made some great advances in editing.  For one thing, their old program had a tendency to crash a lot with editing.  This one seems rock stable.For another, many PDF programs have problems with mucked up spacing or paragraphing when you try to edit. Changing a few characters can mess up all the paragraphing below the correction.  Power PDF recognizes characters as characters. It basically places each line of text in its own text box, so that correcting one line will not affect any others.One major glitch on the editing, which only happened in a PDF I tried to edit that was made in Apple's Pages--if the font you wish to edit has no analogous font; you can erase text in that section but if you try to type text, Power PDF pops up an error window and will not allow you add text to edit that section.  There may be a work around, but I am not aware of it. (The best I could do was to erase the line altogether and add my own text.  Adding text can be done using the typing tool or going under the forms tab and adding a text field.  It's all a bit clunky, but such is the world of PDFs.)There is no way to 'paint on' a format to change the entire body of text to a font that Power PDF understands so that you can have full-featured editing.  On the one hand, it is nice that Power PDF can display the font effectively and even handle it like text even though it doesn't have the font available.  On the other hand, it puts you in a sticky editing situation, where you can delete letters but you can't replace them.Pictures and graphics are easily removed, replaced, or resized.  This even works with more complicated, layered graphics, although unless you select all the layers you will have to move them separately.There are no 'extra' types of formatting available.  No shadows, glow, fanciful colors, or 3D effects, but these kinds of things aren't standardThere are easy ways to add watermarks, rearrange pages, and bookmark pages/locations within the document.ANNOTATING/COMMENTINGThere are a variety of features for annotating PDFs that generally work well.  The pop-up, sticky note feature for changes works easily and as expected.Underlines, cross-outs, and highlighting, however, can be wonky. There were no problems in documents with simple layouts, but in more complicated ones are times where you try to underline, cross-out, or highlight and, instead of affecting the intended single word or line, you actually end up affecting a whole section.  Most of the time, you can fidget with it and get it to look right, but this should be a little easier.There are some advanced features, such as 'draw tools,' that allow you to place a 'pencil' mark, draw an oval, or box off an area that you want to comment on.  There are even 'callout' boxes with arrows that point to problem text.  So-called active mark up allows the allows you to annotate an area and at the same time a sticky note pops up titled with the moniker (e.g.'underline') that describes what the sticky note pertains to. There are other options for this as well if you highlight a word or section and right click a mouse you can cross-out text and choose a pop up that will say 'replace text' or 'insert text at cursor.'  Definitely a useful feature.As Nuance makes Dragon Naturally Speaking, you can even click on 'Dragon Notes' and dictate into your annotation boxes.  A nice feature.PDF FORMSPower PDF does a reasonable job at filling in and creating PDF forms is straightforward and very similar to other PDF programs.Adobe still reigns supreme here, with more specific types of forms that can be added (e.g. date forms with a pop-up calendar).  There is probably some way to program these in Java and have them for use in Power PDF, but that would be beyond the scope of my ability.The form fields available here are the standard button field, text field, check box, radio button, combo box, list box, and digital signature.  You can change the properties of the boxes with a right click or double click.  Most properties can be changed for multiple boxes, if you shift-click.  This will select multiple boxes in a row.  Oddly, you need to hit control-RIGHT click to select multiple, non-contiguous boxes.  A bit strange, but it works.In theory, you could produce forms from scratch using the program.  In practice, this would be difficult, as this program (and most PDF programs) lack the elegance and ease of use of a standard word processor.That said, Power PDF does an excellent job of picking up form fields correctly.  Lines become text fields and squares or circles will become check boxes (these would have to be changed to radio buttons if you only want to select one item out of a list).  On the whole, though, for simple forms, it makes things easier.There is an interesting compare option (for some reason under the home tab) that allows you to compare two PDFs.  The program will highlight the differences in the color of your choice.SECURITYDocuments may be made more secure using itms in the security tabs.  This allows you to set signatures, encrypt the documents contents, add password only access, require certificates, etc.  These are fairly straightforward.THE CLOUDSave options include Dropbox, Evernote, and Nuance Cloud Connector.DATAIf you are using PDF forms to collect specific PDF data, this program may not be the one for you.  Try as I may, I couldn't find any PDF data collection forms or a way to output PDF form data on to a spreadsheet.  That doesn't mean that it can't be done, but for the life of me I couldn't figure out how to do it. My guess is that this kind of feature is reserved for the Pro edition.NUANCISMSIn the past, Nuance has been criticized for poor customer support and difficulties regarding draconian security procedures leading to the dreaded activation issues.I have not tried customer support for this product, but their policies have much improved.  It used to be that you were only allowed a single phone call regarding Dragon Naturally Speaking products and over the past few years, they have been better about 30 day support.  Their website has a reasonably organized FAQ section and there is a vast user-contributed database of answers to common and not so common questions.As to security and activation issues, in my experience these things have been largely solved.  Over the past four years, I have not had a problem with a Nuance product (e.g. Dragon or PDF Professional 8) that refused to boot up after I swapped out a hard drive or connected/disconnected a multitude of USB devices.  I even seamlessly migrated a version of Dragon for the PC from one office computer to the other--the only caveat is that you MUST uninstall the program from machine #1 before you install it on machine #2.That said, there have been activation issue horror stories in the past with Nuance products.  I cannot deny them, I can only tell you that I have not personally experienced them.CONCLUSIONPower PDF is Nuances' slickest and best PDF creation and manipulation software to date.  Although Adobe Acrobat Professional remains the gold standard in the field, Nuance has come up with a program that has 98% of the features that most of us are looking for and is actually a whole lot easier to use than Adobe's offering.  Recommended.
