PROS:CompactKeyboard integrated with casePortableLong battery lifeBluetooth connects easilyUniversal fit for 7-8 inch tablets with different dimensionsCONS:Frustrating to use for the touch typistPoor tactile feelToo cramped for fast touch typingPoor layout choices hobble fast touch typingLittle ability to change the angle of the keyboardOVERVIEWThe Belkin QODE Universal Portable Keyboard is a serviceable, Bluetooth keyboard for 7-8 inch tablets.  It works reasonably well as a case and the keyboard is faster than typing directly on to the screen, but in the end the keyboard is just too small to allow for quick, touch typing.FULL REVIEWThe case itself is a simple, portfolio case.  The style of the flat, powder dull, black case mimics the Apple iPad smart and does reasonably well in terms of not showing too much in the way of fingerprints.  However, there is definitely something a little cheap about the feel.  The workmanship is okay, but the production values are clearly not at the highest industry standard, with the edges not perfectly aligned.  The inside surfaces of the case have a soft, microfiber texture and keyboard is recessed enough to protect your screen from scratches.  The battery life is acceptably long, reportedly 155 hours between charges.SETTING UPThe tablet is secured by four rubber brackets, which are connected to the case with elastic bands and thus can accommodate tablets with slightly different dimensions.  It was easy to secure the tablet and, once secured, it was easy to remove it from the case.  In concept, I thought that the system would be a bit dodgy, but once secured, the iPad mini stayed in place. The case can be configured on a table so that the tablet sits like a laptop.  There is little you can do to adjust the angle at this level. You can make it really shallow, but that was a poor angle to type with.  Even so, the angle was good for sitting and typing.  The case kept the tablet stable at the selected angle, so there were no worries about the tablet flopping around while you were typing.  Along with the viewing angle, it would be nice if there was some way to angle the keyboard while typing to help with position/wrist strain.  I have not seen a case where you can actually angle the keyboard itself, but this is a feature that would definitely be helpful.Bluetooth connection was straightforward and they keyboard connected easily to my iPad mini.MAJOR KEYBOARD ISSUESThe major problem with the case is the keyboard itself.  The first thing you notice when you try to type, is that this is a very cramped, chiclet keyboard.  Belkin made some bad choices when downsizing the keyboard.  First and foremost, they did not use the full width of the case.  Had the keyboard even been 1 inch wider, it would have been easier to type on.  Second, they fit in more keys at the bottom of the case by shrinking the space bar.  Not a bad compromise, as most people only use the inner part of the space bar anyway, but they went a little too far.  There is really very little space bar real estate and I found myself hitting the command or the  the ?/ keys, which flank the space bar, when trying to touch type.  The same can be said for the shift keys. The left shift key  poses less of a problem, but arrow-up is right below the right shift key and this causes some frustrating typing errors.The keys themselves are smaller than their large, chiclet key counterparts, which makes them very small targets, indeed. Given the size of the keyboard, they are crowded close together, leading to further typing errors.  Moreover, they are more mushy than clicky, making for a poor tactile experience.Even a small amount of expansion would have been welcome. Oddly, there is space above and below the keyboard which could have been used to expand the size of the keyboard vertically and there is plenty or space beyond the sides of the keyboard for horizontal expansion.  I still don't understand why Belkin decided to make the keyboard so small, when there was ample room to expand without changing the dimensions of the case.Even the keyboard from my ancient HP2133 would have almost fit within the constraints of this case, and the HP2133 keyboard is actually quite easy to type on.  Just small changes in dimensions and a better quality keyboard could have made all the difference.For now, I will continue to use a spare Bluetooth, iMac keyboard that I have, as this is a full size keyboard and works much better than any keyboard case that I have tried in the past.  (It's also not all that heavy and can be taken on the go, if necessary.)CONCLUSIONThe keyboard will work for you if you just want an upgrade from the onscreen, keyboard input.  However, it is more amenable to the hunt-and-peck typist than someone who is a fast touch typist.  For most touch typists, this keyboard will really slow you down given a combination of the crowded spacing of the keys, some poor choices in keyboard layout, and poor tactile feel of the keyboard.

When Ellis Rogers retires, his marriage was on the rocks, his best friend had betrayed him, and he was just been diagnosed with cancer.  Rather than wallow in misery, he uses his engineering skills and some misunderstood equations developed by a forgotten scientist, builds himself a time machine, and whisks himself away into the future.The Hollow World, by Michael Sullivan, follows Ellis' adventures in the utopian world that he has found. Avoiding any spoilers, suffice it to say that Ellis is not only unprepared for what he finds but is also the only one equipped to root out an evil plot that threatens this gentle, future world.Some aspects of Sullivan's future world are unique but others  are horribly cliched. There are a few inconsistencies as well.  But okay.  This may not be genius level science fiction, but for me it was an engaging read from start to finish.  And just when you think that Sullivan might be writing too predictably, he throws in a plot twist that changes everything.The book sometimes wanders a bit and you may not find yourself impressed by the depth of the characters, but Sullivan is a craftsman when it comes to writing an overarching plot and that is really what keeps the book moving.This may not be the book for someone who doesn't love a quick sci fi novel, but I'm a junky and Sullivan gave me my fix.  On the whole, a great effort and something that piqued my interest: I'll be looking for the next adventure in the Hollow World.  So if you are a fan of pulp sci fi, the kind that still tries to make you think at least a bit, this one may be for you.  For the right person (a person like me), I'd recommend it.

Without revealing spoilers or too much detail, Lankester recounts turbulent events that transpired after she unwittingly joined Ron 'the cigar' Sacco's illegal, California bookmaking operation in 1986.  As Lankester tells the story, she was really looking to become a race car driver in the CanAMex car rally.  Her racing partner, Jim Arnold, happened to work as a telephone and security technician for Sacco.  Using his connections, Arnold got Lankester a job as a bet taker so she could support herself until her racing career picked up.  This was the start of an 8 year roller-coaster ride, with the Sacco organization on the run and Lankester in tow, until the whole operation was taken down in 1994.Lankester is actually quite a good writer.  She concentrates less on description and motivation, saving most of the narrative for the action.  The book is rife with guns, intrigue, run ins with the law, love, sex, betrayal, bathos without a lot of pathos,a few bodies left behind, and very little time for serious self reflection.  But you get the idea that that was how things were for Lankester in 1986-1994. She doesn't glorify.  She doesn't justify.  She just tells. And she is quite a good teller.With the exception of a short hiatus after a big bust in 1987, when Lankester and her husband tried to settle down and become a dull, suburban couple, the book is all go, go, go. This is a fast and intriguing read; well worth the price of admission.While the book is a great read, there is one major caveat here: it is hard to completely trust Lankester as a narrator.  In a first person narrative, you take it for granted that you get a one-sided point of view.  I realize that memoir writers are not always interested in telling the whole truth, but Lankester paints a very selective picture and throughout the narrative seems far too naive.I have a hard time believing that she didn't understand why the US Government would want to shut down a $100 million  per month, $1.2 billion dollar per year, illegal, gambling enterprise. Did she really believe that there wasn't a crueler side to Sacco's organization?  Did she really believe that the government didn't care about Sacco recklessly flouting the law and not paying taxes? Did she really think that Sacco didn't have any ties to the mob when it was clear that he had to be working with the mob? I understand that when Lankester started off she didn't know the whole story. I understand that she was in it neck deep by the end.  But the fact that she stuck to it for so long hints that she might have been just a bit more than a telephone operator: Enquiring minds want to know.  You get the idea that Lankester softens her role in the operation in an attempt to avoid any kind of instigation that might arise after publishing the book.It is also a little disconcerting to see that the people that are benefiting from the story of the bust the most are Lankester and the FBI-hired conspirators who helped bring down Sacco's organization in California.  The two conspirators have since incorporated as a private investigation firm--touting their success in bringing down the entire Sacco operation (err... well, for at least a year before Sacco opened shop elsewhere) and that the two were almost certainly skimming money 'off the books' during the sting operation, all the while getting paid handsomely by the FBI.  When the most unlikely people seem to use a story to their own advantage and for their own purposes, it makes you wonder about how straight the narrative really is.Still, Lankester has lived a life that is better than fiction.  After reading the book, it is hard to imagine that this is an orthodox, historical account of the events, but, even so, it is still a great read.  Recommended.

PROSLess expensive than Microsoft OfficeCan open most popular document formats and many more older formats than most modern word processors (except .odt)Basic word processorAble to reveal (and correct) formatting codes more easily than in WordSmall footprint, compared to Microsoft OfficeCONSFew advantages over free alternatives (OpenOffice, Libre Office, Google Office, etc.)Old-style, clunky interfaceLacks true, contextual menusMore primitive formatting optionsVery difficult to make modern, professional looking documents (such as a newsletter)No mirror effect in formatting objectsNo instant alpha/background removal for picturesNo included picture formatting/advanced editing featuresShadow effect in pictures is at best rudimentaryTemplates are generally uncharismatic and  anachronisticHeavy formatting/styling is difficult at bestUnable to convert PDFs to office documents in the Home/Student EditionUnable to complete fillable PDFs in Home/Student EditionNo cloud capabilitiesNot compatible with most third party footnote/end note softwarePresentations are not polishedVery poor presentation templatesFew slide transitionsMost macros do not translate over from Microsoft OfficeLightning is a rudementary digital note book; free options have better interface and better capabilitiesOVERVIEWIf I am paying for software in 2014 it has to be more than simply functional: it needs to be easily accessible, have an interface that is easy to navigate, and it needs to produce beautiful documents effortlessly.  More important, the software has to do some thinking for itself: I want contextual menus so I don't have to hunt through multiple menus of features before I find what I want.Although Corel Office X7 may have a lot of power under the hood, it lacks these capabilities and lacks modern fit and finish.  It falls far short of the latest Microsoft Office Suite and Apple's iWork Suite.  In fact, there are some fairly polished, no-cost options such as Open Office, Libre Office, Google Office, and the desktop version Kingsoft Office that will have a more modern and intuitive interface, are easier to use, and actually provide equal--if not better--compatibility with the corporate, Microsoft Office standard.I am sure that there are die-hard WordPerfect fans, who have continuously used this program for years and would never use anything else.  The fact is, I really wanted to like WordPerfect--I have fond memories of it from the 90s when it was features ahead of the curve--but there is little to praise in this latest iteration, as there is little to separate WP X7 from the free competition.  As the free versions of office suites have matured, WP X7 has a hard time distinguishing itself from the pack and it doesn't come close to the latest offerings from Microsoft or Apple.I will first address general issues and then discuss the components of the Corel Office X7 Home Student package.INSTALLThe software install was straightforward.  You are offered an install of Word Perfect X7 and a second install for extras (like clip art).  I went with the complete install, soup to nuts.  I'm not sure why you have to go through with two installs--these days you'd expect to click off the options you want and then a single install would be complete--but it was easy enough, so I'm good with it.  No issues here.OLD-STYLE INTERFACEWhen you open Word Perfect X7 (or any part of the WP office suite), you will be transported back to the halcyon days of 2003.  Residing on top of your document you will find the old-fashioned ribbon menu, not seen in Microsoft Office after Word 2007.There was a lot of brouhaha when Microsoft updated the ribbon in 2007, as 'everything changed,' and all my features were afloat, lost in a strange sea of clickable tabs.  But in the end, I believe, Microsoft was actually right.  Once you got used to the tabs, it is, indeed, easier to find what you want to find.  And when you select something in your document, the tabs switch to what you want in context.  A very clever innovation.Not so in Word Perfect X7.  The tiny, crowded icons on Word Perfect's ribbon are lined up like two rows of soldiers at the top of your document.  No longer used to the anachronistic menu, it took me a while to reorient myself.  I was as surprised at the wayback machine as I was at my inability to navigate it easily--my it has been so long!The old-style ribbon has its advantages.  For one, everything you usually use is tucked in at the top of the menu. The program defaults to displaying the WP menu and the formatting menu. The first problem, as you will remember, is finding where everything else is.  Most of the sub menus are hidden, but can be added to the ribbon by going to view-->toolbars and then clicking on other options (such as 'drawing').  The problem is, as you reach a critical mass of menus, you occupy more screen real estate atop of the document.  Additionally, the more menus you add, the more crowded things get up there and it's harder to find what you want.  When clicked to life, the `extra' menus appear as floating windows.  By double clicking the menu bar, you can embed them in the main menu.  There are some glitches here.  First, clicking on the PDF menu just added an empty ribbon bar.  This may be because the PDF stuff is now on the main ribbon or because the Home and Student edition doesn't have advanced PDF features; either way, this should have been cleaned up after beta testing.  The second problem is the addition of rows.  In the later versions of Word with the old ribbon, you could move the ribbons around and show what you wanted to show.  Here, you are stuck adding rows.  If you try to move the ribbon, the floating window pops up again.  This limits efficient use of screen real estate.In order to make up for the lack of more modern, contextual menus in this early, uncharismatic, 2000s paradigm, the WP folks have created their own contextual menu ("Word Perfect Expert");  an equally uncharismatic, column adorned with horizontal., gray-pinstriped and with text that is fixed to the left side of the screen.  This isn't a terrible solution, but it uses words and not icons for options and takes up too much screen real estate.  You can minimize it, but then you lose your contextual menu.  WP does have at least one contextual menu that is reliable: this is the drawing menu.  When you click on a picture or drawn object on your document, the Word Perfect Expert vaporizes, pin stripes and all, and you will find a leaner, vertical column of  buttons for various drawing options in its place.  Not bad, but you first need an object on board to see this, as there is no way to toggle this left-sided menu using the WP expert column.Word Perfect used to be the chameleon of word processors. Quite cleverly, the WP programmers realized that if you wanted to get people to switch from another word processor, you should allow them to customize the ribbon to resemble their word processor of choice.  This can still be done, but sadly you are unable to manipulate the toolbar to resemble anything past "Word 2002"--not very helpful in a more modern era.  One of the free options, Kingsoft Office (desktop edition), allows you to change the menu from the traditional ribbon to the post Word 2007 one, so it's not as though this kind of thing is impossible.In another, odd anachronism, not all menus in the toolbar are completely embedded.  In more modern software, you might click on the menu item and you get a drop down.  If you highlight a selection on the drop-down, you then get another drop-down.  Here, for example, when you click "view" and then highlight `toolbars" this opens a floating window with check box options instead of another embedded menu with options you can highlight.  This is not a bad thing per se, but is another blast from the past.LIMITED FORMATTING OPTIONSIn using this office suite, it is clear that there has been a lot of building up done in Word Perfect X7 but not a lot of thoughtful rebuilding and restructuring.  The bones of the program are good but the interface suffers.This can be seen when applying formatting.  For example, when you format text in Word 2014, the font names in the drop down are written in their own particular style.  As you scroll through different fonts, the actual text in the document changes.  WP X7 goes old style, with the drop down menu in plain text, with the font shown in a pop up window next to the drop down. The text in the document does change, but there is a significant lag time whereas in Word this is instantaneous.  Worse, when you draw shapes, you must double click on them to bring up the object properties window.  There you can select different fill colors/patterns. You will see the 'preview' in an example box in the upper right of the object properties window, but you will not see changes made to your shape until you click 'okay.'  Not bad for 2004, 10 years later, you should be able to see this preview on the actual drawing in your document.This pattern seems to be pervasive in WordPerfect X7, with virtually every change--from slide coloration and themes in Presentations to table formats in WordPerfect--occurring in a tiny box rather than being previewed within the document.LIMITED STYLING OPTIONSStyles for documents and text are similarly Neanderthal.  It is very easy to make a three dimensional charts and drawings in Microsoft Office and iWork.  Everything is early-2000s-flat in Word Perfect.  The ability to design attractive documents and figures is just not there.  Short of importing drawn elements from another program, you would be hard pressed to make them in WP X7.  Sure, you can whip up a 3D bar graph, but it will look like vintage early 2000s stuff.  I'm not saying that Open Office or Google Docs will do you any better in this regard, but if you are paying for software, you want the latest and greatest and the the bar has been raised for bar graphs since 2007.This is especially a problem when using templates.  The choice of templates for WP is limited and really a throwback to a bygone age.  Everything is flat and unengaging.  My 12-year-old can create a professional looking newsletter for her class in Microsoft Office 2013 or iWork.  You just open the template, lay down some text, and swap out a few pictures.  Wham!  Courtesy of easy-to-use-software, it looks like she's some kind of document prodigy.I suppose it could be done in WP X7, but it would take a lot of picture imports and grunt work to get the text to line up.  That said, picture enhancements are virtually nonexistent: you will have to edit the picture before putting it into a WP document.  Moreover, there are no frames, no instant alpha/background removal,  and no reflection options.  Shadows are possible in drawn objects but are a flat, unrealistic gray, whereas in Word and iWork, they are realistic and make objects look like they are floating off the page.MISCELLANEOUS ANACHRONISTIC FEATURESNot to get off track, there are some other anachronistic features worth highlighting.  I'm all for remembering old friends, but it's been a long time since I've cared to save a document in Ami Pro 1.2-3.0, DisplayWrite 4.0 to 5.0, MultiMate 3.3-4.0 format, Professional Write 1.0-2.2, Volkswriter 4, Wordstar 2.2 to 2000 3.0, and (!) XyWrite III Plus 3.55-4.0.  According to Wikipedia, there is an article from 1986 titled, "Volkswriter 3 Is a Word Processor Not Likely To Be Outgrown," but I haven't seen hide nor hair of it since 1991.Why they included AmiPro and some other dead (and nearly dead) word processors from the 80s and 90s and forgot to add open document format (.odt) capabilities is a mystery to me. I would be ecstatic about the old formats if I was a Luddite and my trusty Kaypro 10 just crashed a final, horrible crash; but in the modern age--and the age of Google Docs and OpenOffice variants--open document format is just more useful.NOTE: in the student edition, you can SAVE to PDF but you CANNOT import from PDF.  For that you need the professional version.  I think this is a major misstep from the WordPerfect folks.  If you are trying to sell a second tier program to the public, you need to supply it with options that make it more attractive than the 'gold standard.' PDF import capabilities might have separated this out from the pack.NO CLOUD CAPABILITIESCorel Office X7 has no cloud capabilities.  Sure, with Microsoft, you will have to pay for this.  But Apple provides iCloud and Google Office is a native cloud-based office suite.  These days, accessibility is important and the ability to save documents to the cloud is almost expected.WORDPERFECT X7The overall experience is not all that different from using OpenOffice, LibreOffice, or Google Docs.  If you are writing simple, unadorned documents this is an easy word processor to use.The spell check was easy and conventional.  The grammar checker was strictly okay but sub par when compared to the Microsoft Word version.Conversion of the more conventional Microsoft Office documents was strictly okay.  Anything with heavy formatting (such as a newsletter) came up with an error or all ajumble.You can insert footnotes and endnotes within the program, but it does not appear to be compatible with standard reference tracking software such as Zotero or Stat!Ref. There is apparently a work around for Zotero, involving .rtf files and having Zotero itself insert the references without using a word processor, but this means that you won't be able embed references in real time.  Reference Manager had a plug in for WordPerfect X3, but I do not know whether they maintained WP compatibility.  Lack of a plug in for a major reference manager may limit the use of WP for those in academia.What Wordperfect does far better than Word or Apple's Pages is reveal the edit codes.  Reveal codes actually allow you to easily clean up wonky formatting.  Once you see where the word processor went wrong, you can delete the codes that are causing the quirky display and easily move right along.  Word does this in some shape or form, but it's not as good as WP.  I really don't know if this is even an option for Apple's Pages.If you want to create complicated and professional documents with ease, this is not the word processor for you. With a lack of templates and old-fashioned style options, any stylized document will look like you designed it 10 years ago.  If you really want to make a modern looking document, you would have to fashion the graphics using another program and import them as pictures in WP.PRESENTATIONSYou could argue that spit and polish in text documents is just vanity, but in presentation software the glitz is the stuff that presentations are made of.Basic templates are a wash here.  The available templates are flat, dull, and uncharismatic.  You can import Powerpoint templates, but the more complicated ones don't translate all that well.  Free office suite options also have fairly cruddy stock templates, but seem to translate Powerpoint ones better.Slide making is easy enough, it is just that the options are limited.  The transitions are limited and really stink compared to Powerpoint or Apple's Presentations.  There are options for flow sheets and embedding graphs, but the results are fairly crappy and two dimensional compared to Microsoft and Apple options.  Animation options are there, but control is limited.  There is little difference between WP Presentations and the other non-paying options.You can import Powerpoint format but the results are less than stellar.  Complicated animations are usually way off, backgrounds can be skewed, pictures may change positions, picture backgrounds eliminated in Powerpoint may return (or the picture may be rendered as square with a white background), and even the text is usually skewed or set in the wrong place.  More complicated presentations will require a lot of clean up.  Once thing that was particularly irksome is that shadowed text from a Powerpoint presentation looked more like double letters when things were converted over to WP Presentations.If all you want is a simple presentation, Presentations will work out okay.  However, the standard for design has changed over the past 10 years, and what looked good in 2004 looks silly and dated in 2014.  Say what you will about style over substance, but style is truly what modern presentation software is about.QUATTROPRONo major complaints other than the interface.  The program functions like a standard spreadsheet program.  It is simple to input data and manipulate it.The problem is that Quattro Pro X7 does very little to separate itself from the free competition. The fact is that Microsoft Excel, for all its flaws, is the corporate standard here.  It has more mathematical functions and operations than Quattro Pro and the macros are not compatible cross platform.  Moreover, there are a lot of third party plug-ins for Excel that won't work in Quattro Pro.Realize, though, that Quattro Pro is more mathematically adept than any of the free office suites.  It appears to be more sophisticated, function wise, than Apple's Numbers as well.  Microsoft, however, still has a little edge at baseline and after you consider the third party add ons, Excel probably wins the race of the most 'functional' spreadsheet program.In terms of displaying your data, Quattro Pro is unable to beat the competition.  You cannot make attractive graphs the same way that you can in Excel or Apple's Numbers (with Apple taking a major lead in this category).  Microsoft and especially Apple's Numbers can really display data in a meaningful and attractive way that Quattro Pro simply can't. Back in the day, you might have crunched your numbers in a spreadsheet and then exported them to another program, like SigmaPlot, to get a more attractive picture or have a better way to display the data.  Nowadays, for all but the most rigorous and scientific-based users, there is little need to have one program to crunch some data and another to display it.  For most power users and corporate users, Excel or Numbers does a fine in manipulating and displaying the data attractively. Quattro Pro can crunch with the best of them, but loses in terms of display.LIGHTNINGLightning is an okay digital notebook.It is eminently usable but it's interface is simply not as attractive or easy to use as Microsoft's One Note (it's very Windows 2000 in feel).  This is made worse by the fact that there are programs like Evernote that take the note idea to the next level, with a more modern interface and a way to access your notes on the web or from your mobile devices.CONCLUSIONCorel Office X7 is not a bad office suite, it just has almost little to recommend it above the free options out there.  I am not averse to spending money on software that makes my life easier.  However, there is little here that is all that different and a lot that is regressive about Office X7 in comparison to the free office versions out there.  The particular standout in the free field was (surprisingly) the desktop version of Kingsoft Office.  It is more limited than Microsoft Office but it is a virtual clone of Microsoft Office.  If you have lighter needs and are used to Microsoft products, Kingsoft isn't a bad way to go.Corel Office X7 offers stability and a better price point the Microsoft, but it lacks in areas of compatibility and has an aging and clunky interface.  As I stated before, the bones of this program are good.  There is no reason why Corel couldn't give this product a long, overdue overhaul and set things right. Additionally, if they threw in some cloud capability, worked with third party vendors for some major plug-ins and tie ins, and added value (e.g. advanced PDF capabilities, eBook capabilities that they offer in their `professional' version) at a lower price point, they could potentially have a winner.  But as things stand, there is little here that you can't get free and when the free competition is actually easier to use, it's hard to justify this software at any price.Sadly, I cannot recommend this product.

PROS:Relatively straightforward constructionAdjusts from about 4 to 7 basket heightSturdy for a basketball hoop with a weighted basePlays like a real basketball hoopHoop will accomodate regulation sized basketballsCONS:Included tools will work but things go much faster with a ratchet setNot regulation heightAs with any freestanding, weighted-base hoop there will be some movement with playOVERVIEW:The SKLZ Pro Mini Hoop Poolside System is a scaled-down version of a regulation free-standing hoop that would work well at poolside or can be used on-ground as a nice starter system for children.  It is easy to put together, is built to last, and has all the features you would expect of its larger cousins in a smaller package.CONTENTS OF THE BOXInside the box you will find the many parts to the hoop itself, a deflated mini-basketball, two disposable wrenches to help with construction, and the instructions.PUTTING IT TOGETHERUnlike many, similar products, the SKLZ product was easy enough to put together.  The directions were helpful, albeit the writing and the diagrams were nearly microscopic.  That said, my kit went together without a hitch.  Im somewhat methodical when I do these things but constructed it solo in under an hour.  There are some parts to the contruction that might work a bit better with 4 hands, but 2 hands were sufficient.  The included wrenches could be used to put the thing together, but as with most such equipment its better to use your own tools if you have them.  I tried valiantly to make it work with the included tools, which probably explains the time requirement.  About half way through I gave it up and went with my ratchet set.  If I started with the ratchet set, it would have sped things up considerably.One bit of advice: be careful not to overtighten the bolts that connect the net to the backboard: if you do the net will angle downwards.  There is also a nut at the base of the spring behind the net that can be loosened or tightened to make the basket level.FUN AND GAMESThe mini-hoop set up itself is nice. The traditional black and orange have been changed to an attractive aqua and white (ostesnibly to match the usual outdoor pool colors).  The hoop is easily adjustable with the pull of a single pin to  itself is scaled down, and adjusts from a minimum of about 4 feet to a maximum height of 7 feet high.  This may disappoint some budding LeBrons and Kobes, but you have to realize that this hoop was really meant as a pool side hoop.  When you are shooting a basket from inside a pool, you are probably standing in at least 4 feet of water--a standard sized hoop at poolside would be a towering 14 feet high for you.  So as a poolside rig, this thing is about right.  If you are using it, as I do, as a hoop for kids, this is just about the right height for the 14 year old and under set.But it is even fun for adults.  Sure its smaller, but when you play with the pint sized basketball that comes with it, its a fun and fast game.  Also, its nice to be able to dunk at 54, something I can never do on a 10 foot hoop! (I almost feel like Yao Ming!)  Whats really nice, though, is that the hoop really plays like the big boys.  SKLZ didnt build it cheap just because it is a small hoop.  There will always be a little jiggling with a free standing hoop that is not anchored in the ground, but this one is one of the more solid hoops out there.  Additonally, the backboard is solid acrylic and doesnt bend or warp when you hit it hard with a basketball.  The hoop itself behaves like a regulation basketball hoop, with a spring at the bottom.  You get the idea that this set up will have some staying power.The hoop is wide enough to accomodate a regulation sized basketball.  However, given the heft of a regulation sized ball and the relative weight of the apparatus and smaller sized base, you will cause jiggling and movement if you slam the net with the basketball pretty hard.  But you can definitely go nuts with the pint sized ball.This is a nice little mini-hoop that thinks like a regulation sized basketball set up.  Rather than making a flimsy kiddie hoop, SKLZ has worked small but thought big.  This hoop works well at poolside and would be a great, free standing hoop for smaller children who are learning how to play. (It really beats the pants off of the usual, little-kid mini-basketball hoops.)  Its even fun for a casual one-on-one for upper teens and adults.  Its different kind of game, where even at 55 I can showcase my dunking skills.  Its good for a whole lot of non-regulation, summer fun!  Recommended.

PROS:Sturdy constructionBlades self-contained in the mandolineSimple adjustment for thickness of cut5 different bladesComfortable hand guard on hopperCONS:Individual blades are hand wash only (the body is dishwasher safe, though)No safety cover when storingCourse and fine grating results are not much differentThe Cuispiro Hand Held Mandoline is a reasonable iteration of this simple type of kitchen device with a couple featues that make it stand out in the field.Mandoline slicers are simple kitchen devices that basically use a slant board and a reverse mounted blade to help yo quickly slice fruits and vegetables into uniform slices with little effort. The food is placed in a hand held hopper so that you dont accidentally slice your finger as you are trying to slice the food.  Different conformations of blades can be placed on the slantboard to cut or grate food to order.  Handheld slicers llike this seem to work best for quick, small to medium sized jobs.  If you are looking at doing your slicing in bulk, it probably makes more sense to bring out the food processor or similar device.The Cuisipro has a large, easy to grip, rubberized handle.  It has rubberized feet that do not slip on the countertop and a notch at the base so that it is easy to use over a bowl.  Blades are conveniently stored on the mandoline itself.  This is a nice feature as you dont have to worry about losing a blade, but it does limit the number of blade choices that may be used. The blades are engaged by slipping them into the active slot and do not require any complex snapping or mounting procedure.  This is a nice touch, as mandoline blades tend to be quite sharp and many an injury can occur snappinga blacde in and out of a device.  There are  3 blades that can be configured for basic slicing, crinkle cutting, waffle cutting, French fry cutting, julienning (thinner than a fry cut), and grating.  The blades comfortablly snap in and snap out and the way it works there is little risk for injury.  There is a knob on the side to adjust the thickness of the cut, which is also a nice tough.The hopper is oversized and has three metal prongs that keep your food in place.  The grip is easy to hold and, once a vegetable is secured, it is easy enough to cut.  That said, some things work better in the hopper than others.  Potatoes and apples seemed to work the best for me.  Carrots and parsnips are difficult to slice, unless you are slicing the thicker bases, as they arent held all that well by the three metal prongs.  Onions were a mixed bag.  If you are trying to slice an onion that is on the mushier side, forget it.  A crisp, firm Vidalia, though, worked just fine for me.The actual slicing worked really well for potatoes, sweet potatoes, and apples.  Anything large and crisp seemed to work the best.  The blades are razor sharp and you can quickly slice through a large, crisp veggie easily and get nice uniform slices no matter what the setting.  Things like carrots and parsnips are generally too narrow to work in the hopper.  You can easily do them if you forgo the hopper; this is not recommended, however, as it is all too easy to slice your finger.  Once again, less crispy vegetables and slightly soft onions did not work well at all in this system and should probably be done in a food processor.The grating attachment has two sides.  One for a fine and the other for a more coarse grate.  I didnt see much of a difference in the size of the final product.  The mandoline works better with hard cheeses but will have a more difficult time grating softer varieties.  The blades themselves appear to be well made.  Its hard to say, of course, how well the blades will hold up over time.One issue I had with this mandoline is that there is no cover for the blades when storing the device. Most of the blades are safely stowed on the machine but there is always on exposed in the cutting position and there should have been a safety cover on this for storage.  Cleaning the blades must be done by hand and is something that you will have to do in a very careful manner, as the blades are very sharp.  It would have been nice if the blades could be cleaned in the dishwasher.This is not the most advanced mandolin device on the market and only has limited number of blades.  However it does work as expected and is quick and easy to use kitchen tool.

Disobeying Hitler, by Randall Hansen, is a study of resistance against Hitler during the Third Reich. The book is clearly written by a scholar in this area and is likely of academic significance. However, as a lay reader I found myself wanting to like the book more than I did.The book starts with a cursory description of Operation Valkyrie,  the July 20, 1944 attempt to assassinate Hitler led by GeneralFredrich Olbricht,  Major General Henning von Tresckow, and Colonel Claus von Stauffenberg. He then describes the aftermath, where distinguished Nazis such as Rommel turned against Hitler because they felt the war was hopeless.  Although Valkyrie failed, Hansen suggests that it became a rallying point for all subsequent, meaningful resistance to the Nazis.After describing Valkyrie and its aftermath, Hansen goes on to describe the actions of a number of German Generals who defied Hitler's 1945 Nero Decree that ordered a scorched earth policy.  Instead of  blowing up bridges, demolishing factories, demolishing the water supply, doing irreparable damage to the power grid, and fighting the allies to the last man, a number of Nazi generals took it upon themselves to put up only a token resistance and ignore Hitler's orders and defying the SS.  By doing this, these renegade generals preserved European cities and avoided countless civilian deaths from collateral damage and starvation.  This also prevented a major post World War II refugee problem.Hansen describes in detail how the actions of General Dietrich von Choltitz preserved Paris and likely saved the lives of countless Parisians.  He then goes on to describe how similar actions of other commanders, backed up by civilian lobbying, saved cities such as Dusseldorf and Heidelberg.  The stories of the cities are interesting, but there are times where Hansen gets bogged down describing troop movements in detail or lingers too long on the motivations of the allies.  The detailed descriptions, of course, are of great academic importance, but are tedious for the casual reader.Hansen also vividly describes how the actions of Albert Speer in thwarting the Nero Decree.  Speer used the Nazi bureaucracy to add layers of approvals that were required to implement the scorched earth policy and urging Nazi generals to avoid unnecessary self-sacrifice and destruction.  Hansen does an excellent job of painting a vivid picture of a very complex man.  In the end, though, it didn't really change my opinion of Speer all that much.  Speer never renounced Nazi ideals, he just knew that the war was lost.  In the end, he acted more for self preservation than anything else.  Even when you read Speer's own writings, it seems clear that he was acting to save what was left of Germany and had a vision that he would become a major leader in Germany's post war reconstruction.In Rise and Fall of the Third Reich, William Shirer pretty much sums up German resistance during the war as too little, too late.  Shirer felt that German resistance in the latter part of WWII did not represent a real change in heart within the German military.  Few were swayed by ethical concerns regarding Holocaust victims.  Most were motivated by self preservation and the understanding that there was no value in destroying cities and fighting on when the war was already lost.Hansen's book definitely gets the point across that Shirer's view only works when you are looking from the outside in.  It would have been far less of a personal risk--even the path of least resistance--for leaders in the Wehrmacht to toe the party line and simply follow orders.  Those commanders who refused to do Hitler's bidding avoided needless civilian and army casualties and avoided needless destruction of European cities.  However, they put themselves at great personal risk to do so, and because of this some commanders paid the ultimate price for this.The book is a very detailed account of Nazi post resistance and certainly has a great academic value and merit.  Unfortunately, it is a difficult read and is hard to recommend to the more casual reader.

I have purchased Hemp Hearts from this company before, and I liked the taste/flavor. I saw these come across in my Vine account, which means that I get to try the bars as long as I leave a review. I was excited and just had my first bar for breakfast....and I was very disappointed.First, the good. The ingredients are few- hemp hearts, organic coconut palm sugar, organic brown rice syrup, dried apple, cinnamon, organic apple flavor, pectin, organic sunflower oil, organic caramel flavor, rosemary extract. Yeah, a good dose of sugar (10g) in the bar, but overall, nothing too offensive. You get a good dose of protein (10g) and Omega 3's & 6's (10g total...doesn't say what the split is on each omega). One bar only has 230 calories.Second, why I was disappointed- the taste. As I said, I really, really wanted to like these bars. But the taste just wasn't that good. I could definitely pick up the hemp heart flavor (which I don't mind), but the apples and cinnamon flavor was so minimal. Overall, it was quite bland. And you know how you have an initial flavor, and as you keep chewing, that flavor might change? I wasn't a fan of the second flavor. I almost stopped eating the bar halfway through, but I trucked on, hoping that maybe it would get better if I finished the bar. It didn't.Taste is so subjective, so maybe you'll enjoy the bars. I would perhaps find them in a health food store and try one bar before you go ahead and buy a whole box like this....that way, if you don't like them, you're not stuck with a ton of them! I wish I could say better things- I really do- but I just am not a fan.

Pretty good TP. The rolls really are "mega" size- quite large! There are no frilly patterns or scents- just simple toilet paper. However, just because it's simple doesn't mean it's cheap in quality. I was impressed right away with how soft it was, and when I asked my boyfriend if the new Charmin stuff was on the roll in the bathroom, his first words agreed- "It's really soft!" Good quality stuff. I'd recommend it!

This is a pretty nice light! I have it next to my computer and love how it doesn't create glare on my screen. I have it on the brightest setting, and I think it's nice that you can dim it if needed (by holding your finger on the area that turns the lamp on). There is no on/off switch as you might expect- instead, at the top of the lamp, you just have to touch the power "area" and the light comes on.I like how the light is flexible, since it has an arm. On the bottom of the unit, it even comes with a hex wrench- in case the joints get loose, you can tighten them back up. I appreciate how the base is flat- while the base is large, this ability saves space in a way since I can stack items on top of the base of the lamp. Finally, I also like that it has the capability of charging up an item via USB (there is one port at the front of the base). Neat idea!My only qualm is that it's not the most attractive thing in the world to me. It's pretty narrow so it doesn't stand out horribly or anything, but it looks a little....robotic, in a way....to me. It probably would look great modern/tech-y style room. The look wasn't enough to really knock down the lamp's rating to 4 stars....it's more of an opinion rather than a malfunction/item issue.Overall, practical, great use of space, good light (and it's a nice, white, bright light too- great for reading/desk work!). I'd recommend it!

I like these treats for my dog because it's a brand I trust and I approve of the ingredients (I have the yogurt, apples, and banana). The ingredients are better than what you would find in some "cheaper" brands of treats- not so much "filler" junk. You also get a lot of treats in the package, and the bars are of decent size (maybe about an inch long). I have a lab/corgi mix who is about 30 lbs; these are a great size treat for her. Better yet- she loves them and approves of them too!

This is my favorite brush. Over the years, I think I've purchased about 4 of them. One to keep at home, one in my travel stuff, one in my gym bag, and one to replace my home one that I lost. It works well and doesn't fall apart (I hate it when other brushes lose the bristles if they get stuck in a knot!). It also doesn't make my hair full of static in the winter. If I ever need an extra brush, I will be buying another of these!

Beautiful cards. I always plan to read just one per day, but I find myself unable to stop going through them to see what information is next (and the illustrations are whimsical and beautiful too- I love looking at those!). Glad I bought them!

I love the huge variety of sequences (everything from sequences for those that sit at a computer all day, to "poses that would be awkward naked" LOL)- it's easy to find something to do based on what you did/how you feel on a particular day. The pictures are also pretty adorable!If you're new to yoga, you might want to buy some sort of companion book that tells you HOW to do the poses (or look online). This book just has many different sequences to choose from so you can build a home practice, but doesn't go about walking you through getting into the poses, modifications, etc. I am not new to yoga myself, and I found myself looking up a few that I was unfamiliar with here and there.This book has motivated me to keep a home practice going. I was getting stagnant and not doing much....the variety in sequences and lengths is really appealing to me and it definitely makes me want to do yoga more often again!
I bought these for my classroom. Great set- inexpensive, tons of popsicle sticks in the box- it will last a long time!

These actually aren't too bad. I was wary due to the inexpensive price, but I got them to use with my Diver mp3 player since everyone said the headphones with that were awful (and they were). These work, but I wish that the ear pieces had different sizes- one of my ear canals is a bit different than the other.I found this out when I sucked it up and invested in higher-quality waterproof headphones (that cost about $70)....they had different sizes and shapes, and those definitely were a LOT more comfortable in my ears than these cheap ones. However, as I said, these cheap ones aren't awful and are a good starter set (especially if you are saving up to eventually invest in a better pair). I had them for a couple of months before upgrading, and they were still working just fine for me.

My grandma passed away recently, and I wanted something to keep in my room as a remembrance of her. I have a couple other Willow Tree angel figurines and decided to find one to add for Grandma; I found this one and absolutely love it. Like all other Willow Tree figurines, it is so incredibly beautiful....and it helps remind me that Grandma is still with me, watching over me, in Heaven.

My dog's daily afternoon treat is about 1/3 slice of American cheese shoved into her Kong, with a Stuff'N snack shoved in to pin the cheese in place and make it more difficult for my dog to get to. She LOVES it! I always bought the peanut butter flavor snacks before, but these ended up being less expensive one day. My dog likes the bacon & cheese flavor just as much as the PB flavor :).

I am in love with this key rack. It is so adorable and has great character- I love that it's made of cast iron (but note that also makes it heavy!). Along with looking great, it is also functional (very important! :)). It's a bit on the small size- check the measurements- but I didn't need anything substantial/huge and am very happy with the way this looks in my house. Great item!

The material is a little cheap and flimsy-feeling, but it functions well and looks okay above the plastic back wall part of my shower (see picture) to give me some extra storage space. It's a good size and I like the "railings" around the shelf, so nothing falls off. I also like that the bottom of the shelf has holes so my bar of soap can dry, and it also works well for sticking a toothbrush into :)

I love this bolster! It is thick, dense, and great for my home yoga practice. It's comparable to what I've used in yoga classes in studios- very high quality. I also like that it has a handle on one end.

I use these to sort my high school kids into groups. There are four different colors and 6 different animals, so I can hand all the animals out and either have the kids get with the people with the same animal as them (making 6 groups of 4), or with the same color as them (making 4 groups of 6). They're cute and just a fun way to "spice" it up in my classroom!I also have the dinosaurs; the jungle animals have a different color that the dinos do not have (the animals have purple and the dinos have blue), so I can even add in an extra set of animals/colors to group kids in more ways than what I mentioned above.

I use these to sort my high school kids into groups. There are four different colors and 6 different dinosaurs, so I can hand all the dinos out and either have the kids get with the people with the same dinosaur as them (making 6 groups of 4), or with the same color as them (making 4 groups of 6). They're cute and just a fun way to "spice" it up in my classroom!

I have tried to put together the metal frames for hanging folders before, and they can be difficult to work with (having to snap/cut off metal pieces so it fits in the drawer, etc). I REALLY like how easy this frame is to set up- you could probably figure it out without even looking at the instructions. It fits in my file cabinet nicely; I like that it is so easy to adjust.The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because it's not quite as sturdy as the metal stands that usually go in file cabinets. I had to fix the legs a couple of times because they would bend inward, and then the whole system would become a little sturdy. I had to adjust the legs a few times so they would stand straight up and down (as in the picture). Overall, I consider this a minor flaw since I appreciate the ease of how easy the frame is to set up (no tools needed!), how you can use the frame in just about any drawer, and the fact that it works!

When you consider the amount of candy you get in this box, as well as the variety, it's a pretty good deal! Currently the price is around $45....with 30 items in the box, each individual item costs roughly $1.50. That's less expensive than what you would pay in most stores/gas stations (plus, again, the wide variety of Skittles & Starburst in the box is pretty fantastic). Also, if you run concessions, you could buy this bulk package and easily make a bit of a profit.Great deal!

I actually got these for an unconventional use- for my high school science students, especially my AP Biology class and STEM 9th grade class. There are many times that I throw out a bunch of materials on a table and tell my students to build a model of something, and they need to be able to explain that model to me. I am always looking for random things to add to my already random collection of objects- the creative uses that kids find for various materials always astounds me!When I first opened the box and saw the five simple pieces, I was unimpressed and wondered how intriguing the kit would actually be. However, when I started looking through the booklet included in the box, I was astounded by what can be made with these pieces! Everything from helicopters to robots.....to maybe even DNA?? (I can totally envision DNA modeled with the pieces!). This kit definitely cultivates creativity, and for the child/student who is building-inclined and hands-on, this would be a great activity for developing critical thinking skills and that aforementioned creativity.I think these building pieces are great and would probably be enjoyed the most by higher elementary students and lower middle school students, and a couple of these kits would be an awesome addition to such classrooms. I picture showing students how to build something like a helicopter, and then letting them run with an idea of their own and see who can create the "coolest" model (however "coolest" would be defined!). Very cool, and I want to look into purchasing more kits for my classroom in the future!

I actually got these for an unconventional use- for my high school science students, especially my AP Biology class. There are many times that I throw out a bunch of materials on a table and tell my students to build a model of something we're learning, and to be able to explain that model to me. I am always looking for random things to add to my already random collection of objects- the creative uses that kids find for various materials always astounds me!I am thrilled with these blocks- they come in a nice, durable bag, have a wide variety of shapes, and are super colorful. Thinking about the building blocks from a more traditional use- for small children- I think these would be great for the reasons I mentioned above, plus, the seem like they would be easy to wash/clean.I think these building blocks are great and would be enjoyed by small children! Of course, if you told a high school student to play with them, the student probably wouldn't pay more than 5 minutes of attention to them, but for my "model something with these materials" tactic, these are perfect for my purposes too!

First of all, let me state that I received this machine for free so I could use it and review it. I am in no way affiliated with the company, so this is my honest review of the item. Secondly, note that this a review from the point of view of a barista- I have about 5 years of experience between working in a coffee shop in college, and again, most recently, during some weekends throughout the school year + during the summer (I am a full time teacher otherwise!). Finally, when I make lattes and cappuccinos at home, I use a Moka pot to brew espresso on the stove and an Aeroccino machine to froth milk. It's been a fine way to make my favorite drinks, but can take awhile and sometimes it would be nice to have something a bit more automatic (it's easy to burn espresso on the stove/with the Moka pot if you're not careful! I find it difficult to make consistently good coffee with it).My first impressions of the machine- it is very sleek, somewhat heavy (not a problem for me, but just an observation), not too big, and it was packaged well. The various compartments are intuitive to put back together if you take them apart, but you definitely need to read the instructions before using the machine for the first time. That part was a little obnoxious- the instructions are quite detailed and lengthy- and I'm the type of person who would rather have someone just SHOW me what to do. It would be nice if the company had the manual PLUS access to visual instructions, like a link to a YouTube video or a DVD of info that would come along with the machine.Needless to say, I figured it out and eventually had my machine running. Note that in the instructions, it does say that it takes 3-4 brews before the espresso tastes the best.Other things:- WATER HARDNESS: When you first set up the machine, it will have you do a hardness test on your water. The machine "knows" how often you need to descale it, based on your water hardness, and will notify you as needed (cleaning fluid comes with the machine).- WATER FILTER: I like that the machine also comes with a water filter (it says you should replace it about every 2 months, but if you do not use the machine often, you'll have to replace it after about 3 weeks).- ADDING COFFEE: I LOVE that you can either add whole beans to the machine, and it will grind them as needed (and yes, the grind can be adjusted if the machine tells you it's too fine), and you can also use pre-ground coffee. I have some espresso already ground for my Moka pot, and I'm excited to be able to use it in the machine.- COOL FEATURES: the machine has neat features like changing the brew strength of the espresso; there's a 2x feature to brew a double shot or increase the amount of milk in your drink; it has a "clean" feature for the froth wand and steams it clean, like a barista does with the big espresso machines; the top of the machine has a cup warmer; you can adjust the espresso nozzles to come down closer to the cup, which helps make the espresso creamier; and so much more.- CLEANING: I haven't had to do a full cleaning of my machine yet, but after I brewed a couple shots, it was simple to take out the bottom tray and rid of any water that it caught + clean out the espresso grounds. The milk container is dishwasher safe and can be washed as needed (and should be washed often, it suggests).Overall- it's an awesome machine that makes great coffee shop-quality drinks. The froth is great, the shots are delicious....the mechanization of the machine makes it so easy to use (once you get the hang of it). While a Moka pot and an Aeroccino (my old way of making fancy drinks) are definitely easier to clean/maintain than this machine, I do like the automation and consistency in the taste of the drinks. On the con side, the Moka and Aeroccino have fewer parts and are less likely to break (or are at least not too expensive to replace)- this machine has so many working parts that if it breaks, it might be hard to fix (it does have a warranty with it, of course).I find that with having experience as a barista, it was easier for me to understand how to work and clean the machine; if you are not as familiar with "fancy" coffee drinks, it might take you a bit longer to get the hang of it. But once you do, it will be smooth sailing! I can see this machine functioning in a home (if you can afford it....it *is* quite expensive), in an office, or even in a restaurant. I can see small restaurants using a machine like this to make some good espresso drinks. It wouldn't do well in a place with super high coffee demand- you would want a bigger machine for that for sure. But for personal use/small business use, it is quite perfect.I am pleased! My machine will definitely be used often!

Note that this vacuum is not for using across a large floor carpet....if that were the case, I would not be giving this vacuum 5 stars. The provided attachments do allow for such cleaning, but if you try, you'll find yourself stooped over (unless you're shorter...I'm 5'7") and it takes a lot longer to do the whole floor that way. So, on to my review in regards to what the vacuum IS made for-First, upon opening and setting up the vacuum, I thought that it was pretty neat-looking. I also noticed that it was pretty compact and lightweight. Other features- the cord is stored in the vacuum's body (you push a button to "suck" it back in), it can be rolled around on the carpet upright (like in the picture) or laying on its side, and the button to turn it on/off (as well as to retract the cord) are large/easy to press/easy to find.I used the vacuum on a variety of surfaces. I didn't think the cord would be long enough for what I was doing, but I was actually able to reach into three rooms in my house without a problem (the length of the hose and the body of the vacuum provide extra length). I immediately noticed how QUIET the vacuum was, and I was impressed! My Dirt Devil (that is a mock Dyson) is pretty darn loud, so this was a nice change. Here is what happened on each floor (note that there are settings to switch between for each floor type):- On the carpet, as mentioned before, it worked, but would be more tedious than using an upright vacuum.- On the kitchen linoleum floor, the suction was so powerful that right under where I was working, it started to pull up a bit (oops! Thankfully no permanent damage) and so I stopped right away and won't be using it on that floor again :P.- On the area rugs, it did a great job pulling up visible dirt and seemed to work very well- On the hardwood floor, it sucked up all my dog's lost hair SO well. The shape of the attachment allowed me to get closer to baseboards and areas that my upright vacuum cannot do (unless you bring out the hose part). I was very impressed!As I mentioned earlier, there is also a furniture setting, and I can imagine that the vacuum would be great to use in that case too.I'm not a huge fan of the fact that it's a bag vacuum (I like bagless because then I don't have to keep buying bags!), but since I won't be using it to clean whole floors all the time, I can imagine I won't go through a ton of bags anyway.Highly recommended!

This blanket is great! First of all, it's so soft that I almost wanted to keep it for myself instead of my dog! I keep it in my car to help prevent some of my dog's back hair from getting all over my seats. It's a great size, looks cute, and again, it's so cozy- I'm pretty sure my dog loves it as much as I do :).

Overall, this is a very nice planner. Things I like about it:- The color scheme- I like the natural brown and with the splash of orange color- The fact that it is spiral-bound, so it lays flat when you open it- The size of the planner- when opened flat, it is the size of a sheet of paper (8.5x11)- The months are tabbed- The whole-month calendar for each month has plenty of space to write in- The weekly calendar pages have plenty of space to write in- There is a plastic pocket in the back cover to hold loose papers, like business cards or folded sheets- The whole thing seems pretty durableWhat I don't like about it:- The weekly calendar pages go from Monday to Sunday. I'm used to calendars starting on Sunday and going through Saturday. I will get used to it, but it is different from all other weekly planners that I have used.Hey, only one thing I don't like about it- not too shabby! This planner will definitely be used  a lot to help me keep track of my busy schedule and I definitely expect it to last a whole year of being toted around and constantly written in :).

I have my high school students complete an engineering project in which they have to make "the best" Alka Seltzer Rocket. I'll spare you the details of the lesson and get right on to my review of these canisters. A couple years back, I went to Walgreens and got leftover canisters from film processing; in comparison to those, these canisters from Amazon are a bit bigger and wider. No problem, though- they worked just fine for shooting parts into the air :). They sealed nice and tight (leakage=no rocket launch) and had no other issues. I'd buy them again from here if I needed more!

My dog mainly eats dry food, but every once in awhile, I like to mix in half a can of wet food as a treat. She LOVES it (of course)!! In terms of Hill's, there is no exception. She gobbles down her food (so it's definitely dog approved) and does not have digestive issues (no gas, no diarrhea, etc) after eating it. I appreciate the ingredients- there's nothing inherently "bad" that jumps out at me, and I appreciate that there are no corn/wheat/soy fillers. I also love that I can spread the can over 2 meals (since I mix in the dry food) and I can make the cans last longer!

I love this thing! The size is perfect- I can easily keep it in the trunk of my car- and it works well in terms of keeping things cold. I love that the side pockets do not always have to be open; I really don't use them as often as I use the cooler portion, so I'm glad that they fold up and out of the way. My main use for the cooler is groceries. It's so convenient to leave the cooler in my car all the time (again, it doesn't take up much space) so I can throw meat or whatever in there to stay cold on my 30 min drive back home from the grocery store.Great, convenient, space-saving, functional cooler!

This is the first electric stapler I've owned, and I am definitely impressed. Note that it is somewhat large, so if you don't have a lot of desk area, you might not wast this bad boy hogging your small space. The stapler has little suction cups at the bottom, which are nice for holding the unit down. The cord is a little short in my opinion, but for me, at least it's still long enough to reach where I need it to go. When I received the stapler, it came with both standard staples as well as heavy duty staples. In terms of functionality, I think it's great!As I said, this is my first electric stapler. When I set it up and loaded it with staples (which was quite easy to do), I put in the heavy duty staples, I putzed around by stapling a single sheet of paper (just to see how the thing worked), and WOAH- 1) the machine is a little loud, and 2) I learned NOT use heavy duty staples for non-heavy duty jobs!! It saw that it poked the legs of the staples back through the front of the paper in a dangerous way!!! I switched back to standard staples, and found that if you are using the machine to staple 2 pieces of paper together, it's still way more force than you need. If you are stapling simple things, use a good ol' fashioned hand stapler. But as you need to staple thicker packets, the Swingline makes the process fast and easy.So if you can get over the fact that the stapler is a little bulky, the cord might be a little short for your needs, and it's a little loud when it staples (the 3 reasons why I give it 4 stars instead of 5), you'll have no problem with this machine, which works and works well! Happy stapling!

I have gone to PT on and off for a couple years for a bad knee, and most recently, for Piriformis Syndrome. In both cases, I have used a Bosu and I loved it. I found a couple at the place I work out at and started using the Bosu's there; I really wanted one at home, but was deterred by the cost. Needless to say, I loved using one so much that I finally just sucked it up and bought one. I'm so glad I did!While the foot pump isn't the best (as other reviews mention), it *does* work. As I started to inflate the Bosu, I thought it was going to take FOREVER to inflate, but it wasn't as awful as I thought. I was able to inflate it properly, put the peg in (that blocks the air hole) without any issues, and I have been using the Bosu for a couple weeks without any issues whatsoever. The DVD that came with it is pretty cheesy, but I bought the Bosu for the Bosu, not the workout video, so I don't really care.As I mentioned before, these are a little expensive....but with how often I use mine (since I don't go to the gym to work out every day) for my own exercises plus my PT exercises, it was well worth the cost.

My crummy apartment kitchen floor gets dirty very easily, especially in winter. I have cleaned it using a sponge mop, wet mop, and cleaning it on my hands and knees with a sponge/rag. The sponge mop only pushed around the dirt, the wet mop left the floor too soppy, and cleaning on my hands/knees was thorough but time-consuming and tedious.Lo and behold, the Shark mop. When it arrived, it looked intimidating, but was actually very easy to set up. I like that it can be used as both a stand-up mop, but you can also remove the main part, attach a hose, and use it to clean things like the shower. Once set up, the mop is still very easy to use- you fill the little pitcher with water, pour it in the green section of the mop, plug it in, turn it on, let it warm up (about 30 sec), and then mop away!There are many reasons why I love this mop. First, the fact that it steam cleans without needing chemicals (it explicitly states not to use chemicals or essential oils on the tank) makes my "green" heart happy. Second, and another thing that makes this mop eco-friendly, is that all of the scrubbing cloths are removable and washable. No needing to purchase special pads (like a Swiffer mop)- just wash and re-use. Third, I love the mop because it is effective and easy! I was able to quickly scrub my kitchen floor with this thing.....it picked up more dirt than my old sponge mop, the floor dried almost right away unlike my wet mop, and it was MUCH more efficient/easy than doing the cleaning on my hands and knees. Oh, and another plus- the cord is decently long, so you can clean a kitchen quite easily (assuming you don't have a ginormous kitchen or other area to clean).I feel that with the ease of use, the effectiveness of the cleaning treatment, and how simple the mop is to set up/take apart, I will be cleaning my floor a lot more often than I used to, and not hating the job as much as before!!

I have a 5 year old corgi-lab mix who is very food-driven. She loves the Nutro Peanut Butter Moist N' Chewy Bites, and this flavor, the BBQ treats, are no exception. Upon smelling inside the bag, she was obviously excited....now she definitely loves being rewarded with these little guys. I do like the size (I can give her multiple throughout the day), and the taste is obviously delicious because she gets really excited when she sees the bag!I trust the Nutro brand and feel comfortable feeding these to my dog. I do agree with other reviews that they are a little "greasy," so you don't want to put them in your pocket or anything, but they are definitely appealing to dogs!

I have a 5 year old corgi-lab mix who is very food-driven. She loves peanut butter, and she loves treats....and this combines both into one tasty concoction! Not that I would know....but I can tell by how much she liked them. As a pet owner, I am always looking for treats with "good" ingredients. While I do question a bit where the first ingredient, "re-hydrated chicken," comes from, I'm not really bothered by the other ingredients. I also trust the Nutro brand, and I like that the treats are small-ish so I can give her multiple throughout the day.When I let Tess stick her nose into the bag, she was immediately intrigued and licking her lips. She ate the treat right away and obviously loved it. These are dog-approved!

Initially, I WAS a fan of this backpack. I viewed it as a nice work backpack- it has a pocket built in for a laptop in the main compartment, has TONS of other pockets and spaces, and feels quite durable. I used it to bike to work, and I was a fan. It was comfortable, and I liked the chest strap- it made the backpack feel more secure as I biked.When considering what type of review to give this product (I received it free to test it out and make a review), I was considering 4 stars- overall, I liked it, but the main compartment seemed a little small. Yes, the main part can fit a laptop, but the space seems "tight." This backpack is designed for travel too, so if you were to use it as a carry on, the limited amount of space makes sense....but I wish it was just a little larger. The top opening also felt a little awkward but I figured I just had to get used to it (it doesn't open like a "normal" backpack- it's a U-shaped zipper at the top).As I was looking at the tag, seeing if there was anything else I should include in my review, my stomach dropped when I read the following:"California Proposition 65 Warning: this product contains chemicals known to the state of California to cause cancer, or birth defects, or other reproductive harm."My views of the product immediately diminished. So, while it's a nice backpack for work or travel, I am disturbed by the use of such chemicals, and unfortunately, would not recommend this product.

Great spatulas. I love the variety of sizes, the colors are fun, and I appreciate that being totally silicone, I can set the spatula down on the edge of a hot pot and not worry about it melting. Recommended!

I've had hormone regulation issues since my thyroid was removed 3 years ago (cancer)- when I went off my birth control about 6 months after my surgery (my acne seemed to be under control), I didn't get a period for a year. I eventually went back on the pill (turns out my adult acne was only taunting me....it came back pretty bad). While it worked for a couple months, I eventually started getting my period every 2 weeks. Definitely not fun.I actually didn't start taking EPO for acne reasons- I was interested more in hormone regulation and weight loss. While I did not experience weight loss (I'm not overweight, but I have about 10-15 extra pounds I'd like to shed), I have experienced some hormone balance. Granted, I'm on a new birth control pill and that might be helping too, my acne patches have faded TREMENDOUSLY and I rarely get zits anymore (which is a big deal, since my acne is cystic). I actually didn't put 2 and 2 together right away.....I came back on Amazon and read reviews about how it really helped some people's acne....and I realized that my face clearing correlated with taking the full dose (3 pills, 2x/day) consistently.So while the EPO might not help you shed those last pounds (CLA might, though! I saw some success with that), if you have adult acne issues, this might be your answer. The results won't be immediate, but I couldn't be happier with the (accidental) results! I also stand behind the NOW brand. I've purchased many of their supplements and appreciate the quality of their products.

I use this with my Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 Tablet; I like the long cord (as compared to the short cord that it originally came with). It works just as well as the original cord (in terms of wall charging- no USB port) and charges my tablet at a decent speed. Recommended!

This stuff tastes amazing, whether with water, almond milk, or the recipe on the side (blended with ice, a banana, and peanut butter). I appreciate the "clean" ingredients and love using this as a post-workout recovery drink.
I purchased this for my grandma, who loves cats, for Christmas. She loved it! It's very cute, not super heavy, and is the perfect garden accessory. Recommended for any cat lover!

I really like this clock. While it's not atomic, I appreciate the large display, the fact that it shows the date, and also the temperature. I have it in my bedroom and am happy that it is not backlit; I like to sleep in as dark a room as possible. I've never had any issues with it, it's easy to set, it looks fine hanging on my wall....no complaints!

I have a larger blender bottle as well as this smaller one. I love the smaller one the most- it makes mixing up one serving of my Silk Almond Milk and Amazing Grass Green Superfood powder really easy. I appreciate the fact that it's BPA free, inexpensive, and easy to clean. I would recommend it!

I've been battling a running injury in the back of my thigh; I was told to try a foam roller. After some research about different materials and types of rollers, I settled on this and I'm happy with it. It is a good size for using on the thigh, dense enough to feel like it's working, but not so dense that it hurts. Yes, some level of hurt is good (that means its working)....but as a beginner, it's been a great first roller that seems like it will last me a long time!

I purchased this frame as a gift; I love the thick, black matte frame. It looks simple yet elegant. The frame is very affordable as well. The picture that I framed looked awesome inside. I would definitely buy this frame again if I ever need one!
Nice, simple brush that is effective for scrubbing vegetables. This is my 2nd one; I got rid of the first one for sanitary reasons (I had it a long time). I liked it enough to buy another!

I much prefer this charger to the one I used to have (which broke). My old charger, when I'd plug my Samsung Galaxy S5 in, would make my radio "fuzzy." I have not had any radio issues with this charger. I like that it has 3 ports, charges items relatively quickly, and has a sleek, simple look. If this one breaks (as long as it lasts a long time), I would definitely re-purchase.

I really like this product. Up to this point, I was using the Say Yes to Carrots night cream, but I wasn't a fan of the thickness. Yes, a night cream should be thick, but it was just too much. I tried the Simple brand and like it a LOT more. It's still thick enough to help lock in moisture, especially on dry patches on my face, but light enough at the same time. I've made the conversion to Simple an plan to keep using it!

The towel is very nice- I love the large size, it's absorbent, and it's super soft (being 100% cotton). I received the "pewter" towel to review, and the only thing I'm not a fan of is the color. It's an off-white, but not a nice off-white...it just looks...dirty. I definitely recommend this dish towel if you want something more "top of the line" in the kitchen, but I would suggest getting some color other than pewter!
