If the Homeland Security folks win then you score points.Each round, the lead player (this rotates from round to round) draws and assembles as many new cases as there are players.The cases have some visible information, e.g., what level of threat they are, and some secret information, e.g., how complex the case is.The cards are designed to fit together in two ways, one way when much of the information is hidden and one way once the case is flipped over to be resolved.The rules are relatively simple.  I playtested this with an experienced gaming group, and we all picked up the rules in less than 30 minutes.The play is quick, and even as total novices we were able to complete a whole game in less than an hour.The game materials are all first rate.I do have a few caveats though.First, it is very, very easy for the terrorist organizations to win.  I recommend playing progressively difficult versions by starting with all of the threats being low level and giving the players more chances to analyze, intervene, and potentially win.  Every time my group played the game, the terrorist organizations won.Second, there is a mechanic where, if the Homeland Security folks win, each player *must* name one player he or she thinks is the mole.  If you pick correctly, the mole loses.Guess what.  With less than six players, the mole is almost always outted no matter how well he or she played.We made up a house rule that you could name the mole (taking the suggested "minus victory points" if you chose incorrectly) or you could pass on guessing (like the SAT where you get some points for not guessing).  This gives the clever mole some chance of escaping - not much, but some.All in all this is a good, quick, fun game for the 12+ age range.

This is a crowd sourced, on-line series that is captured and published as one DVD.The concept is interesting, and the production values are high.This series follows in the footsteps of on-line gamer related series such as Neil, the Guild, etc.This is a fun series to watch for the gaming crowd.** beware spoilers follow **It took me about halfway though the DVD to figure out what was going on.There was a bard who was chronicling the Party.  The Party was theoretically aiding a not-so-bright fighter, but after an ork ambush the cleric is killed, and the ranger and mage characters find a shortcut into the dungeon of infinite dooms.This allows the cowardly Perf, the mage, to become the wielder of the Sword of Fighting.Perf tries to resurrect the cleric, but the spell backfires and brings the cleric back as a sentient undead -- oh no!Through a series of misadventures, the fighter makes his way through the dungeon of doom only to find out that Perf has stolen the Sword of Fighting already.To be continued ... (the series, not this review)

Wow! I'm giving it three stars (make that two instead after thinking this through), and this is the most positive review.OK, why would many readers not enjoy it?  Well, the book has a false premise.You are lead to believe by the title, the dust jacket, and whispered promises all around that Steve Jones is writing a book that examines the Bible in light of modern science.And, no that is not what the book is about.Basically, Steve Jones starts every chapter with a quote from the Bible and then just broadly goes off and starts telling stories that are loosely, loosely related to the subject of the quote.The book does have some interesting facts, but I would be very cautious about quoting them, because I am not sure if the author is making claims "tongue in cheek" or if some of the facts are true.In other words, I know that the author scoffs at religion (he freely admits this in the prologue), but I cannot honestly tell if the whole book is supposed to be a joke on the reader.Also, Steve Jones starts by saying that he is not making judgements about religion in this book and then goes on to scoff at the Bible at points throughout the entire work.The title is probably apt.  The book promises to be one thing, but it turns out that you can't trust a serpent's promise.

The premise is that Dracula was not really a bad guy, just a victim of fate (and a mean older brother), and that Mina Harker actually had the hots for poor, poor, blood sucking Dracula.It is a book in the tradition of "the Vampire Tapes" and other novels where Dracula is portrayed as misunderstood.Syrie James does a good job of pulling the story off, and, if you accept the premise that vampires are real, it flows reasonably well.Ms James also pays homage to previous versions of this story, e.g., the Vampire Tapes, by mentioning some of the elements of those books in this story.All in all, it was a fun read.

This is in the same genre as "Immortal Beloved" where an entire book and movie were written around Beethoven's final will that leaves substantial property to his immortal beloved - whom nobody knew.In this book, we find the famous horror/mystery writer Mr. Poe in a love triangle that only Mrs. Poe and his paramour understand is actually a love triangle.No actual physical cheating takes place in the printed word.It is much more like a traditional Victorian romance in that all the romance occurs via hints and innuendos.The premise is interesting, and Lynn Cullen has done a good job researching the events surrounding Mr. Poe's life.

This is a spoof novel that examines the idea that cheesy science fiction writers might actually be creating reality in another universe.The set-up in the first half of the book is great and funny.All the Sci Fi tropes are there, and our characters are truly baffled by the strange science that manifests on the flagship.The crew figures out that the "main characters" (i.e., Captain, First Officer, Chief Engineer, and romantic lead LT) are essentially immortal, but if a regular crew member accompanies them then he or she is likely to die -- and in a horrible (yet oddly dramatic) way.Then, the book gets to the second half where a very fluffy and funny premise is doused in a barrel of acidic seriousness, and John tries to explain how this works and what horrible emotional things happen if the crew visits the actual writers.The climax involves a hideously mutilated writer's son and some hypercubic logic that lost this poor reader somewhere around the Orion nebula.It was a great read the first half.  I recommend reading in that far and not spoiling the wonderful set-up by reading the end of the book.

I really enjoyed this novel.  Fair warning, it is not what you expect from John Scalzi.The story takes place in either an alternate universe or in our universe far removed in time from the present day.The protagonist, the captain of a god engine vessel, is heading out on a special mission for his Lord, the god of his people.The ships are propelled through space by captured and indentured "gods," supernatural beings of immense power that are able to fold space, power ships, and project weapon fire through space.* Spoilers Follow *The god that the humans have been following is actually a hideously evil being that violates the gods' central tenets of morality.The god of the gods comes at the end of the story to punish the human god.Just when you think things will turn out well, John Scalzi puts on his George R.R. Martin mask and writes the ending that has many of the other reviewers unhappy.If you enjoyed Red Shirts and Old Man's War then you might not like this one, but I say give it a try.

The Star Tablet is the third book in the Jack Stein, Psychic Investigator, series.In this episode Jack is on the trail of an alien artifact that might lead to the alien home world.The complication is that Jack's ward, the intelligent and lovely Billie has disappeared.Jack has to use all of his skills to find his ward and bring her back from the further reaches of space before time runs out.The writing was very uneven, and the dialogue was uniformly poor.In the middle of the book, Jay, the author, introduces an explicit scene with a hooker, but there is no other sex or romance or anything anywhere else in the book.  Without the explicit sex scene, the book could have been a YA (Young Adult) level book, but that scene definitely put it into the hard core adult section, and the scene added *nothing* to the plot, the atmosphere, or any constructive part of the book.** Beware Spoilers Follow **Jack teams up with his old friend, "the Kid" or "Dog."  The Kid has a jump capable ship.  Jack finds some documents at a university situated in "Balance City."  Jack also finds out that his old antagonists are chasing him.Jack and Dog actually find the home world of the aliens, who have been communicating with Jack in his dreams.Jack and Dog also find out that there are more hostile forces in the universe than anyone in the human realm realized.Once Jack recovers Billie, Dog turns on Jack, because ... Dog has been working for the bad guys the whole time.Cue music for cheesy follow-on book.

Michael Moorcock is a giant among the Sci Fi and Fantasy writers of the Twentieth Century.His Eternal Champion books are his best known.Elric, Coram, and a host of other characters from those pages are instantly recognizable.This book was not like any of those.** Beware spoilers follow **This is how the Eternal Champion actually ends according to Moorcock.It says book one, but it has to be another incarnation.The Eternal Champion is summoned to a world where humanity is facing an implacable foe in a war that has been on-going for a million years.The Eternal Champion is incarnated as Erekos.  Erekos suffers from nightmares about being the Eternal Champion.At first he fights for humanity, but then he figures out that humanity is the reason for his bad dreams -- people like to fight.So ... Erekos kills all the humans and "learns the secret of immortality" and stays on this world with the aliens. Forever.  The End.No, no I'm not kidding.
Good beats and an interesting line up.It is on my iPhone now for long trips.

The New Balance (all US owned and operated company) make great shoes.For those of us in the midst of middle age who need a little more cushion in their shoes, New Balance are wonderful.I lost the ability to run during a tour in Iraq back in 2005-07, but after a time and focused effort in physical therapy I was able to walk long distances.I love the 990 series, and these shoes did not disappoint.

This is a wonderful story about parents who are willing to do anything to support their son's passion of (and talent for) physics.Tom Clynes knows his math, science, and engineering, and he did a great job of introducing concepts into the book that would have been tough to explain by a less qualified author.I loved the conversational nature of the book.Brilliant!

In the first book, "Off to be the Wizard," we learned that there was one wizard that failed the trial ... Todd!In this book ,we meet Todd, and we learn why Todd was exiled.Scott Meyer did a great job of making Todd into a three dimensional character.  Todd is a geek who doesn't understand why you can't just use other people and animals like objects.  He is not vicious about it.  Todd simply views them as things.That is what makes Todd a true monster, but Todd is presented in an extremely consistent way.The author also explores time travel possibilities in more detail and with a lot more creativity.The final outcome is mostly predictable, but this is not a literary great work.There are quite a few surprises in the book as Scott pokes fun at geeks, role-playing games, and programmers.

I'm writing this review of Mythica after just finishing Mythica II.The story centers on a common fantasy trope.  A group of assembled adventurers (a wizard in training, a thief, a warrior, a priestess, [and a dark elf -- in Mythica II]) must invade an ancient ruins and recover an artifact to prevent an EEEEEEEEvil necromancer from recovering the artifact and becoming an unstoppable power.The nice thing about this series is that there are some very interesting characters, several of whom grow over the course of the film.The protagonist is a crippled (club footed) young woman who has been taught magic on the side by Kevin Sorbo's cameo appearing wizard character.  She is also a necromancer.  (There is a clear nature vs nurture theme here that is subtle, but present. If you have rabid political feelings about this you might be upset about this thread in the movie.)The party is able to accomplish their mission, but it is a near thing as they confront slavers, orcs, and a nasty troll.It is an entertaining, B-grade, fantasy film

This is definitely a product for the high end hobbiest or starting professional.First, it uses an XLR microphone connector with potential for 48 mV phantom power.  This is not going to be your first mic if you are starting out.Second, the jacks are all 1/4".  Most consumer items come in 1'8" jacks and plugs.I previously owned a TASCAM iUR2 that worked well with my IPad2 until the IOS outran the iUR2 ability to interface.Here are a few Q/A topics to talk through the capabilities of the device.How hard was it to set-up?  It was simple.  You unwrap it, grab your mic, iPad, and iPad power adapter, and you plug them in.Does it run off of the iPad's power? No, you plug the iPad into the iOne using the regular iPad to USB cable.  The power comes from plugging in the mini-USB connector from the iOne to the power supply for the iPad's USB jack.What is the sound quality like?  It is OK.  Most mics need to be run through a pre-amp to get the volume up into the workable range.  I was able to import the CAF files produced into ProTools at 48Khz and 16bits of fidelity.  With that level of detail, I was able to increase the volume, filter, compress, etc. with reasonable results.Is the device compatible with a variety of software packages?  I was able to use it both on my PC and my iPad.  The truth is that I have many other recording options for my PC.  I got the iOne for use with my iPad.  I did not have a good way to record high quality sound since the iUR2 became obsolete.OK, you told me the good things. Do you have any areas where it could be improved?  Sure.  First, you can import the tracks produced by using iTunes, but the audio files are all in CAF format, not AIF, not WAV, not MP3 or MP2, not in ...  Well, you get the idea.  Most of my sound packages could not read the files.  Apparently, you can download to your computer and then reload into iTunes and ship back to your iPad and read using Garage Band to then export as a sound file that is a little more standard.  Fortunately, my copy of ProTools was able to read the file and import it.  Many of you are not going to have a copy of ProTools sitting around.I've heard that it is hard to get information from IOne to other music programs.  Is that true?  There is an export button in the program, but it is looking for a copy of Studio One.  There are no other immediately obvious export options from inside the program.  That said, I just plugged my iPad into iTunes and was able to download the CAF files right away.Pros: one of the few professional recording capabilities that just uses an iPad or iPhone.  The sound quality is good (48 KHz and 16 bits), but quiet.  You will need to do some editing/production work on it.  The device is easy to set-up and start using immediately.Cons: The CAF format for the sound files is not one of the most common.  It might be tricky to convert CAF to AIF, WAV, or MP3 files.  There are minimal instructions that came with the device and not much on-line.  You will need quarter inch plugs with everything to make it work.

This is the game that Wizards of the Coast always wanted to make.When I received the first, beta-version of Magic the Gathering from Rich back in 1992, I thought to myself this is a card game version of WizWar, where magicians challenge each other by casting spells and summoning creatures to fight one another.After 23 years, this is the board game for Magic the Gathering.I like it.  I like it a lot.As with all WotC products, the quality of the components is very high.Each player take the role of a Planeswalker (wizard) that summons creatures and spells to attack opponents.Once your points are gone, you are out of the game.Last wizard standing is the winner.The rules are simple, but they game is infused with the themes and flavor of the collectible card game.There is lots and lots of room for expansions, but the base rules are less than ten pages long and those pages are liberally filled with colorful diagrams and photos.Great game!  I highly recommend it!

This is the second book in the Red Rising trilogy.Red Rising, the first book in the trilogy, blew me away.  The characters were amazing.  The envisioned Society was detailed and compelling, and the pace was incredible.This is a different book, and, though it was still good, it was not as compelling as Red Rising.** Beware Spoilers Follow **Golden Son takes place in the same world with the same protagonist, Darrow, but most of the gains in the first book disappear in the first three chapters of this book.  As a reader, I felt a little cheated.  You got the feeling that the events of the last third of the book had to be forced a bit in the first third.He is sent to the Academy, where the Golds learn to fight wars.  Darrow is about to kill his arch-nemesis' cruiser when suddenly we find out that there was one ship left that, though badly, badly mauled, managed to survive long enough to take out Darrow's fleet.Just because of coming in second, the Arch-governor of Mars essentially disowns Darrow.Darrow is in despair and contacts his Sons of Ares handlers and finds out that they are beginning a war against the Society.We find out the mysterious thing that Eo said before she was hung.  She was carrying Darrow's child.Darrow, filled with rage, takes a detonator and intends on blowing up all of the noble Gold families that evening at a gala on the Moon held by the high Gold herself.But, Darrow changes his mind (for reasons not entirely clear), threatens his arch-enemy's house in the way of Cassius, and we find out that Darrow was the last student of the Master of the Willow -- supposedly no one studied under the man in years.And so on, and so on, ...Ares contact's Darrow via Goblin who knows now what Darrow is, but seems to be fine with it.It was interesting, and I will read the third book, but I would think of this more as a bridge than as new development in the Red Rising plot-line.

It's Munchkin, and the theme is Adventure Time.It is a fine game, and the makers of Munchkin did a good job integrating in the tropes of Adventure Time.Interestingly, Adventure Time is one of the best translations, because every episode is really about metaphorically kicking in the door and finding cool stuff.

This is a wonderful movie for the youngest of the Lego fan.I loved the Lego movie and some of the DC and Star Wars shorts that Lego has done.All the movies share a certain charm and cheesy quality that appeals to both kids and adults.This one though is really just a movie for kids.  The scene where Luthor and gang are picking out the members of the Doom squad was aimed squarely at the 5-6 year old crowd.There were no plot surprises.Great movie for the kids, but you might want to balance the checkbook or make dinner while this one is playing.
Fun, melodic songs that entertain.

I'm a fan of the series.The first four seasons all featured a common form.  There is the stable of ensemble cast that makes regular appearances and act as continuity, and there is one bad, bad villain that will eventually be defeated by the end of the season.The Florida Crow clan are the villains this time.Seasons one through four are five star performances with interesting plot twists, clever moral dilemmas, and multi-dimensional villains.Season five ... er, not as much.**Spoilers Follow**We spend a lot of time cleaning up complications from previous seasons, e.g., Raylon's part in the mob execution, which is actually resolved in a very unsatisfying way.  In the final episode of the season, Boyd Crowder blurts out that Raylon was complicit, and the other folks in the office essentially blow it off.  *sigh*Eva murders folks in prison and becomes a harder core criminal, and eventually makes a deal to become Raylon's CI to monitor and report on Boyd.Art actually does reassign Raylon to Florida, but the hook for season six is that Raylon has to help the office in Harlan bring down Boyd Crowder before departing.The Florida Crows are essentially a bunch of horrible people who are also ignorant.There is a mother - son team of Crows who are a little less odious and stupid than the rest who actually get away at the end.  (Raylan engineers the mom to kill her brother and then writes it up as self-defense - the man killed is unarmed at the time of his murder.)We'll see how it is all wrapped up in season six.

This is the magnum opus of Dr. Dawna Markova.  She has been working in the field of collaboration, organizational effectiveness, and collective psychology for over four decades.  So, the book is filled with stories, illustrations, and anecdotes from someone who has "been there" and been effective at it.It is really three separate books in one.  (The book says there are four parts, but the final portion is a section that summarizes the first three and advocates for using all three of the previously developed topics together.)The first portion describes mind patterns.  Dr. Markova describes twelve thinking patters.  She posits that we all have three modes of concentrating on something: focus, sorting, and open.  They are pretty much as their names imply.  Dr. Markova gives examples to illustrate the modes.  Focused implies alert and detailed.  Sorting means exploring and maybe a little confused.  Open leads to imagination and creativity.  She points out that all of these states are necessary, and we all go through them every day.The next thing that Dr. Markova points out though is interesting and different.  She says that these states are triggered by certain types of stimulation: visual, audio, or kinesthetic.  She then divides folks into thinking types based on which of the triggers brings the subject into what state.  You may be a VKA that would mean that visual/written material tends to put you into a focuses state, whereas auditory stimulus would put you into the open condition.Dr. Markova includes many worksheets and questions that you can use to determine not only your own patterns, but those you work with as well.This is very helpful.  If you have a boss or colleague that is reacting poorly to your input, it might be because it is in a format that causes confusion for that person.Interesting.  Truth in lending.  I have not been able to apply it yet, but the idea is intriguing and makes some sense.The second portion of the book talks about "thinking talents" and elaborates on 35!!! different talents ranging from "wanting to win" to "believing" and "collecting."  The author provides questions, descriptions, and even a bit on shadow attributes (you might have this if you manifest this kind of behavior).  Once you are able to select the top several talents that describe your most common behaviors, you also try to find out the talents that are most deficit in your own personality.  The deficit talents are those behaviors that tend to make you uncomfortable.The talents are then clustered into quadrants: analytic, innovative, relational, and procedural.As with the first section, with talents, you are encouraged to find out what your colleagues' talents are and see if you are interacting with them in their deficit areas, inadvertently being less effective than you might.I also found this portion of the book very interesting.  There are so many potential talents that it is hard to imagine someone who cannot connect with a few of them.  (One caveat though ... I found myself having interests in so many of the talents that it was hard to focus into a single quadrant.  This might be something that will require social learning and trial and error.)The third big idea in the book was that people tend to have different modes of finding out about the world, inquiring, that map directly to their talent quadrant.The insight is that if you are trying to inform someone with a different talent quadrant than your own, you might want to adjust your information presentation to better match his or her inquiry style.The final portion of the book asked you to use all three of the proceeding concepts by changing how you think about your work environment and your interactions with others.It was a very interesting and well-written book.  I ordered ten copies to give to my department managers and principals in my command.I highly recommend this book!

This is a heart warming story of true love, acceptance, and forgiveness.Emmalyn finds herself in the northern reaches of Minnesota and Wisconsin far away from the man she loves, because he committed a crime and is doing the time.This is a wonderful, wonderful story told with skill and will a lot of heart.** Spoilers Follow **The story takes place in the last two years of Greg's sentence.  While Emmalyn makes the best of things, she has some adventures with local characters that both challenge and expand her compassion.When the book begins, the reader is most uncertain about the future of Emmalyn's and Greg's marriage, but by the time we reach Chapter 30, we both know, accept, and are gladdened by the fact that they do get together.Thomas Aquinas said that someone who has never doubted the existence of God doesn't believe in God.  If Emmalyn had never questioned her marriage to Greg while he was in prison then I'm not sure the reader could have accepted that their love was real.Ms. Ruchti, the author, did a skillful job of weaving the realities of northern Wisconsin and Minnesota into the book.  She used local flavor with foods, sayings, and insightful descriptions of the countryside to make you feel as though you were there.While she not pummel anyone with it, it is clear that Ms. Ruchti comes from a religious background in a very positive way.  That positive aspect shines through as a ray of hope and love in the book.All in all, a great read, and a very uplifting story.

This is a wonderful book of card games by the master game designer and player, Sid Sackson.It covers games from all over the world and explains the rules in simple, easy to understand form.This is a must have book for the serious card game aficionado.

A spunky horse, a mischievous puppy, and two sisters alone with grandma - what could happen?The answer is plenty happens in Ms. Greens debut reader for the Silver Pony Ranch series.The book works very well for the first time chapter book reader.  The book adds interest without resorting to violence, disturbing, or scarey topics.My only caution was that, while realistic, the sibling rivalry between the two young sisters was a little intense at times.

I admit that I did not understand this album.It was a trance album, but the vocals were hit or miss at best.Occasionally, they were a good match to the music.Sometimes though, you were caught scratching your head and saying, "wow! that was only in here, because it rhymes."

The production qualities on this album are superb.From the title, you might expect incoherent screaming combined with oppressive guitar chugs and squeals.While it has music that hints at those qualities, this album stays firmly in the territory of understandable and musical.
Great songs, great beats, and excellent production qualities.Another great album by the King of BPM, Armin Van Buuren.

The game has three levels of complexity, and it is chalked full of information types, parts, and descriptions of horses.Truth in advertising, I had to work through the third scenario/game several times.  So, don't rush into it.  You will want to spend some time carefully going through the steps and might want to play a practice game or two before taking it on full throttle.Over half the fun of this game is wonderful information on horses.You won't go wrong by giving this to the horse, game loving person in your life.

This is a book about games by board and card game players.It is really a collection of pithy statements.One of the points that the book makes early on is that role-playing games are "toys" and not games (rule #6), but the book actually has a large number of its pithy statements that involve RPGs.  I'm adding this point up-front in the review, because this is a book about board and card games, not RPGs even though Robin Laws does the foreword.I read the whole book cover to cover while riding the stationary bike at the local Rec Center in less than twenty minutes.  Most of the pages in the book are 2/3 to 3/4 white space.It is going for about $15 at the time I write this, and that is a lot better than the $40 I paid to buy it hot off of the presses.There are some books, "Defining Fun," "101 Design Methods," "Mastering the Game," etc. that you will read, re-read and learn something new from every time you invest the time to delve into the book. Other books are entertaining at the time, but once you read them you have gotten every thing out of them that you can.  This book falls into that latter category.Wil Wheaton, John Kovalic, and other of the contributors are well known in and ardent supporters of the gaming community, and it was worth a read to see their quotes.

Great games for the entire family.It has a built-in ten minute time limit.Each player is trying to accumulate crystals that will give them a better chance of surviving the trapped temple.It is cooperative.  Players can help one another explore the temple and escape traps and curses.

This is a companion book to the map book that also recently came out.Rather than a general gazetteer, this book looks in detail at some of the lands, and spends very little time on other, large areas.Not surprisingly, it focuses on the areas of the world explored in the TV series and popular novels, Westeros.It is very interesting, and in addition to satisfying the curiousity of the hard-core Game of Thrones fans, this would also be very useful for the Game of Thrones RPG fans.  I would find the information in this book helpful for running a campaign set in the world.  (This is one of the few source-books to draw from.)

This is a very thorough story book of the new Witcher game.  It follows the adventures of Geralt, the Witcher, but it is told as though this is an encyclopedia of knowledge about the world of the Witcher.The book is beautifully illustrated and comes in a coffee table sized, sturdy bound volume.The illustrations are done in four color offset on glossy paper, the highest mass produced quality.Even if you never intend on playing the computer game, you will love this book.  It is the next best thing to playing through the game.I highly recommend this book to any fantasy fan.

This is a tremendously fun game that almost anyone can play.The goal is to get rid of all your cards.  Each player starts with a pile of face down cards in front of him or her.Each round, the players take turns flipping their topmost card.  If that card matches the face-up card of another player, a contest ensues.Both try to grab the plastic totem in the middle of the table before the other.The winner gives all of this discards to the unfortunate, slower competitor.It sounds simple, and it is, but the cards are fiendishly well designed.  You have to pay careful attention to know when your cards match (and, when they don't).If you grab the totem when the cards don't match, you have to take *everyone's* discard piles!  *UGH!*I've bought more than a dozen copies of this game to give out to friends and colleagues.  Everyone loves it!

This is a fun game for one  five players that can be played in less than 90 minutes.Each player takes the role of a colony of ants. You are trying to accumulate victory points by expanding your colony and conducting raids against other colonies.Much like the earlier game Insektoid, you also have the option of evolving your aunts to become more formidable.The catchphrase on the box is "explore, evolve, emerge victorious." This is a pretty good description of the game in a single phrase.The components are very high quality, and this game has a very high replay value.Yes, you can play it solo.I highly recommend this game

It's an interesting game. I am not familiar with Legion games, but this appears to be a work of love. (My guess is that this is a homegrown game that the author worked hard to get published.)It is a game for two  four players. Each player is trying to become a deity.Each turn has four steps: reveal, marketplace, raid, and reinforce. There are two possible ways to win. You can accumulate for matching mystic symbols or you can pummel your opponents.The game is very evenly balanced (very, very, very evenly balanced). So, the pummel strategy is bound to lead to a relatively long game. The mystical symbol win is a way of guaranteeing that no game goes on too long.The pieces are very high-quality, and it is unlikely that anyone in your gaming group has ever played this particular one before.For the gamer who has everything, this is a great ad, and it is a great gift for that gamer who's hard to buy for.

I like this game. It's a deck building game where the players work in a semi-cooperative way. Unlike other semicooperative games, you don't spend any time in this one back stabbing other players.You can play with anywhere between two  six players. One of the nice things about this game is that you never have a turn where you just sit with nothing to do. You must accumulate resources, combat, cunning, or spirit, to vanquish foes, and score points.Many of the classic New England monsters are here for you to pick your wits against. Another nice thing about the game is that it plays in less than an hour.There is enough randomness to it that it has a moderately high replay value.

I am a fan of the the Diablo franchise.  So, please understand that this review is done with a mixed heart.This book tries to answer the question what led to the events in Diablo III.It is written from the perspective of Deckard Cain.Sometimes less is more, and, when you try to explain where a story began, you cannot effectively do it.In this book, we find that Cain is a relatively misanthropic, maladjusted human being. He doesn't really like children, and, to be honest, he's not very good at life.Yes, the events described in "the order" could have led to Diablo III, or they could've led just as easily to Deckard Cain lying under a bench in a large city somewhere with a bottle of hooch.What this book most reminded me of were some of the skits that they used to do on sitcoms making fun of the old radio shows where they would try to re-create what both sides of a phone conversation sounded like. In the old radio shows, you only heard one side of the phone conversation, and the playwrights had to include a lot of information so that the audience could follow. Of course, no real phone conversation would ever play out that way. That was the joke.That is the joke in this book to.It is interesting, but ultimately it knocks Deckard Cain off of the pedestal that many gamers have him on.

It's a great game with potentially hundreds of hours of playtime available.The game takes full advantage of the PS4's powerful graphics capabilities.The voice acting is excellent, and the cut scenes are absolutely awesome! (Especially when viewed via HDMI on a high definition television.There is an extensive and engaging main quest, but the real fun in this third edition of the game is the open world. You could literally play for hundreds of hours without ever solving the main quest. There are so many side and subordinate activities.For those of you that enjoy naughty fun, this edition has some of the same activities as the previous two. This is the best PS4 game that I have played this year.

The powder came in a nicely sealed bag which contained a desiccant capsule. Also included was a plastic dosage spoon which unfortunately was way too big for the recommended dosage. This however was very promptly handled by the seller which sent me a whole packet of correct size spoons (~100mg), they are not labelled on the spoon however. As this supplement is one of the very few that may actually do something for cognitive functions per limited testing, its the closest thing to endorsement by consumer magazines and web md sources that I have seen. It is vegetable not bovine derived. Personally it definitively causes an urge to do, write, or create something about an hour after it is taken and that effect lasts for about 3-4 hours. I only take it occasionally and once a day. Additionally I had a nerve induced tooth/head ache for a long time, after taking this it got slightly better, after taking it for about a week it was totally gone. This was after a year of trying all sorts of non and prescription NSAs. Could have been a coincident, but I am very thankful. I give it only four stars because its difficult to use. This powder tends to clump very easily, and you may be better off with a capsule version.

The Flash cord I received is branded "focus", see the picture attached. If anything it may be better for some as the part that mounts on the camera hot shoe has another hot shoe on top of it rather than a smooth top in the description. Again see my photo. This allows you to have two flashes mounted on the camera and with the built in switch control which one fires. Unless one is an optical slave they will not fire at the same time though.I have tested both the top mounted and the cord mounted shoes, and they both communicate with the camera based on the switch position. When the flash is mounted on the off position shoe, the camera says cannot communicate with the flash ; off or incompatible. The TTL functions well as do all the in the camera control functions for all the features your flash is capable of. The cord is about 18" long coiled and stretches to about 3ft. The locking mechanism is the rotary plastic ring screw, and the camera mount is all plastic shoe. A very handy device for no red eye, dual flash setup and macro photographs where a long lens would throw a shadow and a standard flash would aim too high.

This for the most part is the same review as I did for the Neewer branded version of what appears to be the exact same flash. It certainly performed the same way. Interestingly mine did exactly the same thing as in one review below mine. When initially powered up, it made a noise as if it was charging, then it died. I swapped in several sets of batteries, it appears that one of the springs in the bottom of the battery compartment gets stuck. Once freed up, when both the top and bottom of the batteries made contact, the flash came back to life. I now use the built in camera flash as a main light and trigger for two of these little slave flashes which I position on either side of my subject. My estimate of the guide number is 20-30 (ft) at Iso 100. Not very powerful, but great as fill and side lights.Comments applicable from before: I use this slave flash as a fill in light for impromptu portraits. It works extremely well for removing harsh shadows by placing the slave off to one side or slightly behind your subject. To use it along with a Canon DSLR in ETTL II camera mode, set the switch on the back to S2. Then you can use the camera flash compensation +- 3EV to vary the light ratio between the slave and the camera, or leave the camera flash setting at 0EV and move the slave closer or further away.The second way to use the slave is to set the camera flash to manual mode. This requires the slave to be set to position S1. Place the slave where it illuminates your subject well (it even works for hair highlights when used from behind), then you can use the on camera flash power adjustment from 1/128 to 1/2, or the f-stop to control the overall picture look and feel.It is truly amazing how much fun and creativity you can have with this one unit. I am rating the The Zeikos version of this flash slightly lower than Neewer because of the battery contact issues.

I was interested in this food due to its "limited ingredient diets" claim. My dog has some skin issues and some have mentioned limiting the food ingredients as a possible solution. But first and foremost, the dog must want to eat it. Would she even eat kangaroo??I am happy to say, after allowing my dog to choose between this and 2 other foods, that although not her first choice it came in second place. She seems to like it just fine.The labeling states it contains balanced omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids along with high quality protein to help support healthy skin and a shiny coat. Along with the potato and kangaroo, which are the main ingredients there is some brewers yeast and salmon oil along with some vitamins and minerals. Sounds pretty simple and a lower than most fat content only 10%.So while my dog has only been on it for a week, and it is too early to tell if it will help her skin condition, I am crossing my fingers and will continue on this regimen.

I use this slave flash as a fill in light for impromptu portraits. It works extremely well for removing harsh shadows by placing the slave off to one side or slightly behind your subject. To use it along with a Canon DSLR in ETTL II camera mode, set the switch on the back to S2. Then you can use the camera flash compensation +- 3EV to vary the light ratio between the slave and the camera, or leave the camera flash setting at 0EV and move the slave closer or further away.The second way to use the slave is to set the camera flash to manual mode. This requires the slave to be set to position S1. Place the slave where it illuminates your subject well (it even works for hair highlights when used from behind), then you can use the on camera flash power adjustment from 1/128 to 1/2, or the f-stop to control the overall picture look and feel.It is truly amazing how much fun and creativity you can have with this one unit. I am also buying the Zeikos version of this for comparison (looks identical, but at a lower price)

Not as great as I thought (fake texture and cardboard feel), but very good nonetheless. The construction does seem to contain only a cardboard stiffener inside the faux textured leatherette plastic cover. The back is hard plastic with a similar faux leather insert. The auto on off function works perfectly. I am amazed that much more expensive covers do not all have this feature. The cover is very hard to remove without tools. I accidentally put it on backwards. Nails are not very helpful to pry it back off, but a business card slid all the way around works very well. All the button and speaker openings are aligned exactly. All in all I am still amazed at what you get for the money.

Whether checking your own blood alcohol level or making sure that your guests know their limits, there are times when having a BAC devices are worthwhile. There are websites like celtickane that will let you input body weight, volume and type of drinks consumed, and elapsed time, then calculate the blood alcohol content. These are what I used to check the calibration..The small portable BAC keychain model has been very well received by consumer test agencies, and was the first unit I purchased. It has a single AAA battery, 13 sec countdown times from power up, fold away sample tube (with removable covers if you want), audible prompts, and an instant display of BAC. However it only has two digits, ie .08. It seems to be not very sensitive to volume of air you blow thru it, it will tolerate high and low velocity fairly well, but will complain with a FL (flow error) display if you do not blow at all.The larger new Pro Model says its police grade accuracy and that it meets DOT standards. To start, ignore the assembly manual part which states be careful when inserting the mouth tube, it only goes in a few centimeters. In actuality it only goes in a few millimeters, but the ridge on the mouth piece seems to indicate it should go in up to the ridge, which would be a few centimeters. Nope, the ridge and the instructions have nothing to do with the insertion length. It only goes in about 1/8. See photo. It is powered by supplied two AAA batteries, also has a 13 sec countdown timer. When you turn it on, the entire mouth tube glows an electric blue However after you are done blowing, you hear some sort of an internal device closing shut, and you wait about 20 seconds for a display to show up. The results are in three decimal format, ie .083. The results are stored in 10 memory slots. It also comes with a storage pouch and several removable reusable tips see photosBased on calculated BAC, both models were within .01 point of theoretical and each other. Initially the keychain unit was reading slightly high (.007 est), and after 30 minutes of consumption (you should not test within 20min of drinking) it was reading .001 low when compared to the Pro model. One advantage of the Pro model triple digits is that as you continue testing, you can see the BAC first climb up, then go down as the alcohol is metabolized. The keychain model does not allow you to see the initial swings due to its limited resolutionBoth models come with excellent guides to BAC and its effects and proper testing. Both will let you get a good idea of BAC vs how you feel. The Pro model definitively seems to be more accurate, the 30 min results matched the theoretical calculations to .001, or exactly the same. You should be very happy with either model.

The vacuum cleaner was very easy to assemble, which a good thing. Because some of attached assembly instructions were for a different/older? model. There were a total of three instruction booklets between all of which you can figure everything out though. The machine has very nice construction which is immediately apparent on the brushed nickel multi, multi adjustable inlet wand. There are quality details all throughout; from multiple stowage points, to a tapered self retracting power plug (keeps it from slamming too hard against the stop), to snaps holding the bags (non reusable) and a latch which holds the bag compartment open while you swap the bags.The accessory holder slot on the top of the wand (one of several possible mounts) is very tight. I had difficulty removing it once installed and moved it to the bottom of the wand.The vacuum is very quiet, and has a pleasant turbine like sound when running. The motor actually changes speed when you go from the minimum to the maximum setting. (It varied from 60 to 71 dbA, min to max noise level at 3 ft, which is VERY quiet).The alternating high/low bristle wood floor nozzle (see pictures) worked extremely well. Unlike my upright with always rotating brush, it picked up all of the dust immediately without blowing it all over the place.The vacuum/air powered rotary carpet nozzle worked acceptably well despite not having an electric motor built in. I do suggest periodically manually cleaning off any long hairs which tend to wrap around the roller and may slow it down. That it picked up all of the pet hairs is a good testimonial though.All in all with the light weight, low noise, and very good performance this is as much joy to use as vacuuming can be.

It is what it is. Hopefully you already know what Minoxidil is. While it may not regrow hair for all, if most probably will slow down the loss of hair for most At least on the vertex, top, of the head, the only location for which it is advertised to work. That is my experience. The local Costco quit selling the liquid a while back in favor of the foam. Based on many testimonials and tests the foam is easier to use, but not as effective, and definitively has to be used twice a day. The liquid has a reputation for lasting 24 hours. It does appear that this supplier has a source of fresh Kirkland labelled Minoxidil. The box appears to be exactly like the one I got at Costco previously. As purchased in February 2015, the expiration date embossed on the bottom of the package says 08 2016.

Excellent vice for small projects that you want to do in the house. This vice is a perfect complement for a small vacuum vice I used on a smooth table top. I had a small metal vice, but unfortunately the clamp opening was only 1, and would not open wide enough to grip the table edge. With a healthy 2 opening, and a removable bottom clamp (see photo) this vice addressed that problem. Another pleasant surprise is that one of the jaws has a small Vee groove cut horizontally and vertically into its face. This allows you to grip round objects without having them try to roll within the jaws. As supplied the jaws are protected by snap on rubber covers which keep the jaws from marring delicate surfaces. These protectors as you can see in the photos have a rubber tab in the back to hold them securely on the jaws, they did not slip off accidentally at all.  The head rotates 360 degrees and pivots down at 45 degrees all the way around. There is a notch in the base that will allow the head to pivot all the way to 90 degrees (perpendicular to the table edge), but will not rotate in that position. Construction is cast aluminum jaws and base, chrome plated steel tightening screws, plastic bottom tightening knob, and rubber protective covers on the jaws and top of the table clamp. All in all an excellent mid size home hobby vice.

Both instruments while not constructed with the greatest quality materials, appear to do the job quite well. The TDS meter checked out distilled purified water at 2 ppm, my tap water at 141 ppm and coffee at 900ppm with the X10 indicator flashing for a 9000 ppm actual reading. All are values well within the expected for those fluids.There is a calibration hole in the back with a visible screw, but I did not adjust it as I was satisfied with the readings. This meter comes with a velcro closure vinyl pocket protector style holder.The pH meter comes in a nice translucent hard plastic case. Included are 6.86 4.0 pH buffer solution powders that you can dissolve in 250ml  of water to check calibration. Also a well established homemade calibration solution can be made from laundry Borax powder, it should test at pH of 9.2 (slightly concentration and temperature dependent). Although my tap water reading of pH 8.9 surprised me at first, calibration checks showed the meter as reading only 0.1 high (pretty good straight out of the box). Using the adjustment screw in the back I was able to correct the reading. Notice I did not say I was easily able to correct the reading. The adjustment is extremely sensitive, half turn changed the reading by 2.0 pH units. Subsequent checks with the now calibrated meter on vinegar, wine, lemon juice, soap and coffee all showed results within 0.1 pH of common published values. As a result this set is very well within my expectations and appears to be accurate enough. It is not made of top quality materials but that was not my expectation for the price either.

I have a desk filled with inexpensive reading glasses of various strengths. Actually had to put a piece of tape on them to tell me which ones to use for what, IE I have everything from a +1.25 to a +3.0. This is not ideal. In the past I have had prescription safety glasses for work, those were plano on top and up to +2.0 on the bottom, they worked out well but the nose pads and the hinges wore out. These Foster Grant's at +2.0 on bottom and half(?) normal strength on top actually work perfect for me. Almost an exact replacement for my old prescription glasses. Yes sometimes I do have to tilt my head slightly to get perfect focus, but even without doing that they work very well. Be aware that if you have not worn progressive lenses before (bifocal and trifocal are not really the same effect), there will be an adjustment time. Things will seem slightly blurry as the focus changes slightly with head movement. This was the case with my prescription progressive lenses, it took me about a week to get used to them.These glasses are incredibly well made. The lenses are multicoated to reduce glare. They have a blue green coating reflection like good camera lenses if you look at them from the side. The hinges are spring loaded and do have a hinge screw. The tortoise shell is fairly subdued and dark, and the temple pieces are fairly wide in a classical fashion. You do get a soft lined cloth carry case and a cleaning cloth as well. I will still keep a pair of +3.0 glasses for close up work, but these will eliminate the need for switching as often.March '15 update. Dropped from five to three stars. The temple screws have stripped out on their own, cannot be tightened, and the temple pieces are now wobbly. Fortunately the hinge is so thick the wobble is tolerable.April '15 End of month. The tortoiseshell pattern has began to peel of at the nose pad area. It is just a thin coating over clear plastic.
It fits superbly and very easy to use and prop up the touchpad. Now that you can install Android using Cyanogenmod on the touchpad, the useful life of the device is much extended.

Works well for letting you attach the camera using the various accessories. However the way you get it onto the camera involves spreading the thin plastic frame almost to the point of breaking just to slip it over the case. It really feels like it is about to break. I wish the corners would have been made out of more flexible material.

The air output is very little. You have to be less than a couple of inches away to even notice the "fresh" air aroma. After a while (less than a month of  use) a carbon looking wick started to protrude out of one of the outlet holes, so the unit might not really be functioning at 100% anymore. See photo. It really seems to be effective only in bathroom size, ~100sq ft spaces only.

Great way to to look at the wine tasting kinda like seasons for clothing. I have tried this method by giving the tests at several wine tastings. After much grumbling about the questions not being pertinent and complaints about people not liking any of the answers the conclusions were............ Not really surprising. Those that liked mostly reds were either fall or winter. Those that liked mostly whites were spring or summer. The problem with trying to categorize will work best with beginner wine drinkers, or people that do not like to experiment much. Once the world of wine "opens" up to you, I would say that that you will enjoy more than three quarters of the wines mentioned. And of course it is here that the book shines, the answer key is arranged in a circle, such that spring follows, winter, etc. So it should become clear that the best way to pick wines is not just by the season, but pick wines that are adjacent to each other on the wheel. (Then pick a good example of one exactly diagonally opposite, and see if you truly do not like that style). I had great fun with this.

I thought this might be worth trying based on its claims of a unique protein source (bison), and sweet potato as the main carbohydrate source. These are ingredients not found in your run of the mill dog foods. I am hoping that by limiting and changing the sources of food she eats she will scratch less. I don't think she has been on this diet long enough to tell yet, but she does seem to like it.One thing they could improve upon is the size of the food. This food is in the shape of a disc, slightly larger than half inch in diameter. (See photo) Since she is a small breed it seems a little difficult for her to chew, although she does eat it all.. The claim is that it is suitable for all breeds so I think a smaller pellet size would be easier for small breeds to chew.Overall it seems a good product with a lower fat content than other foods,and quality ingredients. I am including a nutritional info and ingredients photo.

I chose this product due to the intriguing name and the implication of some "raw" food inside. The ingredient list seems good ,and mentions glucosamine, chondroitin, omega 3 and 6 fatty acids and with various veggies and fruits along for the ride.It turns out the "raw" parts are bits of freeze dried chicken bone, which also supplies the glucosamine and chondroitin. My dog simply LOVES chicken. Unfortunately there are really not many of these bits mixed along with the other kibble. (see photos)I do appreciate that the kibble is small in size-since I have a small dog, as well as the variety of veggies, fruit and even flaxseed that are in this product. It is my gut feeling that all this variety is a good thing. My dog also seems to approve, as she eats it with gusto! I am including a nutritional info and ingredients photo.

In summary I have lived with GPS units from Magellan, Garmin, TomTom, Lowrance, Mio and Rand McNally. They all have their strengths and weaknesses. This Magellan is no different. However as I detail in this unfortunately necessarily long review, the 5430 while being long on looks and speed, falls short on some features and user friendliness which make a difference in the long run.General Info:The advanced instruction manual actually IS available on the Magellan website. Just search for 5340 NOT 5430, their misprintTakes about 25 seconds from powered off to ready to acquire signal and same for warm boot.Connecting to a computer disconnects the GPS, you can then browse the android directory, but cannot really do anything there. Do not modify this.Connecting to a wall USB charger allows you to use GPS indoors.Sensitivity is very good indoors. Lock is indicated by the vehicle symbol arrow turning Blue, NOT the red X at the top of screen which is no traffic info indicator.The 5430 Android OS uses a home hard button, at many screens you may be stuck at wondering how to get out of them, there is no BACK or cancel soft key. Use the hard home key at the top of the shell.In first 20 miles of route driving the device did not use landmark guidance at all. Just as well, the example of turn right at the X gas station is not likely to stay current/accurate very long, and the map updates have been years behind in my experienceTotal space reported on the GPS 2.9gb, free space 1.1 gb, inserting a micro SD card, did not change either number. The GPS and the SD card appear as two hard drives to the computer.The detachable mount pivot ball is the same diameter as a Garmin, in case you have a favorite dash mount you want to use. See photoAlthough not specified, you can use lat and long for a go to destination. In the address box simply type for example; 30.0, -91.0Pluses:Great screen resolution at least 640x480, I like the gloss screen, have not had glare problems yet.Very good ahead of the turn spoken directions-best timing I have had.It does let you know which side of the road the destination is.Does offer search options like along route, or near destination.Fastest, shortest, or least freeways routing options, graphically and instantly appear after a successful destination search. This screen also instantly shows estimated distance and arrival time for each option.Fastest screen scrolling by finger of any GPS I have had.Multi destination Route Optimization works well.Minuses:Screen too white, not enough contrast in the color scheme. Although the device directory includes something called Jupiter with colour schemes, there is no way to modify the schemes.Volume is barely adequateOn a short test drive Speed/light cameras warning got two of 5 warnings wrong, there was never a camera there, ever at any point in time.You cannot click on POIs showing on screen to tell what they are. Have to search nearby instead.No utility screen showing signal precision or satellite status,.NO way to import existing POIs. At this time for many people this will not be a first GPS, but rather a replacement or an upgrade. I literally have hundreds of POIs, such as friends, parks, historical sites, unusual tourist destinations, anything that has ever appeared on the food network, etc. The only way to add them is to enter them manually one by one, or to use Magellans web interface and to import them one by one from web pages.Spurious make a U turn directions were given even when following a route exactly.Screen is a tad too responsive, merest brush against a letter causes unwanted input, or a wild screen scroll.Map utility data screen does not show issue date, no way of knowing how old it is without using the Magellan web site and computerTraffic reception only works for big cities. Ie In my state capitol city of 300000 people there was no FM traffic signal (but plenty of traffic).The mount is hard for me to use. The power cord is mounted on the suction cup holder. You have to slide the GPS into the holder while trying to maneuver the power cord into its receptacle. They ARE NOT aligned well and not easily assembled.The power shut down for me unexpectedly several times, may have touched something inadvertently, the red charging light would blink on and off. My bet is that the power cord as described above is not making a good connection. They actually talk about this problem in the quick start manual (why not fix it instead). Would have been MUCH better if the power plug was totally independent of the mount.When searching for POIs, and when the GPS does not find any (say a restaurant by name). It just sits at a blank screen. Would be nice if it said no results found Note that when searching for items by name, click on the results places box ratrher than default addresses. Looking up a library missed the nearest one. This bothered me so much that I finally found the nearby library under public buildings then libraries. To use a keyword search I had to use libraries not library. No string subset search? Really?Moreover recently found items are NOT on a GOTO menu, you have to go to home screen, then address book first before you can select from you history, only then can you add it to the route or set it as a destination. For me at least this is backwards.Overall I liked the interface responsiveness, search speed, and the screen. The entire unit just looks very good. This comes at a price, shortcomings of the interface features, and the lack of POI import. These can be fixed with a firmware update. However as is, the 5430 is not as easy, or intuitive, or feature rich to use as other dedicated GPS units.March 2015 Update. Since this is an Android device, unless you force it to shutdown by holding the power button extra long, normally it only goes into Suspend mode. As a consequence battery life is terrible. Unless you turn it all the way off, in a couple of days the battery will be completely dead.

I have always used an electric razor, and most of the time they were the Norelco brand (last one was 7310XL and before that a 5861XL) and at other times Remington. To start off with the shaving comfort is comparable (I shave dry), but with a slight edge to the Norelco, it seems like the XR1340 dual concentric blades seem to leave  a slight razor burn. Also while the Norelco took an average of 1min 15sec to get a smooth face, the Remington needed a few more scrapes and a total time of 1min 30 sec.Ergonomics wise I had lots of issues with the XR1340; starting with the charger which is a clamp on shell that you snap around the shaver (vs a simple plug in cord). This clamshell often seemed to work loose from the contacts, the charge light would go out and I had to open it up, re snap it shut and wiggle it on the shaver to re establish charging. There is no remaining charge percentage indicator, but with a lithium ion battery you can always top off the charge if you will be away from an outlet without a fear of damaging the battery.Second, to clean the heads you pry a finger nail under one of three recesses and then pry the head off. I always got the feeling that I am about to break the head into three pieces (on the Norelco you push a single button and the head pivots open). To close the head back up, you have to align three pins and then evenly push the entire assembly back on. I say evenly because on several occasions I snapped two of the three heads back on and one was left slightly open. This resulted in the shaver shaving poorly and only after shaving for much more than a regular time did I realize that the head was not on all the way. Finally, for a thorough cleaning, to remove the rotary elements, you pop off the head, and then slide a uni directional piece of plastic from the top of the rotary elements. It pretty much snapped and flew onto the ground every time I tried to do this. This was not the problem though, putting it back on was. It only goes back on one way (vs any position in other symmetrical retaining design shavers), and its not a simple task to figure it out. I wish it was color coded at least. At least the cutting wheels are color coded, gray, blue and black, such that you can always return them into the correct slotted cutting head once they become honed into place.So overall I got a similar shave, but it took a slightly longer time. Ergonomic wise, I had lots of problems. And finally value wise, unless you have to have the special edition paint scheme this shaver does not offer any features that you cannot get from the XR1370 or even XR1330 (slightly less battery run time) at a substantial saving. If the ergonomics I talk about bother you, I suggest checking out the PT370 (replaced the 7310XL).

Right out of the box the Diamondhead sights feel sturdy, which was my main worry since they were polymer and flip up. However every part of the sight is thick and does not feel likely to crack or break. There is also no play in the sights in the up or folded position, the springs are strong and keep everything in place. The sights are also very easy to operate. The spring release button is easy to press and the sights snap back down after you apply enough pressure.With an easy install and solid feel, all that is left is the sight picture. The sights are easy to look through and require no tools to adjust. What I like most about the sights is how the diamond shape aiming much quicker and easier. Everything seems to line up quicker and it is obvious where you are aiming.The only downside to the sights is their photo luminescent inserts. They only work well when you shine a very bright light on them, and even then you have a very short for them to glow. Because of this, I would not recommend these be bought for the sole purpose of low light shooting, tritium sights are well worth the extra expense for that purpose.Overall, the Diamondhead sights felt very solid and performed well. The sights seem to naturally line up and are easy to adjust, but the NiteBrite inserts are definitely not the selling point for the sights. 4.5 of 5 or 5 since there are no half stars

This fan looks terrific in any dcor. Be it classical or modern. College dorm or a grand mansion. The polished nickel finish is class, as they say almost a museum quality piece. The base is solid, the blade guard is a two piece wire grille, with a stainless band holding it on. The blades are not cupped for efficiency though, and only have the trailing edge bent up to generate air flow. In keeping with the minimalist look, the speed adjustment on the base is a slide switch, let to right, off, hi, med, low. This is only indicated by a line mark of slightly longer or shorter lengths. As a matter of fact at first I could not tell if the speed was really changing, but it was, only not very much. Low is 8 mph, medium is 9.5 mph and the high is about 11 mph. I really wish there was a lower speed just to stir the air around.As is, the fan is moderately quiet, the left right rotation is engaged by a traditional knob that you pull up or push down on the top of the motor. There is almost exactly 90 deg of travel left to right. The vibration is very low at any speed. The energy consumption varied from about a low of 33 watts to a high of  38 watts, so this is a really low cost to operate appliance.Overall this is a terrific looking, and a solidly constructed fan. If it had a lower speed setting it would be a solid 5 stars.

I have eaten many protein bars, mostly as a food supplement when hiking or in situations where stopping to eat was not convenient. Most of the time it was not truly enjoyable, as the taste was reminiscent of flavored sawdust. With time it became an acquired taste, with Cliff Bars being the preferred product. (Clif Bars: Chocolate Chip Peanut Crunch of 2.4 Oz - 12 Bars(2 boxes)). I got these V8 bars from Amazon as a periodic recalibration regarding what is available on the market. I compared the V8 chocolate peanut butter, the Cliff chocolate peanut crunch and Nature Valley sweet and salty peanut granola bar (Nature Valley Sweet and Salty Peanut Granola Bars 48 Count Value Box). I looked at the nutrition and flavor. The protein bars are the serious/sports at 10g protein each contenders, vs the granola snack food item Nature Valley, which has only 4g protein. In the photo left to right:Cliff Bar, V8, Nature Valley.Nutrition:For the most part Cliff and V8 are very similar in nutrient composition and cost per bar, but these are the areas where they differ by a good amount; Cliff is 38% heavier (2.4 vs 1.7 oz) V8 gets more cal from fat (38% vs 24%), Cliff has 61% more sugar and 18% more sodium. Cliff also has 78% more carbs.Vitamin wise they are close as well with the exception that Cliff has almost five times the vitamin E and C. Cliff shows quite a few minerals such as iodine, magnesium, selenium, etc which the V8 does not.Taste:I had set up a taste test with several people, and of course the tasting notes were all over the place. Cliff: Good, not too sweet or bitter. Tasteless and sawdust like. Dense, strong grain taste with some peanuts and very little chocolateV8: Waxy, predominantly bittersweet chocolate taste, little peanuts. Almost candylike.Nature Valley: Very sweet and gooey. Very strong peanut and caramel nougat taste. StickyOverall: Unless you have a very strong preference for gritty nutrition or a seriously sweet tooth, the V8 protein bar appears to be an excellent compromise of taste and nutrition. Surprisingly it had less sodium and sugar than the Cliff. Perhaps the best part is that if you are carrying the nutrition for several people, the V8 will satisfy the largest percentage with just one item.

This set pretty much combines the essential elements for enjoying wine at a level above that of simply popping the cork out of the nearest Merlot to the check out counter. NOT that there is anything wrong with that! The point is, that as we start enjoying ever more complex flavor profiles of more and more variety of grapes we find that certain tools make for a more complete experience. Of course I would suggest that everyone starts  with a wonderful tool called the aroma wheel invented by Ann Noble, which will allow you to identify and express the many flavors in the wine. Second, perhaps a wonderful , useful, beginner-master wine tasting book such as the One minute wine master The One Minute Wine Master: Discover 10 Wines You'll Like in 60 Seconds or Less, And finally this kit. The opener is a no nonsense, solid feeling tool with a best two step levered pulling mechanism there is. Other than on a fragile cork (a two bladed puller is suggested MONOPOL Two-prong Cork Puller "Ah-so" (Waiter's Friend), Superfine Polished, Satin Finished, in Gift-box - Made in Germany) this will tackle the most stubborn cork. The vacuum preserver will allow you to extend the life of an opened bottle for perhaps up to a week (drinking, chilling and nitrogen are other possibilities). I have found that some wines that are opened too young, say a big Cab that's less than 5 years old sometimes benefit from this table aging. The aerator also allows for what I would call accelerated "aging", so a wine that is "closed" in, say does not have much nose/smell/bouquet may be improved by using this device. Be aware that some wines may taste worse after this treatment, they go flat. And lastly the carafe. This will allow for keeping the wine at a perfect serving temperature, whites more so than reds, by judiciously adding a right level of ice cubes to the central cooling chamber. It also serves as a serving and decanting carafe. This is a much better and less messy way than utilizing an ice bucket. I have found that it can be used to properly chill a bottle of white in about 10 minutes. Do be careful though, as the glass portion of the carafe is made of very thin glass and an accidental tap of the center stainless steel chamber against it can end in a disaster.Overall as I said it is a terrific way of adding to your wine enjoyment. The four stars refers only to the lighter duty plastic components, and not to the functionality. Highly recommended.

Yes this is a very attractive coffee pot (fits right in inside a stainless trim kitchen), and despite a large array of convenience features, it can be as simple to operate as pushing one button to brew (the on-off button) coffee. I really like the safety feature of the power button being near the top, as my old coffee maker had it on the base, such that anything that was slid on the counter, quite often inadvertently turned on the power, and it was only the vaguely hot burning smell that alerted you to the event. This is further enhanced by the auto one or two hour turn off, the beep which alerts you that the brew cycle is finished and the timer that shows how long since the brew cycle completed.The enclosure is fairly large, it is 14" tall which extends to 23" tall with the cover open. I had to slide it out from under the cabinets to fill with water. While pushing it back under the counter I sloshed some water out from two holes in the back of the unit which prevent you from overfilling the reservoir. Note that on my unit 12 cups as measured on the carafe was a little over 10 cups as measured on the side gage of the coffee maker. If you use the side markers and fill to 12 cups, you WILL overflow the carafe (voice of experience).Brewing comments; For the coffee enthusiast, the temperature of the water dripping on the grounds is about 195 deg F. This is on the low side of recommended (195-205) for best extraction, but assures that you will not get any burned taste. This was confirmed by taste which was medium strength. There is a "strong" option button (has to be tuned on prior to main power button to engage) but this button only seems to extend the brewing time 50%. For example four cups took exactly four minutes to brew under regular and six minutes under strong setting. This appears to be the same function as the 1-4 vs 4-12 cup setting, the coffee gets more time to brew.Miscellaneous:Programming is very easy. You do everything before turning on the main power. IE push program, set the start time, push auto. The "strong" and the "auto off" (one or two hours setting) have to be used before the on button is pushed, they will not have any effect once the brew cycle is started.The sneak a cup function simply closes a drip valve to the carafe when the carafe is removed. It has a fairly strong spring in it and about half the time I put the carafe back in place, it pushes up against the spring which in turn pushed up on the coffee basket container which in turn popped open the top lid of the maker (some steam escaped).The tea function does truly remove the coffee basket from the water path, so you will not get residual coffee flavor in your tea if you brew both. The tea reservoir is moved into the pot, and the pot cover seals the leaves in the basket (mostly, if you pour the tea without removing the basket you may get some leaves in the cup). The tea brew time is 5 minutes PLUS the time to run the drip cycle (~1 min/cup), so for 12 cups you will have up to 15 minutes total brewing time, which may be too strong.The blue clock backlight is bright enough to serve as a nightlight in the kitchen. The manual recommends to unplug the unit when not in use. This will reset the clock.It is definitively better than average due to the features, looks and sturdiness. What keeps it from getting a perfect score is inconsistent volume labels, and the lid intermittently popping off when the carafe is moved. If you have the space under the cabinets, or on the open counter this is a good mid priced coffee maker.

Totally dead after 23 months and maybe two dozen charge cycles. Worked well for about a year then the capacity dropped to about 50 percent when compared to the Canon. Today I put it in the charger and it was totally not registering as inserted. Put it in the camera, the camera would not turn on. So my initial joy at having a great low cost battery is very much diminished. My original five year old Canon battery still has about 70% capacity, although battery info shows recharge performance as a red bar

Bushnell Trophy Cam EssentialIntro Note: I got one of the updated firmware cameras out of the box. Serial numbers less than B140610000 will need to be updated due to a date/time bug. The camera will now keep the date and time even when turned off. If you remove the batteries though, the settings will be kept, but the date and time will have to be reset. Regarding the batteries, my camera worked just fine with the Eneloop rechargeable batteries (which are not recommended, manual suggests Alkaline or Lithium). With 8 Lithium batteries, potential run time is up to a year.This trail cam is truly an "essential" model. It does the basics very well and the rating is relative to its cost and intended purpose. The photo quality is much better than I expected. The range of the motion detect, with the added bonus of taking interval based photos will work very well for a game trail. The video capture is basic quality only, and the glowing night vision led's may give the camera away.Out of the box setup was truly intuitive, (I did not have to read the manual first). I do wish the labels on the setup buttons were more legible, or that the buttons were oriented as described in a cross pattern, rather than all in a row. Each time I wanted to change the setup, I had to bring the camera into bright light. I used the camera with both a tripod and the included strap, both worked well.Performance: The daylight photos have great detail and color, at the 5mp (850k size) and 6mp (950k size) resolution (look much better than my GoPro Silver 3+ at 10mp). Even the 3mp (625k size) pictures look very detailed. I could easily tell the difference say between a raccoon and an opossum at over 100ft. That is probably due in part to the fairly narrow 50degree field of view. In very bright light there was substantial washout of highlights. Night photos are susceptible to motion blur. The lens is specified as  f3.1 but the camera Exif data reports it as f2.8. I don't know if I would trust the Exif data all that much as it always showed ISO 100, and 1 second shutter speed no matter what. Every brand of SD card I had worked just fine, and the camera will accept up to a 32GB size.The camera switches to night mode with a click and does so at an early dusk. The IR night vision LED's glow red similar to a small portable heater red when they light up.  So if you are looking in the direction of the camera you will see them. On the other hand they did have a good range, I would fully agree that they are good out to 60 feet, compared to black led's which are spec'd out to only 45 feet. The flash does not seem to throttle down a lot, and images of objects at less than 5 feet will be very washed out.The motion detect trigger range is very interesting.
