One of these is a superb duet with Plant on "Ohio" a haunting alt country lament with an excellent accompanying video. " The album's only cover, Lefty Frizzell's classic "Mom and Dad's Waltz," is very well executed with a sparse sounding guitar and mandolin accompanying Griffin's tremendous singing. More hard edged support comes from the Dickenson brothers on the more rocking blues of "Don't let me die in Florida" where Griffin shows her versatility. In the midst of all this we get effortless Griffin acoustic ballads like the aching "Wild old dog", the slow country of "Mom and Dad's Waltz" and the deeply sad piano lament "Irish Boy" which is just plain wonderful. The mood is lifted by the old time jaunty skiffle of "Get Ready Marie" but overall the ambience is sombre and often cathartic and some songs like the hurting "That kind of lonely" and "Not a bad man" about her fathers enlistment are almost too sad to endure."American Kid" is a deeply personal record and feels like a form of musical exorcism for Griffin. It represents a mature statement by a superb musician coming to terms with the big themes of life, its comings, it's everyday pleasures plus its painful departures. Throughout she proves she has one of the best and most emotive singing voices in modern music and now sits right bang smack on the top of the pinnacle of Americana music. Honestly this reviewer can't recommend "American Kid" highly enough.

This is a collection of nine pre-WWII short stories featuring Simon Templar, the dashing modern-day Robin Hood created by Leslie Charteris. The tales are all enjoyable if sometimes rather insubstantial. Still, there are enough little twists -- often predictable, once you get the hang of a typical Saint plotline -- and clever banter by endearing if somewhat stock characters to make it all quite fun.

Solar Pons is a vintage pastiche of Sherlock Holmes, invented by August Derleth in the 1920s and whose stories have been compiled in various editions, in both limited editions from Mycroft & Moran and mass market paperbacks. This slim volume gives some background to Derleth's creation and milieu, as well as three short stories, two of which are in the science fictional vein. For the Pons enthusiast, this is a must-have.

My reaction to this film parallels those by the three-star reviews of 09/12/14 and 09/14/14. This is a fast moving action film that has some good fight scenes and more than a few tense moments, laced with a bit of thoughtful philosophy. Nonetheless, the plot tries to pack in far too many elements -- many of them reaching into other previous films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, so that Crossover Syndrome gets to be too much: you have to be aware of and remember events in other films in order to make full sense of some of what happens and is said in this one. Chris Evans continues his perfectly nailed depiction of Cap, and Scarlett Johansson is impeccable in her role. In the end, however, this becomes too much of a mish-mash that is wrapped up through the expedient of things-blowing-up while keeping a number of threads still very loose. In that sense, this is often seems more an all-purpose prequel than a film that tells a complete, satisfying story. But it's still okay, and more than watchable.

My reaction to this film largely parallels that of the 1 October 2014 three-star reviewer. This is one of two films to emerge from the Starz original series The Chair, in which two first-time directors were given the same source material with which to create their own film. The other effort, by YouTuber Shane Dawson, turned out to be an incredibly unfunny, mawkish hot mess of a teen raunchy comedy wannabe. This one, directed by Anna Martemucci, at least has adult sensibilities and aspirations, but in the end fails to be terribly engaging or satisfying.The fault lies partly with the male lead, Tobin Mitnick as Scott, who strikes me as a latter-day Richard Benjamin: likable in his way, but unable to make me believe he's not an android. His performance conveys very little emotional depth, and I found him not terribly interesting, and actually longed to see more of Philip Quinaz as Scott's older brother, who came off as a subdued but at least intriguingly quirky guy. Meanwhile, the female lead, Rachel Keller as Tori, does reasonably well but is somewhat camouflaged amid a small group of other young women, all of whom seem almost indistinguishable from one another. The story, meanwhile, veers from aimless to forced, and I had to force myself to keep watching to the end.Given the circumstances of the film's making -- part of a reality show, limited budget and shooting/casting constraints, plus a first-time director -- it's not a half-bad effort, I suppose. In absolute terms, however, it's nothing special.

This is one of a series of Saint reprints in uniform paperback editions, in this case a collection of three novellas from the 1930s. A freewheeling buccaneer happy to right wrongs and bring justice to the deserving -- even if it means breaking the law and more, Simon Templar (aka The Saint) is the epitome of dashing devil-may-care combined with brutal efficiency. The tales are told with wit and charm, even when murder intrudes, and though one can often guess where things will lead and how, this trio of romps are wonderful fun. Recommended.

About the only good thing one can say about this film is that the title is a great example of self-reference. I first learned about the movie -- and Shane Dawson -- through the Starz original program The Chair, which is a follow-up of sorts to the Project Greenlight series of many years ago. Two first-time directors, one of whom is Dawson, were given the same script and allowed to alter and run with it as they saw fit, within the limits of budget and filming in Pittsburgh. The series was interesting to watch as two train wrecks running in parallel with each other, though this is by far the worse of the pair.Dawson appears to have been somewhat of a YouTube prodigy, but like most prodigies, his art (using the term very loosely here) has failed to mature. Indeed, one can't even call this film sophomoric; it's thoroughly infantile. Dawson's sensibilities are those of a fifth-grader who has discovered the art of talking dirty and thinks that repetition of brainless utterances constitutes wit. The humor, if it can be called that, is cliched and stupid and, well, just not funny, unless you're amused by people defecating in public, vomiting on others, or displaying buttocks or genitalia through windows. It's not so much that it's offensive; it's just n-o-t f-u-n-n-y. The supposedly serious portions, meanwhile,  are so maudlin, cliche and forced that there's no appropriate single-word description that applies to this film other than stinkburger. Its high collective rating is due entirely to mass voting by Dawson's internet fans, and one shudders at the thought that there are over 200 people who actually find this boring piece of crap engaging or worthwhile. The only thing remotely good is Cherami Leigh's depiction of Tori; too bad she didn't have adequate material to work with.The physicist Wolfgang Pauli would sometimes dismiss a theory by saying that it wasn't even wrong. This film isn't even bad.

This is perhaps the ultimate bibliography of master SF writer Jack Vance, who passed on in 2013. All works are listed in first appearance and subsequent reprints, with identifying features for book first editions. Nonfiction, interviews, honors and awards, guest of honor appearances, maps and drawings and more are also included, as well as a timeline of Vance's life and career. And a brief introduction by Robert Silverberg to boot. Five stars, indeed.

This second season of DCI Banks includes three stories on two discs, each of the stories consisting of two one-hour portions. Even more so than in season one, the photography, casting, and sense of brooding is simply excellent. I do have quibbles here and there. As at least one other reviewer declared, Banks is too emotional -- and in my opinion, suffers from occasional bad judgment -- to completely enthrall me. Minor character tics and flaws can be endearing, of course, but sometimes as I watched these episodes, I winced at what I thought were bad calls by Banks.A good part of each story is really concerned with the private lives of one or more characters, which is a plus, except that at times I felt that intimate angle pushed the mystery itself out the window, leaving it almost like an afterthought. And more than once, there were loose plot threads or unexplained aspects that gnawed just a bit too much. Still, this series is so well-produced that one can overlook those negative personal reactions -- at least, I can. A fine series, made better by the replacement of Annie with Morton.

This set contains the second half of the only season of this ITC series from 1967-8 revolving around McGill, a disgraced American agent in Europe who takes on freelance assignments. I didn't watch it during its original run, but viewing them now is a wonderful exercise in time travel, for the photography, sets and music evoke the real spirit of the late 60s, at least as represented by quirky action shows. And quirky is a good word to use with this show. McGill often accepts jobs from questionable clients with ambiguous morals, the stories sometimes begin in midstream and not infrequently end ambiguously or with the sense of another shoe about to drop. Ron Grainer's main theme is catchy in the extreme, and the musical backgrounds and cues are reminiscent of programs like The Prisoner and Danger Man. (And, in fact, apparently Man in a Suitcase employed many crew members from Danger Man (aka Secret Agent) when star Patrick McGoohan moved on to make The Prisoner.)And nothing is more quirky about the series than Richard Bradford, who plays McGill. A dedicated method actor, Bradford lurches about and smugly emotes without let-up. Yet, from start to finish, the offbeat plots, the music, and the presence of a number of ITC and other familiar character actors in support makes this a must-watch for the period afficionado. I give it four stars because, well, it's not perfect: at times it's got a cheesy look, story details become improbable or slightly questionable, and there is that frenetic dance scene in The Whisper. Nonetheless, this one is fun and engaging.

This is the first of two seasons revolving around a young aspiring Scottish journalist trying to make her way in 1980s Glasgow, hindered by a less than perfect family situation and male colleagues who are afflicted with varying degrees of chauvinism. David Morissey and Peter Capaldi are part of a nice ensemble cast. Indeed, the supporting characters are perhaps the best thing about this story. The central plot is grim and compelling, though many of the characters' actions in pursuit of a solution would today be questionable or illegal. Jayd Johnson is excellent as Paddy Meehan, the young would-be journalist, though like at least one other reviewer, I was put off by other characters describing Meehan as a "fat lassie" when the actress is decidedly not plump. In the end, I found the story stalling at times, but the character portrayals more than made up for it. If I could, I'd give this 3.5 stars: more than just okay, but not quite superior.

My reaction to season two of Line of Duty is so completely at odds with the preceding reviewers that I suppose you can consider me an extreme outlier in this case. I'll certainly grant that the casting is very good, and the performances are in the main excellent. There's an excellent underlying tension and slow build-up of relationships among the elements of the story, but in the end, that story becomes so involved and far-fetched that despite the perhaps unmatched degree of plot reversals and surprises, I lost real interest in this along the way, with only a small nagging curiosity egging me on to the end. Along  the way there are a few "conveniences ex machina": for example, the supposition that an upper story hospital room -- and an intensive care room at that -- has windows without screens that can open. Plot twists are generally a plus, but this series reaches way too far in the cause of twist for the sake of twist. If your gullibility is high and you enjoy surprises, you'll probably enjoy it. If you're the type of person who analyzes plot and frequently asks questions of the stories you read or watch, this may not be your cup of tea. Again, it's well-acted and produced, but the storyline is quite a stretch. I didn't care for it.

My wife is a mystery fan and has read Louise Penny's works, and she was eager to watch this dramatization. In the end, she liked it, more or less, though she did note some differences between this production and the original novel, something which other reviewers have commented on. Coming to this with no experience of having read the original material, I confess that I was put off from the very beginning by what I thought to be a very strange tone. I can't quite put my finger on it, but the manner in which the main character interacted with locals and with his staff struck me as unprofessional at times and puzzling at others. I also thought that the somewhat communal life of the principal local characters wasn't clearly defined, leading me to be left a bit at sea in terms of understanding those relationships. Finally, I found the resolution of the mystery quite unconvincing, though it had the novelty of being supplied by someone other than the main detective. All in all, this was a nicely atmospheric story, but one which really failed to paint a convincing and compelling portrait of the central character.

Hinterland is in large part a Wallander wannabe, and actually does a fine job of it on several fronts. The photography is astounding. The characters are well-drawn and compelling. The atmosphere is all-enveloping. The plots themselves are rather good, with one exception, and was easily hooked and held captive all the way through. And yet...Brooding and grimness are "in" these days, an age dominated by the spirit of all those doleful Scandinavian crime writers. And I am taken with that mood, except that sometimes I feel that in Hinterland, as in other series, silent staring is used to make us fill in the blanks with our own imagination. That's certainly a justifiable dramatic strategy, but Hinterland perhaps over-uses that technique, so that a good part of each episode consists of people just staring at each other or at the landscape.There are some back stories present, but we get only hints of most. Mathias had a brother who is presumably dead, and he doesn't want to talk about it. He also appears to have had a pair of daughters, and a wife who won't speak to him. I'm guessing the daughters are dead as well, but we don't know yet. One of Mathias' assistants has a poor relationship with her daughter, so far presented as a pretty stock example of that kind of disfunction. And then there is the creepy Superintendent, who appears to have something to hide -- perhaps something ghastly and criminal. Maybe we'll get to that in season two. Anyway, the back stories are proceeding glacially and in this first season take on the qualities of a somewhat tedious tease.I mentioned plot earlier, and on the whole, the episodes hold up reasonably well -- except for the last one, which includes a number of plot holes, major loose threads, and highly unprofessional and seemingly unmotivated behavior by Mathias. It's one huge mess, but the others are fine. If you take to brooding atmospherics, this set will take you to heights you may not have known existed. If you are one who is entranced by plot rather than style, this will be enjoyable but not the brilliant tour de force that some see it as.For me, it's not perfect, but superbly executed.

As noted by a few other reviewers, the lack of extras or commentary is a big negative for this set, and of course we also have the annoying "Volumes 1 & 2" format instead of the complete first season. Still, these early Mason episodes are marvelous to watch. The early 50s faux noir ethos is in full display -- there's alcohol, hats, cigarettes, and dames with secrets, not to mention those marvelous period automobiles. The stories are enjoyable, though more than once there are serious plot holes, and I have to agree with Mr. Burr that the courtroom antics get a bit out of hand. Nonetheless, this is one example where there is substance lurking behind the glow of nostalgia, and -- allowing for the era and the formulaic endings -- this set is a great ride. Recommended.

I've found that many of the television programs of my youth do not hold up well across the decades. This, however, is not one of those. Based on characters from a series of 1940s films, this early 1960s series chronicles, at times in soap opera manner, the hardships and triumphs of an intern (Richard Chamberlain), who stands in awe of the senior Dr. Gillespie (Raymond Massey). The stories are well-written, and the direction is top-notch. In addition, we get to see several actors who later achieved television or movie fame, or in a couple cases, aging cinema actors strutting their stuff on the small screen. And to top it off, the music is by Jerry Goldsmith, back when he was known as Jerrald. Although at times dated, as well as occasionally heavy-handed and mannered, this one truly does stand the test of time and is rewarding far more often than not.

This is the pilot of the DCI Banks series, and it's not included in the U.S. DVD set of the first season -- perhaps Aftermath is considered Season Zero. In any case, I found the story quite uninteresting despite its sensational subject matter: Five girls are missing, and by chance police break in on what they think is a domestic violence case but is actually the home of the killer and rapist, for in fact four of the five girls are in the basement, and the perpetrator's wife lies beaten upstairs. During the resulting confrontation, one of the discovering policemen is killed.It's a brutal but promising start to a grim drama, but in the end the main plot thread is pretty simple, and in fact the police sort out almost everything rather early, except for the whereabouts of the presumed fifth victim, a mystery which is solved through brute force rather than deductive skill. In the meanwhile, there are side plots involving a concerned father who's also a sleazeball, a neighbor who is more involved than we initially suspect, and police politics.At the end of the day, as I said, the plot is actually rather simple and not that interesting, and the side-plots don't had a whole lot, either. The characters are complex, but frankly that of Annie is rather repulsive, and Banks himself doesn't come off well, either. She's ambitious and amoral, while he is too impulsive. My wife has read some of the novels on which these television dramas are based, and according to her, in many instances some significant changes have been made. Be  that as it may, although I thought the Season One set was good, this pilot stinks just a bit, to my taste.

This series began with With the Lightnings, published more than 15 years. A well-written and nicely plotted military SF novel, it was followed a couple years later by Lt. Leary, Commanding, not quite as good as its predecessor but still rewarding. From then, through eight additional installments including this one, the series had its hits and misses while generally spiraling downward in a confused mess of formula, repetition and very odd sentiment. This is the first one I can say I actively did not like.Daniel remains a likable character, with a few self-admitted, endearing flaws around the edges but retaining all the qualities one expects in the standard hero. Adele, however, has grown increasingly repulsive. In one instance, she regards an enemy captive who happens to be a farmer recruited for the opposing side as a contemptible fool, but why? She knows nothing of his personal characteristics -- only that he is a farmer. Does that, by itself, make him a fool? A fool, by the way, who is expendable without second thought. And, while dismissing her fellow humans, she constantly reminds herself that she is, after all, Mundy of Chatsworth. One hoped at the beginning of this series that this intially awkward, scarred being would find redemption. Instead, she has become a self-absorbed fascist. Her personal servant Tovera, meanwhile, has always been a cartoon character of sorts -- a psychopath who jokes about killing while being slavishly devoted to Adele. Indeed, everyone in the crew dotes on "the Mistress" to a rather ridiculous extent.The plot of this novel is thoroughly confusing. I found it difficult to keep every faction straight in my head, and it didn't take me too many pages to simply not care anymore. There is no combat in space this time around, just some minor dirt scuffles and a lot of introductions and negotiations, and as usual, Adele magically gets into everyone's database or control system to take charge of opposing weapons or gain crucial information -- the same ho-hum deus ex machina magic that we've gotten used to in this series.What is truly excruciating, however, is the absurd level of repetition in the writing. Once more, we get multiple reminders of the usual items: Adele's little sister was murdered and beheaded, Adele is troubled by images of the people she's killed, Adele has found a family with the RCN, and so on ad nauseam. This tired series started out beautifully; at this point, however, it needs to be put out of its misery.

By and large, this season of adaptations from the Alan Banks novels of Peter Robinson is well done. There are three two-part stories in all, each one dark and brooding in its way, although according to my wife, who has read the books, there are some significant alterations in at least one of them. The Annie Cabbot character comes off, to me at least, as rather annoying in the first episode, and less so in the other two. Banks himself, meanwhile, shows poor judgment at times, but that does make him human, although a human who stares a lot. The landscapes, photography and acting are all first-rate, but I found the scripts a bit flawed here and there. That might be due to fitting a possibly intricate story into a couple of hours, or just poor writing -- I can't tell which. There are some loose threads here and an inexplicable now and then. As one mild example, in one episode a battered body is found in a club restroom, but loud music and dancing continue as a police underling phones in to Banks to report the incident. When the others arrive, the dancing is still going on, and there appears to have been no attempt to sequester the crowd or otherwise secure the scene. Little things like that keep one wondering on the side, but on the whole, this is an engaging trio of English mysteries that is anything but quaint.

This double helping of schlock features two films that are hardly classics. H.G. Wells' The Shape of Things to Come has nothing to do with Wells' novel of the same title, other than a couple character names. Mankind has colonized the Moon after the robot wars laid waste to Earth, but it is dependent on an anti-radiation drug manufactured on a planet named Delta Three for continued health. Trouble is, Jack Palace in a cape has overthrown the governor of Delta Three -- Carol Lynley, for god's sake -- and is sending empty cargo ships to crash into the lunar settlement. Barry Morse and his son, along with a female tech and a refurbished robot named Sparks head off on an unlikely mission to solve the problem. Veteran actor John Ireland suffers the indignity of a small role as Senator Smedley, and it suffices, I think, to simply note that this is a Canadian science-fiction film. It's incredibly lame but still watchable. The same compliment cannot be given to the companion piece in this set, Luigi Cozzi's Contamination, sometimes known as Alien Contamination. This one has alien eggs aboard an abandoned cargo vessel, a hard-nosed female security officer, a wise-cracking New York cop, and a ton of disgusting exploding bodies punctuating the boring stretches. Not my cup of tea.

I think the Booklist reviewer got it completely right. If you are a casual Civil War buff or are more concerned with the military aspects of the conflict rather than the political, cultural and philosophical ones, this book is probably not for you. On the other hand, if legal and philosophical fine points are your daily bread, you'll likely gobble it up with gusto. After briefly explaining that most anti-slavery Americans put their hopes into a policy of containment that would cause the institution to wither and die, the author spends most of his book detailing fine points concerning the treaties that ended the American Revolution and the War of 1812. These provisions had to do with American slaves emancipated by British forces and demands by the former owners for a return of their "property" or compensation for its loss. Debates over these issues, both between Americans and British people and among Americans themselves helped lay the groundwork for U.S. emancipation as it eventually occurred in practice.I found the book interesting in the beginning, but by the end of the first third, repetition began to set in for me, and while the overall thrust of the book casts an interesting perspective on the intellectual run up to the Civil War, I confess I found the second half to be a long-winded exercise in going over the same points again and again. Following that good first half, the book just withered away for me.

This Project Runway spinoff stresses all the bad elements of its parent, including the principal one: Angst over Art. In the original Runway, Tim Gunn mentors the designers, who often spat and denigrate each other. Here, Gunn mentors three past Runway participants, who then act as mentor to their own small group of designers. So now the designers can spat, the mentors can spat, and the clothes get moved even farther to the back of the stage. Indeed, Project Runway is all about personal validation, rather than validation of one's art, and it wouldn't be part of the Runway franchise if we didn't have tears and self-pity and pretensions of hipness, which we get in spades this time around. There's an episode of disgusting bullying by people who themselves claim to have been bullied (including one of the mentors), as well as a moment involving a confession of attempted suicide that seems to be nothing but a pathetic bid for sympathy to avoid elimination. Tim Gunn, who has now become a caricature of himself, acquiesces in the bullying, not at all to his credit. Then there are the judges, a second rate trio if there ever was one, including one loud-mouthed person who is nothing but smoke and mirrors. I won't divulge the ultimate winners, of course, but I will say that the show partially redeems itself by selecting correctly at the very end. If you enjoy the slummy aspects of Runway, this will appeal to you. If you hate the fact that Runway is like professional wrestling, then you might want to steer clear.

This is an illuminating look at the literary and cultural influences that shaped Tolkien's creation of Middle-Earth and its stories -- principally The Lord of the Rings. The book is easy to read, is graced with good illustrations, and the author's text is well-organized. Snyder deals not only with the Tolkien texts themselves, but also adaptations, most notably the Peter Jackson film versions. There is a danger here of having those adaptations overshadow the originals, but Snyder doesn't really allow that to happen, while granting the subsequent influence of the cinematic renditions on popular culture. All in all, a good journey.

Comprised of decidedly second tier Golden Age heroes, this counterpart to the Justice Society boasted only one character with anything resembling super-powers: Shining Knight. The stories have the expected form: A menace comes on the scene and the Legionaires divvy up the challenges, then each tackles his problem in a chapter, followed by the next, and then we have a summing up. The tales are reasonably good, and the villains are for the most part intriguing. The artwork shines as well, each hero's individual chapter portrayed by a different artist (Mort Meskin, George Papp and others) before Ed Dobrotka takes over all the interior art starting with issue No. 4. Although the relative lack of super-powers is a downside to this title, in my view, the talent of the art collective that worked on this title, plus the writing -- in part by Bill Finger -- manage to move this volume up the scale.

There have been complaints about the reproduction of the art in this volume, some of which I agree with. Frankly, overall, I think that what you get in this volume is closer to the original in feel than if reconstruction and glossy paper had been used. However, there would have been some benefit to making the book just a bit larger. The artwork is so busy at times that, at the reduced size, it becomes a bit of a jumble. Meanwhile, the stories are quite good -- several notches above standard Golden Age fare -- but I confess that the Guardian is a pretty ho-hum hero, and he's not around much of the time. Admittedly, that allows the boys, who are the real colorful characters, to take center stage, but it also means that the artwork, although dynamic, lacks variety when there's no costumed hero present. Still, there's no denying either the classic S&K borderline grotesque aesthetic, or the good stories.

This second volume of Atom Archives includes issues that I had never read before, since this run occurs about the time I stopped reading comics as a child. All the stories included were written by Gardner Fox and pencilled by Gil Kane, with Murphy Anderson doing most of the inking, replaced by Sid Greene on occasion. These issues also saw the initial team-up of Atom with Hawkman. The Atom's stories were among the most verbose and highly detailed among DC super-heroes of the time, and I think that sometimes the plots might have gotten just a bit too intricate. On the other hand, the characters come across as highly textured, and Jean and Ray, and their relationship, was one of the best of DC's Silver Age. Gil Kane's artwork is a joy to behold, especially when inked by Anderson, but Greene was no slouch, either. Compared to Volume 1, I find these stories a bit more gimmicky, perhaps, and while some may have liked the teaming of the Atom with Hawkman, it frankly doesn't excite me. Still, there's a lot of talent on display here.

I enjoyed this performance very much, but I confess that my preferences are still the rendition conducted by Bruno Weil, for period instrument performance, and the vintage "modern"recording on Sony directed by Bernstein. Hickox's version is magnificent, and you can't go wrong choosing it; it's just that my tastes lean me toward those other discs instead -- I find Weil's more focused and Bernstein's more grand without being heavy. This performance is quite wonderful in its own right, though, and the sonic presence is excellent, arguably better than my two aforementioned favorites.

Hummel may not have been a great artist, but he was a consummate craftsman, and those skills are in evidence in the compositions performed on this disc by pianist Howard Shelley. We may not go to great heights or depths with this music, but there is a reasonable spectrum of emotion conveyed in these selections. I confess that the Variations on a Theme of Gluck was fun in its way but really didn't capture me, but everything else I found very much to my liking, especially the Sonata No. 2.

The is a nicely large and varied set of regimental marches, played in rather grand fashion by the band of the Coldstream Guards. If you're a military band devotee or even a casual listener to such music, as I am, you should be delighted by this album. The playing is measured and expansive, but there is a gentle but firm impetus to the performances that speaks of tradition. Very enjoyable.

Though my corresponding rating isn't as bad as that person's, I do agree with the reviewer who thought that the arranger went a bit overboard on bells and whistles when setting these mostly familiar tunes for brass band. As it is, some of the themes are masked by all  the ornament and such. But these are mostly stirring pieces of music, and I don't fault the performers themselves. As this sort of album goes, it's okay, but I would prefer to be able to hear more of the original tunes, frankly.

I had heard a number of Cannabich's symphonies before on the Naxos label and liked them very much. This disc equals or surpasses those. Certainly, I think the playing itself is superior. These works are second tier material, but highly engaging and inventive. When wanting a change of pace from Mozart or Haydn, I usually try J.C. Bach, Rosetti and Vanhal, among others. This disc of Cannabich symphonies deserves to join that group. Recommended.

This volume reprints the work Simon and Kirby performed on the revamped Golden Age Sandman character. In his Forties reboot, Wesley Dodds picked up a generic superhero costume and a young male sidekick, as well as the standard S&K manic energy. Much has been written about the reproduction of the art, most of it quite negative. Although I agree that it's uneven and comes out a bit muddy at times, I don't think the reproduction overall is that bad, and on many pages is actually pretty good -- with the use of non-glossy paper, I think the look and feel is closer to the original. The stories themselves are very active, usually exaggerated affairs, and like the art, perhaps just a tad bit busy, but these are tales that have often been written about but never readily available, and just being able to read them is a huge plus.

Reading these stories by Fletcher Hanks is like being in a dream where the salt shaker on the table is really your father, even though it looks like a salt shaker, and the final answer to everything always stays behind your back, no matter how fast you turn around. In similar fashion, the seemingly crude artwork and even more apparently crude story lines seem to mask a deep, delicate and detailed psychological reality that can be perceived but not quite expressed. Perhaps I'm not making sense. Suffice it to say that this book and its companion volume, You Shall Die By Your own Evil Creation, give a peek into the mind of a man perhaps better characterized as a creature of self-torture who introduced some very primal elements into his storytelling art. Interesting, and recommended.

Although now seriously dated in its treatment of the history of spaceflight, a treatment that was rather limited in scope to begin with, this book does provide a clear and informative introduction to the basics of orbital dynamics from a qualitative point of view. Easy to understand and nicely illustrated, it's a fine first step in grasping the mechanics of spaceflight, at least in terms of orbital paths. I agree with another reviewer that the book would have been greatly improved with more background on spacecraft systems. Still, this is definitely recommended.

Forty years ago, I enjoyed this album on vinyl, then a decade later found it on a cassette, which I still have. Now, at last, it moves to compact disc and mp3, and the transition is most welcome. This anthology of instrumental and vocal music for small ensemble is by turns lilting, plaintive and quietly rhythmic -- and almost always captivating. More of those wonderful Nonesuch records of long ago should receive equal treatment; I'm glad this one has.

The reviewer of 03/04/04 has given such an eloquent general appraisal of this book that I'd first refer you to his brief essay. One aspect of the Superman and most other superhero sagas of previous eras was that they really didn't have an end. There would be changes, both slow and abrupt, transformations and costume changes, but (almost) never the seismic shifts that occur in real life, with gut-wrenching losses, deep spiritual realizations, and the acceptance of finity as opposed to infinity. This was Alan Moore's take on how all that might take place for Kal. Pacing, layering, shifts in perception -- everything is about as right as it should be. And as painful to read. This is the moment when the son of Krypton came down to Earth, for real. The other two stories are also good -- particularly "For the Man Who Has Everything," but the centerpiece is "Whatever Happened...."

This is one of my favorite releases from the Waverly Consort, and I'm at a loss as to why it has never made it to compact disc. It's a wonderful album of Elizabethan music, performed with prim energy. Highly recommended, no matter what the format.

I agree with the previous reviewer. This is one of the best early music albums that Nonesuch put out, and they issued a lot of them. The music is marvelous, and the performances are exquisite. It probably won't ever make it to compact disc, but one can dream....

This is one of Les Daniels' histories in the trilogy that also encompasses Superman and Wonder Woman. It's a marvelous read, full of information and insight, and more than amply illustrated with comic pages and photos of various bat memorabilia. My only reason for rating it at four stars rather than five is that it was written in 1999, and in the ensuing fifteen years, more history has been added to the saga that's not in this book. Still, the 60 years that had gone before is just as important, if not more so. Highly recommended, and perhaps invaluable.

This is the second of two Osprey volumes on infantry tactics of the Second World War, focusing on the company and batallion levels. (The other deals with squadron and platoon levels.) Coverage extends to both side in the conflict, and proceeds from a general overview to an examination of the use of machine guns, mortars, mines and anti-tank tactics, plus more. The illustrations are  informative and helpful. As Osprey books of this type go, it's pretty good, providing a good general summary without getting lost in too much detail or too many anecdotes.

There are several naval dictionaries out there, and as a casual reader in this subject I'm not familiar with all of them, but I find this one very useful, enlightening and enjoyable. I haven't counted, but I'd estimate there are on the order of 2500 words and phrases defined in this book, though some of them might be considered marginally relevant to life aboard a merchant or combat ship: Bernouilli's Principle is nice to be aware of, but to me it doesn't seem to quite fit here. Terms explained include both historical and modern day. Again, I can't say this is the best of its kind, but in absolute terms if succeeds quite well, I think.

I usually shy away from underwire bras, they tend to dig into all of the wrong places on me, especially under the arms. My work is fairly physical so I need a really comfortable bra to wear on a daily basis. I'm very happy this bra is an exception, super comfortable with plenty of support for my size (36C). This bra feels very light as the name claims ("Ultra Light Illusion") and will be great to wear during the hot Summer season this year. The cups provide a smooth look which looks nice under t shirts and is "demure" enough to wear under some of my more sheer tops. This is a very natural look, no seams or lace to detract or distract from a smooth look.I like that the cups are generous towards the outside and don't flatten there, no "spillage" if you get what I mean. I have shoulders that are wide rather than narrow and the straps hit just right. I am tall (5'10") and the proportion of this bra is just right for me, and the straps are long enough. I hardly know I'm wearing this bra! I do plan on coming back for more in the nude and other colors - the seafoam and purple are very pretty. Keep in mind that this is an ULTRA LIGHT bra, not for heavy support. If it were, it wouldn't be nearly so comfortable. Bali never disappoints me....this is a GREAT bra!

Like other reviewers here with one star ratings, this pie shield destroyed my pies. I have been baking pies for over 30 yr and have never had one turn out as badly as this. I tried the shield a few times and still got the same results, regardless of the temperature I was baking at. It flattened and shrunk my fluting and burnt the daylights out of the edge. I primarily bake my pies in an electric oven, and make butter pastry crusts on my pies. I don't ever bake frozen pies, this shield may be useful for that, but not in my case with the kind of homemade soft pastry my family loves. My husband loves a bit darker crust, but this was ridiculous! So disappointed in this shield and I can't understand how it works so well for others but created  "hell no pies" for me :(

These birds are just adorable and they feel like porcelain rather than resin. It's too bad they are out of stock since a few family members have fallen in love with them and would like a pair for themselves. The color of the birds is very shiny & vibrant, they look and feel very high quality. The photo here on Amazon is pretty accurate as far as the color but they look even more charming in person. I love the wings and tail, which look like leaves instead of feathers. They are a perfect size, neither too large or small for displaying. They would make a very thoughtful and wonderful gift for a bird/Nature lover!

This mat works really well for making standard size pastry for pies, I like that I don't need to use as much flour as my old mat. It really resists sticking unless your pastry isn't chilled, you WILL need to use more flour in that case. I only wish it was WIDER. I still have to use wax paper on the edges to make a quiche (quiche pans can be much larger than pie pans!) which sort of defeats the purpose of using the mat. I still find the Sili Bake handy for certain types of baking. It's slip proof, and the diagrams on the mat save me from having to dig out a cookbook for certain measurements. I store it in the box to keep it clean and prevent any denting from my other cooking utensils. Sili Bake sent me a nice PDF of some basic recipes too, after I purchased, which was a nice surprise. Highly recommended, especially for pie bakers.

I have been looking for a substitute for King Arthur's Instant Clear Jel and I'm so glad I found this version by Barry Farms. There's a very decent amount here (much more than KA's) and I like that the sugar and citric acid have been left out, this is just plain ol' clear jel. This product is fantastic for making pies, works so much better than ordinary cornstarch or flour. Simply mix - I like to toss with your fresh fruit and other ingredients and add to your pie crust. This gives a lovely "jam-like" consistency to pie fillings and will firm up the juice if you're using berries or wet fruit so you avoid a soggy crust. There are no instructions but you can find recipes on KA's website for a general idea of how much it takes when you bake a pie. For example, I used 1/4 cup in the last 10 inch apple pie I made, 2-3 TBSP would be appropriate for smaller (or flatter) pies. You may need to experiment a bit with your baking, I like that this Clear Jel doesn't clump or harden like regular cornstarch if you use a bit too much, it mixes very well. It also works very well with low pectin fruit. The price is very reasonable too! Highly recommended!

I like this oil additive, I noticed the most difference with idling when it was used on my 25 yr old Toyota. This product MUST be used with an oil change, so keep this in mind before you order. My husband was quite curious about this company's products since he's a fan of NEO products ( a brand used on formula race cars which we've used in the past) and wanted to know more about it. We visited the STA-BIL website, they manufacture a multitude of products for cars, motorbikes, and marine usage. As I've mentioned, I notice a much smoother idle, particularly when my car is cold. As far as wear and tear on the engine that will take some time to see if that's really so. I have used products like this for many years ( with great results) with both conventional & synthetic oil so I feel very comfortable with trying this brand.I honestly feel it's the sort of product that needs to be used with EVERY oil change to really make a difference long term. My husband had some questions and emailed the company twice with no answer, so I'm docking a star due to that. I believe this product would be especially useful if you live in harsh weather (either hot or cold), your engine needs a bit more TLC, or for whatever reason you need some additional protection (like my son, who drives his car across country a few times a year and drives a great deal for his work).

I have naturally coarse, slightly wavy hair that tends to frizz, especially in humid weather. This product allows my hair to fall into nice, soft "beach waves" that have movement but are less defined than using a waving iron (or a permed look). After shampooing & conditioning my hair (and making sure the majority of the water is towel dried, this is an important step!) I spritz the Fekkai Beach Waves onto my hair and SCRUNCH. I find that turning upside down and giving the hair underneath several good scrunches with this product works really well on my long hair, and gives it extra fullness, especially at the crown. I spend a little extra time scrunching my ends so that they have a nice soft curl to them as well. When my hair dries it looks fantastic. The ends have the same look as when I've freshly trimmed my hair. My hair is left with a light, citrusy "tropical" scent that isn't overwhelming. In about 30 min., the scent fades which is nice, I don't like heavy or overwhelming scents. I LOVE that this product doesn't dry out my parched hair, which has always been an issue with other salt sprays. My favorite has been a spray made by Schwartzkopf, but I can only use it for about 4 days maximum, and my hair starts feeling dry and my scalp is itchy. I have a medical condition that causes my hair and scalp to be dry so I'm sensitive to products that perhaps other people can use without a problem.For a bit of shine, I apply the Fekkai Pre-Soleil (Sunscreen for hair), another product I adore in this same line. My beach waves still hold up after applying this on top, which is wonderful....my hair needs a bit more product to get some shine. These 2 products in addition to the Fekkai Shea Hair Masque have my hair looking beautiful during the hot, dry days of Summer (an exciting thought since it usually is a bundle of frizz that I must braid to control).This size is perfect for popping into my gym bag or travel but I'd like an even larger size for regular use. I have waist length, thick hair that requires a fair amount of product regardless of what I'm using. That's the only drawback for me. I use at least 4-6 sprays on my hair + 3 for the ends after a fresh wash (less on dry hair), so I probably will go through this product fairly quickly. Other than that, I'm super pleased with how pretty my hair looks, and it's a time saver for those situations when I want my hair to look nice but don't have the time or energy to iron or curl it. Highly recommended!

I'm very happy with this "at a glance" planner and started using it the moment it arrived. I'm a right brain person who's usually frustrated with the layout style of most planners. Yet this planner is absolutely perfect for me in it's minimalist style, very easy to read and the layout makes sense. There's plenty of space for writing out my important day-to-day events with high quality paper & binding of the planner itself. There's a nice pocket stashed in the back for notes and papers. Being that the planner is very new and "crisp" there does seem to be a bit of stiffness in closing the front cover, however, that should loosen up over time with usage. I like the spiral binding and the neutral colors (it feels almost like leather) although my granddaughter tells me she needs to "make it pretty" for grandma. I'm going to let her do just that. That being said, this planner is professional enough for business and/or casual enough for personal use. 5 stars & highly recommended.

These napkins really are pretty! Definitely a "Madras Plaid- ish" (or Buffalo Check) looking style. They are made of very dense feeling cotton similar to a lightweight canvas, and are made in India. The colors are very bright and cheerful (the squares are 3" X 3" rather than small squares) and they hold up well to washing. They felt a bit stiff when they arrived but feel much nicer after a wash and are ready to use. They DO need to be ironed since they are 100% cotton. They look perfect with my red and chrome retro kitchen look. I have the feeling that they will look good for some time (due to the quality) and might even look very cool when the color fades a bit. I have some pillow shams in my living room with the same colors and design which match perfectly. They would look great with just about any decor particularly Country or Western style. Definitely festive and fun for picnics, barbecues, and Summer gatherings. Highly recommended!

I'm actually a bit surprised at the effectiveness of this herbal complex. I do have adrenal fatigue coupled with hypothyroid, a very common "combination issue". I noticed results right away. Yet, I don't find this product to be "stimulating" in the least. So if that's what you're looking for you'll be disappointed. It's very common for people with adrenal fatigue to reach for stimulants (like caffeine) yet that makes the fatigue worse in the long run. I've made this mistake myself in using ginseng, etc.The Adrenal Complex works differently, it levels your energy instead of creating "bursts" throughout the day. It feels subtle ( calming and relaxing ) yet is powerful in other ways. I noticed the greatest difference in not feeling sleepy/tired at about 3pm in the afternoon. My energy usually takes a nosedive at this time and I've dealt with it for YEARS. Even getting my thyroid straightened out didn't help. It's great (no, super great!) that I no longer have this problem thanks to this supplement. My level of "awake-ness" is the same all day long.I'm also not greatly fatigued after working. Much of the time I do fairly hard physical labor, and this supplement keeps me on an even keel throughout the day as well as the day after. I no longer suffer post work or workout exhaustion. I just feel "normal".I also had some residual swelling on my thyroid even after taking natural dessicated thyroid (my thyroid levels are optimal now). So I can only guess that my adrenal glands played a part in the swelling. There were no abnormalities otherwise, but it had me concerned. A few days after taking this supplement, the swelling is going down.It's important to note that Schizandra is classified as a sedative/hypnotic adaptogen remedy in Chinese Medicine. Again, it is NOT energizing. It harmonizes your natural energy instead. It really depends what your issues are as far as whether it will work for you or not. It's effects are SUBTLE and build over the long term. Most traditional Chinese remedies work this way, and can be frustrating for those looking for an instant gratification. I did not have any issues with sleep, either. I can't say that my sleep is better or worse, I take Cherry for that now and it works for me in getting me to sleep when my mind is overactive. Since I'm very physically active during the day, I'm definitely tired enough to sleep and my mind shuts off nicely with Cherry. I used to take a remedy called "An Shen Bu Xin Wan" for sleep (more for the hard core insomniac), that stuff really works (!) it also depends upon WHY you have insomnia. I stopped taking it when I got my thyroid back on track.The recommended dosage is 2 tablets twice daily between meals. That's 4 tablets per day! I find this is correct, I can't imagine taking less than that. So, it's effectiveness might be impaired if you take the tablets with meals or are taking too few. The tablets are very digestible (I have very sensitive digestion) so there are no issues there. I take 2 in the morning before I eat and another 2 later in the afternoon. Your needs may be different than mine, you can adjust accordingly. My husband, however, takes his tabs singly throughout the day, that method works better for him. His work and lifestyle is much more sedentary than mine, so that may be key.All in all I'm very happy with this supplement for the reasons stated & highly recommend it if you've been diagnosed with Adrenal Fatigue, especially coupled with thyroid or other Endocrine disorders. Give it some time to do it's magic! And by all means, do some research if you're taking any medication that might interact with Chinese Herbs....this is really important! More info about Schizandra and what it does here: [http://examine.com/supplements/Schisandra+chinensis/]

This is a time travel adventure novel for the dinosaur-loving middle grade reader.  It should appeal to both boys and girls because there are characters for both.  With the exception of the dinosaur names, the reading level and length of the book skews more toward the younger end of the middle grade range.  It might also be appropriate for younger children who are at a reading level more advanced than their ages.

I really wanted to love this book, but it didn't wow me.  I wanted to love it because I loved the premise -- what is going on in the lives of the teens who aren't the Chosen Ones during the epic battles of good and evil.I do need to make clear that I am far from the target age group.  Teen readers may like this book a lot more than I did but I'll be surprised if it becomes the latest teen mega-hit book.The story is told in a clever format that left me cold.  The story of the Chosen Ones is largely restricted to short paragraphs at the beginning of each chapter and cameo appearances by the "indie kids" in the lives of the main characters in this book.  I like the idea that what would be the "main" story in most YA fantasy books is such an insignificant part of this book.  But it made the book feel very disjointed while I was reading.The main characters in this book are siblings Mike and Mel and their friends Jared and Henna.  Considering that they are supposed to be the "average" kids, they didn't seem very ordinary.  Mike has a bad case of OCD and Mel nearly died from anorexia.  Jared is the farthest from normal -- and really makes the whole idea that these are the regular kids laughable.  I won't tell you what is special about Jared because that would be a spoiler.  The worst part is that I never felt invested in any of the characters and thus didn't care too much about them.As a Christian, it really bothered me that the families of Mike, Mel, and Henna supposedly attended a very conservative church, but their faith was virtually nonexistent either in their values or their behavior.  Had the author not made a big deal about it and one plot point involving mission work, you would never guess that religion had any part in their lives. As is often the case in YA books, the parents play little part in the teens' lives.There is some teen snark (always appreciated by me) but not nearly enough to offset what I didn't like about the book.  I wanted to give a content warning to parents who monitor their teens' reading.  There is discussion of some teen same sex experimentation and also some teen drinking and hetero sex.  The sex is not graphic but it is there.  Some occasional swearing but not nearly as much as some YA novels.

All kidding aside, these are much nicer garden stakes than they sell at my local big box builder store.  They aren't tall enough for staking tomatoes (at least not the tomatoes I want to grow) but they are a good size for staking Brussel sprouts, pepper plants, etc. and for making rows to hold bush beans upright.Outside the garden, they would be nice for yard signs and stakes to hold holiday path lights.

I have to walk a lot for my cardiac care and trained this past summer to walk a half marathon.  On my long training walks, it is important to have some water along.  My other waistpack has a large bottle, but water is heavy so the larger the bottle, the heavier it is when filled.This one doesn't carry as much water, but it is a lot lighter than my other one.  The nylon on this pack is really light.  I don't care much for the gels so I'm glad the pouch that holds a tiny bottle for gels comes off with a velcro strip so I can remove it.  There is another removable pouch that fits my cell phone.  And the main pack in the back has room for several Shotbloks as well as my keys.This has several tiny reflective strips on the waist strap but I wouldn't rely on it to be my only reflective strips if out walking after dusk.

I really enjoy Sandford's Lucas Davenport series so I was interested to see how he would do with science fiction.  After reading this book, I think he should stick to mysteries but there will be many people who really enjoy it and I'll explain what I didn't like about it so prospective readers can decide whether they will be in the group that thinks this book is really good.I should make it clear that I don't read science fiction for the science.  I grew up with Star Trek and Star Wars, not hard science fiction books.  And I don't care if the science in the stories is shaky or nonexistent.  I want a good exciting story that captures my attention.This book will please people who want legitimate science in their science fiction.  The story is set in the relatively near future (2066) so there are no wormholes or warp drives that sent spaceships vast distances in very short periods of time.  Working out how to power a ship for a trip to Saturn in the least amount of time takes up a good part of the book.  That was mildly interesting to me, but I'd have been happy with more action and less science.There is also a lot of political "drama" in the book but it doesn't provide a lot of thrills and suspense until very late in the book.  There are some interpersonal conflicts, but again they are all fairly lukewarm for someone who was hoping for a thriller in space.  The main character is a young rich guy who is viewed as a dilettante but has more depth to him.  However, I never warmed to him as a character because he was neither "bad boy" not "good guy" enough to give me any strong feelings.  Some of the other characters seemed to come out of Central Casting as stereotypes so I never got invested in them.For me this book was "meh" because the science dominated and I wasn't all that interested in it and the thrills were minor and very late in the book.  Hard science fans are certain to enjoy this much more than I did.

There are pros and cons to this apron.Pros:  It is inexpensive; I like the neck loop adjustment; and the body of the apron is wide and long enough to fit most people.Cons:  The fabric is much thinner than I prefer for an apron and that makes the apron feel cheap.  The pocket is poorly placed in the center front.  If I put anything in the pockets, it feeIs like it would be in the way.  I much prefer pockets on the side.Bottom line:  It is OK but nothing special.

I am in a constant search for the Holy Grail of a nonsurgical/nonprescriptive way to deal with the wrinkles under my eyes.  And I wear contact lenses so I don't want something so strong that it bothers my eyes.This cream definitely succeeds on the second point.  I haven't had any sensitivity at all from this cream so that is a plus.  But it has had little effect on the wrinkles under my eyes.  I've been using it only on one eye so I can compare it to the other eye (and I haven't been using anything on that eye so it is full wrinkle).  If I really look hard, I might see a little difference, but I doubt that anyone looking at me could tell.  This might be better for younger women whose wrinkles are not as deep as mine.So far the best product I've used has been Hydroxatone Hydrolyze Intensive Under Eye Treatment, Net Wt. 0.5 Oz.

The packaging of this made me crazy.  It is packaged to ensure that no one looking at this in a big-box store could easily open the package and slip out the pliers.  That also means that one cannot easily open the package period.  And the plastic isn't even recyclable.  I understand the need to protect against store theft but this was ridiculous packaging.The pliers have a nice heft to them and come oiled so they shouldn't get rusty on the trip from China or sitting in the store.  The handles are OK but they are slipped on and not dipped so I worry that as these get use they will become loose and slip off.  I don't expect to give these heavy use -- I'm just going to use them for repairs and such around the house so it shouldn't be an issue.I do wish they were made in the US.

Although a technologically advanced spaceship is the central character in the story, this science fiction novel is more about a totalitarian government and interrogation of a suspected terrorist by a homeland security-type than it is about space exploration.  The ship has a crew of three, but Althea the engineer is one of the main human characters.  The other two characters who make up most of the action and dialogue are Ivan the suspected terrorist and Ida Stays, the female government agent who comes to question him.  Although I enjoy books with female main characters, I never clicked with Althea and Ida (inexplicably called Miss Stays by the other characters) was simply unpleasant.One thing kept bothering me throughout the book.  Everything hinges on Ivan and his partner tricking the ship into letting them board the ship.  I simply couldn't believe that a ship so advanced and secret didn't have better systems security.  And because of that, I never bought into the whole premise of the story.Even so, I am likely to read the next book just to see where the author takes the story.

I think the trim on the sides of this hooded towel is really cute.  But the towel is very thing and not especially soft.  I hope it softens up with repeated washing but right now it doesn't seem good for a baby's sensitive skin.I think I'd give up the organic cotton for some nice soft terry cloth.  I originally thought this might make a nice baby shower gift, but I couldn't recommend it for that.

I enjoyed this book, but it definitely was not what I was expecting.I can't give too much away without spoiling major plot points, but just be aware that this is NOT really a legal thriller -- at least not the usual type where the lawyer gets involved in a case or a mystery, she is in peril related to the case/mystery and then solves it.  There are some of the elements in this book.  The main character is a lawyer and she does get involved in a cold case of a serial killer who has never been caught.  And at some point in the book she is in peril.But the author takes this book in a very different direction.  I probably would have enjoyed it more if it had been a more typical legal thriller like what I expected.  I really like legal thrillers, especially ones with a female main character.  The first half of the book seemed like it was going to be a legal thriller except that one of the characters was a little creepy and the main character did things I thought were reckless.  About halfway in, the author takes this book into a whole different direction.  It is a direction that not everyone will want to go, but I can't tell you what that is without spoiling the book for those who haven't read it.All I can say is that if you just want a normal legal thriller, this is probably not the book for you.

The first time I saw parents with a cart cover at Target, I thought it was really a smart idea.  Most of the ones I've seen have been quilted fabric, but this neoprene one is even more practical because you can wipe it down and don't have to always put it in the wash.  In addition to shopping carts, you can use this on restaurant high chairs and swings at the playground plus use it flat as a changing pad.  It also folds up  nicely.

I have never really used toner before, mostly because I was never really sure what the purpose was.  This bottle tells me it is to remove makeup residue after cleansing.  That's a little troubling to think that cleanser alone isn't removing everything, but I thought it would be fun to give toner a chance.It felt pretty good -- a little cool and refreshing but not too drying.  I put my evening moisturizer on right after I used this so I don't know how it would have felt without that.I like this so far and will have to see whether I think toner adds enough to my daily routine to buy it after this bottle is empty.
This blend of young adult historical novel plus fantasy elements didn't wow me.  A lot of it is too much like a romance novel (not surprising from Harlequin Teen)

I thought this was an interesting book for middle grade readers -- especially boys, but I wouldn't recommend it for everyone.The interaction between Walter and Charlie is really quite delightful to read.  The dialogue is snappy and the two boys are so different in personality, it is a little like a middle grade Odd Couple.  This relationship, so to speak, was my favorite part of the book.And the author surprised me.  I was so sure I knew where the story was going, but the author dropped in a twist and that made me happy because figuring out what is going to happen too soon spoils some of the fun of a book.The reason I hesitate to recommend it whole-heartedly is because of the demons who are almost continuously attacking Charlie.  I am not of the flavor of Christianity that sees demons or the devil behind every adversity.  Nonetheless, I am not completely comfortable with being too casual around the subject, even in light children's fiction.  I suggest that anyone who is especially religious might want to skip this book.

I thought this YA novel was interesting and liked it, but I didn't love it.  It primarily is a historical Gold Rush-era novel, with a little bit of fantasy/magic.  Leah, the main character, has the ability to sense gold.  She and her parents keep this ability a secret but things happen that make her leave her home.The fantasy portion of this book is a big part of what drives the plot, but a very small part of the book itself.  The biggest part of the book is a journey story -- both the physical journey Leah sets out on and the emotional journey she goes through on the way.  She is a likeable character but a lot of the other characters were either stereotypes or just in the background without a lot of dimension.  The hazards and details of the journey were probably the most interesting part of the book.Even though I didn't love this book, I would definitely read the next book in the trilogy to see what happens next.

It's a sad day when you get old enough that the hair you want starts to thin but hair starts growing where you don't want it.  I recently started noticing hair in my nose and didn't like it.  This takes some getting used to but it is small and easy to use.  It tickles a little but doesn't hurt like tweezing the hairs out would.  I haven't had the problem with it coming apart that other reviewers have mentioned, but I am kind of dainty with it and haven't used it very long yet.  I can't see whether I have ear hair that needs trimming so have only used it for my nose hairs.

My Max is partial to IAMS dry food in the original formula but I have tried so many different foods on him lately that he has become accustomed to variety.  This food is not the favorite but he hesitates only a little bit before chowing down.  It doesn't seem to have had any adverse effect on his digestive system and that makes it a success as far as I'm concerned.I probably would not buy this as his regular food because of the price.  As much as I love my cats, my budget is a little too tight to spend this much money on cat food.

This is the kind of book that people are likely to have wildly differing opinions about, depending on whether they have the right frame of reference to get the humor.  To be able to "get" the humor, I think you need background knowledge in two areas to understand what the author is poking fun at:  the fantasy novel genre and what I'll call "British-isms."  In addition, there is bonus humor if you are fairly familiar with the current trend of more serious childrens and young adult literature.  I have read enough fantasy and childrens/YA to get the humor there but as an American reader, I'm pretty sure I missed a lot of what was funny about the descriptions of Murdstone's village.I almost wished I could have a version with footnote explanations so I could get all the laughs.  Even so, I thought this book was funny and enjoyed it.

Most furniture covers are sized for specific pieces of furniture and cover one item at a time.  This is a better and more effective version of just throwing a big sheet of plastic over a bunch of things together.I live in Minnesota and really should bring my patio furniture inside during the long cold snowy winter, but I don't have any room to do so.  And it is expensive to buy covers for everything I have.  With this, I can pull my chairs up to the table, close the patio umbrella and lay it on top of the table, bring the umbrella stand under the table and drape this cover over the whole thing.The vents and the straps will keep this from being lifted off by the wind, though it is quite heavy due to the combination of the weight of the fabric and the water resistant undercoating.  You may want to use two people to get this adjusted, though the handles will help move it around to the right spot.  ETA:  11/13/2015:  We had a lot of wind yesterday and this morning I looked out the window and saw this on the ground next to the table and chairs it was covering.  Clearly it is not too heavy for the wind to lift and the vents don't prevent it from flying up.  Perhaps the issue was that it was strapped to some light aluminum chairs that were also tossed about, but I will need to re-do the straps that I thought would hold this down.Because it does leave the very bottom of my table and chair legs exposed, I think it is better for a climate where rain is the issue, not deep snow.  But this is a good start and about the best I can do without having a place to bring my patio furniture inside for the winter.  I have been using http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00D2VUOSW for two winters now and it is still going strong and not showing wear.I think this would be 5 stars for climates milder than Minnesota winters.

I really enjoy the author's Ruth Galloway series of mysteries and that made me both eager and a bit hesitant to read this book because I know the author is talented but was worried I wouldn't enjoy this book as much.I didn't enjoy this book quite as much as I do the other series, but it is a matter of degree and nothing to be worried about.  This book takes place decades earlier than the Ruth Galloway books so there will be no crossover visits from Ruth.  It is set in Brighton, in post-WW2 England.The cast of characters include some dodgy people from the world of music hall variety shows, including some magicians, who had been part of the Secret Service during the War.  Although Detective Edgar Stephens should be the main character, the magician Max Mephisto really steals the show so to speak.  A murder in the style of a magic act brings Max and Edgar back in contact with some of their old company.I would definitely read another book with these characters.

I have an issue with hair products that have a strong scent/odor and this one was so strong that I wanted to wash it out as soon as I put it on.  The scent eventually dissipated, but it was really tough waiting it out.  This could be the best product in the world and I wouldn't use it because of the scent.

When I first started reading this book, I was really into it.  I liked the main character eda because she is a physically strong fighter and she has a personal mission to follow that guides her actions.  I also really liked the world building.  The desert setting is very different from anything I have read before in fantasy.But there is so much put into this book that I started wanting it to move more quickly and be more tightly plotted and that made me start to lose interest in where the story was going.  I don't know if I just wasn't in the mood for epic fantasy or if it was dragging more than it should have.  But for whatever reason, I was getting impatient enough with the story that I decided to put it down for awhile.

The softgel capsules for these CLA supplements are fairly large -- at least as large as fish oil capsules.  I recommend taking them with food because I've been taking them about 1/2 to 1 hour before eating my breakfast and I have had some issues with a weird oily taste burping up.I've been taking these at a fairly low dosage (especially because of the weird aftertaste) and haven't yet noticed any real change in my metabolism.  If I can get the aftertaste issue covered, I'll take them at closer to the recommended dose and see if that makes any difference.

When I first saw this product, I was skeptical and though you could do the same thing with a magic marker.  But when I tried it, I was surprised at how well it works.We all get a lot of things in the mail that we don't want to put into recycling with all our information on them because of the worries about identity theft.  If you don't have a shredder at home, you have to save them up to bring to a retail shredding place or tear them in pieces and try to separate the parts with identifying information from the rest.  And when a prescription bottle is empty, I peel off the label and tear that up before putting the bottle into recycling.This product is an easier solution to the problem.  And its faster and works better than just crossing things out with a black marker.  This is an inked roller with lots of seemingly random little letter facing different directions.  The ink path is a little more than an inch wide and it wide enough to cover most address boxes in one path.  It doesn't completely cover with ink but the little letters are very close together and camoflauge the letters and numbers you want to obscure.  I think it is better than simple black marker because it you hold the page up to the light you can't see/read the letters underneath.I used this on some credit card mailings and, with one exception I'll discuss below, it rendered all my personal information unreadable.  I also used it on a prescription bottle and it covered up all but the same kind of lettering.The instructions list some things that don't cover well with this product and that includes (in addition to some specialty papers) characters with raised price, characters printed in color, and characters in a large font size.The large font size characters were the things I noticed that didn't cover well.  The name of my prescription medicine on the bottle was in much larger print and it was still readable and one of the lines of non-personalized text on the credit card that was in the area of what I covered up was also still readable with some concentration.I think this product is good enough that I will get one for my 81 year old mother to use.

This is a lovely little book, both aesthetically and spiritually.  I like the author because she doesn't hide her issues -- and depression is something I struggle with as well.These daily readings start with a short writing by the author and then have several short passages of Scripture that fit the topic of her writing.  They can easily be done in the 5 minutes of the title or you could spend more time meditating on the Scripture verses.I really liked the design of the book -- the floral border on the cover is also a page border on the first page of each new devotion.  I know the way a book looks isn't nearly as important as the content, but I do enjoy a book with a nice design.The book has 50 readings so if you do one every day, you will be done in less than 2 months.  A book with more devotions would be nice but there is nothing stopping you from going through it a few times.

The best way to get good gut bacteria is to eat fermented foods that contain the good bacteria.  But my problem is that I don't like sauerkraut (and thus am pretty sure I wouldn't like kimchi) and I'm not over fond of kefir.  I eat Greek yogurt nearly every day but am not sure if my brand contains live cultures.  That leaves me looking at probiotic supplements to get a dose of good bacteria.This one is easy to take.  The capsule is not too big and I am able to swallow it along with my regular prescription medicines.  the packaging indicates that they are gluten free, dairy free, soy free, vegetarian and shelf stable.As with most supplements, it is hard for me to tell if it is actually working.  I do not have any particular digestive issues at the moment so there is no obvious improvement to look for.  I can say that I don't have any issues or side effects as a result of taking these probiotics.

For some time I have intended to read Harry Turtledove's alternate history novels but haven't gotten around to it.  I thought this book of stories and essays would be a good introduction to the author and perhaps get me so excited to read his books that I'd move them up in the "to be read" list.Unfortunately, that was not the case.  Part of the problem was that the stories and essays in this book seem  so random.  I couldn't sense a theme or anything that connected them.  It felt as if someone just grabbed a bunch of stories that hadn't been published in a while and then tossed in a couple essays to add some more pages.One of the essays, about how to write alternate history, was the most interesting to me because it gave me some insight into how the author approaches the novels I am interested in.If I were to judge simply by this collection of stories, I would completely lose interest in reading the alternate history novels because I just wasn't that interested in them.  So I wouldn't read this book if you are not already a fan of the author.However, the novels have been recommended to me by enough people that I am not going to write them off on the basis of my lack of enjoyment of these stories.

The first most important thing about any locker door accessory is how well it will stick to the locker door. The magnet on the back of this is good sized so it should stick to the door unless you really load it up with some heavy notes.The mirror itself is fairly small.  It is less than half the height of the board.  But it is large enough for a quick glance in between classes.  If you want or need a larger mirror, I'd suggest doing without the push pin board and going with Five Star Locker Mirror and Locker Light, Locker Accessories, Teal, 4.5 in. x 4.5 in. x .88 in. (73595) or Five Star Locker Mirror, 5.5 x 5.5 Inches, Berry Pink/Purple (72562).The foam backing on this board is pretty thick so push pins -- either the four that come with this or regular office push pins -- have plenty of place to stick.  There are also four tiny magnets but not a lot of place to use them to stick things to this.  However, you could use the magnets to stick things to the metal locker surface.I wish I'd had something like this when I was in high school.
